catch your death (of cold) to get very cold 得重伤风；得致命的感冒: Don't go out without a coat -- you'll catch your death! 出门别不穿外套，不然要得重伤风！ catch fire to start burning, often accidentally 失火: Nobody knows how the building caught fire. 没有人知道大厦起火的原因。 catch sb red-handed to find sb just as he/she is doing sth wrong 当场撞见（劣行）；逮个正着: The police caught the burglars red-handed with the stolen jewellery. 窃贼连同被偷去的珠宝当场被警方抓获。 catch sight/a glimpse of sb/sth to see sb/sth for a moment 瞥见: We waited outside the theatre, hoping to catch a glimpse of the actress. 我们等在戏院门外，希望一睹那女演员的风采。 catch the sun
1 to shine brightly in the sunlight 在阳光下闪耀: The panes of glass flashed as they caught the sun. 玻璃窗在太阳下闪闪发光。
2 to become burned or brown in the sun 晒黑: Your face looks red. You've really caught the sun, haven't you? 你脸上红通通的，刚晒过太阳，是吗？
catch on(informal 非正式)
1 to become popular or fashionable 流行起来；受人欢迎: The idea has never really caught on in this country. 这个想法在这国家从没真正流行过。
2 to understand or realize sth 领会: She's sometimes a bit slow to catch on. 她有时比人家慢一步才把事情搞明白。
catch sb out to cause sb to make a mistake by asking a clever question 问某人问题以便把他难住: Ask me anything you like -- you won't catch me out. 随便问吧，你难不倒我。 catch up (with sb); catch sb up to reach sb who is in front of you 赶上: Sharon's missed so much school she'll have to work hard to catch up with the rest of the class. 沙伦缺了那么多课，她得努力学习才能赶上班里的其他人。 Go on ahead, I'll catch you up in a minute. 你只管走你的，我一会儿就赶上你。 catch up on sth to spend time doing sth that you have not been able to do for some time 补做: I'll have to go into the office at the weekend to catch up on my work. 周末我得到办公室赶完没做的工作。 be/get caught up in sth to be or get involved in sth, usually without intending to 卷入: I seem to have got caught up in a rather complicated situation. 看来我已被卷入了相当复杂的处境中。
catch²
/kætʃ ||; kætʃ/noun[C]
1 an act of catching sth, for example a ball 接（球等）
2 the amount of fish that sb has caught 捕鱼量；渔获: The fishermen brought their catch to the harbour. 渔民把捕获的鱼运到港口。
3 a device for fastening sth and keeping it closed 锁；扣: I can't close my suitcase -- the catch is broken. 我手提箱的扣子坏了，合不拢。 a window catch 窗钩
4 a hidden disadvantage or difficulty in sth that seems attractive 蹊跷；圈套；隐含的毛病: It looks like a good offer but I'm sure there must be a catch in it. 乍一看来这个建议很动人，但我敢担保里面另有文章。

ˈcatch-all
noun [C]
1 a thing for holding many small objects 放什物的东西
2 a group or a description that includes different things and that does not state clearly what is included or not 笼统的一类﹙或描述﹚ ➔ˈcatch-all adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前): a catch-all phrase/term 涵义甚广的短语/术语

catcher
/ˈkætʃə(r) ||; ˈkætʃɚ/noun [C] (sports 体育) (in baseball 棒球) the player who stands behind the person who should hit the ball (the batter) and catches the balls that he/she does not hit 接球员

catching
/ˈkætʃɪŋ ||; ˈkætʃɪŋ/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) (informal 非正式) (used about a disease 指疾病) that can easily be passed from one person to another 传染性 ☞A more formal word is infectious. 较正式的用语为 infectious。

catchment area
/ˈkætʃmənt eəriə ||; ˈkætʃmənt ˌɛrɪə/noun[C]
1 the area from which a school gets its students, a hospital gets its patients, etc 属区（某学校可在该区招生、某医院可为该区居民服务等）
2 (also catchment) (technical术语) the area from which rain flows into a particular river or lake （江河或湖泊的）汇水面积，汇水盆地

catchphrase
/ˈkætʃfreɪz ||; ˈkætʃˌfrez/noun [C] a phrase that becomes famous for a while because it is used by a famous person 名言；警句

catchy
/ˈkætʃi ||; ˈkætʃɪ/adj (used about a tune or song) easy to remember （指曲调或歌）琅琅上口，易记

catechism
/ˈkætəkɪzəm ||; ˈkætəˌkɪzəm/noun [sing] a set of questions and answers that are used for teaching people about the beliefs of the Christian Church （基督教的）教理问答，教义问答

categorical
/ˌkætəˈgɒrɪkl; US -ˈgɔ:r- ||; ˌkætəˈgɔrɪkḷ/adj very definite 断然的: The answer was a categorical ‘no’. 答案是斩钉截铁的“不”。 ➔categorically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv The Minister categorically denied the rumour. 部长断然否认这种谣传。

categorize
/ˈkætəgəraɪz ||; ˈkætəgəˌraɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to divide people or things into groups; to say that sb/sth belongs to a particular group 分类

*category
/ˈkætəgəri; US -gɔ:rɪ ||; ˈkætəgɔrɪ/noun [C] (plural categories) a group of people or things that are similar to each other 类；级: This painting won first prize in the junior category. 这画获得初级一等奖。 These books are divided into categories according to subject. 这些书按科分类。

cater
/ˈkeɪtə(r) ||; ˈketɚ/verb[I]
1 cater for sb/sth;cater to sth to provide what sb/sth needs or wants 迎合；为…服务: We need a hotel that caters for small children. 我们需要一家专为小孩而设的旅店。 The menu caters to all tastes. 这菜单迎合所有人的口味。
2 to provide and serve food and drink at an event or in a place that a lot of people go to 承办（酒席）: Our firm caters for the 5000 staff and visitors at the festival. 我们公司在节日期间为5000名职工和来宾提供饮食。

caterer
/ˈkeɪtərə(r) ||; ˈketərɚ/noun [C] a person or business that provides food and drink at events or in places that a lot of people go to 酒席承办人；酒席承办商

catering
/ˈkeɪtərɪŋ ||; ˈketərɪŋ/noun [U] the activity or business of providing food and drink at events or in places that a lot of people go to 酒席承办（业）: the hotel and catering industry 酒店饮食业 Who's going to do the catering at the wedding? 谁来承办这次婚礼的酒席？

caterpillar
/ˈkætəpɪlə(r) ||; ˈkætɚˌpɪlɚ/noun [C] a small hairy animal with a long body and a lot of legs, which eats the leaves of plants. A caterpillar later becomes an insect with large, often colourful wings (a butterfly)or(a moth). 毛虫；蠋 ☞picture at insect 见 insect 插图

catharsis
/kəˈθɑ:sɪs ||; kəˈθɑrsɪs/noun [U] [C] (plural catharses /kəˈθɑ:si:z ||; kəˈθɑrˌsiz/) (technical术语) the process of expressing strong feeling, for example through plays or other artistic activities, as a way of getting rid of anger, reducing suffering, etc 宣泄，感情发泄（如通过演戏等艺术活动） ➔cathartic /kəˈθɑ:tɪk ||; kəˈθɑrtɪk/ adj It was a cathartic experience. 这是一次发泄感情的经历。

cathedral
/kəˈθi:drəl ||; kəˈθidrəl/noun [C] a large church that is the most important one in a district 大教堂（某教区内最主要的教堂）

catheter
/ˈkæθɪtə(r) ||; ˈkæθətɚ/noun [C] a thin tube that is put into the body in order to remove liquids 导管

cathode
/ˈkæθəʊd ||; ˈkæθod/noun [C] the place on a battery or other electrical device where the electric current leaves （电池等的）阴极，负极 ☞Look at anode. 参看 anode。

ˌcathode ˈray tube
noun [C] a tube inside a television, computer screen, etc inside which ELECTRONS produce images on the screen 阴极射线管

Catholic
/ˈkæθlɪk ||; ˈkæθlɪk/ =ROMAN CATHOLIC ➔Catholicism /kəˈθɒləsɪzəm ||; kəˈθɑləˌsɪzəm/=ROMAN CATHOLICISM

cation
/ˈkætaɪən ||; ˈkætˌaɪən/noun [C] (in chemistry 化学) an ION with a positive electrical charge 阳离子 ☞Compare anion. 与 anion 比较。

catkin
/ˈkætkɪn ||; ˈkætkɪn/noun [C] a group of very small soft flowers that grows on the branches of some trees. Some catkins are long and hang down like pieces of string; others are short and stand up. 柔荑花序

cattle
/ˈkætl ||; ˈkætḷ/noun [pl] male and female cows, for example on a farm 牛: a herd of cattle (= a group of them) 一群牛 ☞Look at the note at cow. 参看cow的注释。

Caucasian
/kɔ:ˈkeɪʒn ||; kɔˈkeʒən/noun [C] adj (of) a member of a race of people who have white or light-coloured skin 白种人的；高加索种人的

caucus
/ˈkɔ:kəs ||; ˈkɔkəs/noun[C]
1 (especially US 尤为美) a meeting of the members or leaders of a political party to choose representatives(candidates)or to decide policy; the members or leaders of a political party as a group （政党挑选候选人或决定政策的）党员或领导人会议；决策委员会；政党党员或领导人（总称）
2 a group of people with similar interests, often within a larger organization or political party 一群有类似利益的人（通常在某个组织或政党内部）

caught
past tense, past participle ofCATCH¹

cauldron
/ˈkɔ:ldrən ||; ˈkɔldrən/ (especially US 尤为美 caldron) noun [C] a large, deep, metal pot that is used for cooking things over a fire （煮食用的）大锅

cauliflower
/ˈkɒliflaʊə(r); US ˈkɔ:lɪ- ||; ˈkɔləˌflaυɚ/noun [C,U] a large vegetable with green leaves and a round white centre that you eat when it is cooked 花椰菜；菜花 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

*cause¹
/kɔ:z ||; kɔz/noun
1 [C] a thing or person that makes sth happen 因由；原因: The police do not know the cause of the accident. 警方仍未查明事故的起因。 Smoking is one of the causes of heart disease. 吸烟是心脏病的病因之一。
2 [U] cause (for sth) reason for feeling sth or behaving in a particular way 理由；依据: The doctor assured us that there was no cause for concern. 医生向我们保证没什么好担心的。 I don't think you have any real cause for complaint. 我看不出你真有什么可以抱怨的。
3 [C] an idea or organization that a group of people believe in and support 目标；事业: We are all committed to the cause of racial equality. 我们大家都以种族平等为奋斗目标。
a lost cause→LOST² be for/in a good cause to be worth doing because it will help other people 值得做（因为对别人有好处）
*cause²
/kɔ:z ||; kɔz/verb [T] to make sth happen 引起；导致: The fire was caused by an electrical fault. 这场火灾由电路故障引起。 High winds caused many trees to fall during the night. 昨晚很多树都给强风吹倒。 Is your leg causing you any pain? 你的腿疼不疼？

causeway
/ˈkɔ:zweɪ ||; ˈkɔzˌwe/noun [C] a road or path that is built higher than the area around it in order to cross water or wet ground 因穿越水洼或湿地而抬高的道路或小道；堤道: The island is connected to the mainland by a causeway. 该岛有堤道与大陆相连。

caustic
/ˈkɔ:stɪk ||; ˈkɔstɪk/adj
1 (used about a substance) able to burn or destroy things by chemical action （指物质）腐蚀性的
2 critical in a cruel way 尖酸刻薄的: a caustic remark 刻薄的话

ˌcaustic ˈsoda
noun [U] a chemical used in making paper and soap 苛性苏打，烧 碱（用于造纸和制皂）

caution¹
/ˈkɔ:ʃn ||; ˈkɔʃən/noun
1 [U] great care, because of possible danger 谨慎；小心: Any advertisement that asks you to send money should be treated with caution. 对任何让你寄钱的广告都要小心对待。
2 [C] a spoken warning that a judge or police officer gives to sb who has committed a small crime （法官或警察发出的）口头警告
caution²
/ˈkɔ:ʃn ||; ˈkɔʃən/verb[I,T]
1 caution (sb) against sth to warn sb not to do sth 告诫某人别做某事: The President's advisers have cautioned against calling an election too early. 总统的顾问警告不要过早举行选举。
2 to give sb an official warning 给某人正式警告: Dixon was cautioned by the referee for wasting time. 狄克逊因浪费时间被裁判警告。

cautionary
/ˈkɔ:ʃənəri; US -nerɪ ||; ˈkɔʃənˌɛrɪ/adj giving a warning 告诫；劝导: The teacher told us a cautionary tale about a girl who cheated in her exams. 老师给我们讲了个关于某个女孩考试作弊的警世故事。

cautious
/ˈkɔ:ʃəs ||; ˈkɔʃəs/adj taking great care to avoid possible danger or problems 谨慎；小心: I'm very cautious about expressing my opinions in public. 我对于公开表达意见十分谨慎。 ➔cautiously adv

cavalry
/ˈkævlri ||; ˈkævḷrɪ/noun [sing] [with.sop] the part of the army that fought on horses in the past; the part of the modern army that uses heavily protected vehicles （旧时的）骑兵；（现代的）装甲部队

cave¹
/keɪv ||; kev/noun [C] a large hole in the side of a cliff or hill, or under the ground 山洞；地洞；洞穴: When it started to rain, we ran to shelter in a cave. 雨下起来的时候，我们都跑进山洞里避雨。
cave²
/keɪv ||; kev/verb cave in
1 to fall in 塌落；坍塌；内陷: The roof of the tunnel had caved in and we could go no further. 隧道顶部已塌陷，我们无法再前进。
2 to suddenly stop arguing or being against sth 屈服；妥协: He finally caved in and agreed to the plan. 他终于软化，同意了这个计划。

caveman
/ˈkeɪvmæn ||; ˈkevˌmæn/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/)
1 a person who lived many thousands of years ago in CAVES(= large holes in the side of a hill) （几千年前的）穴居野人
2 (informal 非正式) a man who behaves in an aggressive way 行为粗野的男人

cavern
/ˈkævən ||; ˈkævɚn/noun [C] a large, deep hole in the side of a hill or under the ground; a big cave 又大又深的洞穴；大岩洞 ☞picture at limestone 见limestone插图

caviar
/ˈkæviɑ:(r)/ (also caviare) noun [U] the eggs of a large fish (a sturgeon) that we eat. Caviar is usually very expensive. 鱼子酱（用鲟鱼的卵子制成的一种昂贵食品）

cavity
/ˈkævəti ||; ˈkævətɪ/noun [C] (plural cavities) an empty space inside sth solid 凹处: a cavity in a tooth 龋洞；龋齿的洞 a wall cavity 墙的中空处

cayenne
/keɪˈen ||; keˈɛn/ (also ˌcayenne ˈpepper) noun [U] a type of red pepper used in cooking to give a hot flavour to food 红辣椒

CBI
/ˌsi: bi: ˈaɪ ||; ˌsi bi ˈaɪ/abbr the Confederation of British Industry; an employer's association 英国工商业联合会

cc
/ˌsi: ˈsi: ||; ˌsi ˈsi/abbr cubic centimetre(s) 立方厘米: a 1200cc engine 1200立方厘米的引擎

CCTV
/ˌsi: si: ti: ˈvi: ||; ˌsi si ti ˈvi/abbr closed-circuit television 闭路电视

CD
/ˌsi: ˈdi: ||; ˌsi ˈdi/ (also compact disc) noun [C] a small, round piece of hard plastic on which sound is recorded or information stored. You play a CD on a special machine (CD player). 激光唱片；激光唱片；光盘；光盘

CD-ROM
/ˌsi: di: ˈrɒm ||; ˌsi di ˈrɑm/noun [C,U] compact disc read-only memory; a CD for use on a computer, which has a lot of information recorded on it. The information cannot be changed or removed. 只读光盘；只读光盘

cease
/si:s ||; sis/verb [I,T] (formal 正式) to stop or end 停止；结束: Fighting in the area has now ceased. 该区的战斗现在已经停止。 That organization has ceased to exist. 那个组织已不再存在。

ceasefire
/ˈsi:sfaɪə(r) ||; ˈsisˈfaɪr/noun [C] an agreement between two groups to stop fighting each other 停火 ☞Look at truce. 参看 truce。

ceaseless
/ˈsi:sləs ||; ˈsɪslɪs/adj continuing for a long time without stopping 持久 ➔ceaselessly adv

cedar
/ˈsi:də(r) ||; ˈsidɚ/noun
1 [C] a type of large tree that never loses its leaves and has wide spreading branches 雪松
2 (also cedarwood /ˈsi:dəwʊd ||; ˈsidɚˌwυd/) [U] the hard red wood of the cedar tree 雪松红木

cede
/si:d ||; sid/verb [T] (written 书面语) to give land or control of sth to another country or person 割让；让出

*ceiling
/ˈsi:lɪŋ ||; ˈsilɪŋ/noun[C]
1 the top surface of the inside of a room 天花板: a room with a high/low ceiling 天花板很高╱很低的房间
2 a top limit 上限；最高限度；最大限额: The Government has put a 10% ceiling on wage increases. 政府规定了工资的最高升幅不得超过一成。

*celebrate
/ˈselɪbreɪt ||; ˈsɛləˌbret/verb [I,T] to do sth to show that you are happy about sth that has happened or because it is a special day 庆祝；祝贺: When I got the job we celebrated by going out for a meal. 我一找到了工作，我们就出去吃饭庆祝。 Nora celebrated her 90th birthday yesterday. 诺拉昨天庆祝她的90寿辰。 ➔celebratory /ˌseləˈbreɪtəri ||; ˌsɛləˈbretərɪ/ adj We went out for a celebratory meal after the match. 比赛以后我们出去吃了一顿，庆祝一下。

celebrated
/ˈselɪbreɪtɪd ||; ˈsɛləˌbretɪd/adj (formal 正式) famous 闻名: a celebrated poet 著名诗人

celebration
/ˌselɪˈbreɪʃn ||; ˌsɛləˈbreʃən/noun [C,U] the act or occasion of doing sth enjoyable because sth good has happened or because it is a special day 庆祝；庆典: Christmas celebrations 圣诞节庆祝活动 I think this is an occasion for celebration! 看来这个时刻应该庆祝一下！

celebrity
/səˈlebrəti ||; səˈlɛbrətɪ/noun [C] (plural celebrities) a famous person 名人；名流: a TV celebrity 电视名人

celery
/ˈseləri ||; ˈsɛlərɪ/noun [U] a vegetable with long green and white sticks that can be eaten without being cooked 芹菜: a stick of celery 一根芹菜 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

celibate
/ˈselɪbət ||; ˈsɛləbɪt/adj (formal 正式) never having sexual relations, often because of religious beliefs 独身，守贞（往往出于宗教信仰） ➔celibacy /ˈselɪbəsi ||; ˈsɛləbəsɪ/ noun [U]

cell
/sel ||; sɛl/noun[C]
1 the smallest living part of an animal or a plant 细胞: The human body consists of millions of cells. 人体由几百万个细胞构成。 red blood cells 红血球
2 a small room in a prison or police station in which a prisoner is locked 牢房；囚室
3 a device for producing an electric current, for example by the action of chemicals or light 电池: solar cells 太阳能电池 ☞picture at energy 见 energy 插图

cellar
/ˈselə(r) ||; ˈsɛlɚ/noun [C] an underground room that is used for storing things 地窖；地下室 ☞Look at basement. 参看 basement。 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

cellist
/ˈtʃelɪst ||; ˈtʃɛlɪst/noun [C] a person who plays the cello 大提琴手

cello
/ˈtʃeləʊ ||; ˈtʃɛlo/noun [C] (plural cellos) a large musical instrument with strings. You sit down to play it and hold it between your knees. 大提琴 ☞Look at the note at piano. 参看 piano 的注释。 ☞picture at music 见 music 插图

Cellophane™
/ˈseləfeɪn ||; ˈsɛləˌfen/noun [U] a transparent plastic material used for covering things 赛璐玢；玻璃纸

cellphone
/ˈselfəʊn ||; ˈsɛlfon/ (also ˌcellular ˈphone)=MOBILE PHONE

cellular
/ˈseljələ(r) ||; ˈsɛljəlɚ/adj consisting of cells (1) 细胞组成的: cellular tissue 细胞组织

cellulite
/ˈseljulaɪt ||; ˈsɛljəˌlaɪt/noun [U] a type of fat that some people get below their skin, which stops the surface of the skin looking smooth 皮下脂肪团

cellulose
/ˈseljuləʊs ||; ˈsɛljəˌlos/noun [U] a natural substance that forms the cell walls of all plants and trees and is used in making plastics, paper, etc 纤维素

Celsius
/ˈselsiəs ||; ˈsɛlsɪəs/ (also centigrade) adj (abbr C) the name of a scale for measuring temperatures, in which water freezes at 0° and boils at 100° （温度）摄氏: The temperature tonight will fall to 7°C. 今晚温度会降至7摄氏度。 We say ‘seven degrees Celsius’. 7摄氏度，英语说seven degrees Celsius。 ☞ Look also at Fahrenheit and kelvin. 另参看 Fahrenheit 及 kelvin。

Celtic
/ˈkeltɪk; US ˈseltɪk ||; ˈsɛltɪk/adj connected with the people (the Celts) who lived in Wales, Scotland, Ireland and Brittany in ancient times, or with their culture 凯尔特人的，凯尔特文化的（凯尔特人为古时居住在威尔士、苏格兰、爱尔兰及布列塔尼的民族）

cement¹
/sɪˈment ||; səˈmɛnt/noun [U] a grey powder, that becomes hard after it is mixed with water and left to dry. It is used in building for sticking bricks or stones together or for making very hard surfaces. 水泥 ☞picture at building 见building插图
cement²
/sɪˈment ||; səˈmɛnt/verb[T]
1 to join two things together using cement, or a strong sticky substance （用水泥或接合剂）胶合
2 to make a relationship, agreement, etc very strong 巩固（关系、协议等）: This agreement has cemented the relationship between our two countries. 这项协议巩固了贵我两国的关系。

ceˈment mixer
(also concrete mixer) noun [C] a machine with a large round container(a drum)that holds sand, water and a grey powder(cement)and turns to mix them all together 水泥搅拌器 ☞picture at truck 见 truck 插图

cemetery
/ˈsemətri; US ˈseməterɪ ||; ˈsɛməˌtɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural cemeteries) a place where dead people are buried, especially a place that does not belong to a church 公墓（尤指不是教堂的墓地） ☞Look at graveyard and churchyard. 参看 graveyard 及 churchyard。

censor¹
/ˈsensə(r) ||; ˈsɛnsɚ/verb [T] to remove the parts of a book, film, etc that might offend people or that are considered politically dangerous （对书籍、电影等）审查: The soldier's letters home had to be censored. 士兵写的家书都得经过审查。 ➔censorship noun [U]: state censorship of radio and television programmes 国家对电台及电视台节目的审查制度
censor²
/ˈsensə(r) ||; ˈsɛnsɚ/noun [C] an official who censors books, films, etc （书籍、电影等）审查员: All films have to be examined by the board of film censors. 所有电影都须经过电影审查当局检查。

censure
/ˈsenʃə(r) ||; ˈsɛnʃɚ/verb [T] (written 书面语) to tell sb, in a strong and formal way, that he/she has done sth wrong 指责；谴责: The attorney was censured for not revealing the information earlier. 这个律师因未尽早公开资料而遭非议。 censure noun [U]

census
/ˈsensəs ||; ˈsɛnsəs/noun [C] (plural censuses) an official count of the people who live in a country, including information about their ages, jobs, etc 人口普查

*cent
/sent ||; sɛnt/noun [C] (abbr c, ct) a unit of money that is worth 100th part of a US dollar or of the main unit of money in some other countries 分（货币单位，为一美元或其他主要货币单位的百分之一） ☞Look at per cent. 参看 per cent。

centenary
/senˈti:nəri ||; ˈsɛntəˌnɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural centenaries) (US 美 centennial /senˈteniəl ||; sɛnˈtɛnɪəl/) the year that comes exactly one hundred years after an important event or the beginning of sth 一百周年: 2001 is the centenary of Disney's birth. 2001年是迪斯尼诞生一百周年。

center
(US 美) =CENTRE

centi-
/ˈsentɪ- ||; ˈsɛntɪ/prefix (in nouns 用于名词)
1 one hundred 一百: centipede 百脚
2 (often used in units of measurement 常用于度量衡单位) one HUNDREDTH 百分之一；厘: centilitre 厘升

centigrade
/ˈsentɪgreɪd ||; ˈsɛntəˌgred/ =CELSIUS

*centimetre
/ˈsentɪmi:tə(r) ||; ˈsɛntəˌmitɚ/ (US 美 centimeter) noun [C] (abbr cm) a measure of length. There are 100 centimetres in a metre. 厘米；公分

centipede
/ˈsentɪpi:d ||; ˈsɛntəˌpid/noun [C] a small animal like an insect, with a long thin body and very many legs 百脚（唇足纲节肢动物，如蜈蚣）

*central
/ˈsentrəl ||; ˈsɛntrəl/adj
1 in the centre of sth 处于中心的；中央的: a map of central Europe 中欧地图 Our flat is very central (= near the centre of the city and therefore very convenient). 我们那套公寓离市中心不远。
2 most important; main 主要的；首要的；核心的: The film's central character is a fifteen-year-old girl. 影片的中心人物是个十五岁少女。
3 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) having control over all other parts 起支配作用的: central government (= the government of a whole country, not local government) 中央政府（代表全国的政府，有别于地方政府） the central nervous system 中枢神经系统

ˌcentral ˈheating
noun [U] a system for heating a building from one main point. Air or water is heated and carried by pipes to all parts of the building. 集中供热系统；中央暖气系统

centrally
/ˈsentrəli ||; ˈsɛntrəlɪ/adv in or from the centre 处于中央；由中央出发: a centrally located hotel (= near the centre of the town) 地处市中心的酒店

ˌcentral ˈprocessing unit
noun [C] (abbr CPU) (computing计算机技术) the part of a computer that controls all the other parts of the system 中央处理机

ˌcentral reserˈvation
(US 美 medianmedian strip) noun [C] a narrow piece of land with a barrier that separates the two sides of a motorway （高速公路的）中央分车带

centralize
/ˈsentrəlaɪz ||; ˈsɛntrəlˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to give control of all the parts of a country or organization to a group of people in one place 集中；集权: Our educational system is becoming increasingly centralized. 我们的教育制度正日益中央集权化。 ➔centralization(also -isation) /ˌsentrəlaɪˈzeɪʃn; US -lɪˈz- ||; ˌsɛntrələˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

*centre¹
/ˈsentə(r) ||; ˈsɛntɚ/ (US 美 center) noun
1 [C] [usu.sing] the middle point or part of sth 中心；中央: I work in the centre of London. 我在伦敦市中心工作。 Which way is the town centre, please? 请问到市中心怎么走？ She hit the target dead centre (= exactly in the centre). 她击中靶子正中心。 ☞Look at the note at middle. 参看 middle 的注释。 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图
2 [C] a building or place where a particular activity or service is based （用来举行活动或提供服务的）中心: a sports/health/shopping centre 体育╱保健╱购物中心 This university is a centre of excellence for medical research. 这所大学集医学研究之大成。
3 [C] a place where sb/sth is collected together; the point towards which sth is directed （人或物）集中区，焦点: major urban/industrial centres 主要的市中心区╱工业区 She always likes to be the centre of attention. 她老是爱出风头。 You should bend your legs to keep a low centre of gravity. 你应当屈腿以降低重心。
4 [sing] [with.sop] a political position that is not extreme 中间派: Her views are left of centre. 她的观点属于中间偏左。
centre²
/ˈsentə(r) ||; ˈsɛntɚ/ (US 美 center) centre on/around sb/sth to have sb/sth as its centre 集中于: The life of the village centres on the church, the school and the pub. 这村子生活的中心不外乎教堂、学校、酒馆这三个地方。

-centric
/ˈsentric ||; ˈsɛntrɪk/ (used in compounds 用于复合词) concerned with or interested in the thing mentioned 以…为中心的；对所述东西感兴趣的: Eurocentric policies (= concerned with Europe) 以欧洲为中心的政策

centrifugal
/ˌsentrɪˈfju:gl ||; sɛnˈtrɪfjυgḷ/adj (technical术语) moving away from a centre point 离心的: centrifugal force 离心力

centrifuge
/ˈsentrɪfju:dʒ ||; ˈsɛntrəˌfjudʒ/noun [C] (technical术语) a machine with a part that turns round very quickly to separate substances, for example liquids from solids, by forcing the heavier substance to the outer edge 离心机

centripetal
/ˌsentrɪˈpi:tl ||; sɛnˈtrɪpətḷ/adj (technical术语) moving towards a centre point 向心的

*century
/ˈsentʃəri ||; ˈsɛntʃərɪ/noun [C] (plural centuries)
1 a particular period of 100 years that is used for giving dates 世纪: We live in the 21st century (= the period between the years 2000 and 2099). 我们生活在21世纪（2000年至2099年这段时期）
2 any period of 100 years 100年时间: People have been making wine in this area for centuries. 几百年来人们一直在这个地区酿酒。

CEO
/ˌsi: i: ˈəʊ ||; ˌsi i ˈo/abbr the abbreviation for ‘chief executive officer’; the person with the most powerful position in a company or business （公司或企业的）首席执行官，总裁

cephalopod
/ˈsefləpɒd;ˈke-||; ˈsɛfələˌpɑd/noun [C] any of the CLASSof sea animals that have a large soft head, large eyes and eight or ten long thin legs(tentacles) 头足纲动物（头大而软，大眼睛，有八或十只细长的腕足）: Octopus and squid are cephalopods. 章鱼和枪乌贼是头足纲动物。

ceramic
/səˈræmɪk ||; səˈræmɪk/adj made of clay that has been baked 陶器的: ceramic tiles 瓷砖 ➔ceramic noun [C] [usu.pl] an exhibition of ceramics by Picasso 毕加索陶艺展

*cereal
/ˈsɪəriəl ||; ˈsɪrɪəl/noun[C,U]
1 any type of grain that can be eaten or made into flour, or the grass that the grain comes from 谷类食品: Wheat, barley and rye are cereals. 小麦、大麦、黑麦都是谷物。
2 a food that is made from grain, often eaten for breakfast with milk 谷物；麦片: a bowl of cereal 一碗麦片 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

cerebellum
/ˌserɪˈbeləm ||; ˌsɛrəˈbɛləm/noun [C] (plural cerebellums or cerebella /-ˈbelə ||; -ˈbɛlə/) the part of the brain at the back of the head that controls the movement of the muscles 小脑

cerebral
/ˈserəbrəl; US səˈri:brəl ||; səˈribrəl/adj of the brain 跟脑有关的

ˌcerebral ˈpalsy
noun [U] a medical condition, usually caused by brain damage before or at birth, that causes the loss of control of the arms and legs 脑瘫；大脑性麻痹

ceremonial
/ˌserɪˈməʊniəl ||; ˌsɛrəˈmonɪəl/adj connected with a ceremony 礼仪的；仪式的: a ceremonial occasion 典礼场合 ➔ceremonially /-niəli ||; -nɪəlɪ/ adv

*ceremony
/ˈserəməni; US -məʊnɪ ||; ˈsɛrəˌmonɪ/noun (plural ceremonies)
1 [C] a formal public or religious event 仪式；典礼: the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games 奥运会开幕式 a wedding ceremony 婚礼
2 [U] formal behaviour, speech, actions, etc that are expected on special occasions 礼仪；礼节: The new hospital was opened with great ceremony. 这家新医院举行了隆重的开业典礼。

*certain
/ˈsɜ:tn ||; ˈsɝtṇ/adj
1 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) certain (that...);certain (of sth) completely sure; without any doubts 确信；肯定；确定: She's absolutely certain that there was somebody outside her window. 她确信窗外有人。 We're not quite certain what time the train leaves. 火车什么时候开，我们不大有把握。 I'm certain of one thing -- he didn't take the money. 有一点我是肯定的，他没拿那个钱。
2 certain (that...);certain (to do sth) sure to happen or to do sth; definite 必然的: It is almost certain that unemployment will increase this year. 今年的失业人数会上升，这差不多成了定局。 The Director is certain to agree. 主任一定会同意。 We must rescue them today, or they will face certain death. 今天我们必须营救他们，要不他们必死无疑。
3 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) used for talking about a particular thing or person without naming him/her/it 某；某些: You can only contact me at certain times of the day. 一天里你只有某些时候可以跟我联络上。 There are certain reasons why I'd prefer not to meet him again. 为了某些原因我不想再跟他见面。
4 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) some, but not very much 一些；不多: I suppose I have a certain amount of respect for Mr Law. 我想我对劳先生怀有一点敬意。
5 noticeable but difficult to describe 一点的；稍微的: There was a certain feeling of autumn in the air. 那时候已略有秋意。
6 (formal 正式) used before a person's name to show that you do not know him/her （置于人名之前表示跟此人不相识）: I received a letter from a certain Mrs Berry. 我收到一位贝里太太的来信。
for certain without doubt 确切地；无疑地: I don't know for certain what time we'll arrive. 我说不准我们什么时候能到。 make certain (that...)
1 to do sth in order to be sure that sth else happens 确保: They're doing everything they can to make certain that they win. 他们正在尽一切努力确保胜利。
2 to do sth in order to be sure that sth is true 弄清楚: We'd better phone Akram before we go to make certain he's expecting us. 我们离开前最好打个电话给阿克拉姆，以确定他在等我们。

*certainly
/ˈsɜ:tnli ||; ˈsɝtṇlɪ/adv
1 without doubt; definitely 无疑；必然: The number of students will certainly increase after 2001. 2001年后学生人数必然增加。
2 (used in answer to questions) of course （用于回答问题）当然: ‘Do you think I could borrow your notes?’ ‘Certainly.’ “你的笔记可以借我吗？”“当然可以。”

certainty
/ˈsɜ:tnti ||; ˈsɝtṇtɪ/noun (plural certainties)
1 [U] the state of being completely sure about sth 肯定；毫无疑问: We can't say with certainty that there is life on other planets. 我们还不能肯定其他行星上有生命。 [OPP] uncertainty 反义词为 uncertainty
2 [C] something that is sure to happen 必然之事；必然性: It's now almost a certainty our team will win the league. 我们的队将赢得联赛，这差不多已经成了定局。

*certificate
/səˈtɪfɪkət ||; sɚˈtɪfəkɪt/noun [C] an official piece of paper that says that sth is true or correct 证书: a birth/marriage/medical certificate 出生╱结婚╱健康证书

certify
/ˈsɜ:tɪfaɪ ||; ˈsɝtəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle certifying third person singular present certifies;past tense past participle certified)
1 to say formally that sth is true or correct 证实；证明: We need someone to certify that this is her signature. 我们须有人来证明这确实是她的签名。
2 to give sb a certificate to show that he/she has successfully completed a course of training for a particular profession 发给证书（以证明修毕某种专业课程）: a certified accountant 持有证书的合格会计师

certitude
/ˈsɜ:tɪtju:d; US ˈsɜ:rtɪtu:d ||; ˈsɝtəˌtud/noun (formal 正式)
1 [U] a feeling of being certain about sth 确信
2 [C] a thing about which you are certain 确信的事物

cervix
/ˈsɜ:vɪks ||; ˈsɝvɪks/noun [C] (plural cervices /-vɪsi:z ||; -ˈvaɪsiz/) the narrow passage at the opening of the place where a baby grows inside a woman's body(uterus) 子宫颈 ➔cervical /ˈsɜ:vɪkl ||; ˈsɝvɪkḷ/ adj

cesarean
(US 美) =CAESAREAN

cesium
(US 美) =CAESIUM

cessation
/seˈseɪʃn ||; sɛˈseʃən/noun [U] [C] (formal 正式) the stopping of sth; a pause in sth 停止；中止；停顿: The UN have demanded an immediate cessation of hostilities. 联合国要求立即休战。

cesspit
/ˈsespɪt ||; ˈsɛsˌpɪt/ (also cesspool /ˈsespu:l ||; ˈsɛsˌpul/) noun [C] a covered hole or container in the ground for collecting waste from a building, especially from the toilets （有盖的）污水坑（尤指粪坑）

cf.
abbr compare 比较

CFC
/ˌsi: ef ˈsi: ||; ˌsi ɛf ˈsi/noun [C,U] chlorofluorocarbon; a type of gas found, for example, in cans of spray which is harmful to the earth's atmosphere 含氯氟烃；氟氯碳化合物 ☞Look at ozone layer. 参看 ozone layer。

ch.
abbr chapter （书等的）章

*chain¹
/tʃeɪn ||; tʃen/noun
1 [C,U] a line of metal rings that are joined together 链子；链条: a bicycle chain 自行车链条 She was wearing a silver chain round her neck. 她脖子上戴着银项链。 a length of chain 一段链子 ☞pictures at bicycle, jewellery, key and padlock 见bicycle、jewellery、key及padlock插图
2 [C] a series of connected things or people 一系列，一连串（相关的人或物）: a chain of mountains/a mountain chain 一条山脉 The book examines the complex chain of events that led to the Russian Revolution. 这本书对引发俄国革命的一系列错综复杂的事件进行了分析。 The Managing Director is at the top of the chain of command. 董事是行政管理系统之首。
3 [C] a group of shops, hotels, etc that are owned by the same company 连锁店，联号（由同一家公司所拥有的一组商店、酒店等）: a chain of supermarkets 超级市场连锁店 a fast-food chain 连锁快餐店
chain²
/tʃeɪn ||; tʃen/verb [T] chain sb/sth (to sth);chain sb/sth (up) to fasten sb/sth to sth else with a chain 用链子拴住: The dog is kept chained up outside. 那只狗被人用链子拴在外面。

ˈchain letter
noun [C] a letter or an e-mail sent to several people asking them to make copies of the letter and send them on to more people 连锁信；连锁电邮

ˌchain reˈaction
noun [C]
1 (in chemistry 化学) a chemical change that forms products which themselves cause more changes and new products 链式反应
2 a series of events, each of which causes the next 连锁反应

chainsaw
/ˈtʃeɪnsɔ: ||; ˈtʃenˌsɔ/noun [C] a tool made of a chain with sharp teeth set in it, that is driven by a motor and used for cutting wood 链锯

ˈchain-smoke
verb [I] to smoke continuously, lighting one cigarette after another 一支接一支地抽烟 ➔chain-smoker noun [C]

ˈchain store
noun [C] one of a number of similar shops that are owned by the same company 连锁店（由同一家公司拥有的一组类似商店之一）

*chair¹
/tʃeə(r) ||; tʃɛr/noun
1 [C] a piece of furniture for one person to sit on, with a seat, a back and four legs 椅子: a kitchen chair 厨房用椅 an armchair 扶手椅 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图
2 [sing] the person who is controlling a meeting 会议主席: Please address your questions to the chair. 如有问题，请向主席提出。
3 [C] the position of a university teacher of the highest level (professor) 大学教授的职位: She holds the chair of economics at London University. 她担任伦敦大学经济学教授一职。
chair²
/tʃeə(r) ||; tʃɛr/verb [T] to be the chairman or chairwoman of a meeting 主持（会议）: Who's chairing the meeting this evening? 今晚的会议谁来主持？

chairman
/ˈtʃeəmən ||; ˈtʃɛrmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/)
1 the head of a company or other organization （公司或其他组织的）主席，总裁，董事长
2 a person who controls a meeting 会议主席 ➔chairmanship noun [sing]

chairperson
/ˈtʃeəpɜ:sn ||; ˈtʃɛrˌpɝsṇ/noun [C] (plural -persons) a person who controls a meeting 会议主席

chairwoman
/ˈtʃeəwʊmən ||; ˈtʃɛrˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a woman who controls a meeting 女会议主席

chalet
/ˈʃæleɪ ||; ʃæˈle/noun [C] a wooden house, especially one built in a mountain area or used by people on holiday （尤指位于山区或度假用的）小木屋

chalk¹
/tʃɔ:k ||; tʃɔk/noun
1 [U] a type of soft white rock 白垩: chalk cliffs 白垩崖
2 [C,U] a small stick of soft white or coloured rock that is used for writing or drawing 粉笔
chalk²
/tʃɔ:k ||; tʃɔk/verb [I,T] to write or draw sth with chalk 用粉笔写或画: Somebody had chalked a message on the wall. 有人用粉笔在墙上留言。 chalk sth up to succeed in getting sth 赢得；顺利获得: The team has chalked up five wins this summer. 这支球队今年夏天已经赢了五场赛事。

chalkboard
/ˈtʃɔ:kbɔ:d ||; ˈtʃɔkˌbɔrd/ (US 美) =BLACKBOARD

*challenge¹
/ˈtʃælɪndʒ ||; ˈtʃælɪndʒ/noun[C]
1 something new and difficult that forces you to make a lot of effort 艰巨的新任务: I'm finding my new job an exciting challenge. 我觉得这个新工作令人兴奋而具有挑战性。 The company will have to face many challengesin the coming months. 在未来几个月里，公司得面临许多艰巨任务。 How will this government meet the challenge of rising unemployment? 这个政府将怎样处理失业率不断上升的难题？
2 a challenge (to sb) (to do sth) an invitation from sb to fight, play, argue, etc against him/her （为比试实力而发出的）挑战: The Prime Minister should accept our challenge and call a new election now. 首相应该接受我们的挑战，实时重新举行选举。
*challenge²
/ˈtʃælɪndʒ ||; ˈtʃælɪndʒ/verb[T]
1 challenge sb (to sth/to do sth) to invite sb to fight, play, argue, etc against you 向某人挑战: They've challenged us to a football match this Saturday. 他们已摆下擂台，约我们这个星期六比赛足球。
2 to question if sth is true, right, etc, or not 质疑: She hates anyone challenging her authority. 她不喜欢别人挑战她的权威。

challenger
/ˈtʃælɪndʒə(r) ||; ˈtʃælɪndʒɚ/noun [C] a person who invites you to take part in a competition, because he/she wants to win a title or position that you hold 挑战者

challenging
/ˈtʃælɪndʒɪŋ ||; ˈtʃælɪndʒɪŋ/adj forcing you to make a lot of effort 富挑战性的: a challenging job 一份具挑战性的工作

chamber
/ˈtʃeɪmbə(r) ||; ˈtʃembɚ/noun[C]
1 an organization that makes important decisions, or the room or building where it meets 作出重要决定的组织；这种组织的会议厅或楼: a council chamber 议事厅
2 a closed space in the body, a machine, etc （动植物体内的）腔，室；（机器的）膛，室: the four chambers of the heart 心脏的四个房室
3 a room that is used for a particular purpose 作特定用途的房间: a burial chamber 墓室

chambermaid
/ˈtʃeɪmbəmeɪd ||; ˈtʃembɚˌmed/noun [C] a woman whose job is to clean and tidy hotel bedrooms （清理酒店房间的）女房务员

ˈchamber music
noun [U] a type of music (classical music)that is written for a small group of instruments 室内乐，室乐（古典音乐）

chameleon
/kəˈmi:liən ||; kəˈmilɪən/noun [C] a type of small reptile that can change the colour of its skin 避役；变色蜥蜴

champagne
/ʃæmˈpeɪn ||; ʃæmˈpen/noun [U] [C] a French white wine which has a lot of bubbles in it and is often very expensive 香槟酒（一种法国白酒，泡沫多，价格往往十分昂贵）

*champion¹
/ˈtʃæmpiən ||; ˈtʃæmpɪən/noun[C]
1 a person, team, etc that has won a competition 冠军: a world champion 世界冠军 a champion swimmer 冠军泳手
2 a person who speaks and fights for a particular group, idea, etc 斗士；拥护者: a champion of free speech 捍恒言论自由的斗士
champion²
/ˈtʃæmpiən ||; ˈtʃæmpɪən/verb [T] to support or fight for a particular group or idea 捍恒: to champion the cause of human rights 捍恒人权

championship
/ˈtʃæmpiənʃɪp ||; ˈtʃæmpɪənˌʃɪp/noun [C] (often plural 常用复数) a competition or series of competitions to find the best player or team in a sport or game 锦标赛: the World Hockey Championships 世界曲棍球锦标赛

*chance¹
/tʃɑ:ns; US tʃæns ||; tʃæns/noun
1 [C] a chance of (doing) sth;a chance (that...) a possibility 可能性: I think there's a good chance that she'll be the next Prime Minister. 我认为她很有可能是下届首相。 to have a slim/an outside chance of success 成功的可能性极小／极渺茫 I think we stand a good chanceof winning the competition. 我认为我们很有可能赢得这项比赛。 Is there any chance of getting tickets for tonight's concert? 有没有希望弄到今晚音乐会的票？
2 [C] chance (of doing sth/to do sth) an opportunity 机会: If somebody invited me to America, I'd jump at the chance (= accept enthusiastically). 如果有人邀请我去美国，我马上会抓住这个机会。 Be quiet and give her a chanceto explain. 安静点，给她一个解释的机会。 I think you should tell him now. You may not get another chance. 我想你现在就应该跟他说，要不就没机会啦。 ☞Look at the note at occasion. 参看occasion的注释。
3 [C] a risk 风险: We may lose some money but we'll just have to take that chance. 也许我们会亏本，但必须冒冒那个风险。 Fasten your seat-belt -- you shouldn't take (any) chances. 系上安全带─你不要冒险。 I didn't want to take a chance on anyone seeing me, so I closed the curtains. 我不想冒险让任何人看见我，因此我拉上窗帘。
4 [U] luck; the way that some things happen without any cause that you can see or understand 机缘；运气: We have to plan every detail -- I don't want to leave anything to chance. 每个细节我们都得计划好─我不想抱任何侥幸心理。 We met by chance (= we had not planned to meet) as I was walking down the street. 我是在路上偶然碰见他的。
by any chance (used for asking sth politely) perhaps or possibly （用于客气询问）可能，也许: Are you, by any chance, going into town this afternoon? 今天下午你会到镇上去吗？ the chances are (that)...(informal 非正式) it is probable that... 很可能: The chances are that it will rain tomorrow. 明天很可能下雨。 no chance(informal 非正式) there is no possibility of that happening 不可能: ‘Perhaps your mother will give you the money.’ ‘No chance!’ “也许你妈妈会给你那笔钱。”“不可能！” on the off chance in the hope that sth might happen, although it is not very likely 碰碰运气: I didn't think you'd be at home, but I just called in on the off chance. 我想你多半不在家，可我还是登门拜访，碰碰运气。
chance²
/tʃɑ:ns; US tʃæns ||; tʃæns/verb
1 [T] (informal 非正式)chance sth/doing sth to risk sth 冒险: It might be safe to leave the car here, but I'm not going to chance it. 把车放在这里也许是安全的，但我不想冒这个险。
2 [I] (formal 正式)chance to do sth to do sth without planning or trying to do it 碰巧；凑巧: I chanced to see the letter on his desk. 我碰巧看见他桌上放着那封信。
chance³
/tʃɑ:ns; US tʃæns ||; tʃæns/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) not planned 偶然的；碰巧的: a chance meeting 巧遇

chancellor
/ˈtʃɑ:nsələ(r); US ˈtʃæns- ||; ˈtʃænsəlɚ/noun[C]
1 the head of the government in some countries 总理: the German chancellor 德国总理
2 (also ˌChancellor of the Exˈchequer) (Brit 英) the government minister who makes decisions about taxes and government spending 财政大臣

chandelier
/ˌʃændəˈlɪə(r) ||; ˌʃændḷˈɪr/noun [C] a large round frame with many branches for lights or candles, that hangs from the ceiling and is decorated with small pieces of glass 枝形吊灯（从天花板悬垂的华灯，由多盏灯泡或多枝蜡烛组成）

*change¹
/tʃeɪndʒ ||; tʃendʒ/verb
1 [I,T] to become different or to make sb/sth different （使）改变: This town has changed a lot since I was young. 这个镇比我年轻的时候变了许多。 Our plans have changed -- we leave in the morning. 我们的计划已经改变─我们将在早上离开。 His lottery win has not changed him at all. 他彩票中了奖，可是他一点都没有变。 [SYN] alter 同义词为alter
2 [I,T] change (sb/sth) to/into sth;change (from A) (to/into B) to become a different thing; to make sb/sth take a different form （使）转化，变为: The traffic lights changed from green to red. 交通管理灯由绿色变成红色。 They changed the spare bedroom into a study. 他们把多余的卧室改成书房。 The new job changed him into a more confident person. 新工作使他变得更有信心。
3 [T] change sth (for sth) to take, have or use sth instead of sth else 更换: Could I change this blouse for a larger size? 可不可以把这件女装衬衫换大一点的尺寸？ to change jobs 换工作 to change a wheel on a car 换个汽车轮子 to change direction 转向 Can I change my appointment from Wednesday to Thursday? 我可以把星期三的约会改到星期四吗？
4 [T] to change sth (with sb) (used with a plural noun 与复数名词连用) to exchange sth with sb, so that you have what he/she had, and he/she has what you had 交换: The teams change ends at half-time. 两队在半场时互换场地。 If you want to sit by the window I'll change seats with you. 如果你想坐在窗口，我可以跟你换位子。 [SYN] swap 同义词为swap
5 [I,T] change (out of sth) (into sth) to take off your clothes and put different ones on 换衣服: He's changed his shirt. 他把衬衫换了。 I had a shower and changed before going out. 我出门之前淋了个浴，换了衣服。 She changed out of her work clothes and into a clean dress. 她把工作服脱下来，换上了一身干净衣裳。
Get changed is a common expression meaning ‘to change your clothes ’ You can get changed in the bedroom. 换衣服一般叫做get changed：You can get changed in the bedroom.你可以到卧室换衣服。
6 [T] to put clean things onto sb/sth 换上清洁的东西: The baby's nappy needs changing. 要给婴孩换尿布了。 to change the bed (= to put clean sheets on) 换床单
7 [T] change sth (for/into sth) to give sb money and receive the same amount back in money of a different type 兑换: Can you change a ten-pound note for two fives? 可以帮我把一张十英镑的纸币换成两张五英镑的吗？ I'd like to change fifty pounds into US dollars. 我想把五十英镑换成美元。
8 [I,T] to get out of one bus, train, etc and get into another 换车（包括公共汽车、火车等）: Can we get to London direct or do we have to change (trains)? 我们能直达伦敦还是得换（火）车？
change hands to pass from one owner to another 转手；易手 change your mind to change your decision or opinion 改变决定或主意: I'll have the green one. No, I've changed my mind -- I want the red one. 我要绿的。不，我改变了主意─我还是要红的。 change/swap places (with sb)→PLACE¹ change the subject to start talking about sth different 转换话题 change your tune(informal 非正式) to change your opinion or feelings about sth 改换口吻；改变看法 change your ways to start to live or behave in a different and better way from before 开始改进生活或行为方式 chop and change→CHOP¹ change over (from sth) (to sth) to stop doing or using one thing and start doing or using sth else 改换（作业方法）: The theatre has changed over to a computerized booking system. 戏院已改用计算机订票系统。
*change²
/tʃeɪndʒ ||; tʃendʒ/noun
1 [C,U] change (in/to sth) the process of becoming or making sth different 改变；变化: There was little change in the patient's condition overnight. 晚上病人的情况并没有什么改变。 After two hot summers, people were talking about a change in the climate. 过了两个炎热的夏天，大家都说气候变了。
2 [C] a change (of sth) something that you take, have or use instead of sth else 改动: We must notify the bank of our change of address. 我们得通知银行我们改了地址。 I packed my toothbrush and a change of clothes. 我装好牙刷和要换的衣服。
3 [U] the money that you get back if you pay more than the amount sth costs 找头: If a paper costs 60p and you pay with a pound coin, you will get 40p change. 要是报纸60便士一份，而你付了一英镑硬币，那么找给你的就是40便士。
4 [U] coins of low value 零钱: He needs some change for the phone. 他需要零钱打电话。 Have you got change for a twenty-pound note? (= coins or notes of lower value that together make twenty pounds) 你换得开一张二十英镑纸币吗？
a change for the better/worse a person, thing or situation that is better/worse than the one before 好转或恶化 a change of heart a change in your opinion or the way that you feel 意见或感觉的改变 for a change in order to do sth different from usual 改变常规；变变花样: I usually cycle to work, but today I decided to walk for a change. 我通常骑自行车上班，但今天我决定走路，换个花样。 make a change to be enjoyable or pleasant because it is different from what you usually do 别开生面；一新耳目

changeable
/ˈtʃeɪndʒəbl ||; ˈtʃendʒəbḷ/adj likely to change; often changing 变幻不定的；变化多端的: English weather is very changeable. 英国的天气变化无常，很不稳定。

changeover
/ˈtʃeɪndʒəʊvə(r) ||; ˈtʃendʒˌovɚ/noun [C] a change from one system to another 制度改变；改弦易辙

ˈchanging room
noun [C] a room for changing clothes in, for example before or after playing sport 更衣室

*channel¹
/ˈtʃænl ||; ˈtʃænḷ/noun[C]
1 a television station 电视台: Which channel is the film on? 这电影在哪个频道播放？ ☞Look at station ¹(4) 参看station^1(4)。
2 a band of radio waves used for sending out radio or television programmes （电台或电视台播送节目的）波段，频道，信道: terrestrial/satellite channels 地上／恒星信道
3 a way or route along which news, information, etc is sent （传递信息的）渠道: a channel of communication 沟通渠道 You have to order new equipment through the official channels. 你得通过官方渠道来订新设备。
4 an open passage along which liquids can flow 水道: a drainage channel 排水道
5 the part of a river, sea, etc which is deep enough for boats to pass through 航道
6 the Channel(also the English Channel) the sea between England and France 英吉利海峡
channel²
/ˈtʃænl ||; ˈtʃænḷ/verb [T] (channelling;channelled (US also 美亦作) channeling;channeled) to make sth move along a particular path or route 引导；传送: Water is channelled from the river to the fields. 引河水灌田。 (figurative 比喻) You should channel your energies into something constructive. 你该把精力放到有建设性的事情上来。

chant¹
/tʃɑ:nt; US tʃænt ||; tʃænt/noun
1 [C] a word or phrase that is sung or shouted many times （重复多次的）吟唱，喊叫: A chant of ‘we are the champions’ went round the stadium. 体育场里响起了“我们必胜”的歌声。
2 [C,U] a usually religious song with only a few notes that are repeated many times （只有几个音符、重复多次的）圣歌，吟颂
chant²
/tʃɑ:nt ||; tʃænt/verb [I,T] to sing or shout a word or phrase many times 重复地吟唱或喊叫: The protesters marched by, chanting slogans. 示威者列队大步走过，一边高喊口号。

chaos
/ˈkeɪɒs ||; ˈkeɑs/noun [U] a state of great disorder; confusion 混乱: The country was in chaos after the war. 这个国家战后一片混乱。 The heavy snow has caused chaos on the roads. 大雪致使道路陷入混乱。

chaotic
/keɪˈɒtɪk ||; keˈɑtɪk/adj in a state of chaos 乱七八糟的；混乱的: With no one in charge the situation became chaotic. 没有人主持大局，情况混乱起来。

chap
/tʃæp ||; tʃæp/noun [C] (especially Brit 尤为英) (informal 非正式) a man or boy 男子；家伙；小伙子

chapatti
/tʃəˈpæti; US -ˈpɑ:ti ||; tʃəˈpɑtɪ/ (also chapati) noun [C] a type of flat round Indian bread 印度薄饼

chapel
/ˈtʃæpl ||; ˈtʃæpḷ/noun [C,U] a small building or room that is used by some Christians as a church or for prayer 小教堂；礼拜堂: a Methodist chapel 循道宗教堂

chaperone
/ˈʃæpərəʊn ||; ˈʃæpəˌron/noun [C] in the past, an older person, usually a woman, who went to public places with a young woman who was not married, to look after her and to make sure that she behaved correctly 年长女伴（指旧时在社交场合陪伴未婚少女，确保其言行合乎规范的妇女，一般年岁略长） chaperone verb [T]

chaplain
/ˈtʃæplɪn ||; ˈtʃæplɪn/noun [C] a priest who works in a hospital, school, prison, etc （医院、学校、监狱等的）牧师: an army chaplain 随军牧师

chapped
/tʃæpt ||; ˈtʃæpt/adj (used about the lips or skin 指嘴唇或皮肤) rough, dry and sore, especially because of wind or cold weather 粗糙，皲裂（尤指因为刮风或天气寒冷）

*chapter
/ˈtʃæptə(r) ||; ˈtʃæptɚ/noun [C] one of the parts into which a book is divided 章；篇；回: Please read Chapter 2 for homework. 你们的家庭作业是看第2章。 (figurative 比喻) The last few years have been a difficult chapter in the country's history. 过去几年是这个国家历史上的一个困难时期。

*character
/ˈkærəktə(r) ||; ˈkærɪktɚ/noun
1 [C] [usu.sing] [U] the qualities that make sb/sth different from other people or things; the nature of sb/sth 个性；特质: Although they are twins, their characters are quite different. 虽然他们俩是孪生的，性格可不一样。 These two songs are very different in character. 这两首歌的性质是很不同的。
2 [U] strong personal qualities 内涵；品格: The match developed into a test of character rather than just physical strength. 这场比赛不单是体力上的角逐，而且也是毅力方面的比试。
3 [U] qualities that make sb/sth interesting 特色；特性: Modern houses often seem to lack character. 现代房屋看来往往缺乏独特风格。
4 [U] the good opinion that people have of you 名誉；名声: The article was a vicious attack on the President's character. 这篇文章是对总统名望的恶毒攻击。
5 [C] (informal 非正式) an interesting, amusing, strange or unpleasant person 奇人；妙人；怪人: Neil's quite a character -- he's always making us laugh. 尼尔这人可绝了─他老是惹我们发笑。 I saw a suspicious-looking character outside the bank, so I called the police. 我在银行外面看见一个形迹可疑的人，于是我叫了警察。
6 [C] a person in a book, story, etc （书、故事等中的）人物，角色: The main character in the film is a boy who meets an alien. 这部电影的主人公是个碰见外星人的男孩。
7 [C] a letter or sign that you use when you are writing or printing 书写符号；字: Chinese characters 汉字
in/out of character typical/not typical of sb/sth 符合或不符合…的个性、特质: Emma's rude reply was completely out of character. 埃玛回答得很粗鲁，这完全不符合她的个性。

*characteristic¹
/ˌkærəktəˈrɪstɪk ||; ˌkærɪktəˈrɪstɪk/noun [C] a characteristic of (sb/sth) a quality that is typical of sb/sth and that makes him/her/it different from other people or things 特征
*characteristic²
/ˌkærəktəˈrɪstɪk ||; ˌkærɪktəˈrɪstɪk/adj characteristic of (sb/sth) very typical of sb/sth 特有的；独特的；典型的: The flat landscape is characteristic of this part of the country. 地势平坦是该国这一地区的特征。 [OPP] uncharacteristic 反义词为uncharacteristics ➔characteristically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv ‘No’ he said, in his characteristically direct manner. 他用一贯率直的口吻说﹕“不行。”

characterization
/ˌkærəktəraɪˈzeɪʃn ||; ˌkærɪktraɪˈzeʃən/ (also -isation) noun [U] [C]
1 the way that a writer makes the characters in a book or play seem real （书、戏剧中作者对人物的）特性描写，栩栩如生的刻画
2 (formal 正式) the way in which sb/sth is described 性格化；形象化

characterize
/ˈkærəktəraɪz ||; ˈkærɪktəˌraɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 (often passive 常用于被动语态) to be typical of sb/sth 成为…的特征: the tastes that characterize Thai cooking 典型泰国菜的味道
2 characterize sb/sth (as sth) to describe what sb/sth is like 刻画…的特征: The President characterized the meeting as friendly and positive. 总统把这次会晤形容为友好和有益的。

charade
/ʃəˈrɑ:d; US ʃəˈreɪd ||; ʃəˈred/noun
1 [C] a situation or event that is clearly false but in which people pretend to do or be sth 显而易见的伪装: They pretend to be friends but it's all a charade. Everyone knows they hate each other. 他们表面上是朋友，可都是做给别人看。谁都知道他们憎恨对方。
2 charades [U] a party game in which people try to guess the title of a book, film, etc that one person must represent using actions but not words 哑谜猜字游戏（一方用操作表示某本书、某部电影等的名字，另一方猜出字谜）

charcoal
/ˈtʃɑ:kəʊl ||; ˈtʃɑrˌkol/noun [U] a black substance that is produced from burned wood. It can be used for drawing or as a fuel. 木炭（可作燃料或用来作画）

*charge¹
/tʃɑ:dʒ ||; tʃɑrdʒ/noun
1 [C,U] the price that you must pay for sth 费用: The hotel makes a small charge for changing currency. 酒店兑换货币要收一点费用。 We deliver free of charge. 我们免费送货。 ☞Look at the note at price. 参看price的注释。
2 [C,U] a statement that says that sb has done sth illegal or bad 控告；指控: He was arrested on a charge of murder. 他被控谋杀而遭逮捕。 The writer dismissed the charge that his books were childish. 那位作家拒不接受关于他的书不成熟的指责。
3 [U] a position of control over sb/sth; responsibility for sb/sth 掌管；负责: Who is in charge of the office while Alan's away? 艾伦不在的时候由谁主管办公室？ The assistant manager had to take charge of the team when the manager resigned. 经理辞职以后副经理不得不负责这个班子。
4 [C] a sudden attack where sb/sth runs straight at sb/sth else 冲击；冲锋
5 [C] the amount of electricity that is put into a battery or carried by a substance 电荷；充电: a positive/negative charge 正╱负电荷
bring/press charges (against sb) to formally accuse sb of a crime so that there can be a trial in a court of law 正式向法院控告某人犯某罪 reverse the charges→REVERSE¹
charge²
/tʃɑ:dʒ ||; tʃɑrdʒ/verb
1 [I,T] charge (sb/sth) for sth to ask sb to pay a particular amount of money 收费: We charge £35 per night for a single room. 单人房每晚收费35英镑。 They forgot to charge us for the drinks. 他们忘了收我们的饮料钱。 ☞Look at overcharge. 参看overcharge。
2 [T] charge sb (with sth) to accuse sb officially of doing sth which is against the law 控告: Six men have been charged with attempted robbery. 有六名男子被控抢劫未遂。
3 [I,T] to run straight at sb/sth, or in a particular direction, in an aggressive or noisy way 冲击；冲锋: The bull put its head down ready to charge (us). 公牛低下头，准备（朝我们）冲过来。 The children charged into the room. 孩子们冲进房间。
4 [T] to put electricity into sth 充电: to charge a battery 给电池充电 ☞Look at recharge. 参看recharge。

chariot
/ˈtʃæriət ||; ˈtʃærɪət/noun [C] an open vehicle with two wheels that was pulled by a horse or horses in ancient times 敞篷双轮马车

charisma
/kəˈrɪzmə ||; kə3rɪzmə/noun [U] a powerful personal quality that some people have to attract and influence other people 领袖魅力；吸引力: The president is not very clever, but he has great charisma. 总统不大聪明，但他很有魅力。 ➔charismatic /ˌkærɪzˈmætɪk ||; ˌkærɪzˈmætɪk/ adj

charitable
/ˈtʃærətəbl ||; ˈtʃærətəbḷ/adj
1 kind; generous 宽厚的；慈善的: Some people accused him of lying, but a more charitable explanation was that he had made a mistake. 有些人指责他撒谎，但比较厚道的说法是，他犯了错。
2 connected with a charity 跟慈善机构有关的

*charity
/ˈtʃærəti ||; ˈtʃærətɪ/noun (plural charities)
1 [C,U] an organization that collects money to help people who are poor, sick, etc or to do work that is useful to society 慈善机构: We went on a sponsored walk to raise money for charity. 我们参加步行筹款活动，为慈善机构筹款。 [C]
2 [U] kindness towards other people 慈悲；仁爱；慈善: to act out of charity 本着仁爱之心行事

ˈcharity shop
noun [C] a shop that sells clothes, books, etc given by people to make money for charity （为慈善事业义卖集资的）慈善商店

charlatan
/ˈʃɑ:lətən ||; ˈʃɑrlətṇ/noun [C] a person who says that he/she has knowledge or skills that he/she does not really have 假充内行者
*charm²
/tʃɑ:m ||; tʃɑrm/verb[T]
1 to please and attract sb 取悦；吸引: Her drawings have charmed children all over the world. 她的画迷倒了世界各地的儿童。
2 to protect sb/sth as if by magic 用魔法或符咒保护: He has led a charmed life, surviving serious illness and a plane crash. 他的生命如有神灵庇佑，经历过大病和坠机意外也大难不死。

charm¹
/tʃɑ:m ||; tʃɑrm/noun
1 [C,U] a quality that pleases and attracts people 魅力；吸引力: The charm of the island lies in its unspoilt beauty. 这个岛的魅力在于那未遭破坏的自然美。 Barry found it hard to resist Linda's charms. 巴里发现难以抗拒林达的吸引力。
2 [C] something that you wear because you believe it will bring you good luck 护身符；吉祥物: a necklace with a lucky charm on it 带有吉祥物的项链

charming
/ˈtʃɑ:mɪŋ ||; ˈtʃɑrmɪŋ/adj very pleasing or attractive 迷人的；可爱的: a charming old church 可爱的老教堂 ➔charmingly adv

charred
/ˈtʃɑ:d ||; ˈtʃɑrd/adj burnt black by fire 烧焦

chart¹
/tʃɑ:t ||; tʃɑrt/noun
1 [C] a drawing which shows information in the form of a diagram, etc 图表: a temperature chart 温度表 This chart shows the company's sales for this year. 这张图表显示公司今年的销售额。 ☞Look at pie chart and flow chart. 参看pie chart及flow chart。
2 [C] a map of the sea or the sky 航海图；航空地图: navigation charts 导航图
3 the charts [pl] an official list of the songs or CDs, etc, that have sold the most in a particular week （反映唱片等销量的）排行榜
chart²
/tʃɑ:t ||; tʃɑrt/verb[T]
1 to follow or record sth carefully and in detail 跟踪；考察；详细记录: This television series charts the history of the country since independence. 这套电视片详述了这个国家独立至今的历史。
2 to make a map of one area of the sea or sky 绘制导航图: an uncharted coastline 未经探测的海岸线

charter¹
/ˈtʃɑ:tə(r) ||; ˈtʃɑrtɚ/noun[C,U]
1 a written statement of the rights, beliefs and purposes of an organization or a particular group of people 宪章；章程: The club's charter does not permit women to become members. 这家俱乐部的章程规定，妇女不得成为会员。
2 the renting of a ship, plane, etc for a particular purpose or for a particular group of people 包租（船只、飞机等）: a charter airline 包机公司
charter²
/ˈtʃɑ:tə(r) ||; ˈtʃɑrtɚ/verb [T] to rent a ship, plane, etc for a particular purpose or for a particular group of people 包租（船只、飞机等）: As there was no regular service to the island we had to charter a boat. 去那个岛没有定期航班，我们不得不包一条船。

chartered
/ˈtʃɑ:təd ||; ˈtʃɑrtɚd/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used about people in certain professions) fully trained; having passed all the necessary exams （指特定专业人士）完全合乎资格的，特许的: a chartered accountant 特许会计师

ˈcharter flight
noun [C] a flight in which all seats are paid for by a travel company and then sold to their customers, usually at a lower price than that of a SCHEDULED FLIGHT 包机；乘包机飞行

ˌcharter ˈmember
noun [C] (US 美) = founder-member

*chase¹
/tʃeɪs ||; tʃes/verb
1 [I,T] chase (after) sb/sth to run after sb/sth in order to catch him/her/it 追逐；追捕: The dog chased the cat up a tree. 狗把猫赶到树上。 The police car chased after the stolen van. 警车追踪那辆被偷走的面包车。
2 [I] to run somewhere fast 奔跑: The kids were chasing around the park. 孩子们在公园里到处奔跑。
*chase²
/tʃeɪs ||; tʃes/noun [C] the act of following sb/sth in order to catch him/her/it 追逐；追捕: an exciting car chase 紧张刺激的汽车追逐 give chase to begin to run after sb/sth in order to try to catch him/her/it 展开追逐或追捕: The robber ran off and the policeman gave chase. 劫匪逃脱，警察展开追捕。

chasm
/ˈkæzəm ||; ˈkæzəm/noun[C]
1 a deep hole in the ground 地下深渊
2 a wide difference of feelings, interests, etc between two people or groups 鸿沟；分歧；差距

chassis
/ˈʃæsi ||; ˈʃæsɪ/noun [C] (plural chassis /ˈʃæsi ||; ˈʃæsɪ/) the metal frame of a vehicle onto which the other parts fit 车架；（车辆的）底盘

chaste
/tʃeɪst ||; tʃest/adj (old-fashioned 旧)
1 not involving thoughts and feelings about sex （思想、感情等）干净的，纯洁的: She gave him a chaste kiss on the cheek. 她纯真地吻了吻他的脸颊。
2 never having had a sexual relationship, or only with your husband/wife 贞洁的（没有过性行为，或除了跟自己的伴侣外没有跟别人有过性行为） ➔chastity /ˈtʃæstəti ||; ˈtʃæstətɪ/ noun [U]

chastise
/tʃæˈstaɪz ||; tʃæsˈtaɪz/verb[T]
1 chastise sb (for sth/for doing sth)(formal 正式) to criticize sb for doing sth wrong 批评，申斥（某人干错事）
2 (old-fashioned 旧) to punish sb physically 对（某人）施行体罚 ➔chastisement noun [U]

chat¹
/tʃæt ||; tʃæt/verb [I] (chatting;chatted)chat (with/to sb) (about sth) to talk to sb in a friendly, informal way 跟某人闲谈或聊天: The two grandmothers sat chatting about the old days. 两位老大妈坐着聊起往事来了。 chat sb up (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to talk to sb in a friendly way because you are sexually attracted to him/her 搭讪；攀谈；调情
chat²
/tʃæt ||; tʃæt/noun [C,U] a friendly informal conversation 闲谈；聊天: I'll have a chat with Jim about the arrangements. 我将跟吉姆聊一聊安排的事儿。

ˈchat room
noun [C] (computing计算机技术) an area on the Internet where people can communicate with each other, usually about one particular topic （因特网上的）闲聊室，聊天室

ˈchat show
noun [C] a television or radio programme on which well-known people are invited to talk about themselves 清谈节目，访谈节目（电视、电台上的访问或讨论节目，常请名人谈自己的事）

chatter
/ˈtʃætə(r) ||; ˈtʃætɚ/verb[I]
1 to talk quickly or for a long time about sth unimportant 胡扯一通；喋喋不休: The children were laughing and chattering excitedly. 孩子们兴奋地说说笑笑，叽叽喳喳。
2 (used about your teeth) to knock together because you are cold or frightened （指牙齿）打颤 chatter noun [U]

chatty
/ˈtʃæti ||; ˈtʃætɪ/adj
1 talking a lot in a friendly way 爱聊天的；健谈的
2 in an informal style 闲聊式的: a chatty letter 闲话家常的信

chauffeur
/ˈʃəʊfə(r); US ʃəʊˈfɜ:r ||; ʃoˈfɝ/noun [C] a person whose job is to drive a car for sb else （受雇佣的）司机: a chauffeur-driven limousine 由司机驾驶的豪华轿车 chauffeur verb [T]

chauvinism
/ˈʃəʊvɪnɪzəm ||; ˈʃovɪnˌɪzəm/noun [U]:
1 the belief that your country is better than all others 沙文主义；本国至上主义；盲目的爱国主义
2 (also male ˈchauvinism) the belief that men are better than women 大男子主义 ➔chauvinist /ˈʃəʊvɪnɪst ||; ˈʃovɪnɪst/ noun [C] adj

*cheap¹
/tʃi:p ||; tʃip/adj
1 low in price, costing little money 便宜的: Oranges are cheap at the moment. 这时候橘子很便宜。 Computers are getting cheaper all the time. 计算机始终是越来越便宜。 [SYN] inexpensive 同义词为inexpensive [OPP] expensive 反义词为expensive
2 charging low prices 索价低廉的: a cheap hotel/restaurant 廉价酒店╱饭馆
3 low in price and quality and therefore not attractive 价廉质劣的；蹩脚的: The clothes in that shop look cheap. 那家店里的衣服看上去很蹩脚。
dirt cheap→DIRT
cheap²
/tʃi:p ||; tʃip/adv (informal 非正式) for a low price 以廉价…: I got this coat cheap in the sale. 这件外套是我趁减价的时候买的。 be going cheap(informal 非正式) to be on sale at a lower price than usual 减价出售

cheapen
/ˈtʃi:pən ||; ˈtʃipən/verb[T]
1 to make sb lose respect for himself or herself 使某人失去自尊: She felt cheapened by his treatment of her. 他这样对待她使她觉得很丢脸。 [SYN] degrade 同义词为degrade
2 to make sth lower in price 使降价
3 to make sth seem to have less value 贬低某事物的价值: The movie was accused of cheapening human life. 这部电影被指责贬低人类生活。

cheaply
/ˈtʃi:pli ||; ˈtʃiplɪ/adv for a low price 以廉价

*cheat¹
/tʃi:t ||; tʃit/verb
1 [T] to trick sb, especially when that person trusts you; to deceive sb 欺骗: The shopkeeper cheated customers by giving them too little change. 店主以少找钱来欺骗顾客。
2 [I] cheat (at sth) to act in a dishonest or unfair way in order to get an advantage for yourself 作弊: Paul was caught cheating in the exam. 保罗考试作弊给当场发现。 to cheat at cards 玩牌时作弊
3 [I] cheat (on sb) to not be faithful to your husband, wife or regular partner by having a secret sexual relationship with sb else （对配偶或伴侣）不忠
cheat sb (out) of sth to take sth from sb in a dishonest or unfair way 骗取: They tried to cheat the old lady out of her savings. 他们想把那位老太太的积蓄骗个精光。
cheat²
/tʃi:t ||; tʃit/noun [C] a person who cheats 作弊者；行骗者

*check¹
/tʃek ||; tʃɛk/verb
1 [I,T] check (sth) (for sth) to examine or test sth in order to make sure that it is safe or correct, in good condition, etc 检验；检查: Check your work for mistakes before you hand it in. 把你的作业检查一遍，看看有没有错，然后再交上来。 The doctor X-rayed me to check for broken bones. 医生给我做了X光检查，看骨头有没有断。
2 [I,T] check (sth) (with sb) to make sure that sth is how you think it is 核实；确定: You'd better check with Tim that it's OK to borrow his bike. 你最好跟蒂姆确定一下，是不是可以借用他的自行车。 I'll phone and check what time the bus leaves. 我会打电话核实一下公共汽车的发车时间。
3 [T] to stop or make sb/sth stop or go more slowly （使）停下；（使）减慢: She almost told her boss what she thought of him, but checked herself in time. 她差点把自己对老板的看法告诉老板，但是及时打住了。 Phil checked his pace as he didn't want to tire too early. 菲尔放慢步子，他不想太早走得很累。
4 [T] (US 美) =TICK¹(2)
check in (at...); check into... to go to a desk in a hotel or an airport and tell an official that you have arrived （向酒店或机场柜台）登记，报到 check sth off to mark names or items on a list （在列表所列的项目旁边）打上记号: The boxes were all checked off as they were unloaded. 这些箱子一经卸下便打上记号。 check (up) on sb/sth to find out how sb/sth is 了解；查明: We call my grandmother every evening to check up on her. 我们每天晚上都打电话给奶奶，了解她的情况。 check out (of...) to pay your bill and leave a hotel 办理酒店付账及退房手续；结账离去 check sb/sth out
1 to find out more information about sb/sth, especially to find out if sth is true or not 查明是否属实；查证: We need to check out these rumours of possible pay cuts. 我们要查明这些有关可能减薪的传闻是否属实。
2 (especially US 尤为美) (informal 非正式) to look at sth, especially to find out if you like him/her/it 察看；查访: I'm going to check out that new club tonight. 今晚我要去那家新俱乐部看看。
check up on sb/sth to make sure that sb/sth is working correctly, behaving well, etc, especially if you think he/she/it is not 盘查，查核（确保做对、表现良好等，尤指觉得对方做得不好）
*check²
/tʃek ||; tʃɛk/noun
1 [C] a check (on sth) a close look at sth to make sure that it is safe, correct, in good condition, etc 检验；检查: We carry out / doregular checkson our products to make sure that they are of high quality. 我们定期检验产品以保证高质量。 I don't go to games, but I like to keep a check on my team's results. 我不去看比赛，但我喜欢了解我队的比赛结果。
2 [C,U] a pattern of squares, often of different colours （一般为花色的）格子图案: a check jacket 有格子图案的夹克 a pattern of blue and red checks 蓝红两色的格子图案
3 [U] the situation in a particular game (chess), in which a player must move to protect his/her king （国际象棋）将军 ☞Look at checkmate. 参看checkmate。
4 [C] (US 美) =CHEQUE
5 [C] (US 美) =BILL¹(1)
6 [C] (US 美) =TICK²(1)
hold/keep sth in check to stop sth from advancing or increasing too quickly 停止；减慢: government measures to keep inflation in check 政府遏止通胀的措施

checkbook
(US 美) =CHEQUEBOOK

ˈcheck box
noun [C] (computing计算机技术) a square on a computer screen that allows you to choose sth by pressing(clicking)on it with your mouse button 校验框；确认对话框

checked
/tʃekt ||; tʃɛkt/adj with a pattern of squares 有格子花纹的: a red-and-white checked tablecloth 红白格子花纹桌布

checkers
/ˈtʃekəz ||; ˈtʃɛkɚz/ (US 美) =DRAUGHT¹(2)

ˈcheck-in
noun [C]
1 the act of checking in at an airport （在机场）办理登机手续: Our check-in time is 10.30 am. 我们办理登机手续的时间是上午10点30分。
2 the place where you check in at an airport （机场的）办理登机处

ˈchecking account
(US 美) =CURRENT ACCOUNT

checklist
/ˈtʃeklɪst ||; ˈtʃɛkˌlɪst/noun [C] a list of things that you must do or have 清单

checkmate
/ˌtʃekˈmeɪt ||; ˈtʃɛkˌmet/noun [U] the situation in a particular game (chess), in which you cannot protect your king and so have lost the game （国际象棋）将死 ☞Look at check ²(3). 参看check^2(3)。

checkout
/ˈtʃekaʊt ||; ˈtʃɛkˌaυt/noun [C] the place in a large food shop (supermarket) where you pay （超级市场的）付款处

checkpoint
/ˈtʃekpɔɪnt ||; ˈtʃɛkˌpɔɪnt/noun [C] a place where all people and vehicles must stop and be checked 检查站: an army checkpoint 军事检查站

ˈcheck-up
noun [C] a general medical examination to make sure that you are healthy 体格检查

cheddar
/ˈtʃedə(r) ||; ˈtʃɛdɚ/noun [U] a type of hard yellow cheese 切德干酪（一种质硬色黄的干酪）

*cheek
/tʃi:k ||; tʃik/noun
1 [C] either side of the face below your eyes 颊；脸蛋 ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 [C,U] (Brit 英) rude behaviour; lack of respect 粗鲁无礼: He's got a cheek, asking to borrow money again! 他脸皮真厚，又来借钱！
(with) tongue in cheek→TONGUE

cheekbone
/ˈtʃi:kbəʊn ||; ˈtʃikˌbon/noun [C] the bone below your eye 颧骨 ☞picture at body 见body插图

cheeky
/ˈtʃi:ki ||; ˈtʃikɪ/adj (Brit 英) (cheekier;cheekiest) not showing respect; rude 粗鲁无礼的: Don't be so cheeky! Of course I'm not fat! 别这么胡说八道！我当然不胖！ ➔cheekily adv

*cheer¹
/tʃɪə(r) ||; tʃɪr/verb
1 [I,T] to shout to show that you like sth or to encourage sb who is taking part in competition, sport, etc 欢呼；喝彩: Everyone cheered the winner as he crossed the finishing line. 优胜者冲过终点线的时候人人都向他欢呼。
2 [T] to make sb happy or more hopeful 鼓舞: They were all cheered by the good news. 他们因这个好消息都欢欣鼓舞。
cheer sb on to shout in order to encourage sb in a race, competition, etc 给某人打气: As the runners started the last lap the crowd cheered them on. 当赛跑选手开始跑最后一圈的时候，群众都欢呼为他们打气。 cheer (sb/sth) up to become or to make sb happier; to make sth look more attractive （使）振作起来；（使）…增添色彩: Cheer up! Things aren't that bad. 振作起来吧！事情还没有那么坏呢。 A few pictures would cheer this room up a bit. 挂几幅画会使这房间增添一点生气。
*cheer²
/tʃɪə(r) ||; tʃɪr/noun [C] a loud shout to show that you like sth or to encourage sb who is taking part in a competition, sport, etc （用来打气的）欢呼声，喝彩声: The crowd gave a cheer when the president appeared. 总统露面时人群里响起了欢呼声。

*cheerful
/ˈtʃɪəfl ||; ˈtʃɪrfəl/ feeling happy; showing that you are happy 愉快的；开朗的: Caroline is always very cheerful. 卡罗琳总是兴高采烈的。 a cheerful smile 欢笑 ➔cheerfully /-fəli ||; -fəlɪ/ adv ➔cheerfulness noun [U]

cheerio
/ˌtʃɪəriˈəʊ ||; ˈtʃɪrɪˌo/ exclamation (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) goodbye 再见

cheerleader
/ˈtʃɪəli:də(r) ||; ˈtʃɪrˌlidɚ/noun [C] (especially in the US) one of a group of girls or women at a sports match who wear special uniforms and shout, dance, etc in order to encourage people to support the players （尤为美）拉拉队员（多为女性，在体育比赛时穿着特制的制服，吶喊跳舞，鼓励观众为运动员打气）

cheers
/tʃɪəz ||; tʃɪrz/ exclamation (informal 非正式)
1 used to express good wishes before you have an alcoholic drink 干杯: ‘Cheers,’ she said, raising her wine glass. 她举起酒杯说道﹕“干杯！”
2 (Brit 英) goodbye 再见
3 (Brit 英) thank you 谢谢

cheery
/ˈtʃɪəri ||; ˈtʃɪrɪ/adj happy and smiling 兴高采烈的；喜气洋洋的: a cheery remark/wave/smile 亲切的话╱招手╱微笑 ➔cheerily adv

*cheese
/tʃi:z ||; tʃiz/noun
1 [U] a type of food made from milk. Cheese is usually white or yellow in colour and can be soft or hard. 干酪；奶酪；起司: a piece of cheese 一块干酪 a cheese sandwich 干酪三明治 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
2 [C] a type of cheese 某种干酪的品种: a wide selection of cheeses 琳琅满目的干酪品种

cheeseburger
/ˈtʃi:zbɜ:gə(r) ||; ˈtʃizˌbɝgɚ/noun [C] a sandwich made of chopped meat in a flat, round shape (a hamburger) with a slice of cheese on top 干酪汉堡包

cheesecake
/ˈtʃi:zkeɪk ||; ˈtʃizˌkek/noun [C,U] a type of cake that is made from soft cheese and sugar on a pastry or biscuit base, often with fruit on top 干酪糕饼；起司蛋糕

cheetah
/ˈtʃi:tə ||; ˈtʃitə/noun [C] a large wild cat with black spots that can run very fast 猎豹（身上有黑色斑点，善跑） ☞picture at lion 见lion插图

chef
/ʃef ||; ʃɛf/noun [C] a professional cook, especially the head cook in a hotel, restaurant, etc 大厨师（尤指酒店、餐馆等的厨师长）

ˈchef's salad
noun [C] (US 美) a large salad consisting of lettuce, tomato and other vegetables with slices of cheese and meat such as chicken or ham, on top 厨师色拉﹙用生菜、西红柿、干酪片、肉片等做成﹚

*chemical¹
/ˈkemɪkl ||; ˈkɛmɪkḷ/adj connected with chemistry; involving changes to the structure of a substance 化学的: a chemical reaction 化学反应 ➔chemically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv
*chemical²
/ˈkemɪkl ||; ˈkɛmɪkḷ/noun [C] a substance that is used or produced in a chemical process 化学品: Sulphuric acid is a dangerous chemical. 硫酸是一种危险的化学品。 chemical weapons/warfare 化学武器；化学战

*chemist
/ˈkemɪst ||; ˈkɛmɪst/noun[C]
1 (also pharmacist, US 美 druggist) a person who prepares and sells medicines 药剂师
2 the chemist's(US 美 drugstore) a shop that sells medicines, soap, camera film, etc 药房: I got my tablets from the chemist's. 我的药片是在药房里买的。
3 a person who is a specialist in chemistry 化学家

*chemistry
/ˈkemɪstri ||; ˈkɛmɪstrɪ/noun [U]:
1 the scientific study of the structure of substances and what happens to them in different conditions or when mixed with each other 化学: We did an experiment in the chemistry lesson today. 我们今天上化学课的时候做了一个实验。
2 the structure of a particular substance 化学结构；化学特性

chemotherapy
/ˌki:məʊˈθerəpi ||; ˌkɛmoˈθɛrəpɪ/noun [U] the treatment of an illness using chemical substances 化学疗法: She was suffering from leukaemia and undergoing chemotherapy. 她患了白血病，正接受化疗。

*cheque
/tʃek ||; tʃɛk/ (US 美 check) noun [C,U] a piece of paper printed by a bank that you sign and use to pay for things 支票: She wrote out a cheque for £20. 她开了一张20英镑的支票。 I went to the bank to cash a cheque. 我去银行将支票兑现。 Can I pay by cheque ? 我可不可以用支票付款？ ☞picture at money 见money插图

chequebook
/ˈtʃekbʊk ||; ˈtʃɛkˌbυk/ (US 美 checkbook) noun [C] a book of cheques 支票簿

ˈcheque card
noun [C] (Brit 英) a small plastic card that you show when you pay with a cheque as proof that your bank will pay the amount on the cheque 支票保付限额卡；支票卡 ☞Look at cash card and credit card. 参看cash card及credit card。

cherish
/ˈtʃerɪʃ ||; ˈtʃɛrɪʃ/verb[T]
1 to love sb/sth and look after him/her/it carefully 珍爱: The ring was her most cherished possession. 这枚戒指是她最珍爱的东西。
2 to keep a thought, feeling, etc in your mind and think about it often 抱有，怀有（想法、感情等）: a cherished memory 怀念

cherry
/ˈtʃeri ||; ˈtʃɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural cherries)
1 a small round black or red fruit that has a stone inside it 樱桃 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图
2 (also cherry tree) the tree that produces cherries 樱桃树

cherub
/ˈtʃerəb ||; ˈtʃɛrəb/noun [C] a type of ANGEL(= a spirit who is believed to live in heaven with God) that looks like a fat male child with wings 小天使（形似胖乎乎的男孩，生有翅膀）

chess
/tʃes ||; tʃɛs/noun [U] a game for two people that is played on a board with 64 black and white squares (a chessboard). Each player has sixteen pieces which can be moved according to fixed rules. 国际象棋，西洋棋（两人对奕，各有十六个棋子，按规则移动；棋盘由六十四个黑白方格相间组成）: Can you play chess ? 你会下国际象棋吗？

*chest
/tʃest ||; tʃɛst/noun[C]
1 the top part of the front of your body 胸部 ☞picture at body 见body插图
2 a large strong box that is used for storing or carrying things 箱子（用来储存或携带物品） ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图
get sth off your chest(informal 非正式) to talk about sth that you have been thinking or worrying about 倾吐心事

chestnut
/ˈtʃesnʌt ||; ˈtʃɛsˌnʌt/noun[C]
1 (also chestnut tree) a tree with large leaves that produces smooth brown nuts in shells with sharp points on the outside 栗树
2 a smooth brown nut from the chestnut tree. You can eat some chestnuts 栗子: roast chestnuts 炒栗子 ☞Look at conker. 参看conker。 ☞picture at nut 见nut插图

ˌchest of ˈdrawers
noun [C] a piece of furniture with drawers in it that is used for storing clothes, etc （有抽屉的）衣柜 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

*chew
/tʃu: ||; tʃu/verb[I,T]
1 to break up food in your mouth with your teeth before you swallow it 咀嚼
2 chew (on) sth to bite sth continuously with the back teeth 用后牙不停地嚼: The dog was chewing on a bone. 那狗在啃骨头。

ˈchewing gum
(also gum) noun [U] a sweet sticky substance that you chew in your mouth but do not swallow 口香糖 ☞Look at bubblegum. 参看bubblegum。

chewy
/ˈtʃu:i ||; ˈtʃuɪ/adj (used about food) difficult to break up with your teeth before it can be swallowed （指食物）难嚼碎的: chewy meat/toffee 难嚼碎的肉╱太妃糖

chic
/ʃi:k ||; ʃik/adj fashionable and elegant 时髦雅致的 chic noun [U]

chick
/tʃɪk ||; tʃɪk/noun [C] a baby bird, especially a young chicken 雏鸟；（尤指）小鸡 ☞picture at chicken 见chicken插图

*chicken¹
/ˈtʃɪkɪn ||; ˈtʃɪkɪn/noun
1 [C] a bird that people often keep for its eggs and its meat 鸡
2 [U] the meat of this bird 鸡肉: chicken soup 鸡汤
Notice that chicken is the general word for the bird and its meat. A male chicken is called a cock (US rooster), a female is called a hen and a young bird is called a chick. 注意，chicken常用来指鸡、鸡肉。公鸡叫做cock（在美国叫做rooster），母鸡叫做hen，小鸡叫做chick。 Don't count your chickens (before they're hatched)→COUNT¹
chicken²
/ˈtʃɪkɪn ||; ˈtʃɪkɪn/verb chicken out (of sth)(informal 非正式) to decide not to do sth because you are afraid 胆怯退缩；临阵退缩: Mark chickened out of swimming across the river when he saw how far it was. 马克看到河的对岸颇远，便临阵退缩，不敢游过去了。

ˈchicken feed
noun [U] (informal 非正式) an amount of money that is not large enough to be important 一笔微不足道的钱

ˈchicken flu
noun [U] = avian influenza⇒

chickenpox
/ˈtʃɪkɪnpɒks ||; ˈtʃɪkɪnˌpɑks/noun [U] a disease, especially of children. When you have chickenpox you feel very hot and get red spots on your skin that make you want to scratch. 水痘（一种疾病，患者多为儿童，症状是体温升高，皮肤上出现会发痒的丘疹）

chicory
/ˈtʃɪkəri ||; ˈtʃɪkərɪ/ (US 美 endive) noun [U] a small pale green plant with bitter leaves that can be eaten cooked or not cooked 菊苣（一种浅绿色植物，叶味苦，可熟吃或生吃）

*chief¹
/tʃi:f ||; tʃif/noun[C]
1 the person who has command or control over an organization （机构的）首长: the chief of police 警察局局长
2 the leader of a tribe （部落的）酋长
chief²
/tʃi:f ||; tʃif/adj (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前)
1 most important; main 首要的；主要的: One of the chief reasons for his decision was money. 他作出这个决定，主要原因之一是为了钱。
2 of the highest level or position 为首的；最高级别的: the chief executive of a company 公司的总裁

chiefly
/ˈtʃi:fli ||; ˈtʃiflɪ/adv mainly; mostly 主要地；多半: His success was due chiefly to hard work. 他的成功主要靠勤奋工作。

chieftain
/ˈtʃi:ftən ||; ˈtʃiftən/noun [C] the leader of a tribe 酋长；族长: a twelfth-century Scottish chieftain 十二世纪的苏格兰族长

chiffon
/ˈʃɪfɒn ||; ʃɪˈfɑn/noun [U] a very thin, transparent type of cloth used for making clothes, etc 雪纺绸；薄绸

chihuahua
/tʃɪˈwɑ:wə; US -ˈwɑ:wɑ: ||; tʃɪˈwɑwɑ/noun [C] a very small dog with smooth hair 奇瓦瓦狗﹙体小、毛光滑﹚

chilblain
/ˈtʃɪlbleɪn ||; ˈtʃɪlˌblen/noun [C] a painful red area on your foot, hand, etc that is caused by cold weather （手、脚等的）冻疮

*child
/tʃaɪld ||; tʃaɪld/noun [C] (plural children /ˈtʃɪldrən ||; ˈtʃɪldrən/)
1 a young boy or girl who is not yet an adult 小孩；儿童: A group of children were playing in the park. 一群孩子正在公园里玩耍。 a six-year-old child 六岁大的小孩
2 a son or daughter of any age 儿子；女儿；子女: She has two children but both are married and have moved away. 她有两个孩子，但都结了婚，搬走了。
An only child is a child who has no brothers or sisters. A couple may adopt a child who is not their own son or daughter (for example if the child's parents are dead). A foster child is looked after for a certain period of time by a family that is not his/her own. 独生子、独生女叫做only child。夫妇可领养(adopt)小孩（比如小孩父母双亡）。寄养在别的家庭的小孩叫做foster child。
ˌchild ˈbenefit
noun [U] money that is paid every week by the British government to parents for each child that they have 儿童津贴（由英国政府每周给每个孩子的父母）

childbirth
/ˈtʃaɪldbɜ:θ ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌbɝθ/noun [U] the act of giving birth to a baby 分娩: His wife died in childbirth. 他的妻子分娩时死亡。

childcare
/ˈtʃaɪldkeə(r) ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌkɛr/noun [U] the job of looking after children, especially while the parents are at work 小孩托管（尤指父母都上班的时候）: Some employers provide childcare facilities. 有些雇主提供照看孩子的设施。

childhood
/ˈtʃaɪldhʊd ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌhυd/noun [C,U] the time when you are a child 童年: Harriet had a very unhappy childhood. 哈丽雅特的童年十分不愉快。 childhood memories 童年往事

childish
/ˈtʃaɪldɪʃ ||; ˈtʃaɪldɪʃ/adj like a child 幼稚的: childish handwriting 孩子般的字迹 ➔childishly adv If you say that people or their behaviour are childlike, you mean that they are like children in some way His childlike enthusiasm delighted us all.if you say that an adult's behaviour is childish, you are criticizing it because you think it is silly Don't be so childish! You can't always have everything you want. 说人家天真可爱，用childlike：His childlike enthusiasm delighted us all. 他那么纯真热情，令我们高兴极了。说人家幼稚，用childish：Don't be so childish! You can't always have everything you want.别那么孩子气！你不能老是想要什么就有什么。
childless
/ˈtʃaɪldləs ||; ˈtʃaɪldlɪs/adj having no children 无子女的

childlike
/ˈtʃaɪldlaɪk ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌlaɪk/adj like a child 孩子般的；天真无邪的 ☞Look at childish. 参看childish。

childminder
/ˈtʃaɪldmaɪndə(r) ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌmaɪndɚ/noun [C] (Brit 英) a person whose job is to look after a child while his/her parents are at work （受雇为工作的父母）照顾小孩的人，保姆

childproof
/ˈtʃaɪldpru:f ||; ˈtʃaɪldˌpruf/adj designed so that young children cannot open, use or damage it 能防止孩子打开、使用或弄坏的: childproof containers for medicine 对孩子安全的药罐

ˈchildren's home
noun [C] an institution where children live whose parents cannot look after them 儿童之家，儿童福利院（收养父母无法照看的孩子的机构）

chili
(US 美) =CHILLI

chill¹
/tʃɪl ||; tʃɪl/noun
1 [sing] an unpleasant cold feeling 寒意；寒冷: There's a chill in the air. 寒气逼人。 (figurative 比喻) A chill of fear went down my spine. 我感到毛骨悚然。
2 [C] (informal 非正式) an common illness that affects your nose and throat; a cold 风寒: to catch a chill 着凉
chill²
/tʃɪl ||; tʃɪl/verb[I,T]
1 to become or to make sb/sth colder （使）变冷
2 (also chill out) (informal 非正式) to relax and not feel angry or nervous about anything 冷漠；悠然；懒洋洋: I work hard all week so on Sundays I just chill out. 我整个星期拚命工作，因此到了星期日我就懒洋洋的。

chilli
/ˈtʃɪli ||; ˈtʃɪlɪ/ (US 美 chili) noun [C,U] (plural chillies (US 美) chilies) a small green or red vegetable that has a very strong hot taste 辣椒: chilli powder 辣椒粉 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

chilling
/ˈtʃɪlɪŋ ||; ˈtʃɪlɪŋ/adj frightening 恐怖的: a chilling ghost story 恐怖的鬼故事

chilly
/ˈtʃɪli ||; ˈtʃɪlɪ/adj (chillier;chilliest) (used about the weather but also about people) too cold to be comfortable （指天气，但也指人）冷得使人不舒服: It's a chilly morning. You need a coat on. 今早很冷，你需要穿件外套。 We got a very chilly reception (= unfriendly) 我们受到很冷淡的接待。

chime
/tʃaɪm ||; tʃaɪm/verb [I,T] (used about a bell or clock) to ring （指铃或钟）响 chime noun [C] chime in (with sth)(informal 非正式) to interrupt a conversation and add your own comments 插话

*chimney
/ˈtʃɪmni ||; ˈtʃɪmnɪ/noun [C] a pipe through which smoke or steam is carried up and out through the roof of a building 烟筒；烟囱 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

ˈchimney sweep
noun [C] a person whose job is to clean the inside of chimneys with long brushes 烟囱清扫工

chimpanzee
/ˌtʃɪmpænˈzi: ||; ˌtʃɪmpænˈzi/ (informal 非正式chimp /tʃɪmp ||; tʃɪmp/) noun [C] a small intelligent animal like a monkey but without a tail (an ape) which is found in Africa 黑猩猩（产于非洲） ☞picture at primate 见primate插图

*chin
/tʃɪn ||; tʃɪn/noun [C] the part of your face below your mouth 颏；下巴 ☞picture at body 见body插图

china
/ˈtʃaɪnə ||; ˈtʃaɪnə/noun [U]:
1 white clay of good quality that is used for making cups, plates, etc 瓷: a china vase 瓷花瓶
2 cups, plates, etc that are made from china 瓷器

ˌchina ˈclay
=KAOLIN

chink
/tʃɪŋk ||; tʃɪŋk/noun [C] a small narrow opening 裂缝；缝隙: Daylight came in through a chink between the curtains. 日光从窗帘之间的缝隙照进来。

chinos
/ˈtʃi:nəʊz ||; ˈtʃinoz/noun [pl] informal trousers made from strong cotton 斜纹布裤: a polo shirt and a pair of chinos 一件马球衫和一条斜纹布裤

chintz
/tʃɪnts ||; tʃɪnts/noun [U] a shiny cotton cloth with a printed design, usually of flowers, which is used for making curtains, covering furniture, etc （摩擦轧光的）印花棉布（用于做窗帘、家具罩等）

*chip¹
/tʃɪp ||; tʃɪp/noun[C]
1 the place where a small piece of stone, glass, wood, etc has broken off sth 缺口；口子: This dish has a chip in it. 这碟子有个缺口。
2 a small piece of stone, glass, wood, etc that has broken off sth （石、玻璃、木等的）碎片，碎屑
3 (US 美 French fry) [usu.pl] a thin piece of potato that is fried in hot fat or oil 炸马铃薯条；炸薯条 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
4 (also potato chip) (US 美) =CRISP²
5 =MICROCHIP
6 a flat round piece of plastic that you use instead of money when you are playing some games 筹码
have a chip on your shoulder (about sth)(informal 非正式) to feel angry about sth that happened a long time ago because you think it is unfair 心怀怨愤（因冤屈）: My dad still has a chip on his shoulder about being thrown out of school. 我爸爸仍为被学校开除一事感到愤愤不平。
chip²
/tʃɪp ||; tʃɪp/verb [I,T] (chipping;chipped)
1 to break a small piece off the edge or surface of sth （在边缘或表面）碰下碎片；使缺损: They chipped the paint trying to get the table through the door. 他们想把桌子搬过门去，结果把油漆给碰掉了。
2 (in sport) to kick or hit a ball a short distance through the air （体育）切削击球
chip in (with sth)(informal 非正式)
1 to interrupt when sb else is talking 打岔
2 to give some money as part of the cost of sth 凑份子: We all chipped in and bought him a present when he left. 他走的时候，我们凑份子给他买了一件礼物。

chipmunk
/ˈtʃɪpmʌŋk ||; ˈtʃɪpmʌŋk/noun [C] a small North American animal with a long, thick tail and bands of dark and light colour on its back 花鼠（产于北美，尾巴又长又粗，背部有深色和浅色条纹）

ˈchip shop
/ˈtʃɪpi ||; ˈtʃɪpɪ/ (also chippy) noun [C] (in Britain) a shop that cooks and sells fish and chips and other fried food to take away and eat （英国）薯条店（外卖炸鱼和炸马铃薯条等油炸食物的店）

chiropodist
/kɪˈrɒpədɪst ||; kaɪˈrɑpədɪst/ (US 美 podiatrist) noun [C] a person whose job is to look after people's feet 足病治疗师；足医

chiropody
/kɪˈrɒpədi ||; kaɪˈrɑpədɪ/ (US 美 podiatry) noun [U] the care and treatment of people's feet 足部治疗

chiropractor
/ˈkaɪərəʊpræktə(r) ||; ˈkaɪrəˌpræktɚ/noun [C] a person whose job involves treating some diseases and physical problems by pressing and moving the bones in a person's back(spine) （以指压和推拿脊骨治病的）按摩师 ☞Compare osteopath. 与 osteopath 比较。

chirp
/tʃɜ:p ||; tʃɝp/verb [I] (used about small birds and some insects) to make short high sounds （指小鸟及某些昆虫）叽叽叫，啁啾

chisel
/ˈtʃɪzl ||; ˈtʃɪzḷ/noun [C] a tool with a sharp end that is used for cutting or shaping wood or stone 凿子 ☞picture at tool 见tool插图

chivalry
/ˈʃɪvəlri ||; ˈʃɪvḷrɪ/noun [U] polite and kind behaviour by men which shows respect towards women 侠义精神，骑士气概，尊重女性的风度（就男人对待女人而言，尤指殷勤、体贴、有礼等） ➔chivalrous /ˈʃɪvlrəs ||; ˈʃɪvḷrəs/ adj

chive
/tʃaɪv ||; tʃaɪv/noun [C] [usu.pl] a long thin green plant that tastes like onion and is used in cooking （用于烹调的）细香葱
