chloride
/ˈklɔ:raɪd ||; ˈklɔraɪd/noun [U] a chemical compound of CHLORINE and another chemical 氯化物

chlorinate
/ˈklɔ:rɪneɪt ||; ˈklɔrɪˌnet/verb [T] to put chlorine in sth, especially water 加氯消毒（尤指给水）: a chlorinated swimming pool 加氯消毒过的游泳池 ➔chlorination /ˌklɔ:rɪˈneɪʃn ||; ˌklɔrɪˈneʃən/ noun [U]

chlorine
/ˈklɔ:ri:n ||; ˈklɔrin/noun [U] (symbol Cl) a greenish-yellow gas with a strong smell, that is used for making water safe to drink or to swim in 氯；氯气

chlorofluorocarbon
/ˌklɔ:rəʊˈflʊərəʊkɑ:bən ||; ˌklɔroˈfluroˌkɑrbən/noun [C] = cfc

chloroform
/ˈklɒrəfɔ:m ||; ˈklɔrəˌfɔrm/noun [U] (symbol CHCl₃) a colourless liquid with a strong smell used by doctors in the past to make people unconscious, for example before an operation 氯仿，三氯甲烷，哥罗仿（医生用于麻醉病人，如在手术之前）

chlorophyll
/ˈklɒrəfɪl ||; ˈklɔrəˌfɪl/noun [U] the green substance in plants that takes in light from the sun to help them grow 叶绿素

chloroplast
/ˈklɒrəplɑ:st ||; ˈklɔrəˌplæst/noun [C] (technical术语) the part of a green plant cell that contains chlorophyll and in which PHOTOSYNTHESIS(= the changing of light from the sun into energy)takes place 叶绿体

chock-a-block
/ˌtʃɒk ə ˈblɒk ||; ˈtʃɑk ə ˈblɑk/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) completely full 挤满；塞满；充满: The High Street was chock-a-block with shoppers. 购物的人潮把高街挤得水泄不通。

chocoholic
/ˌtʃɒkəˈhɒlɪk ||; ˌtʃɑkəˈhɔlɪk/noun [C] a person who loves chocolate and eats a lot of it 爱吃巧克力的人；巧克力狂

*chocolate
/ˈtʃɒklət ||; ˈtʃɑkəlɪt/noun
1 [U] a sweet brown substance made from seeds (cocoa beans )that you can eat as a sweet or use to give flavour to food and drinks 巧克力: a bar of milk/plain chocolate 一块奶油╱纯巧克力 a chocolate milkshake 一杯巧克力奶昔
2 [C] a small sweet that is made from or covered with chocolate 巧克力糖: a box of chocolates 一盒巧克力糖
3 [C,U] a drink made from powdered chocolate with hot milk or water 巧克力饮料: a mug of hot chocolate 一大杯热巧克力
4 [U] a dark brown colour 深褐色

ˌchocolate ˈchip
noun [C] a small piece of chocolate(1) used in baking ﹙用于烤制糕点的﹚巧克力碎片 ➔ˌchocolate-ˈchip adj: chocolate-chip cookies/ice cream 含巧克力碎片的曲奇饼/冰淇淋

*choice¹
/tʃɔɪs ||; tʃɔɪs/noun
1 [C] a choice (between A and B) an act of choosing between two or more people or things 选择；挑选: David was forced to make a choice between moving house and losing his job. 戴维不得不在搬家和失业之间作出选择。
2 [U] the right or chance to choose 选择的权利或机会: There is a rail strike so we have no choice but to cancel our trip. 铁路工人在罢工，我们只好取消旅行。 to have freedom of choice 享有选择自由 [SYN] option 同义词为option
3 [C,U] two or more things from which you can or must choose （可供）选择（的事物）: This cinema offers a choice of six different films every night. 这家电影院每晚上映六部不同的影片，供观众选择。
4 [C] a person or thing that is chosen 选中的人或事物: Barry would be my choice as team captain. 我会选巴里当队长。 ☞verb choose 动词为choose
out of/from choice because you want to; of your own free will 自愿地: I wouldn't have gone to America out of choice. I was sent there on business. 有选择的话我才不会去美国；我是被派到那里出差的。
choice²
/tʃɔɪs ||; tʃɔɪs/adj of very good quality 优质的；上选的: choice beef 优质牛肉

choir
/ˈkwaɪə(r) ||; kwaɪr/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of people who sing together in churches, schools, etc （教堂、学校等的）唱诗班，合唱团

choke¹
/tʃəʊk ||; tʃok/verb
1 [I,T] choke (on sth) to be or to make sb unable to breathe because sth is stopping air getting into the lungs （使）窒息: She was choking on a fish bone. 她的喉咙给一根鱼骨哽住了。 The smoke choked us. 浓烟呛人。 ☞Look at strangle. 参看strangle。
2 [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) choke sth (up) (with sth) to fill a passage, space, etc, so that nothing can pass through 堵塞；阻塞: The roads to the coast were choked with traffic. 通往海边的几条路挤满了车辆。
choke sth back to hide or control a strong emotion 按捺住强烈的感情: to choke back tears/anger 强忍住眼泪╱怒火
choke²
/tʃəʊk ||; tʃok/noun[C]
1 the device in a car, etc that controls the amount of air going into the engine. If you pull out the choke it makes it easier to start the car. （汽车等的）阻塞门，阻风门
2 an act or the sound of sb choking 窒息；窒息时发出的声音: A tiny choke of laughter escaped her. 她发出一阵轻轻的窒息般笑声。

cholera
/ˈkɒlərə ||; ˈkɑlərə/noun [U] a serious disease that causes stomach pains and vomiting and can cause death. Cholera is most common in hot countries and is carried by water. 霍乱（一种急性传染病，症状是肚子痛和呕吐，可导致死亡。流行于酷热地区，致病细菌可经水传播）

cholesterol
/kəˈlestərɒl ||; kəˈlɛstəˌrol/noun [U] a substance that is found in the blood, etc of people and animals. Too much cholesterol is thought to be a cause of heart disease 胆固醇（胆固醇过多会引致心脏病）

*choose
/tʃu:z ||; tʃuz/verb [I,T] (past tense chose /tʃəʊz ||; tʃoz/ past participle chosen /ˈtʃəʊzn ||; ˈtʃozṇ/)
1 choose (between A and/or B);choose (A) (from B);choose sb/sth as sth to decide which thing or person you want out of the ones that are available 选择: Choose carefully before you make a final decision. 请仔细挑选再作最后决定。 Amy had to choose between getting a job or going to college. 埃米的面前摆着两条路：找工作还是上大学。 The viewers chose this programme as their favourite. 观众都说这个节目他们最喜欢看。
2 choose (to do sth) to decide or prefer to do sth 决定做；宁愿做: You are free to leave whenever you choose. 你爱什么时候走就什么时候走。 They chose to resign rather than work for the new manager. 他们宁可辞职也不愿为那个新上任的经理效力。 ☞noun choice 名词为choice
pick and choose→PICK¹

choosy
/ˈtʃu:zi ||; ˈtʃuzɪ/adj (informal 非正式) (used about a person) difficult to please （指人）难讨好的，挑剔的

chop¹
/tʃɒp ||; tʃɑp/verb [T] (chopping;chopped)chop sth (up) (into sth) to cut sth into pieces with a knife, etc 劈开；剁碎: finely chopped herbs 切细的香草屑 Chop the onions up into small pieces.把洋葱剁成小片。 chop and change to change your plans or opinions several times 数次更改（计划或意见）；朝三暮四 chop sth down to cut a tree, etc at the bottom so that it falls down 砍倒（树木等） chop sth off (sth) to remove sth from sth by cutting it with a knife or a sharp tool 劈下；砍下
chop²
/tʃɒp ||; tʃɑp/noun[C]
1 a thick slice of meat with a piece of bone in it 排骨；肋条肉 ☞Look at steak. 参看steak。 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
2 an act of chopping sth 剁；劈；砍: a karate chop 空手道的掌侧劈

chopper
/ˈtʃɒpə(r) ||; ˈtʃɑpɚ/noun [C] (informal 非正式)= HELICOPTER

ˈchopping board
noun [C] a piece of wood or plastic used for cutting meat or vegetables on 砧板；菜墩子 ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图

choppy
/ˈtʃɒpi ||; ˈtʃɑpɪ/adj (used about the sea) having a lot of small waves, slightly rough （指大海）波浪起伏

chopstick
/ˈtʃɒpstɪk ||; ˈtʃɑpˌstɪk/noun [C] [usu.pl] one of the two thin pieces of wood used for eating with, especially in Asian countries 筷子 ☞picture at pan 见 pan 插图

choral
/ˈkɔ:rəl ||; ˈkɔrəl/adj (used about music) that is written for or involving a group of singers (a choir) 为合唱团创作的，合唱团的，合唱的（音乐）

chord
/kɔ:d ||; kɔrd/noun[C]
1 two or more musical notes that are played at the same time 和弦；和音 ☞Compare arpeggio. 与arpeggio比较。
2 (mathematics数学) a straight line that joins two points on a curve 弦 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图

chore
/tʃɔ:(r) ||; tʃɔr/noun [C] a job that is not interesting but that you must do （乏味的）杂务，琐事: household chores 家务

choreograph
/ˈkɒriəgrɑ:f; US ˈkɔ:rɪəgræf ||; ˈkɔrɪəˌgræf/verb [T] to design and arrange the movements of a dance 编舞；舞蹈设计或创作 ➔choreographer /ˌkɒriˈɒgrəfə(r) ||; ˌkɔrɪˈɑgrəfɚ/ noun [C]

choreography
/ˌkɒriˈɒgrəfi; US ˌkɔ:rɪ- ||; ˌkɔrɪˈɑgrəfɪ/noun [U] the arrangement of movements for a dance performance 舞蹈编排或创作

chorus¹
/ˈkɔ:rəs ||; ˈkɔrəs/noun
1 [C] the part of a song that is repeated at the end of each verse 副歌；歌曲迭句 [SYN] refrain 同义词为refrain
2 [C] a piece of music, usually part of a larger work, that is written for a large group of people (a choir) to sing 合唱曲
3 [C] [with.sop] a large group of people who sing together （大规模的）合唱团
4 [C] [with.sop] the singers and dancers in a musical show who do not play the main parts 歌舞队
5 a chorus of sth [sing] something that a lot of people say together 齐声说的话: a chorus of cheers/criticism/disapproval 齐声欢呼╱批评╱反对
chorus²
/ˈkɔ:rəs ||; ˈkɔrəs/verb [T] (used about a group of people) to sing or say sth together （指一组人）合唱，齐声说: ‘That's not fair!’ the children chorused. 孩子们异口同声地说：“那不公平！”

chose
past tense ofCHOOSE

chosen
past participle ofCHOOSE

Christ
/kraɪst ||; kraɪst/ (also JesusJesus Christ /ˌdʒi:zəs ˈkraɪst ||; ˌdʒizəs ˈkraɪst/) noun the man who Christians believe is the son of God and whose teachings the Christian religion is based on 基督；耶稣基督

christen
/ˈkrɪsn ||; ˈkrɪsṇ/verb[T]
1 to give a person, usually a baby, a name during a Christian ceremony in which he/she is made a member of the Church （在洗礼中）给…取教名: The baby was christened Simon Mark. 这个婴孩取了教名，叫西门˙马克。 ☞Look at baptize. 参看baptize。
2 to give sb/sth a name 给…取名: People drive so dangerously on this stretch of road that they've christened it ‘The Mad Mile’. 人们在这段路上开车，惊险万状，因此他们称这段路为「亡命大道」。

christening
/ˈkrɪsnɪŋ ||; ˈkrɪsṇɪŋ/noun [C] the church ceremony in the Christian religion in which a baby is given a name 洗礼 ☞Look at baptism. 参看baptism。

Christian
/ˈkrɪstʃən ||; ˈkrɪstʃən/noun [C] a person whose religion is Christianity 基督徒 Christian adj

Christianity
/ˌkrɪstiˈænəti ||; ˌkrɪstʃɪˈænətɪ/noun [U] the religion that is based on the teachings of Jesus Christ 基督教

ˈChristian name
(especially US 尤为美 given name) noun [C] the name given to a child when he/she is born; first name 教名 ☞Look at the note at name ¹. 参看 name^1 的注释。

Christmas
/ˈkrɪsməs ||; ˈkrɪsməs/noun
1 [C,U] the period of time before and after 25 December 圣诞节节期: Where are you spending Christmas this year? 今年圣诞节你会在哪里过？
2 Christmas Day [C] a public holiday on 25 December. It is the day on which Christians celebrate the birth of Christ each year. 圣诞节（即12月25日） ☞Christmas is sometimes written as Xmas in informal English. 在英语里，Christmas在非正式场合有时写作Xmas。

ˈChristmas card
noun [C] a card with a picture on the front and a message inside that people send to their friends and relatives at Christmas 圣诞卡

ˌChristmas ˈcarol
=CAROL

ˌChristmas ˈcracker
=CRACKER(2)

ˌChristmas ˈdinner
noun [C] the traditional meal eaten on Christmas Day 圣诞晚宴: We had a traditional Christmas dinner that year, with roast turkey, Christmas pudding and all the trimmings. 那年我们吃了一顿传统的圣诞晚宴，有烤火鸡、圣诞布丁和各色配菜。

ˌChristmas ˈEve
noun [C] 24 December, the day before Christmas Day 圣诞节前夕，圣诞夜，平安夜（即12月24日）

ˌChristmas ˈpudding
noun [C,U] a sweet dish made from dried fruit and eaten hot with sauce at Christmas dinner 圣诞布丁（圣诞晚餐上的甜点）

ˈChristmas tree
noun [C] a real or artificial tree, which people bring into their homes and cover with coloured lights and decorations at Christmas 圣诞树

chromatic
/krəˈmætɪk ||; kroˈmætɪk/adj (technical术语) used to describe a series of musical notes that rise and fall in SEMITONES(= notes that are next to each other on a piano) 半音的；变音的: the chromatic scale 半音音阶

chromatography
/ˌkrɒməˈtɒgrəfi ||; ˌkroməˈtɑgrəfɪ/noun [U] (technical术语) the separation of a liquid mixture by passing it through a material through which some parts of the mixture travel further than others 色谱法

chrome
/krəʊm ||; krom/ (also chromium /ˈkrəʊmiəm ||; ˈkromɪəm/) noun [U] (symbol Cr) a hard shiny metal that is used for covering other metals 铬

chromosome
/ˈkrəʊməsəʊm ||; ˈkroməˌsom/noun [C] a part of a cell in living things that decides the sex, character, shape, etc that a person, an animal or a plant will have 染色体 ☞Look at X chromosome and Y chromosome. 参看X chromosome及Y chromosome。

chronic
/ˈkrɒnɪk ||; ˈkrɑnɪk/adj (used about a disease or a problem) that continues for a long time （指疾病或问题）慢性的，迁延的，长期的: There is a chronic shortage of housing in the city. 该市的住房长期短缺。 ☞Compare acute. 与acute比较。 ➔chronically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

chronicle
/ˈkrɒnɪkl ||; ˈkrɑnɪkḷ/noun [C] (often plural 常用复数) a written record of historical events describing them in the order in which they happened 编年史；纪事；大事纪

chronological
/ˌkrɒnəˈlɒdʒɪkl ||; ˌkrɑnəˈlɑdʒɪkḷ/adj arranged in the order in which the events happened 按时间先后顺序排列的: This book describes the main events in his life in chronological order. 该书按年月顺序叙述他一生的遭遇。 ➔chronologically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

chronology
/krəˈnɒlədʒi ||; krəˈnɑlədʒɪ/noun [U] [C] (plural chronologies) the order in which a series of events happened; a list of these events in order （事件）按发生先后排列；年表: The exact chronology of these events is a subject for debate. 这些事件发生的确切次序是个可以争论的问题。 a chronology of Kennedy's life 肯尼迪生平的年表

chrysalis
/ˈkrɪsəlɪs ||; ˈkrɪsḷɪs/ (plural chrysalises) noun [C] the form of an insect,(a butterfly)or(a moth), while it is changing into an adult inside a hard case, also called a chrysalis （蝴蝶、蛾等昆虫的）蛹 ☞picture at insect 见insect插图 A similar form of other insects is called a pupa. 其他昆虫一种类似的形体叫做蛹(pupa)。
chrysanthemum
/krɪˈsænθəməm ||; krɪsˈænθəməm/noun [C] a large garden flower which is brightly coloured and shaped like a ball 菊；菊花 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图

chubby
/ˈtʃʌbi ||; ˈtʃʌbɪ/adj slightly fat in a pleasant way （逗人欢喜地）胖乎乎的: a baby with chubby cheeks 脸蛋胖乎乎的婴儿

chuck
/tʃʌk ||; tʃʌk/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to throw sth in a careless way 随意抛扔: You can chuck those old shoes in the bin. 你可以把那些旧鞋扔到垃圾箱去。 chuck sth in to give sth up 放弃: He's chucked his job in because he was fed up. 他受够了就索性辞职不干。 chuck sb out (of sth) to force sb to leave a place 撵走；赶走: They were chucked out of the cinema for making too much noise. 他们在电影院吵闹得太厉害，结果给人家撵了出来。

chuckle
/ˈtʃʌkl ||; ˈtʃʌkḷ/verb [I] to laugh quietly 低声轻笑；暗自笑: Bruce chuckled to himself as he read the letter. 布鲁斯看着信，不禁暗自发笑。 chuckle noun [C]

chug
/tʃʌg ||; tʃʌg/verb [I] (chugging;chugged)
1 (used about a machine or engine) to make short repeated sounds while it is working or moving slowly （指机器或引擎）轧轧作响
2 chug along, down, up, etc to move in a particular direction making this sound （朝某方向）轧轧地移动: The train chugged out of the station. 火车轧轧地开出了车站。

chunk
/tʃʌŋk ||; tʃʌŋk/noun [C] a large or thick piece of sth 一大块；一厚块: chunks of bread and cheese 几大块抹了干酪的面包

chunky
/ˈtʃʌŋki ||; ˈtʃʌŋkɪ/adj
1 thick and heavy 厚实的: chunky jewellery 沉甸甸的珠宝首饰
2 (used about a person) short and strong （指人）矮而壮实的: He was a short man with chunky legs. 他是个两腿粗壮的矮子。
3 (used about food) containing thick pieces （指食物）成厚片的: chunky banana milkshake 含有香蕉块的奶昔

*church
/tʃɜ:tʃ ||; tʃɝtʃ/noun
1 [C,U] a building where Christians go to pray, etc 教堂: Do you go to church regularly? 你经常上教堂吗？
When you are talking about going to a church ceremony or service you say ‘in church’, ‘to church’ or ‘at church’ without ‘ a ’ or ‘ the ’ Was Mrs Stevens at church today? 参与在教堂举行的礼式（礼拜叫做service），英语说in church、to church或at church；church前面没有a或the：Was Mrs Stevens at church today?斯蒂文斯太太今天去了教堂没有？
2 Church [C] a particular group of Christians （基督教的）教会，教派: the Anglican/Catholic/Methodist Church 圣公会；天主教会；循道公会
3 (the) Church [sing] the ministers or the institution of the Christian religion 基督教的牧师或机构: the conflict between Church and State 政教冲突

churchgoer
/ˈtʃɜ:tʃgəʊə(r) ||; ˈtʃɝtʃˌgoɚ/noun [C] a person who goes to church regularly 按时去教堂做礼拜的人

churchyard
/ˈtʃɜ:tʃjɑ:d ||; ˈtʃɝtʃˌjɑrd/noun [C] the area of land that is around a church 教堂庭院 ☞Look at cemetery and graveyard. 参看cemetery及graveyard。

churn
/tʃɜ:n ||; tʃɝn/verb
1 [I,T] churn (sth) (up) to move, or to make water, mud, etc move around violently （使）翻腾，翻搅: The dark water churned beneath the huge ship. 黑漆漆的水在大船底下翻腾。 Vast crowds had churned the field into a sea of mud. 一大群一大群的人把田野搅成一汪泥泞。
2 [I] if your stomach churns or sth makes it churn, you feel sick because you are disgusted or nervous （使）反胃（反感或紧张引起的）: Reading about the murder in the paper made my stomach churn. 看了报上的谋杀新闻令我反胃。
3 [T] to make butter from milk or cream （用牛奶或奶油）制黄油
churn sth out(informal 非正式) to produce large numbers of sth very quickly （快速大量地）生产，制造: Modern factories can churn out cars at an amazing speed. 现代化的工厂能够以惊人的速度大量生产汽车。

chute
/ʃu:t ||; ʃut/noun [C] a passage down which you can drop or slide things, so that you do not have to carry them 滑道；斜道；滑槽: a laundry/rubbish chute (from the upper floors of a high building) 送洗衣物╱垃圾的滑道（从大楼的上层） a water chute(at a swimming pool) （游泳池的）滑水道

chutney
/ˈtʃʌtni ||; ˈtʃʌtnɪ/noun [U] a thick sweet sauce that is made from fruit or vegetables. You eat chutney cold with cheese or meat. 酸辣酱

CIA
/ˌsi: aɪ ˈeɪ ||; ˌsi aɪ ˈe/abbr the Central Intelligence Agency; the US government organization that tries to discover secret information about other countries （美国）中央情报局

ciabatta
/tʃəˈbætə ||; tʃəˈbætə/noun [U] [C] a type of Italian bread; a whole piece (loaf)of this 意大利乡村面包

cicada
/sɪˈkɑ:də ||; sɪˈkɑdə/noun [C] a large insect that lives in many hot countries. It makes a continuous high sound by rubbing its legs together. 蝉；知了

cider
/ˈsaɪdə(r) ||; ˈsaɪdɚ/noun [U]:
1 (Brit 英) an alcoholic drink made from apples 苹果酒: dry/sweet cider 无甜味的╱甜苹果酒
2 (US 美) a drink made from apples that does not contain alcohol 苹果汁

cigar
/sɪˈgɑ:(r) ||; sɪˈgɑr/noun [C] a roll of dried tobacco leaves that people smoke. Cigars are larger than cigarettes 雪茄

*cigarette
/ˌsɪgəˈret; US ˈsɪgəret ||; ˈsɪgəˌrɛt/noun [C] tobacco in a tube of thin white paper that people smoke 香烟: a packet of cigarettes 一包香烟

cigaˈrette lighter
(also lighter) noun [C] an object which produces a small flame for lighting cigarettes, etc 打火机

ciliary muscle
/ˈsɪlɪəri mʌsl ||; ˈsɪlɪˌɛrɪ ˈmʌsḷ/noun [C] a muscle in the eye that controls how much theLENS(= the transparent part of the front of the eye that controls the direction of light that passes through it)curves 睫状肌 ☞picture at eye 见 eye 插图

cinder
/ˈsɪndə(r) ||; ˈsɪndɚ/noun [C] a very small piece of burning coal, wood, etc 炭渣；煤渣；炉渣

*cinema
/ˈsɪnəmə ||; ˈsɪnəmə/noun
1 [C] (Brit 英) a place where you go to see a film 电影院: What's on at the cinema this week? 这个星期电影院上映什么电影？
In American English, you use movie theater to talk about the building where films are shown but the movies when you are talking about going to see a film there There are five movie theaters in this town. Let's go to the movies this evening. 美国英语称电影院为movie theater：There are five movie theaters in this town.这个镇有五家电影院。去看电影则用the movies：Let's go to the movies this evening.今晚我们去看电影吧。
2 [U] films in general; the film industry 电影（总称）；电影业: one of the great successes of British cinema 英国电影业的辉煌成就之一

cinnamon
/ˈsɪnəmən ||; ˈsɪnəmən/noun [U] a sweet brown powder that is used for giving flavour to food （调味用的）桂皮，肉桂

circa
/ˈsɜ:kə ||; ˈsɝkə/prep (abbr c) (written 书面语) (used with dates) about; approximately （与日期连用）大约: The vase was made circa 600 AD. 这个花瓶约于公元600年制成。

*circle¹
/ˈsɜ:kl ||; ˈsɝkḷ/noun
1 [C] a round shape like a ring 圆圈: The children were drawing circles and squares on a piece of paper. 孩子们在一张纸上画圆圈画方框。 We all stood in a circle and held hands. 我们大家手拉着手围成一个圈站着。
2 [C] a flat, round area 环状物: She cut out a circle of paper. 她剪下一块圆纸片。 ☞picture at shape 见shape插图
3 [C] a group of people who are friends, or who have the same interest or profession 圈子；阶层；界: He has a large circle of friends. 他交游甚广。 Her name was well known in artistic circles. 她在艺术界颇有名气。
4 the (dress) circle(US 美 balcony) [sing] an area of seats that is upstairs in a cinema, theatre, etc （电影院、剧场等的）楼上包厢
a vicious circle→VICIOUS
*circle²
/ˈsɜ:kl ||; ˈsɝkḷ/verb
1 [I,T] to move, or to move round sth, in a circle 环绕；盘旋: The plane circled the town several times before it landed. 飞机在该镇上空盘旋了几圈才降落。
2 [T] to draw a circle round sth 圈起来: There are three possible answers to each question. Please circle the correct one. 每道题的答案都有三个选择，请把正确的答案圈出来。

circuit
/ˈsɜ:kɪt ||; ˈsɝkɪt/noun
1 [C] a circular journey or track round sth 环行；绕一圈: The cars have to complete ten circuits of the track. 参赛汽车必须跑完十圈才行。
2 [C] a complete circular path that an electric current can flow around 电路 ☞picture at switch 见switch插图
3 [sing] a series of sports competitions, meetings or other organized events that are regularly visited by the same people 巡回（体育比赛、会议或其他有组织的活动）: She's one of the best players on the tennis circuit. 她是网球巡回赛的最佳选手之一。

ˈcircuit board
noun [C] (technical术语) a board inside a piece of electrical equipment that holds circular paths(circuits)around which electric currents can flow 电路板

ˈcircuit-breaker
noun [C] (technical术语) a safety device that automatically stops the flow of electricity if there is danger 断路器；断路开关

*circular¹
/ˈsɜ:kjələ(r) ||; ˈsɝkjəlɚ/adj
1 round and flat; shaped like a circle 圆形的: a circular table 圆桌
2 (used about a journey, etc) moving round in a circle （指旅程等）环行的: a circular tour of Oxford 环游牛津
circular²
/ˈsɜ:kjələ(r) ||; ˈsɝkjəlɚ/noun [C] a printed letter, notice or advertisement that is sent to a large number of people 通告；通传；传单

circulate
/ˈsɜ:kjəleɪt ||; ˈsɝkjəˌlet/verb[I,T]
1 to go or be passed from one person to another （使）流传，传播，传发: Rumours were circulating about the Minister's private life. 有关部长私生活的流言蜚语四处流传。 We've circulated a copy of the report to each department. 我们已将这份报告传发给每个部门。
2 (used about a substance) to move or make sth move round continuously （指物质）（使）环行，循环: Blood circulates round the body. 血液在体内循环。

circulation
/ˌsɜ:kjəˈleɪʃn ||; ˌsɝkjəˈleʃən/noun
1 [U] the movement of blood around the body 血液循环: If you have bad circulation, your hands and feet get cold easily. 血液循环不良，手脚容易发冷。
2 [U] the passing of sth from one person or place to another 流传: the circulation of news/information/rumours 消息╱信息╱谣言的传播 Old five pence coins are no longer in circulation (= being used by people). 旧的五便士硬币不再流通。
3 [C] the number of copies of a newspaper, magazine, etc that are sold each time it is produced （报纸、杂志等的）发行量: This newspaper has a circulation of over a million. 这份报纸的发行量超过100万份。

circulatory
/ˌsɜ:kjəˈleɪtəri ||; ˈsɝkjələˌtɔrɪ/adj connected with the movement of blood around the body 与血液循环有关的

circum-
/ˈsɜ:kəm ||; ˈsɝkəm/prefix (in adjectives, nouns and verbs 用于构成形容词、名词及动词) around 环绕；在…周围: to circumnavigate(= to sail around) 环绕…航行╱飞行

circumcise
/ˈsɜ:kəmsaɪz ||; ˈsɝkəmˌsaɪz/verb [T] to cut off the skin at the end of a man's sexual organ (penis) or to remove part of a woman's sexual organs(clitoris), for religious or sometimes (in the case of a man) medical reasons 割包皮或阴蒂 ➔circumcision /ˌsɜ:kəmˈsɪʒn ||; ˌsɝkəmˈsɪʒən/ noun [C,U]

circumference
/səˈkʌmfərəns ||; sɚˈkʌmfərəns/noun [C,U] the distance round a circle or sth circular 周长；圆周: The Earth is about 40000 kilometres in circumference. 地球的周长约为40000公里。 ☞Look at diameter and radius. 参看diameter及radius。 ☞picture at circle 见circle插图

circumspect
/ˈsɜ:kəmspekt ||; ˈsɝkəmˌspɛkt/adj (formal 正式) thinking very carefully about sth before you do it because you think it may involve problems or dangers 考虑周到的；谨慎的

*circumstance
/ˈsɜ:kəmstəns ||; ˈsɝkəmˌstæns/noun
1 [C] [usu.pl] the facts and events that affect what happens in a particular situation 情况；情形；态势: Police said there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding the boy's death. 警方说，男孩之死没有可疑之处。 In normal circumstances I would not have accepted the job, but at that time I had very little money. 在正常情况下，我是不会接受这份差事，可当时我手头很紧。
2 circumstances [pl] (formal 正式) the amount of money that you have 经济状况: The company has promised to repay the money when its financial circumstances improve. 公司已承诺在财政状况改善时偿还这笔钱。
in/under no circumstances never; not for any reason 在任何情况下都不可；无论如何都不可: Under no circumstances should you enter my office. 你在任何情况下都不该进我的办公室。 in/under the circumstances as the result of a particular situation 在这种情况下: My father was ill at that time, so under the circumstances I decided not to go on holiday. 那时候我爸爸生病，在这种情况下，我决定不去度假。 It's not an ideal solution, but it's the best we can do in the circumstances. 这不是理想的解决办法，但我们目前最多就只能这样了。

circumstantial
/ˌsɜ:kəmˈstænʃl ||; ˌsɝkəmˈstænʃəl/adj (used in connection with the law) containing details and information that strongly suggest sth is true but are not actual proof of it （用于法律）与环境有关的，依环境而定的（但缺乏真凭实据的）: circumstantial evidence 间接证据

circumvent
/ˌsɜ:kəmˈvent ||; ˌsɝkəmˈvɛnt/verb[T]
1 to find a clever way of avoiding a difficulty or rule 以计谋规避（困难或规则）
2 to go round sth that is in your way 绕过（障碍）

circus
/ˈsɜ:kəs ||; ˈsɝkəs/noun [C] a show performed in a large tent by a company of people and animals 马戏

cirque
/sɜ:k ||; sɝk/ =CORRIE ☞picture at glacial 见glacial插图

cirrhosis
/səˈrəʊsɪs ||; sɪˈrosɪs/noun [U] a serious disease of theLIVER(= the organ in the body that cleans the blood), caused especially by drinking too much alcohol 肝硬化；肝硬变

cirrostratus
/ˌsɪrəʊˈstrɑ:təs; US -ˈstreɪtəs ||; ˌsɪroˈstretəs/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of cloud that forms a thin layer at a very high level 卷层云 ☞picture at cloud 见cloud插图

cirrus
/ˈsɪrəs ||; ˈsɪrəs/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of light cloud that forms high in the sky 卷云 ☞picture at cloud 见cloud插图

CIS
/ˌsi: aɪ ˈes ||; ˌsi aɪ ˈɛs/abbr the Commonwealth of Independent States 独立国家联合体（独联体）；独立国协 ☞Look at USSR. 参看USSR。

cistern
/ˈsɪstən ||; ˈsɪstɚn/noun [C] a container for storing water, especially one that is connected to a toilet 水箱，水槽（尤指抽水马桶的）

citadel
/ˈsɪtədəl ||; ˈsɪtədḷ/noun [C] (in past times) a castle on high ground in or near a city where people could go when the city was being attacked （旧时）城堡，要塞 (figurative 比喻) citadels of private economic power 私有经济力量的堡垒

cite
/saɪt ||; saɪt/verb [T] (formal 正式) to mention sth or use sb's exact words as an example to support, or as proof of, what you are saying 引证: She cited a passage from the President's speech. 她从总统的讲话中引了一段话。 ➔citation /saɪˈteɪʃn ||; saɪˈteʃən/ noun [C,U]

*citizen
/ˈsɪtɪzn ||; ˈsɪtəzṇ/noun[C]
1 a person who is legally accepted as a member of a particular country 公民: She was born in Japan, but became an American citizen in 1981. 她在日本出生，1981年入籍美国。
2 a person who lives in a town or city 市民；居民: the citizens of Paris 巴黎市民 ☞Look at senior citizen. 参看senior citizen。

citizenship
/ˈsɪtɪzənʃɪp ||; ˈsɪtəzṇˌʃɪp/noun [U] the state of being a citizen of a particular country 公民身分: After living in Spain for twenty years, he decided to apply for Spanish citizenship. 在西班牙住了二十年后，他决定申请西班牙国籍。

citric acid
/ˌsɪtrɪk ˈæsɪd ||; ˌsɪtrɪk ˈæsɪd/noun [U] a weak acid that is found in the juice of oranges, lemons and other similar fruits 柠檬酸

citrus
/ˈsɪtrəs ||; ˈsɪtrəs/adj used to describe fruit such as oranges and lemons 柑橘类水果的（比如橘子、柠檬）

*city
/ˈsɪti ||; ˈsɪtɪ/noun (plural cities)
1 [C] a large and important town 城市: Venice is one of the most beautiful cities in the world. 威尼斯为全球最美丽的城市之一。 Many people are worried about housing conditions in Britain's inner cities (= the central parts where there are often social problems). 英国城市市内旧城区的居住环境引起广泛忧虑。 the city centre 市中心
2 the City [sing] the oldest part of London, which is now Britain's financial centre 伦敦金融区（伦敦的最古老部份，现为英国的金融中心）

ˌcity ˈslicker
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who behaves in a way that is typical of people who live in big cities 油头滑脑的城里人；城里老油子

civic
/ˈsɪvɪk ||; ˈsɪvɪk/adj officially connected with a city or town 城市的: civic pride (= feeling proud because you belong to a particular town or city) 市民的自豪感 civic duties 公民义务 the civic centre (= the area where the public buildings are in a town) 市政中心（包括政府办公大楼）

civil
/ˈsɪvl ||; ˈsɪvḷ/adj
1 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) connected with the people who live in a country 跟一国的居民有关的: civil disorder(= involving groups of people within the same country) 内乱
2 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) connected with the state, not with the army or the Church 跟国家（相对于军队或教会）有关的；民政的: a civil wedding(= not a religious one) 公证婚礼（非教会主持的婚礼）
3 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) (in law) connected with the personal legal matters of ordinary people, and not criminal law （法律）民事的: civil courts 民事法庭
4 polite, but not very friendly 有礼貌，彬彬有礼（但不很友好） civility /səˈvɪləti ||; səˈvɪlətɪ/ noun [U]: Staff members are trained to treat customers with civility at all times. 员工受过训练，对顾客始终很有礼貌。 ➔civilly /ˈsɪvəli ||; ˈsɪvḷɪ/ adv

ˌcivil engiˈneering
noun [U] the design, building and repair of roads, bridges, etc; the study of this as a subject 土木工程（学）

*civilian
/səˈvɪliən ||; səˈvɪljən/noun [C] a person who is not in the army, navy, air force or police force 平民；百姓: Two soldiers and one civilian were killed when the bomb exploded. 炸弹爆炸造成两名士兵和一名平民丧生。

*civilization
/ˌsɪvəlaɪˈzeɪʃn; US -əlɪˈz- ||; ˌsɪvḷəˈzeʃən/ (also -isation) noun
1 [C,U] a society which has its own highly developed culture and way of life 文明社会；文明世界: the civilizations of ancient Greece and Rome 古希腊、古罗马的文明社会 Western civilization 西方文明社会
2 [U] an advanced state of social and cultural development, or the process of reaching this state 文明: the civilization of the human race 人类文明
3 [U] all the people in the world and the societies they live in considered as a whole 全世界的人和社会: Global warming poses a threat to the whole of civilization. 地球暖化对整个世界造成威胁。

civilize
/ˈsɪvəlaɪz ||; ˈsɪvḷˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to make people or a society develop from a low social and cultural level to a more advanced one 开化；文明化

*civilized
/ˈsɪvəlaɪzd ||; ˈsɪvḷˌaɪzd/ (also -ised) adj
1 (used about a society) well organized; having a high level of social and cultural development （指社会）文明的，开化的
2 polite and reasonable 有礼貌兼讲理的: a civilized conversation 有礼得体的对话

ˌcivil ˈrights
(also ˌcivil ˈliberties) noun [pl] a person's legal right to freedom and equal treatment in society, whatever his/her sex, race or religion 公民权；民权: the civil rights leader Martin Luther King 民权领袖马丁˙路德˙金

ˌcivil ˈservant
noun [C] (especially Brit 尤为英) a person who works for the government's or State's own organization(the civil service) （文职）公务员；文官

ˌcivil ˈwar
noun [C,U] a war between groups of people who live in the same country 内战

CJD
/ˌsi: dʒeɪ ˈdi: ||; ˌsi dʒe ˈdi/abbr Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease; a disease of the brain caused by eating infected meat 克罗伊茨费尔德–雅各布布病，克雅二氏病（一种病毒性脑病） ☞Look at BSE. 参看BSE。

cl
abbr centilitre(s) 厘升，公勺（=1/100升）

clad
/klæd ||; klæd/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) (old-fashioned 旧) dressed (in); wearing a particular type of clothing 穿着或穿得…: The children were warmly clad in coats, hats and scarves. 孩子们穿了外套，戴了帽子，围了围巾，一身暖和的打扮。

*claim¹
/kleɪm ||; klem/verb
1 [T] claim (that);claim (to be sth) to say that sth is true, without having any proof 声称: Colin claims the book belongs to him. 科林声称这本书是他的。 The woman claims to be the oldest person in Britain. 这个女人自称是英国最长寿的人。
2 [I,T] claim (for sth) to ask for sth from the government, a company, etc because you think it is your legal right to have it, or it belongs to you （向政府、公司等）索求，认领: The police are keeping the animal until somebody claims it. 这头动物暂由警方看管，直至有人认领为止。 Don't forget to claim for your travel expenses when you get back. 回来的时候别忘了申报旅费。 (figurative 比喻) No one has claimed responsibility for the bomb attack. 还没有人声称对这起炸弹袭击事件负责。
3 [T] to cause death 引致死亡: The earthquake claimed thousands of lives. 这场地震夺去了成千上万条生命。
*claim²
/kleɪm ||; klem/noun[C]
1 a claim (that) a statement that sth is true, which does not have any proof 声言: I do not believe the Government's claim that they can reduce unemployment by the end of the year. 我不相信政府声称到年底可以把失业人数减少的说法。
2 a claim (to sth) the right to have sth 拥有权；所有权: You will have to prove your claim to the property in a court of law. 你要在法庭上拿出证明支持你的业权。
3 a claim (for sth) a demand for money that you think you have a right to, especially from the government, a company, etc 要求，索取（尤指从政府、公司等）: to make an insurance claim 申领保险赔偿 After the accident he decided to put in a claim for compensation. 意外发生后他决定索取赔偿。
stake a/your claim→STAKE²

claimant
/ˈkleɪmənt ||; ˈklemənt/noun [C] a person who believes he/she has the right to have sth 要求者；认为有权索取的人: The insurance company refused to pay the claimant any money. 保险公司拒绝付钱给那个要求赔偿的人。

clairvoyant
/kleəˈvɔɪənt ||; klɛrˈvɔɪənt/noun [C] a person who some people believe has special mental powers and can see what will happen in the future 有超人智慧的人；有洞察力的人

clam¹
/klæm ||; klæm/noun [C] a type of shellfish that can be eaten 蛤；蛤蜊；蚌 ☞picture at shellfish 见shellfish插图
clam²
/klæm ||; klæm/verb (clamming;clammed) clam up (on sb)(informal 非正式) to stop talking and refuse to speak especially when sb asks you about sth 缄口不言；保持沉默

clamber
/ˈklæmbə(r) ||; ˈklæmbɚ/verb [I] clamber up, down, out etc to move or climb with difficulty, usually using both your hands and feet 吃力地爬或攀登: She managed to clamber up the over the wall. 她设法爬过墙去。

clammy
/ˈklæmi ||; ˈklæmɪ/adj cold, slightly wet and sticky in an unpleasant way 潮ni4的；黏湿的: clammy hands 潮ni4的双手

clamour
/ˈklæmə(r) ||; ˈklæmɚ/ (US 美 clamor) verb [I] clamour for sth to demand sth in a loud or angry way 高声地或愤怒地提出要求: The public are clamouring for an answer to all these questions. 公众在大声疾呼，要求有关方面就所有问题作出答复。 clamour(US 美 clamor) noun [sing] the clamour of angry voices 愤怒的呼喊

clamp¹
/klæmp ||; klæmp/noun[C]
1 a tool that you use for holding two things together very tightly 钳；夹具；夹钳 ☞pictures at laboratory, plug and vice 见laboratory、plug及vice插图
2 (also wheel clamp) (Brit 英) a metal object that is fixed to the wheel of a car that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot drive away 扣锁（用以扣住违章停放的车辆）
clamp²
/klæmp ||; klæmp/verb[T]
1 clamp A and B (together);clamp A to B to fasten two things together with a clamp 钳住: The metal rods were clamped together. 这几根铁棒给钳在一起。 Clamp the wood to the table so that it doesn't move. 把这根木头钳住桌子使它不动。
2 to hold sth very firmly in a particular position 夹紧: Her lips were clamped tightly together. 她紧闭双唇。
3 to fix a metal object to the wheel of a vehicle that has been parked illegally, so that it cannot move 扣锁（违章停放的车辆）: Oh no! My car's been clamped. 啊，糟了！我的车子给扣了。
clamp down on sb/sth(informal 非正式) to take strong action in order to stop or control sth 取缔；镇压；打击: The police are clamping down on people who drink and drive. 警方致力取缔酒后驾车。

clampdown
/ˈklæmpdaʊn ||; ˈklæmpˌdaυn/noun [C] strong action to stop or control sth 取缔；打击；严格限制: a clampdown on tax evasion 打击逃税

clan
/klæn ||; klæn/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of families who are related to each other, especially in Scotland （尤指苏格兰的）宗族，家族

clandestine
/klænˈdestɪn ||; klænˈdɛstɪn/adj (formal 正式) secret and often not legal 秘密的；地下的: a clandestine meeting 秘密集会

clang
/klæŋ ||; klæŋ/verb [I,T] to make or cause sth metal to make a loud ringing sound （使）当当作响: The iron gates clanged shut. 铁门砰的一声关上了。 clang noun [C]

clank
/klæŋk ||; klæŋk/verb [I,T] to make or cause sth metal to make a loud unpleasant sound （使）当当作响: The lift clanked its way up to the seventh floor. 电梯当当地开到七楼。 clank noun [C]

*clap¹
/klæp ||; klæp/verb (clapping;clapped)
1 [I,T] to hit your hands together many times, usually to show that you like sth 鼓掌；拍手: The audience clapped as soon as the singer walked onto the stage. 歌手一登上舞台，听众随即鼓掌欢迎。
2 [T] to put sth onto sth quickly and firmly 用力捂住: ‘Oh no, I shouldn't have said that,’ she said, clapping a hand over her mouth. “喔，糟了，我不该这么说。”她一边说一边用手捂住嘴巴。
clap²
/klæp ||; klæp/noun[C]
1 a sudden loud noise 突然发出的巨响: a clap of thunder 一声霹雳
2 an act of clapping 鼓掌；拍手

claret
/ˈklærət ||; ˈklærət/noun
1 [U] [C] a dry red wine, especially from the Bordeaux area of France. There are several types of claret. 干红葡萄酒（尤指法国波尔多地区产的）
2 [U] a dark red colour 暗紫红色 claret adj

clarification
/ˌklærəfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌklærəfəˈkeʃən/noun [U] an act of making sth clear and easier to understand 澄清；阐明: We'd like some clarification of exactly what your company intends to do. 贵公司究竟打算做些什么，我们希望您作一些说明。 ☞Look at clarity. 参看clarity。

clarify
/ˈklærəfaɪ ||; ˈklærəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle clarifying third person singular present clarifies;past tense past participle clarified) to make sth become clear and easier to understand 澄清；阐明: I hope that what I say will clarify the situation. 我希望我说的话可以把情况澄清一下。 ☞adjective clear 形容词为clear

clarinet
/ˌklærəˈnet ||; ˌklærəˈnɛt/noun [C] a musical instrument that is made of wood. You play a clarinet by blowing through it. 单簧管；竖笛 ☞Look at the note at piano. 参看piano的注释。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

clarity
/ˈklærəti ||; ˈklærətɪ/noun [U] the quality of being clear and easy to understand 清晰: clarity of expression 表达的清晰度 ☞Look at clarification. 参看clarification。

clash¹
/klæʃ ||; klæʃ/verb
1 [I] clash (with sb) (over sth) to fight or disagree seriously about sth 角斗；激辩；冲突: A group of demonstrators clashed with police outside the Town Hall. 市政厅门外一群示威者跟警方发生冲突。
2 [I] clash (with sth) (used about two events) to happen at the same time （指两件事）（日程、时间等）撞期，有冲突: It's a pity the two concerts clash. I wanted to go to both of them. 真可惜，两场音乐会时间撞期，我原来想两场都去呢。
3 [I] clash (with sth) (used about colours, etc) to not match or look nice together （指颜色等）不调和: I don't think you should wear that tie -- it clashes with your shirt. 别结这条领带，它跟你的衬衫色彩不协调。
4 [I,T] (used about two metal objects) to hit together with a loud noise; to cause two metal objects to do this （指两件金属物体）（使）砰然相撞: Their swords clashed. 他们的剑斗得铿锵作响。
clash²
/klæʃ ||; klæʃ/noun[C]
1 a fight or serious disagreement 激辩；搏斗；冲突: a clash between police and demonstrators 警方与示威者的冲突
2 a big difference 重大分歧: a clash of opinions 意见分歧 There was a personality clash between the two men (= they did not get well on together or like each other). 这两个男人个性截然不同（他们不能和睦相处或喜欢对方）。
3 a loud noise, made by two metal objects hitting each other （两件金属物体撞击时发出的）碰击声

clasp¹
/klɑ:sp; US klæsp ||; klæsp/noun [C] an object, usually of metal, which fastens or holds sth together （一般用金属制造的）搭扣，搭钩: the clasp on a necklace/brooch/handbag 项链╱胸针╱手提包的搭扣
clasp²
/klɑ:sp; US klæsp ||; klæsp/verb [T] to hold sb/sth tightly 紧握；紧抱: Kevin clasped the child in his arms. 凯文把小孩紧紧地搂着。

*class¹
/klɑ:s; US klæs ||; klæs/noun
1 [C] [with.sop] a group of students who are taught together 班级: Jane and I are in the same class at school. 珍妮在学校跟我同班。 The whole class is/are going to the theatre tonight. 今晚整个班级去看戏。
2 [C,U] a lesson 上课；课: Classes begin at 9 o'clock in the morning. 早上9时开始上课。 We watched an interesting video in class(= during the lesson)yesterday. 昨天我们在课堂上看了一部挺有趣的录像片。
3 [U] [C] the way people are divided into social groups; one of these groups 阶级；阶层: The idea of class still divides British society. 当今的英国社会仍受阶级观念支配。 class differences 阶级差异
4 [C] (technical术语) a group of animals, plants, words, etc of a similar type 类别；纲: There are several different classes of insects. 昆虫有好些不同的纲。 A class is smaller than a phylum. 纲(class)小于门(phylum)。
5 [U] (informal 非正式) high quality or style 优等；上乘；优秀: Pele was a football player of great class. 比利是个一流的足球员。
6 [C] (especially in compounds 尤用于构成复合词) each of several different levels of service that are available to travellers on a plane, train, etc （飞机、火车等舱位或车厢的）等级: a first-class carriage on a train 火车上的头等车厢 He always travels business class. 他旅行总是坐商务舱。
7 [C] (Brit 英) (used to form compound adjectives 用于构成复合形容词) a mark that you are given when you pass your final university exam 等，级（大学毕业考试的成绩）: a first-/second-/third-class degree 一等╱二等╱三等学位
class²
/klɑ:s; US klæs ||; klæs/verb [T] class sb/sth (as sth) to put sb/sth in a particular group or type 归类；分类；列为: Certain animals and plants are now classed as ‘endangered species’. 有些动植物现在被列为濒危物种。

classic¹
/ˈklæsɪk ||; ˈklæsɪk/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前)
1 typical 典型的；有代表性的: It was a classic case of bad management. 这是管理不善的典型例子。
2 (used about a book, play, etc) important and having a value that will last （指书、戏剧等）经典的: the classic film ‘Gone With The Wind’ 经典电影《乱世佳人》
classic²
/ˈklæsɪk ||; ˈklæsɪk/noun
1 [C] a famous book, play, etc which has a value that will last 经典作品: All of Charles Dickens' novels are classics. 查尔斯˙狄更斯的小说都是经典之作。
2 Classics [U] the study of ancient Greek and Roman language and literature 古典语言文学研究，古典学（以古希腊、古罗马的语言文学为研究对象的学问）

classical
/ˈklæsɪkl ||; ˈklæsɪkḷ/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前)
1 (used about music) serious and having a value that lasts （指音乐）古典的: I prefer classical music to pop. 我爱听古典音乐，不爱听流行音乐。 ☞Look at jazz, pop and rock. 参看jazz、pop及rock。
2 traditional, not modern 传统的: classical ballet 古典芭蕾舞
3 connected with ancient Greece or Rome 跟古希腊或古罗马有关的: classical architecture 古典建筑 ➔classically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

classified
/ˈklæsɪfaɪd ||; ˈklæsəˌfaɪd/adj officially secret 机密的: classified information 机密情报

ˌclassified adˈvertisement
(Brit 英 (informal 非正式)ˌclassified ˈadsmall ad) noun [usu.pl] a small advertisement that you put in a newspaper if you want to buy or sell sth, employ sb, find a flat, etc 分类广告；小广告

classify
/ˈklæsɪfaɪ ||; ˈklæsəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle classifying third person singular present classifies;past tense past participle classified)classify sb/sth (as sth) to put sb/sth into a group with other people or things of a similar type 分类；归类: Would you classify it as an action film or a thriller? 你把它归在动作片一类，还是惊险片一类？ ➔classification /ˌklæsɪfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌklæsəfəˈkeʃən/ noun [C,U] the classification of the different species of butterfly 把各种蝴蝶分类

classless
/ˈklɑ:sləs ||; ˈklæsləs/adj
1 with no division into social classes 无阶级的: It is hard to imagine a truly classless society. 一个真正的无阶级社会是难以想象的。
2 not clearly belonging to any particular social class 不属于任何阶级的: a classless accent 不属于任何阶级特征的口音

classmate
/ˈklɑ:smeɪt ||; ˈklæsˌmet/noun [C] a person who is in the same class as you at school or college 同班同学

classroom
/ˈklɑ:sru:m;-rʊm ||; ˈklæsˌrum; -ˌrυm/noun [C] a room in a school, college, etc where lessons are taught 教室；课室

classy
/ˈklɑ:si; US ˈklæsɪ ||; ˈklæsɪ/adj (classier;classiest) (informal 非正式) of high quality or style; expensive and fashionable 高级的；高档的；昂贵的: a classy restaurant 高级餐馆

clatter
/ˈklætə(r) ||; ˈklætɚ/verb [I,T] to make or cause sth hard to make a series of short loud repeated sounds （使硬物）发出啪声: The horses clattered down the street. 马儿在街上嗒嗒地往前跑。 clatter noun [usu.sing]

clause
/klɔ:z ||; klɔz/noun[C]
1 one of the sections of a legal document that says that sth must or must not be done （法律文件上的）条款
2 (grammar语法) a group of words that includes a subject and a verb. A clause is usually only part of a sentence 子句，分句，从句（语法术语，由主语、动词组成的一组词语，一般作为句子的构成部份）: The sentence, ‘After we had finished eating, we watched a film on the video,’ contains two clauses. ‘After we had finished eating, we watched a film on the video’这个句子包含两个子句。

claustrophobia
/ˌklɔ:strəˈfəʊbiə ||; ˌklɔstrəˈfobɪə/noun [U] fear of being in a small or enclosed space 幽闭恐怖症；幽闭恐惧症

claustrophobic
/ˌklɔ:strəˈfəʊbɪk ||; ˌklɔstrəˈfobɪk/adj
1 extremely afraid of small, enclosed spaces 感到幽闭恐怖的: I always feel claustrophobic in lifts. 我搭电梯的时候总是对那密封的小空间感到十分恐惧。
2 used about sth that makes you feel afraid in this way 令人产生幽闭恐怖症的事物: a claustrophobic little room 令人产生幽闭恐怖症的小房间

clavicle
/ˈklævɪkl ||; ˈklævəkḷ/ (medical医学)=COLLARBONE

claw¹
/klɔ: ||; klɔ/noun[C]
1 one of the long curved nails on the end of an animal's or a bird's foot （鸟、兽的）爪 ☞pictures at shellfish and on page C1 见shellfish及C1页插图
2 one of a pair of long, sharp fingers that certain types of shellfish and some insects have. They use them for holding or picking things up （甲壳类水生动物和某些昆虫的）螯，钳: the claws of a crab 蟹钳
claw²
/klɔ: ||; klɔ/verb [I,T] claw (at) sb/sth to scratch or tear sb/sth with claws or with your fingernails （用爪、螯、钳或指甲）抓，撕: The cat was clawing at the furniture. 猫在用爪子抓家具。

clay
/kleɪ ||; kle/noun [U] heavy earth that is soft and sticky when it is wet and becomes hard when it is baked or dried 黏土: clay pots 陶壶

*clean¹
/kli:n ||; klin/adj
1 not dirty 清洁的；干净的: The whole house was beautifully clean. 整幢房子清洁美观。 Cats are very clean animals. 猫是很爱干净的动物。
2 (used about humour) not about sex, etc; not dirty （指幽默）干净的，没有色情内容的: a clean joke 没有色情成分的笑话 [OPP] for senses1 and 2 dirty 第1及2义的反义词皆为dirty
3 having no record of offences or crimes 无违法或犯罪记录的: a clean driving licence 未有违法记录的驾驶执照
a clean sweep a complete victory in a sports competition, election, etc that you get by winning all the different parts of it 大获全胜: The Russians made a clean sweep of all the gymnastics events. 俄罗斯选手在体操赛事中大获全胜。 ☞noun cleanliness 名词为cleanliness
*clean²
/kli:n ||; klin/verb
1 [T] to remove dirt, dust and marks from sth 打扫: to clean the windows 擦窗子 Don't forget to clean your teeth! 别忘了刷牙！
Clean is a general word for removing dirt from something. If you wash something you clean it with water and often soap. You can wipe a surface by rubbing it with a wet cloth; you dust a surface by rubbing it with a dry cloth. If you brush something you clean it with a brush that has a short handle; if you sweep the floor you use a brush with a long handle. 把污垢除去，一般叫clean。洗去污垢，叫wash。用湿布抹，叫wipe；用干布抹，叫dust。用刷子刷，叫brush；用扫帚扫，叫sweep。
2 [I,T] to make the inside of a house, office, etc free from dust and dirt 打扫（室内地方）: Mr Burrows comes in to clean after office hours. 博罗斯先生通常在大家下班后进来打扫。 Do the cleaning is often used instead of clean I do the cleaning once a week. 经常用do the cleaning来代替clean：I do the cleaning once a week.我每周打扫一次。
clean sth out to clean the inside of sth 将某物的内部清理干净: I'm going to clean out all the cupboards next week. 下周我要把所有厨柜全部清理干净。 clean (sth) up to remove all the dirt from a place that is particularly dirty 把特别肮脏的地方打扫清洁: I'm going to clean up the kitchen before Mum and Dad get back. 我要在爸妈回来之前把厨房打扫干净。 Oh no, you've spilt coffee on the new carpet! Can you clean it up? 哎呀，你把咖啡泼在新地毯上了！把它打扫干净，好吗？ ☞Look at dry-clean and spring-clean. 参看dry-clean及spring-clean。
clean³
/kli:n ||; klin/adv (informal 非正式) completely 完全地: I clean forgot it was your birthday. 那天是你的生日，可我全忘了。 come clean (with sb) (about sth)(informal 非正式) to tell the truth about sth that you have been keeping secret 坦白供出；说实话: She decided to come clean with Martin about her relationship with Tom. 她决定把自己跟汤姆的关系向马丁和盘托出。 go clean out of your mind to be completely forgotten 完全被遗忘

ˌclean-ˈcut
adj (used especially about a young man) having a clean, tidy appearance that is attractive and socially acceptable （尤指年轻人）整洁漂亮的: The girls all go for James' clean-cut good looks. 姑娘们都喜欢詹姆斯干净好看的样子。

cleaner
/ˈkli:nə(r) ||; ˈklinɚ/noun
1 [C] a person whose job is to clean the rooms and furniture inside a house or other building 清洁工: an office cleaner 办公室清洁工
2 [C] a substance or a special machine that you use for cleaning sth 去污剂；清洁用具: liquid floor cleaners 地板去污水 a carpet cleaner 地毯清扫器 ☞Look at vacuum cleaner. 参看vacuum cleaner。
3 the cleaner's=DRY-CLEANER'S

cleanliness
/ˈklenlinəs ||; ˈklɛnlɪnəs/noun [U] being clean or keeping things clean 清洁；保持清洁: High standards of cleanliness are important in a hotel kitchen. 酒店厨房要保持高度清洁，这一点很重要。

cleanly
/ˈkli:nli ||; ˈklinlɪ/adv easily or smoothly in one movement 容易地；流畅地: The knife cut cleanly through the rope. 一刀把绳子割断。

cleanse
/klenz ||; klɛnz/verb [T] to clean your skin or a wound 清洗皮肤或伤口 ☞Look at ethnic cleansing. 参看ethnic cleansing。

cleanser
/ˈklenzə(r) ||; ˈklɛnzɚ/noun [C] a substance that you use for cleaning your skin, especially your face （用于皮肤，尤指用于脸部的）清洁剂

ˌclean-ˈshaven
adj (used about men) having recently shaved （指男子）胡子刮得干净

ˈclean-up
noun [C] [usu.sing] the process of removing dirt or other bad things from a place （对污物等坏事物的）清除，清扫: The clean-up of the city centre means that tourists can now go there safely at night. 市中心经过整顿以后，游客夜间可以放心去那里了。

*clear¹
/klɪə(r) ||; klɪr/adj
1 easy to see, hear or understand 清晰的；清楚的: His voice wasn't very clear on the telephone. 他的声音在电话里不大清楚。 She gave me clear directions on how to get there. 那个地方怎么去，她给我说得明明白白。
2 clear (about/on sth) sure or definite; without any doubts or confusion 确凿的；明确的: I'm not quite clear about the arrangements for tomorrow. 我不大清楚明天的安排。 ☞verb clarify 动词为clarify
3 clear (to sb) obvious 明显的: There are clear advantages to the second plan. 第二个计划的好处显而易见。 It was clear to me that he was not telling the truth. 我很清楚他讲的不是真话。
4 easy to see through 透明的；清澈的: The water was so clear that we could see the bottom of the lake. 湖水清澈见底。
5 clear (of sth) free from things that are blocking the way 畅顺的: The police say that most roads are now clear of snow. 警方说大部份马路上的雪已经清除了。
6 free from marks 无痕的；明净的；晴朗的: a clear sky (= without clouds) 晴朗无云的天空 a clear skin (= without spots) 光洁的皮肤
7 free from guilt 无辜的；问心无愧的；清白的: It wasn't your fault. You can have a completely clear conscience. 那不是你的错，你可以完全问心无愧。
make yourself clear;make sth clear/plain (to sb) to speak so that there can be no doubt about what you mean 说清楚: ‘I do not want you to go to that concert,’ said my mother. ‘Do I make myself clear?’ 妈妈说﹕“那个音乐会我不让你去，听明白吗？” He made it quite clear that he was not happy with the decision. 他说得很清楚，他不满意这个决定。
*clear²
/klɪə(r) ||; klɪr/adv
1 =CLEARLY(1) We can hear the telephone loud and clear from here. 我们从这里可以听见电话又响亮又清晰。
2 clear (of sth) away from sth; not touching sth 保持距离: stand clear of the doors (= on a train) （在火车上）不要靠近车门
keep/stay/steer clear (of sb/sth) to avoid sb/sth because he/she/it may cause problems 避开: It's best to keep clear of the town centre during the rush hour. 尽量避免在繁忙时间到市中心去。
*clear³
/klɪə(r) ||; klɪr/verb
1 [T] to remove sth that is not wanted or needed 清除: to clear the roads of snow/to clear snow from the roads 清除路上的积雪 It's your turn to clear the table(= to take away the dirty plates, etc after a meal). 轮到你收拾餐具。
2 [I] (used about smoke, etc) to disappear （指烟等）散开，消失: The fog slowly cleared and the sun came out. 雾慢慢散去，太阳出来了。
3 [I] (used about the sky, the weather or water) to become free of clouds, rain, or mud ﹙指天空﹑天气或水﹚转晴﹔停雨﹔变清: After a cloudy start, the weather will clear during the afternoon. 上午多云，下午天气会转晴。
4 [T] clear sb (of sth) to provide proof that sb is innocent of sth 证明某人无罪: The man has finally been cleared of murder. 这名男子终于洗脱了谋杀罪名。
5 [T] to jump over or get past sth without touching it 顺利越过
6 [T] to give official permission for a plane, ship, etc to enter or leave a place 准许飞机、船舶等进入或离开某地；准予通过: At last the plane was cleared for take-off. 最后飞机获准起飞。
7 [T] clear sth (with sb) to get official approval for sth to be done 获准做某事: I'll have to clear it with the manager before I can refund your money. 我得获得经理批准方能退你钱。
8 [I] (used about a cheque) to go through the system that moves money from one account to another （指支票）过户，交换
clear the air to improve a difficult or uncomfortable situation by talking honestly about worries, doubts, etc （通过畅谈）缓和紧张局面 clear your throat to cough slightly in order to make it easier to speak 清嗓子 clear off(informal 非正式) used to tell sb to go away 吩咐某人滚开 clear sth out to tidy sth and throw away things that you do not want 腾空（地方） clear up (used about the weather or an illness) to get better （指天气或疾病）好转；转晴 clear (sth) up to make sth tidy 整理；收拾: Make sure you clear up properly before you leave. 离开前别忘了把东西收拾好。 clear sth up to find the solution to a problem, cause of confusion, etc 解答问题；找到纠葛的原因: There's been a slight misunderstanding but we've cleared it up now. 我们的确有过小小的误会，可现在没事了。

clearance
/ˈklɪərəns ||; ˈklɪrəns/noun [U]:
1 the removing of sth that is old or not wanted 清除: The shop is having a clearance sale (= selling things cheaply in order to get rid of them). 这家商店正在举行清仓大廉卖。
2 the distance between an object and something that is passing under or beside it, for example a ship or vehicle 净空（一物从另一物下面或旁边经过时，两者间的空隙）: There was not enough clearance for the bus to pass under the bridge safely. 这座桥下的净空不足以让那辆公共汽车安全通过。
3 official permission for sb/sth to do sth 正式批准: She was given clearance to work at the nuclear research establishment. 她被正式批准在核子研究机关工作。

ˌclear-ˈcut
adj definite and easy to see or understand 清晰可见的；明确的

ˌclear-ˈheaded
adj able to think clearly, especially if there is a problem 头脑清楚的（尤指遇到问题时）

clearing
/ˈklɪərɪŋ ||; ˈklɪrɪŋ/noun [C] a small area without trees in the middle of a wood or forest （森林中的）空地

*clearly
/ˈklɪəli ||; ˈklɪrlɪ/adv
1 in a way that is easy to see, hear or understand 清晰地: It was so foggy that we couldn't see the road clearly. 大雾弥漫，我们看不清道路。
2 in a way that is not confused 清醒地: I'm so tired that I can't think clearly. 我累得什么也想不清楚。
3 without doubt; obviously 明显地；无疑: She clearly doesn't want to speak to you any more. 她显然不想再跟你说话。

ˌclear-ˈsighted
adj able to understand situations well and to see what might happen in the future 有眼光兼有远见的

cleavage
/ˈkli:vɪdʒ ||; ˈklivɪdʒ/noun [C,U] the space between a woman's breasts 乳沟

clef
/klef ||; klɛf/noun [C] (in music) a sign (,) at the beginning of a line of written music that shows the area of sound that the notes are in （音乐）谱号（写在谱表开端以表示音符音高的符号，即或）: the bass/treble clef 低音╱高音谱号 ☞picture at music 见music插图

cleft
/kleft ||; klɛft/noun [C] a natural opening or crack, especially in rock or in a person's chin （自然形成的）裂口，裂缝（尤指岩石或人的下巴上的）

clemency
/ˈklemənsi ||; ˈklɛmənsɪ/noun [U] (formal 正式) (in law 法律) kindness shown to sb when he/she is being punished 仁慈；宽大

clementine
/ˈklemənti:n ||; ˈklɛmənˌtin/noun [C] a type of small orange 小柑橘

clench
/klentʃ ||; klɛntʃ/verb [T] to close or hold tightly 合紧；抓紧: She clenched her fists and looked as if she was going to hit him. 她紧握双拳，似乎想揍他一顿。

clergy
/ˈklɜ:dʒi ||; ˈklɝdʒɪ/noun [pl] the people who perform religious ceremonies in the Christian church 神职人员（统称）: a member of the clergy 一位神职人员

clergyman
/ˈklɜ:dʒimən ||; ˈklɝdʒɪmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ;-men ||; -mən; -mɛn/) a male member of the clergy 男性神职人员；男牧师；男教士

clergywoman
/ˈklɜ:dʒiwʊmən ||; ˈklɝdʒɪˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -wɪmɪn/) a female member of the clergy 女性神职人员；女牧师；女教士

cleric
/ˈklerɪk ||; ˈklɛrɪk/noun[C]
1 a priest in the Christian church （基督教的）神职人员，牧师 [SYN] clergyman 同义词为clergyman
2 a religious leader in any religion 宗教领袖: Muslim clerics 伊斯兰教领袖

clerical
/ˈklerɪkl ||; ˈklɛrɪkḷ/adj
1 connected with the work of a clerk in an office 与文书工作有关的: clerical work 文书工作
2 connected with the clergy 与神职人员有关的

clerk
/klɑ:k; US klɜ:rk ||; klɝk/noun[C]
1 a person whose job is to do written work or look after records or accounts in an office, bank, court of law, etc 文书；事务员
2 (also sales clerk) (US 美) =SHOP ASSISTANT

*clever
/ˈklevə(r) ||; ˈklɛvɚ/adj
1 able to learn, understand or do sth quickly and easily; intelligent 聪明的；伶俐的；灵巧的: a clever student 聪明的学生 How clever of you to mend my watch! 你手真巧，还会帮我修表！
2 (used about things, ideas, etc) showing skill or intelligence （指事物、主意等）巧妙的，灵巧的: a clever device 灵巧的装置 a clever plan 精明的计划 ➔cleverly adv ➔cleverness noun [U]

cliché
/ˈkli:ʃeɪ; US kli:ˈʃeɪ ||; kliˈʃe/noun [C] a phrase or idea that has been used so many times that it no longer has any real meaning or interest 陈腔滥调

click¹
/klɪk ||; klɪk/verb
1 [I,T] to make a short sharp sound; to cause sth to do this （使）发出咔嗒声: The door clicked shut. 门咔嗒一声关上了。 He clicked his fingers at the waiter. 他咔嗒一声朝服务员捻了捻手指。
2 [I,T] click (on sth)(computing计算机技术) to press one of the buttons on a mouse 点击（按鼠标上的按钮）: To open a file, click on the menu. 点击菜单，便可打开文件。 Position the pointer and double click the left-hand mouse button(= press it twice very quickly). 摆正光标位置，双击鼠标上的左键。
3 [I] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) (used about two people) to become friendly immediately （指人）一见如故，一拍即合: We met at a party and just clicked. 我们俩在酒会上相识，一见如故。
4 [I] (informal 非正式) (used about a problem, etc) to become suddenly clear or understood （指问题等）突然变得清晰易懂: Once I'd found the missing letter, everything clicked into place. 那封失踪的信找到以后，我就恍然大悟，什么事都明白过来了。
click²
/klɪk ||; klɪk/noun[C]
1 a short sharp sound 尖而短促的声音；咔嗒声: the click of a switch 开关的咔嗒声
2 (computing计算机技术) the act of pressing the button on a computer mouse 点击（按计算机鼠标的键）

client
/ˈklaɪənt ||; ˈklaɪənt/noun[C]
1 somebody who receives a service from a professional person, for example a lawyer （律师等专业人士的）委托人，当事人，客户
2 (computing计算机技术) one of a number of computers that is connected to a special computer(server)that stores shared information 客户机（与储存共享信息的服务器相连接的小型计算机）
Be careful. Client cannot be used for people in shops or restaurants. Those people are customers. Clientele is a general, formal word that includes both clients and customers. 注意：不能用client指商店或餐馆里的顾客。这样的顾客叫做customer。clientele用于正式场合，是client及customer的统称。
clientele
/ˌkli:ənˈtel; US ˌklaɪənˈtel ||; ˌklaɪənˈtɛl/noun [U] all the customers, guests or clients who regularly go to a particular shop, hotel, organization, etc 常客的统称 ☞This word is more formal than similar words such as customers or guests. 与customer、guest等近义词相比，clientele多用于正式场合。

*cliff
/klɪf ||; klɪf/noun [C] a high, very steep area of rock, especially one next to the sea 悬崖，峭壁（尤指海边的） ☞picture on page C8 见C8页插图

cliffhanger
/ˈklɪfhæŋə(r) ||; ˈklɪfˌhæŋɚ/noun [C] an exciting situation in a story, film, etc when you cannot guess what is going to happen next and you have to wait until the next part in order to find out （故事、电影等的）扣人心弦的情节或场面

climactic
/klaɪˈmæktɪk ||; klaɪˈmæktɪk/adj (written 书面语) (used about an event or a point in time 指事件或一点时间) very exciting, most important 激动人心的；极重要的

*climate
/ˈklaɪmət ||; ˈklaɪmɪt/noun[C]
1 the normal weather conditions of a particular region 气候: a dry/humid/tropical climate 干燥╱潮湿╱热带气候
2 the general opinions, etc that people have at a particular time （某时期的）民意，舆论: What is the current climate of opinion regarding the death penalty? 时下舆论对死刑有什么看法？ the political climate 政治气候

climatic
/klaɪˈmætɪk ||; klaɪˈmætɪk/adj connected with the climate (1) 气候的

climatology
/ˌklaɪməˈtɒlədʒi ||; ˌklaɪməˈtɑlədʒɪ/noun [U] the scientific study of climate 气候学

climax
/ˈklaɪmæks ||; ˈklaɪmæks/noun [C] the most important and exciting part of a book, play, piece of music, event, etc （书、戏剧、乐曲、事件等的）高潮: The novel reaches a dramatic climax in the final chapter. 小说在最后一章达到戏剧性的高潮。 climax verb [I]

*climb¹
/klaɪm ||; klaɪm/verb
1 [I,T] climb (up) (sth) to move up towards the top of sth 向上爬；攀登: to climb a tree/mountain/rope 爬树╱山╱绳 She climbed the stairs to bed. 她上楼睡觉。 to climb up a ladder 攀上梯子
2 [I] to move, with difficulty or effort, in the direction mentioned （向所述的方向吃力地）爬: I managed to climb out of the window. 我好不容易才爬出窗口。
3 [I] to go up mountains, etc as a sport 登山（作为运动）
Go climbing is a common way of talking about climbing for pleasure I go climbing in the Alps most summers. 登山作为消遣一般叫go climbing：I go climbing in the Alps most summers.夏天我常到阿尔卑斯山脉爬山。
4 [I] to rise to a higher position 往高处爬升: The plane climbed steadily. 飞机平稳地爬升。 The road climbed steeply up the side of the mountain. 这条路爬上了陡峭的山坡。 (figurative 比喻) The value of the dollar climbed against the pound. 美元兑英镑价格涨了。
climb/jump on the bandwagon→BANDWAGON climb down (over sth)(informal 非正式) to admit that you have made a mistake; to change your opinion about sth in an argument 认错；改口
climb²
/klaɪm ||; klaɪm/noun [C] an act of climbing or a journey made by climbing 攀爬；登山: The monastery could only be reached by a three-hour climb. 到修道院去要走三个小时的上山路。

climbdown
/ˈklaɪmdaʊn ||; ˈklaɪmˌdaυn/noun [C] an act of admitting you have been wrong; a change of opinion in an argument 认错；改口: a government climbdown 政府的让步

climber
/ˈklaɪmə(r) ||; ˈklaɪmɚ/noun [C] a person who climbs mountains as a sport 登山运动员

clinch
/klɪntʃ ||; klɪntʃ/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to finally manage to get what you want in an argument or business agreement ﹙就争论﹑商业协议﹚作出决定╱达成解决方案: to clinch a deal 达成交易

cline
/klaɪn ||; klaɪn/noun [C] a continuous series of things, in which each one is only slightly different from the things next to it, but the last is very different from the first 渐变群；倾群

cling
/klɪŋ ||; klɪŋ/verb [I] (past tense past participle clung /klʌŋ ||; klʌŋ/)
1 cling (on) to sb/sth;cling together to hold on tightly to sb/sth 紧握住；紧贴着: She clung to the rope with all her strength. 她使尽全力抓住绳子不放。 They clung together for warmth. 他们紧抱在一起取暖。
2 cling (on) to sth to continue to believe sth, often when it is not reasonable to do so 相信（常指盲目地）: They were still clinging to the hope that the girl would be found alive. 他们仍旧希望那个女孩还活着，能找到她。
3 cling to sb/sth to stick firmly to sth 黏着；附着: Her wet clothes clung to her. 她的湿衣服黏在身上。 ➔clingy adj a clingy child (= that does not want to leave its parents) 爱黏父母的孩子 a clingy sweater 贴身的毛衣

ˈcling film
noun [U] thin transparent plastic used for covering food to keep it fresh （食物的）保鲜膜，保鲜膜

clinic
/ˈklɪnɪk ||; ˈklɪnɪk/noun[C]
1 a small hospital or a part of a hospital where you go to receive special medical treatment 诊所；（医院的）门诊部: He's being treated at a private clinic. 他在一家私人诊所接受治疗。 an antenatal clinic 产前检查门诊部
2 a time when a doctor sees patients and gives special treatment or advice 诊病时间: Dr Greenall's clinic is from 2 to 4 on Mondays. 格里诺医生的诊病时间是每星期一下午2点到4点。

clinical
/ˈklɪnɪkl ||; ˈklɪnɪkḷ/adj
1 connected with the examination and treatment of patients at a clinic or hospital 临床的: Clinical trials of the new drug have proved successful. 临床试验证实，这种新药有效。
2 (used about a person) cold and not emotional （指人）冷静的

clinically
/ˈklɪnɪkli ||; ˈklɪnɪkəlɪ/adv
1 according to medical examination 依据临床观察: to be clinically dead 临床死亡
2 in a cold way; without showing any emotion 冷静地

clink
/klɪŋk ||; klɪŋk/noun [sing] the short sharp ringing sound that objects made of glass, metal, etc make when they touch each other （玻璃、金属等碰击而发出的）叮当声: the clink of glasses 玻璃杯互相碰撞的叮当声 clink verb [I,T]

clip¹
/klɪp ||; klɪp/noun[C]
1 a small object, usually made of metal or plastic, used for holding things together 夹子；回形针；回形针: a paper clip 回形针 a hairclip 发夹 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图
2 a small section of a film that is shown so that people can see what the rest of the film is like 电影片段 ☞Look at trailer. 参看trailer。
3 (informal 非正式) a quick hit with the hand 快速的一击: She gave the boy a clip round the ear. 她打了男孩一记耳光。
4 the act of cutting sth to make it shorter 削减；缩短
clip²
/klɪp ||; klɪp/verb (clipping;clipped)
1 [I,T] to be fastened with a clip; to fasten sth to sth else with a clip 用别针别住；用夹子夹住: Clip the photo to the letter, please. 请你把相片夹在信上。
2 [T] to cut sth, especially by cutting small parts off 剪；修剪: The hedge needs clipping. 树篱需要修剪一下。
3 [T] to hit sb/sth quickly 飞快碰或击: My wheel clipped the pavement and I fell off my bike. 轮子撞着人行道，我从自行车上跌了下来。

ˈclip art
noun [U] (computing 计算机技术) pictures and symbols that are stored in computer programs or on websites which you can copy into your own computer documents 剪贴画﹙计算机程序或网站中供用户复制的图像或符号﹚: This site offers hundreds of free clip-art images for teachers. 这个网站为教师们提供了成百上千张免费剪贴画。

clipboard
/ˈklɪpbɔ:d ||; ˈklɪpˌbɔrd/noun[C]
1 a small board with a part that holds papers at the top, used by sb who wants to write while standing or moving around （顶部带弹簧夹的）写字板 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图
2 (computing计算机技术) a place where information from a computer file is stored for a short time until it is added to another file 剪贴框，剪贴板（计算机暂存某文档信息之处，直到添加于另一文档）

clippers
/ˈklɪpəz ||; ˈklɪpɚz/noun [pl] a small metal tool used for cutting things, for example hair or fingernails 修剪器（如推子、指甲刀等）: a pair of nail clippers 一把指甲刀 ☞picture at scissors 见scissors插图

clipping
/ˈklɪpɪŋ ||; ˈklɪpɪŋ/ (US 美) =CUTTING¹(1)

clique
/kli:k ||; klik/noun [C] a small group of people with the same interests who do not want others to join their group 小集团；派系；朋党

clitoris
/ˈklɪtərɪs ||; ˈklɪtərɪs/noun [C] the small part of the female sex organs which becomes larger when a woman is sexually excited 阴蒂；阴核

cloak
/kləʊk ||; klok/noun
1 [C] a type of loose coat without sleeves that was more common in former times （旧时较常用的）斗篷，披风 ☞Look at cape. 参看cape。
2 [sing] a thing that hides sth else 遮蔽物；覆盖物: a cloak of mist 一层雾

cloakroom
/ˈkləʊkru:m ||; ˈklokˌrum/noun [C] a room near the entrance to a building where you can leave your coat, bags, etc （设在大楼入口处的）衣帽间

clobber
/ˈklɒbə(r) ||; ˈklɑbɚ/verb [T] (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to hit sb hard 使劲的打

*clock¹
/klɒk ||; klɑk/noun[C]
1 an instrument that shows you what time it is 时钟: an alarm clock 闹钟 a church clock 教堂的钟 ☞Look at watch. 参看watch。
2 an instrument in a car that measures how far it has travelled （汽车的）里程计，里程表: My car has only got 10000 miles on the clock. 我汽车上的里程表显示只走了10000英里。
against the clock if you do sth against the clock, you do it fast in order to finish before a certain time （为如期完成任务）争分夺秒: It was a race against the clock to get the building work finished on time. 为了让大楼工程如期完成而与时间赛跑。 around/round the clock all day and all night 日夜不停；夜以继日: They are working round the clock to repair the bridge. 他们正日夜抢修这座桥梁。 put the clock/clocks forward/back to change the time, usually by one hour, at the beginning/end of summer （在夏季开始或结束的时候）把钟拨快或拨慢（通常为一小时）
clock²
/klɒk ||; klɑk/verb clock in/on; clock off to record the time that you arrive at or leave work, especially by putting a card into a type of clock 记录上下班时间（尤指把记录卡放入记时计）；打卡 clock sth up to achieve a certain number or total 达到（某一数目）: Our car clocked up over 2000 miles while we were on holiday. 我们度假的时候开车跑了2000多英里。

clockwise
/ˈklɒkwaɪz ||; ˈklɑkˌwaɪz/adv adj in the same direction as the hands of a clock 顺时针（方向）: Turn the handle clockwise. 将把手朝顺时针方向转动 to move in a clockwise direction 以顺时针方向移动 [OPP] Britanticlockwise, US counter-clockwise. 英国英语的反义词为anticlockwise，美国英语则用counter-clockwise。

clockwork
/ˈklɒkwɜ:k ||; ˈklɑkˌwɝk/noun [U] a type of machinery found in certain toys, etc that you operate by turning a key （某些玩具等的）发条装置: a clockwork toy 发条玩具 The plan went like clockwork (= smoothly and without any problems). 计划进行顺利。

clog¹
/klɒg ||; klɑg/noun [C] a type of shoe made completely of wood or with a thick wooden base 木屐；木底鞋
clog²
/klɒg ||; klɑg/verb [I,T] (clogging;clogged)clog (sth) (up) (with sth) to block or become blocked 堵塞: The drain is always clogging up. 排水管老是堵塞。 The roads were clogged with traffic. 马路上交通繁忙，堵塞严重。

cloister
/ˈklɔɪstə(r) ||; ˈklɔɪstɚ/noun [C] [usu.pl] a covered passage with arches around a square garden, usually forming part of a large church(cathedral)or building where religious people live(monastery)or(convent) （大教堂的）回廊；（神职人员居住的）隐修院

clone
/kləʊn ||; klon/noun [C] an exact copy of a plant or animal that is produced from one of its cells by scientific methods （植物或动物）无性繁殖而成的个体；克隆 clone verb · A team from the UK were the first to successfully clone an animal. 英国一个小组最先成功地无性繁殖了动物。

*close¹
/kləʊz ||; kloz/verb[I,T]
1 to shut 关；闭；合: The door closed quietly. 门轻轻关上了。 to close a door/window 关门╱窗 Close your eyes -- I've got a surprise. 闭上眼睛，我要给你一个惊喜。
2 to be, or to make sth, not open to the public 不开放；关闭: What time do the shops close? 商店什么时候关门？ The police have closed the road to traffic. 警察把道路封了，不准车辆通行。
3 to end or to bring sth to an end 结束: The meeting closed at 10pm. 会议晚上10点才结束。 Detectives have closed the case on the missing girl. 警探把这起失踪少女案结了案。 [OPP] open 反义词为open
close (sth) down to stop all business or work permanently at a shop or factory 歇业；倒闭: The factory has had to close down. 这家工厂不得不停业。 Health inspectors have closed the restaurant down. 卫生监督员吊销了这家饭馆的营业执照。 close in (on sb/sth) to come nearer and gradually surround sb/sth, especially in order to attack 包围（尤指围攻）；逼近: The army is closing in on the enemy troops. 部队正从四方八面向敌军包抄。 close sth off to prevent people from entering a place or an area 封锁；使隔离: The police closed off the city centre because of a bomb alert. 警方因收到炸弹警报而封锁了市中心。
*close²
/kləʊz ||; kloz/noun [sing] the end, especially of a period of time or an activity 结尾（尤指时段或活动的）: the close of trading on the stock market 股市收市 bring sth/come/draw to a close to end 结束: The chairman brought the meeting to a close. 主席宣布散会。 The guests began to leave as the evening drew to a close. 晚会快要结束的时候，客人开始离去。
*close³
/kləʊs ||; klos/adj adv
1 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) close (to sb/sth);close (together) near 靠近: Is our hotel close to the beach? 我们住的酒店靠近海滩吗？ The tables are quite close together. 两张桌子紧挨着。 to follow close behind someone 紧跟某人之后 I held her close (= tightly). 我紧紧抱着她
2 (used about a friend, etc) known very well and liked （指朋友等）熟悉的，亲密的: They invited only close friends to the wedding. 他们只邀请好朋友出席他们的婚礼。
3 near in a family relationship 亲属关系近的: a close relative 近亲
4 (used about a competition, etc) only won by a small amount （指比赛等）比分接近的，势均力敌的: a close match 势均力敌的比赛 ☞Look at the note at near ¹. 参看near^1的注释。
5 careful; thorough 仔细的；彻底的: On close examination, you could see that the banknote was a forgery. 仔细观察，你会发现这是一张假币。
6 (used about the weather, etc) heavy and with little movement of air （指天气等）闷，空气不流通: It's so close today that there might be a storm. 今天天气很闷，只怕要刮大风了。 ➔closely adv to watch sb closely 密切监视某人 The insect closely resembles a stick. 这种昆虫长得很像一根竹签。 ➔closeness noun [U]
a close shave/thing a bad thing that almost happened 差点发生的灾祸: I wasn't injured, but it was a close shave. 我差点儿受伤，真是好险呀。 at close quarters at or from a position that is very near 近距离 close by (sb/sth) at a short distance from sb/sth 在附近: She lives close by. 她就住在附近。 close/near/dear to sb's heart→HEART close on nearly; almost 差不多: He was born close on a hundred years ago. 他约在百年前出生。 close up (to sb/sth) at or from a very short distance to sb/sth 靠近: You can't tell it's a forgery until you look at it close up. 只有近看才能察觉这是赝品。 come close (to sth/to doing sth) to almost do sth 差不多要做某事: We didn't win but we came close. 我们没有赢，但就差一点儿。
close⁴
/kləʊs ||; klos/noun [C] part of the name of a street 用于街名: 5 Devon Close 德文巷5号

*closed
/kləʊzd ||; klozd/adj not open; shut 关闭: Keep your mouth closed. 别张开嘴。 The supermarket is closed. 超市关门了。 [OPP] open 反义词为open

ˌclosed-ˈcaptioned
adj (used about a television programme) having the words that people say written at the bottom of the screen (captions) that can only be seen by people who have a special machine (a decoder) connected to their television ﹙电视节目﹚带闭路字幕的: This programme is closed-captioned for the hearing impaired. 这个节目为听力受损的观众提供了闭路字幕。

ˌclosed-ˌcircuit ˈtelevision
(abbr CCTV) noun [U] a type of television system used inside a building, for example a shop, to protect it from crime 闭路电视

closet
/ˈklɒzɪt ||; ˈklɑzɪt/noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) a large cupboard that is built into a room 壁橱

close-up
/ˈkləʊs ʌp/noun [C] a photograph or film of sb/sth that you take from a very short distance away 特写镜头；近镜: Here's a close-up of Mike. 这是一张迈克的特写照。

closing¹
/ˈkləʊzɪŋ ||; ˈklozɪŋ/adj (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) coming at the end of a speech, a period of time or an activity （演讲、一段时间或活动）结束时的: his closing remarks 他的结束语 The football season is now in its closing stages. 足球赛季现在处于结尾阶段。 [OPP] opening 反义词为opening
closing²
/ˈkləʊzɪŋ ||; ˈklozɪŋ/noun [U] the act of permanently shutting sth such as a factory, hospital, school, etc （工厂、医院、学院等的）关闭，倒闭: the closing of the local school 当地学校的关闭 [OPP] opening 反义词为opening

ˈclosing time
noun [C] the time when a shop, pub, etc closes （商店、酒馆等的）打烊时间

closure
/ˈkləʊʒə(r) ||; ˈkloʒɚ/noun [C,U] the permanent closing, for example of a business （生意等）歇业: The firm is threatened with closure. 这家公司面临倒闭的危机。

clot¹
/klɒt ||; klɑt/noun [C] a lump formed by blood as it dries （凝结的）血块: They removed a blood clot from his brain. 他们清除了他脑部的血块。
clot²
/klɒt ||; klɑt/verb [I,T] (clotting;clotted) to form or cause blood to form thick lumps （使）结成血块: a drug that stops blood from clotting during operations 一种防止血液在手术过程中凝固的药

*cloth
/klɒθ; US klɔ:θ ||; klɔθ/noun
1 [U] a material made of cotton, wool, etc that you use for making clothes, curtains, etc 布: a metre of cloth 一米布
2 [C] (plural cloths /klɒθs; US klɔ:ðz ||; klɔðz/) a piece of material that you use for a particular purpose 专用布: a tablecloth 桌布 Where can I find a cloth to wipe this water up? 哪里有抹布可以把这水抹掉？ ☞picture at bucket 见bucket插图

clothe
/kləʊð ||; kloð/verb [T] to provide clothes for sb 给…提供衣服: to feed and clothe a child 给孩子温饱

clothed
/kləʊðd ||; kloðd/adj clothed (in sth) dressed; wearing sth 身穿…: He was clothed in leather from head to foot. 他穿了一身皮革。

*clothes
/kləʊðz; US kləʊz ||; kloz/noun [pl] the things that you wear, for example trousers, shirts, dresses, coats, etc 衣服；衣着: Take off those wet clothes. 把湿衣服脱下来。 She was wearing new clothes. 她穿着新衣服。 ☞Look at garment. 参看garment。 Remember that clothes is always plural. We can use an item / piece / article of clothing to describe a single thing that you wear A kilt is an item of clothing worn in Scotland. clothes一定用于复数。服饰中的一项可以说an item／piece／article of clothing：A kilt is an item of clothing worn in Scotland.短褶裙是苏格兰人穿的一种服装。
ˈclothes-hanger
=HANGER

ˈclothes line
noun [C] a thin rope that you hang clothes on so that they can dry 晾衣绳

ˈclothes peg
(US 美 clothes pin)=PEG¹(3)

*clothing
/ˈkləʊðɪŋ ||; ˈkloðɪŋ/noun [U] the clothes that you wear, especially for a particular activity 衣物: You will need waterproof/outdoor/winter clothing. 你准用得着防水╱户外╱冬天衣服。 ☞ Clothing is a more formal word than clothes. 与clothes相比，clothing多用于正式场合。

ˌclotted ˈcream
noun [U] (Brit 英) a type of thick rich cream 浓缩奶油

*cloud¹
/klaʊd ||; klaυd/noun
1 [C,U] a mass of very small drops of water that floats in the sky and is usually white or grey 云: The sun disappeared behind a cloud. 太阳躲进云里去了。 A band of thick cloud is spreading from the west. 一团密云从西边涌过来。
2 [C] a mass of smoke, dust, sand, etc 一股（烟）；一团（尘埃）；一阵（沙）: Clouds of smoke were pouring from the burning building. 一股股的浓烟从着火的大厦里冒出来。
every cloud has a silver lining even a very bad situation has a positive or hopeful side黑暗中总有一线光明。 under a cloud with the disapproval of the people around you 名声不好；不光彩: She left her job under a cloud because she'd been accused of stealing. 她不光彩地离职，因为人家说她偷东西。
cloud²
/klaʊd ||; klaυd/verb
1 [I,T] to become or make sth difficult to see through （使）变得模糊: His eyes clouded with tears. 他泪眼模糊。
2 [T] to make sth less clear or easy to understand 把（事物）变得复杂: Her personal involvement in the case was beginning to cloud her judgement. 这案件跟她有个人牵连，她开始辨不清是非了。
3 [T] to make sth less enjoyable; to spoil 使蒙上阴影；困扰；糟蹋: Illness has clouded the last few years of his life. 他一生的最后几年受疾病所困扰。
cloud over (used about the sky) to become full of clouds （指天空）布满乌云

cloudburst
/ˈklaʊdbɜ:st ||; ˈklaυdˌbɝst/noun [C] a sudden heavy fall of rain 骤雨；暴雨

cloudless
/ˈklaʊdləs ||; ˈklaυdləs/adj (used about the sky, etc) clear; without any clouds （指天空等）晴朗的，碧空无云的

cloudy
/ˈklaʊdi ||; ˈklaυdɪ/adj
1 (used about the sky, etc) full of clouds （指天空等）乌云密布的，多云的
2 (used about liquids, etc) not clear （指液体等）浑浊的: cloudy water 浑浊的水

clout
/klaʊt ||; klaυt/noun (informal 非正式)
1 [C] a hard hit, usually with the hand 重击（通常指用手的）: to give someone a clout 重击某人
2 [U] influence and power 影响力: He's an important man -- he has a lot of clout in the company. 他在公司里有头有脸，影响力很大。

clove
/kləʊv ||; klov/noun[C]
1 the small dried flower of a tropical tree, used to give a special flavour in cooking 丁香（一种热带树的小花，晒干后可用作调味品）
2 one of the small separate sections into which the root of the GARLIC plant is divided 一瓣蒜

ˌcloven ˈhoof
noun [C] the foot of an animal such as a cow or a sheep, that is divided into two parts （牛或羊的）分趾蹄，偶蹄

clover
/ˈkləʊvə(r) ||; ˈklovɚ/noun [C] a small plant with pink or white flowers and leaves with three parts to them 车轴草（一种矮小植物，叶柄上有三片叶子，花呈粉红色或白色） ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图 Sometimes clover leaves have four parts and it is thought to be very lucky if you find one of these. 车轴草的叶柄间或有四片叶子；如果碰上四叶车轴草，据说会走大运。

clown¹
/klaʊn ||; klaυn/noun[C]
1 a person who wears funny clothes and a big red nose and does silly things to make people (especially children) laugh 小丑；丑角
2 a person who makes jokes and does silly things to make the people around him/her laugh 爱开玩笑的人；诙谐的人: At school, Jan was always the class clown. 在学校里，简总是班上最爱开玩笑的人。
clown²
/klaʊn ||; klaυn/verb [I] clown (about/around) to act in a funny or foolish way 耍活宝；扮小丑: Stop clowning around and get some work done! 别耍活宝了，快干活去！

cloying
/ˈklɔɪɪŋ ||; ˈklɔɪɪŋ/adj (formal 正式)
1 (used about food, a smell, etc) so sweet that it is unpleasant （指食物、气味等）甜得倒胃口的
2 using emotion in a very obvious way, so that the result is unpleasant 假作多情反而倒人胃口的: Her novels are full of cloying sentimentality. 她的小说过于假作多情，看了令人ni4烦。

*club¹
/klʌb ||; klʌb/noun
1 [C] a group of people who meet regularly to share an interest, do sport, etc; the place where they meet 俱乐部: to join a club 参加俱乐部 to be a member of a club 成为俱乐部的会员 a tennis/football/golf club 网球╱足球╱高尔夫球俱乐部
2 (also nightclub) [C] a place where you can go to dance and drink late at night 夜总会
3 [C] a heavy stick, usually with one end that is thicker than the other, used as a weapon 棍棒（通常指一端较粗，用作武器的）
4 [C] a long stick that is specially shaped at one end and used for hitting a ball when playing golf 高尔夫球棒 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图 ☞Look at bat, racket and stick. 参看bat、racket及stick。
5 clubs [pl] the group(suit) of playing cards with black shapes with three leaves on them （纸牌四种花色之一）梅花牌（总称）: the two/ace/queen of clubs 梅花二╱爱司╱王后 ☞Look at the note and picture at card. 参看card的注释及插图。
6 [C] one of the cards from this suit （扑克中的一张）梅花牌: I played a club. 我出一张梅花。
club²
/klʌb ||; klʌb/verb (clubbing;clubbed)
1 [T] to hit sb/sth hard with a heavy object 用重物击打
2 [I] go clubbing to go dancing and drinking in a club 去俱乐部跳舞喝酒: She goes clubbing every Saturday. 她每星期六都去俱乐部跳舞喝酒。
club together (to do sth) to share the cost of sth, for example a present 凑份子，共同出资（购买礼物等）: We clubbed together to buy him a leaving present. 我们凑份子给他买了送别礼物。

ˌclub ˈsandwich
noun [C] a sandwich made with three pieces of bread and layers of meat (usually chicken and bacon), tomato and lettuce between them 公司三明治﹙三层面包、两层夹肉、西红柿和生菜﹚

cluck
/klʌk ||; klʌk/noun [C] the noise made by a chicken （鸡的）咯咯叫声 cluck verb [I]

clue
/klu: ||; klu/noun [C] a clue (to sth) a piece of information that helps you solve a problem or a crime, answer a question, etc 线索: The police were looking for clues to his disappearance. 警方正在寻找他失踪的线索。 the clues for solving a crossword puzzle 做填字游戏的提示 not have a clue(informal 非正式) to know nothing about sth 一无所知；毫无头绪

clued-up
/ˌklu:d ˈʌp ||; ˈklud ˈʌp/ (US also 美亦作 ˌclued-ˈin) adj clued-up (on sth) knowing a lot about sth 通晓；熟知: I'm not really clued-up on the technical details. 这些技术细节其实我并不太明白。

clueless
/ˈklu:ləs ||; ˈklulɪs/adj (informal 非正式) not able to understand; stupid 一无所知；愚蠢: I'm absolutely clueless about computers. 我对计算机根本一窍不通。

clump
/klʌmp ||; klʌmp/noun [C] a small group of plants or trees, growing together ﹙花草﹑树木﹚丛╱簇

clumsy
/ˈklʌmzi ||; ˈklʌmzɪ/adj (clumsier;clumsiest)
1 (used about a person) careless and likely to knock into, drop or break things （指人）笨手笨脚的，笨拙的: She undid the parcel with clumsy fingers. 她笨手笨脚地把包裹拆开。
2 (used about a comment, etc) likely to upset or offend people （指评论等）容易冒犯或伤害人的: He made a clumsy apology. 他的道歉很生硬。
3 large, difficult to use, and not attractive in design 笨拙难看；大而无当: a clumsy piece of furniture 一件大而无当的家具 ➔clumsily adv ➔clumsiness noun [U]

clung
past tense, past participle ofCLING

clunk
/klʌŋk ||; klʌŋk/noun [C] a short low sound made when two hard objects hit each other （两硬物相碰发出的）短促而低沉的声音， 哐啷的一声: The car door shut with a clunk. 车门 哐啷的一声关上了。

cluster¹
/ˈklʌstə(r) ||; ˈklʌstɚ/noun [C] a group of people, plants or things that stand or grow close together ﹙人﹑植物﹑东西的﹚丛╱群╱团: a cluster of schoolchildren 一群学童
cluster²
/ˈklʌstə(r) ||; ˈklʌstɚ/verb cluster around sb/sth to form a group around sb/sth 聚集在某人或某物的周围；围拢: The tourists clustered around their guide. 游客簇拥着导游。

clutch¹
/klʌtʃ ||; klʌtʃ/verb [T] to hold sth tightly, especially because you are in pain, afraid or excited 紧握（尤指因痛苦、惊慌或紧张）: He clutched his mother's hand in fear. 他怕得抓紧妈妈的手不放。 clutch at sth to try to take hold of sth 试图抓住某物: She clutched at the money but the wind blew it away. 她还来不及抓住，钞票就让风给吹走了。
clutch²
/klʌtʃ ||; klʌtʃ/noun
1 [C] the part of a vehicle, etc that you press with your foot when you are driving in order to change the GEAR; the part of the engine that it is connected to （汽车的）离合器踏板，离合器: to press/release the clutch 踩下╱松开离合器 ☞picture at car 见car插图
2 clutches [pl] power or control over sb （对某人的）影响力或控制: He fell into the enemy's clutches. 他落入了敌人的魔掌。

clutter¹
/ˈklʌtə(r) ||; ˈklʌtɚ/noun [U] things that are where they are not wanted or needed and make a place untidy 杂乱而无关紧要的东西: Who left all this clutter on the floor? 谁把这些东西乱放在地板上的？ ➔cluttered adj a cluttered desk 凌乱的办公桌
clutter²
/ˈklʌtə(r) ||; ˈklʌtɚ/verb [T] clutter sth (up) to cover or fill sth with lots of objects in an untidy way 乱丢；乱塞: Don't leave those books there -- they're cluttering up the table. 不要把那些书留在那里，桌子都给摆满了。

cm
abbr centimetre(s) 厘米；公分

co-
/kəʊ ||; ko/prefix (in adjectives, adverbs, nouns and verbs 用于构成形容词、副词、名词及动词) together with 共同；一起: co-pilot （飞机）副驾驶员 coexist 共存；共处

c/o
abbr (used for addressing a letter to somebody who is staying at another person's house) care of （书信用语）由…转交: Andy Kirkham, c/o Mrs Potter 由波特太太转交安迪˙柯卡姆收

Co.
abbr
1 company 公司: W Smith & Co Ｗ˙史密斯公司
2 county 县；郡: Co Down 当郡

*coach¹
/kəʊtʃ ||; kotʃ/noun[C]
1 a person who trains people to compete in certain sports （体育运动的）教练: a tennis coach 网球教练
2 (Brit 英) a comfortable bus used for long journeys 长途客车: It's cheaper to travel by coach than by train. 乘长途客车旅行要比乘火车便宜。 ☞picture at bus 见bus插图
3 = CARRIAGE(1)
4 a large vehicle with four wheels pulled by horses, used in the past for carrying passengers 四轮大马车（尤指旧时用的） ☞Look at carriage and car. 参看carriage及car。
coach²
/kəʊtʃ ||; kotʃ/verb [I,T] coach sb (in/for sth) to train or teach sb, especially to compete in a sport or pass an exam 训练（旨在参加体育比赛、考试等） · She is being coached for the Olympics by a former champion. 她正接受一位前冠军的训练，为参加奥运会作准备。

coaching
/ˈkəʊtʃɪŋ ||; ˈkotʃɪŋ/noun [U]:
1 the process of training sb to play a sport, to do a job better or to improve a skill 训练；指导
2 (especially Brit 尤为英) the process of giving a student extra teaching in a particular subject （对学生的）辅导

coagulate
