/kəʊˈægjuleɪt ||; koˈægjəˌlet/verb [I] (used about a liquid) to become thick and partly solid （指液体）凝结: The blood was starting to coagulate inside the cut. 伤口里的血开始凝结了。 ➔coagulation /kəʊˌægjuˈleɪʃn ||; koˌægjəˈleʃən/ noun [U]

*coal
/kəʊl ||; kol/noun
1 [U] a type of black mineral that is dug (mined) from the ground and burned to give heat 煤（从地下开采出来的黑色矿物，可用作燃料）: a lump of coal 一块煤 a coal fire 煤火
2 coals [pl] burning pieces of coal 燃烧中的煤块 ☞picture at fireplace 见fireplace插图

coalface
/ˈkəʊlfeɪs ||; ˈkolˌfes/noun [C] the place deep inside a mine where the coal is cut out of the rock 采煤工作面

coalition
/ˌkəʊəˈlɪʃn ||; ˌkoəˈlɪʃən/noun [C] [with.sop] a government formed by two or more political parties working together （由两个或以上政党组成的）联合政府: a coalition between the socialists and the Green Party 由社会党和绿党组成的联合政府

ˈcoal mine
(also pit) noun [C] a place, usually underground, where coal is dug from the ground 煤矿 ☞Look at colliery. 参看colliery。

ˈcoal miner
(also miner) noun [C] a person whose job is to dig coal from the ground 煤矿工人

coalesce
/ˌkəʊəˈles ||; ˌkoəˈlɛs/verb [I] coalesce (into/with sth)(formal 正式) to come together to form one larger group, substance, etc 联合；合并 ➔coalescence noun [U]

coarse
/kɔ:s ||; kɔrs/adj
1 consisting of large pieces; rough, not smooth 粗糙的: coarse salt 粗盐 coarse cloth 粗布 [OPP] fine 反义词为fine
2 (used about a person or his/her behaviour) rude, likely to offend people; having bad manners （指人或其行为）粗鲁的: His coarse remarks about women offended her. 他对女人粗鲁的评语惹她发怒。 ➔coarsely adv Chop the onion coarsely (= into pieces which are not too small). 把洋葱切成大片 He laughed coarsely. 他粗声粗气地笑起来。

coarsen
/ˈkɔ:sn ||; ˈkɔrsṇ/verb [I,T] to become or to make sth coarse （使）变粗糙或粗鲁

*coast¹
/kəʊst ||; kost/noun [C] the area of land that is next to or close to the sea 海岸；沿海地区: After sailing for an hour we could finally see the coast. 船航行了一个钟头后，我们终于看见了陆地。 Scarborough is on the east coast. 斯卡伯勒位于东海岸。
coast²
/kəʊst ||; kost/verb[I]
1 to travel in a car, on a bicycle, etc (especially down a hill) without using power （乘汽车、骑自行车等）滑行（尤指下坡）
2 to achieve sth without much effort 轻易得到: They coasted to victory. 他们轻易获胜。

coastal
/ˈkəʊstl ||; ˈkostḷ/adj on or near a coast 海岸的；近岸的: coastal areas 沿海地区 ☞Look at pictures at erode. 参看erode的插图。

coastguard
/ˈkəʊstgɑ:d ||; ˈkostˌgɑrd/noun [C] a person or group of people whose job is to watch the sea near the coast in order to help people or ships that are in danger or to stop illegal activities （担任救生、缉私等工作的）海岸警恒队（员）

coastline
/ˈkəʊstlaɪn ||; ˈkostˌlaɪn/noun [C] the edge or shape of a coast 海岸线: a rocky coastline 岩石嶙嶙的海岸线

*coat¹
/kəʊt ||; kot/noun[C]
1 a piece of clothing that you wear over your other clothes to keep warm when you are outside 外套；大衣: Put your coat on -- it's cold outside. 外面冷，把外套穿上吧。 ☞Look at overcoat and raincoat. 参看overcoat及raincoat。 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 the fur or hair covering an animal's body （动物的）皮毛: a dog with a smooth coat 皮毛光滑的狗
3 a layer of sth covering a surface 覆盖层；表层: The walls will probably need two coats of paint. 墙壁很可能需要上两道漆。
coat²
/kəʊt ||; kot/verb [T] coat sth (with/in sth) to cover sth with a layer of sth （用某物）覆盖（某物）；加上一层（某物）: biscuits coated with milk chocolate 加上一层牛奶巧克力的饼干

ˈcoat check
noun [C] (US 美) = cloakroom

ˈcoat hanger
=HANGER

ˌcoat of ˈarms
(plural coats of arms) (also arms [pl]) noun [C] a design that is used as the symbol of a family, a town, a university, etc （家族、市镇、大学等作为标志的）盾形徽章

coating
/ˈkəʊtɪŋ ||; ˈkotɪŋ/noun [C] a thin layer of sth that covers sth else 薄层；表层: wire with a plastic coating 塑料皮电线

coax
/kəʊks ||; koks/verb [T] coax sb (into/out of sth/doing sth);coax sth out of/from sb to persuade sb gently 好言相劝；哄: The child wasn't hungry, but his mother coaxed him into eating a little. 那孩子不饿，可他妈妈哄他吃了点东西。 At last he coaxed a smile out of her. 他终于把她逗乐了。

cobalt
/ˈkəʊbɔ:lt ||; ˈkobɔlt/noun [U]:
1 (symbol Co) a hard silver-white metal that is often mixed with other metals and used to give a deep blue-green colour to glass 钴
2 (also ˌcobalt ˈblue) a deep blue-green colour 深蓝绿色

cobble
/ˈkɒbl ||; ˈkɑbḷ/verb cobble sth together to make sth or put sth together quickly and without much care 胡乱拼凑

cobbler
/ˈkɒblə(r) ||; ˈkɑblɚ/noun [C] (old-fashioned 旧) a person who repairs shoes 补鞋匠

cobbles
/ˈkɒblz ||; ˈkɑbḷz/ (also cobblestones /ˈkɒblstəʊnz ||; ˈkɑbḷˌstonz/) noun [pl] small rounded stones used (in the past) for covering the surface of streets 鹅卵石，圆石（以前用于铺路面） ➔cobbled adj

cobra
/ˈkəʊbrə ||; ˈkobrə/noun [C] a poisonous snake that can spread out the skin at the back of its neck. Cobras live in India and Africa. 眼镜蛇（产于印度和非洲）

cobweb
/ˈkɒbweb ||; ˈkɑbˌwɛb/noun [C] a net of threads made by a spider in order to catch insects 蜘蛛网 ☞Look at web (1). 参看web(1)。

cocaine
/kəʊˈkeɪn ||; koˈken/ (informal 非正式coke) noun [U] a dangerous drug that some people take for pleasure but which is ADDICTIVE(= difficult to stop using) 可卡因；古柯碱

coccyx
/ˈkɒksɪks ||; ˈkɑksɪks/noun [C] the small bone at the bottom of the bones of your back(spine) （脊椎末端的）尾骨 ☞picture at body 见body插图

cochineal
/ˌkɒtʃɪˈni:l ||; ˌkɑtʃəˈnil/noun [U] a bright red substance used to give colour to food 胭脂虫红（用于给食物着色）

cochlea
/ˈkɒklɪə ||; ˈkɑklɪə/noun [C] the part of the inside of your ear(inner ear), which is shaped like a shell and is very important for hearing 耳蜗（位于内耳）

cock¹
/kɒk ||; kɑk/noun[C]
1 (US 美 rooster) an adult male chicken （发育成熟的）公鸡 ☞Look at the note and picture at chicken. 参看chicken的注释及插图。
2 an adult male bird of any type （发育成熟的）雄性鸟类
cock²
/kɒk ||; kɑk/verb [T] to hold up a part of the body 竖起或翘起身体的某一部份: The horse cocked its ears on hearing the noise. 这匹马一听到响声就竖起了耳朵。 cock sth up (Brit 英) (slang 俚语) to do something very badly and spoil sth 弄糟 ☞Look at cock-up. 参看cock-up。

cock-a-doodle-doo
/ˌkɒk ə ˌdu:dl ˈdu: ||; ˈkɑk ə ˌdudḷ ˈdu/noun [sing] the noise made by an adult male chicken (cock) 喔喔喔（公鸡啼声）

cockatoo
/ˌkɒkəˈtu: ||; ˌkɑkəˈtu/noun [C] (plural cockatoos) a large brightly coloured bird with a lot of feathers standing up on top of its head 凤头鹦鹉

cockerel
/ˈkɒkərəl ||; ˈkɑkərəl/noun [C] a young male chicken 小公鸡

cockle
/ˈkɒkl ||; ˈkɑkḷ/noun [C] a small SHELLFISH(= a sea animal that lives inside a shell) that can be eaten 鸟蛤，海扇（一种小贝类水产，可食用）

cockney
/ˈkɒkni ||; ˈkɑknɪ/noun
1 [C] a person who was born and grew up in the East End of London （生长在伦敦东区的）伦敦人
2 [U] the way of speaking English that is typical of people living in this area 伦敦土话；伦敦（东区）方言: a cockney accent 伦敦腔

cockpit
/ˈkɒkpɪt ||; ˈkɑkˌpɪt/noun[C]
1 the part of a plane where the pilot sits （飞机的）驾驶舱
2 the part of a racing car where the driver sits （跑车的）驾驶座

cockroach
/ˈkɒkrəʊtʃ ||; ˈkɑkˌrotʃ/ (US 美 roach) noun [C] a large dark brown insect, usually found in dirty or slightly wet places 蟑螂 ☞picture at insect 见insect插图

cocktail
/ˈkɒkteɪl ||; ˈkɑkˌtel/noun[C]
1 a drink made from a mixture of alcoholic drinks and fruit juices 鸡尾酒（一种用酒和果汁调配的饮料）: a cocktail bar/party 鸡尾酒吧；鸡尾酒会
2 a mixture of small pieces of food that is served cold 什锦食品；拼盘: a prawn cocktail 大虾冷盘
3 a mixture of different substances, usually ones that do not mix together well 混合物（通常指几种不易混合的物质混合在一起）: a lethal cocktail of drugs 致命的混合药物

ˈcock-up
noun [C] (slang 俚语) something that was badly done; a mistake that spoils sth 混乱；一团糟 ☞Look at cock ². 参看cock^2。

cocoa
/ˈkəʊkəʊ ||; ˈkoko/noun
1 [U] a dark brown powder made from the seeds of a tropical tree and used in making chocolate 可可粉（可用以制造巧克力）
2 [C,U] a hot drink made from this powder mixed with milk or water; a cup of this drink 可可饮料: a cup of cocoa 一杯可可

coconut
/ˈkəʊkənʌt ||; ˈkokəˌnʌt/noun [C,U] a large tropical fruit with a hard, hairy shell 椰子 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

cocoon
/kəˈku:n ||; kəˈkun/noun [C] a covering of thin threads that some insects make to protect themselves before becoming adults 茧；卵袋 ☞Look at chrysalis. 参看chrysalis。

cod
/kɒd ||; kɑd/noun [C,U] (plural cod) a large sea fish that lives in the North Atlantic that you can eat 鳕（鱼）

COD
/ˌsi: əʊ ˈdi: ||; ˌsi ˌo ˈdi/abbr (written 书面语) cash on delivery or (in US English) collect on delivery; a way of paying for goods that you have ordered when you receive them 货到付款

coda
/ˈkəʊdə ||; ˈkodə/noun [C] the final passage of a piece of music （一首乐曲的）尾声

code¹
/kəʊd ||; kod/noun
1 [C,U] a system of words, letters, numbers, etc that are used instead of the real letters or words to make a message or information secret 密码: They managed to break/crack the enemy code(= find out what it means). 他们成功地破译了敌方密码。 They wrote letters to each other in code. 他们用密码通信。 ☞Look at decode. 参看decode。
2 [C] a group of numbers, letters, etc that is used for identifying sth 代号；代码: What's the code(= the telephone number)for Stockholm? 斯德哥尔摩的电话代号是什么？ ☞Look at bar code. 参看bar code。
3 [C] a set of rules for behaviour 守则；法规: a code of practice(= a set of standards agreed and accepted by a particular profession) 专业守则 the Highway Code(= the rules for driving on the roads) 公路法规
4 [U] (computing计算机技术) instructions used to form computer programs 代码（用于构建计算机程序）: segments of code 代码段
code²
/kəʊd ||; kod/verb[T]
1 (also encode) to put or write sth in code¹(1) 用密码写出；编成代号: coded messages 密码信息 [OPP] decode 反义词为decode
2 to use a particular system for identifying things （用某系统）识别，分类: The files are colour-coded: blue for Europe, green for Africa. 这些档案按颜色分类：蓝色代表欧洲，绿色代表非洲。
3 (computing计算机技术) to write a computer program by putting one system of numbers, words and symbols into another system 以代码编制计算机程序

codeine
/ˈkəʊdi:n ||; ˈkodin/noun [U] a drug that is used to reduce pain 可待因（一种止痛药）

codify
/ˈkəʊdɪfaɪ ||; ˈkodəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle codifying third person singular present codifies;past tense past participle codified) (technical术语) to arrange laws, rules, etc into a system 把（法律、规则等）编汇成典 ➔codification /ˌkəʊdɪfɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌkodəfəˈkeʃən/ noun [U]

ˌco-eduˈcational
(abbr coed) adj (used about a school) with both boys and girls together in the same classes （指学校）男女同校的，男女兼收的 [SYN] mixed 同义词为mixed ➔ˌco-eduˈcation noun [U]

coefficient
/ˌkəʊɪˈfɪʃnt ||; ˌkoəˈfɪʃənt/noun[C]
1 (mathematics数学) a number which is placed before another quantity and which multiplies it, for example 3 in the quantity 3x 系数（如3x中的3）
2 (technical术语) a number that measures a particular characteristic of a substance 系数（衡量某种物质特性的数字）: the coefficient of friction/expansion 摩擦╱膨胀系数

coerce
/kəʊˈɜ:s ||; koˈɝs/verb [T] (formal 正式)coerce sb (into sth/doing sth) to force sb to do sth, for example by threatening him/her 强迫 ➔coercion /kəʊˈɜ:ʃn; US -ʒn ||; koˈɝʒən/ noun [U]

coexist
/ˌkəʊɪgˈzɪst ||; ˌko·ɪgˈzɪst/verb [I] to live or be together at the same time or in the same place as sb/sth 同时或同地存在；共存；共处 ➔coexistence noun [U]

C. of E.
/ˌsi: əv ˈi: ||; ˌsi əv ˈi/abbr Church of England 英国国教会；英国圣公会

*coffee
/ˈkɒfi; US ˈkɔ:fɪ ||; ˈkɔfɪ/noun
1 [U] the cooked seeds (coffee beans)of a tropical tree, made into powder and used for making a drink 咖啡豆: Coffee is the country's biggest export. 咖啡是该国最大宗的出口物。 coffee beans 咖啡豆
2 [U] a drink made by adding hot water to this powder 咖啡（饮料）: Would you prefer tea or coffee? 你要茶还是咖啡？ a cup of coffee 一杯咖啡
3 [C] a cup of this drink 一杯咖啡: Two coffees please. 请来两杯咖啡。 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
Black coffee is made without milk; white coffee is with milk. Decaffeinated coffee has had the caffeine taken out. Coffee can be weak or strong. Instant coffee is sold in a jar and made by pouring hot water or milk onto coffee powder in a cup. Real coffee is made in a coffee pot from coffee beans that have just been ground. 不加牛奶的咖啡叫做black coffee，加牛奶的叫做white coffee。脱去咖啡因的叫做decaffeinated coffee。咖啡可以淡(weak)，也可以浓(strong)。装在罐中出售，用咖啡粉冲泡的叫做instant coffee（速溶咖啡）。新鲜咖啡(real coffee)是用刚研磨(ground)的咖啡豆在咖啡壶里煮成的。

ˈcoffee bar
(also coffee shop) noun [C] (Brit 英) a place in a hotel, a large shop, etc, where simple food, coffee, tea and other drinks without alcohol are served （旅馆、大商店等的）咖啡馆

ˈcoffee house
noun [C] (US 美) a small restaurant where people go to talk and drink coffee 咖啡馆

ˈcoffee break
noun [C] a short period of rest when you stop working and drink coffee 工间喝咖啡休息时间: Let's take a coffee break. 让我们休息一下，喝杯咖啡吧。

ˈcoffee grinder
noun [C] a machine which turns roasted coffee beans into a powder 咖啡豆研磨机

ˈcoffee maker
noun [C] a machine which heats water and pours it over a powder made from coffee beans to make coffee 煮咖啡器；咖啡壶

ˈcoffee pot
noun [C] a container in which coffee is made and served 咖啡壶 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

ˈcoffee table
noun [C] a small low table for putting magazines, cups, etc, on 茶几 ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

coffin
/ˈkɒfɪn; US ˈkɔ:fɪn ||; ˈkɔfɪn/ (US 美 casket) noun [C] a box in which a dead body is buried or burned (cremated) 棺材；棺木 ☞Look at the note at funeral. 参看funeral的注释。

cog
/kɒg ||; kɑg/noun [C] one of a series of teeth on the edge of a wheel that fit into the teeth on the next wheel and cause it to move （齿轮的）齿；轮齿

cogent
/ˈkəʊdʒənt ||; ˈkodʒənt/adj (formal 正式) strongly and clearly expressed in a way that influences what people believe 有说服力的: a cogent argument/reason 令人信服的论据╱理由

cognac
/ˈkɒnjæk ||; ˈkɑnjæk/noun
1 [U] a type of BRANDY(= a strong alcoholic drink) that is made in France 科涅克酒，干邑（一种产于法国的白兰地酒）
2 [C] a glass of this drink 一杯科涅克酒

cognition
/kɒgˈnɪʃn ||; kɑgˈnɪʃən/noun [U] the process by which knowledge and understanding is developed in the mind 认识或理解（过程）

cognitive
/ˈkɒgnətɪv ||; ˈkɑgnətɪv/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) connected with the processes of understanding 与认识或理解有关的: cognitive abilities 理解能力

cohabit
/kəʊˈhæbɪt ||; koˈhæbɪt/verb [I] (formal 正式) (used about a couple) to live together as if they are married （指情侣）同居

coherent
/kəʊˈhɪərənt ||; koˈhɪrənt/adj clear and easy to understand 连贯的；条理清楚的 [OPP] incoherent 反义词为incoherent ➔coherence noun [U] ➔coherently adv

cohesion
/kəʊˈhi:ʒn ||; koˈhiʒən/noun [U] the ability to stay or fit together well 团结；紧密配合；凝聚力: What the team lacks is cohesion -- all the players play as individuals. 这支球队的队员都各自为政，互相不配合。

coil¹
/kɔɪl ||; kɔɪl/verb [I,T] to make sth into a round shape 卷: a snake coiled under a rock 蛇盘绕在石头上
coil²
/kɔɪl ||; kɔɪl/noun [C] a length of rope, wire, etc that has been made into a round shape 一卷，一盘（绳子、金属线等）: a coil of rope 一盘绳子

*coin¹
/kɔɪn ||; kɔɪn/noun [C] a piece of money made of metal 硬币: a pound coin 一英镑硬币 ☞picture at money 见money插图
coin²
/kɔɪn ||; kɔɪn/verb [T] to invent a new word or phrase 创造（新词或新语）: Who was it who coined the phrase ‘a week is a long time in politics’? “政坛多变，度周如年”这句话是谁说的？

coinage
/ˈkɔɪnɪdʒ ||; ˈkɔɪnɪdʒ/noun [U] the system of coins used in a country 钱币制度: decimal coinage 十进币制

coincide
/ˌkəʊɪnˈsaɪd ||; ˌko·ɪnˈsaɪd/verb [I] coincide (with sth)
1 (used about events) to happen at the same time as sth else （指事件）同时发生: The Queen's visit is timed to coincide with the country's centenary celebrations. 女王到访日期安排在该国一百周年国庆期间。
2 to be exactly the same or very similar 一致；非常相近: Our views coincide completely. 我们的看法完全一致。

coincidence
/kəʊˈɪnsɪdəns ||; koˈɪnsədəns/noun [C,U] two or more similar things happening at the same time by chance, in a surprising way 巧合: We hadn't planned to meet, it was just coincidence. 我们并没有事先安排，这次见面纯属巧合。

coincidental
/kəʊˌɪnsɪˈdentl ||; koˌɪnsəˈdɛntḷ/adj resulting from two similar or related events happening at the same time by chance 巧合的 ➔coincidentally /-təli ||; -təlɪ/ adv

coitus
/ˈkɔɪtəs ||; ˈko·ɪtəs/ =SEX(3)

/kəʊk ||; kok/noun [U]:
1 a solid black substance produced from coal and used as a fuel 焦炭
2 =COCAINE

col
/kɒl ||; kɑl/noun [C] a low point between two higher points in a line or group of mountains 山坳；山口

Col.
abbr Colonel 上校

cola
/ˈkəʊlə ||; ˈkolə/noun [C,U] a brown, sweet cold drink that does not contain alcohol; a glass or can of this 可乐；一杯或一罐可乐

colander
/ˈkʌləndə(r) ||; ˈkʌləndɚ/noun [C] a metal or plastic bowl with a lot of small holes in it that is used for removing water from food that has been boiled or washed 滤器 ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图

*cold¹
/kəʊld ||; kold/adj
1 having a low temperature; not hot or warm 冷的: I'm not going into the sea, the water's too cold. 水太冷，我不下海了。 Shall I put the heating on? I'm cold. 我觉得冷，让我开暖气。
Compare cold, hot, cool, and warm. Cold indicates a lower temperature than cool and may describe a temperature that is unpleasantly low a terribly cold winter. Cool means ‘fairly cold’ and may describe a pleasantly low temperature It's terribly hot outside but it's nice and cool in here. Hot indicates a higher temperature than warm and may describe a temperature that is unpleasantly high I can't drink this yet, it's too hot. Warm means ‘fairly hot’ and may describe a pleasantly high temperature Come and sit by the fire, you'll soon get warm again. 比较cold、hot、cool及warm。cold表示温度比cool要低，也许低得令人难受：a terribly cold winter严寒的冬天。cool指凉，令人舒服的低温度：It's terribly hot outside but it's nice and cool in here.外边火辣辣，里边却阴凉舒服。hot表示的温度比warm要高，或许高得令人难受：I can't drink this yet, it's too hot.这个太烫了，我还喝不了。warm指暖，令人舒服的高温度：Come and sit by the fire, you'll soon get warm again.过来坐在炉边暖和暖和吧。
2 (used about food or drink) not heated or cooked; having become cold after being heated or cooked ﹙指食物﹑饮料﹚未加热的﹔冷却的: a cold drink 冷饮 Have your soup before it gets cold. 汤趁热喝吧。
3 (used about a person or sb's behaviour) very unfriendly; not showing kindness, understanding, etc （指人或其行为）冷漠的，冷冰冰的: She gave him a cold, hard look. 她冷冷地狠盯了他一眼。
cold turkey suddenly and completely, without getting used to sth gradually 突然而完全；无准备: I gave up smoking cold turkey. 我一下子戒了烟。 get/have cold feet(informal 非正式) to become/be afraid to do sth 害怕起来: She started to get cold feet as her wedding day approached. 婚期逼近，她开始害怕起来。 in cold blood in a cruel way and without pity 冷血地；残酷地: to kill sb in cold blood 残酷地杀人
*cold²
/kəʊld ||; kold/noun
1 [sing] [U] lack of heat; low temperature; cold weather 冷；寒冷: We walked home in the snow, shivering with cold. 我们冒雪步行回家，冷得直哆嗦。 Come on, let's get out of the cold and go indoors. 我们快进屋吧，别在外边挨冷。
2 [C,U] a common illness of the nose and throat. When you have a cold you have a sore throat and often cannot breathe through your nose 感冒；伤风: I think I'm getting a cold. 看来我着了凉。 Wear some warm clothes when you go out or you'll catch cold. 出去时穿暖和点，要不你会着凉的。

ˌcold-ˈblooded
adj
1 having a blood temperature that changes with the temperature of the surroundings （指动物）变温的，冷血的: Reptiles are cold-blooded. 爬虫类都是冷血动物。 [OPP] warm-blooded 反义词为warm-blooded
2 cruel; having or showing no pity 残忍的；冷血的: cold-blooded killers 冷血杀手

ˌcold-ˈcalling
noun [U] the practice of telephoning sb that you do not know, in order to sell him/her sth 商品促销电话 ➔ˌcold ˈcall noun [C]

ˌcold ˈcash
(US 美) =HARD CASH

ˌcold-ˈhearted
adj unkind; showing no kindness, understanding, etc 冷酷无情

coldly
/ˈkəʊldli ||; ˈkoldlɪ/adv in an unfriendly way; in a way that shows no kindness or understanding 冷漠；冷冰冰

coldness
/ˈkəʊldnəs ||; ˈkoldnɪs/noun [U] the lack of warm feelings; unfriendly behaviour 寒冷；冷漠

ˈcold snap
noun [C] a sudden short period of very cold weather 短冷期；寒汛

ˈcold sore
noun [C] a small painful area on the lips or inside the mouth that is caused by a VIRUS （由病毒引起的）唇疮疹

ˌcold ˈstorage
noun [U] a place where food, etc can be kept fresh or frozen until it is needed; the keeping of sth in a place like this 冷藏柜；冷藏: to keep meat in cold storage 将肉冷藏

colic
/ˈkɒlɪk ||; ˈkɑlɪk/noun [U] pain in the stomach area, which especially babies get 腹部绞痛（尤指婴儿所患）

collaborate
/kəˈlæbəreɪt ||; kəˈlæbəˌret/verb[I]
1 collaborate (with sb) (on sth) to work together (with sb), especially to create or produce sth 合作: She collaborated with another author on the book. 她跟另一作者合着了这本书。
2 collaborate (with sb) to help the enemy forces who have taken control of your country 跟﹙占领本国的敌入﹚勾结﹔通敌 ☞This word shows disapproval. 这个词含贬意。 ➔collaboration /kəˌlæbəˈreɪʃn ||; kəˌlæbəˈreʃən/ noun [uc] ➔collaborator noun [C]

collage
/ˈkɒlɑ:ʒ; US kəˈlɑ:ʒ ||; kəˈlɑʒ/noun [C,U] a picture made by fixing pieces of paper, cloth, photographs, etc onto a surface; the art of making a picture like this （把纸片、碎布、零碎相片等黏贴在画面上的）拼贴画，拼贴艺术

collagen
/ˈkɒlədʒn ||; ˈkɑlədʒən/noun [U] the main substance(protein)found in the parts of an animal's body that connect the organs and give them support 胶原蛋白

collapse¹
/kəˈlæps ||; kəˈlæps/verb
1 [I] to fall down or break into pieces suddenly 倒塌；塌陷: A lot of buildings collapsed in the earthquake. 很多建筑物在地震中震塌了。
2 [I] (used about a person) to fall down, usually because you are very ill, and perhaps become unconscious （指人）倒下，昏倒: The winner collapsed at the end of the race. 得胜选手冲过终点时昏倒了。
3 [I] (used about a business, plan, etc) to fail suddenly or completely （指企业、计划等）垮台，崩溃: The company collapsed, leaving hundreds of people out of work. 公司垮了台，使得好几百名员工失业。
4 [I,T] to fold sth or be folded into a shape that uses less space 折迭起来
collapse²
/kəˈlæps ||; kəˈlæps/noun
1 [C,U] the sudden or complete failure of sth, such as a business, plan, etc （企业、计划等）垮台，崩溃: The peace talks were on the brink/verge of collapse. 和谈快要破裂。
2 [sing] [U] (used about a building) a sudden fall （指建筑物）倒塌: the collapse of the motorway bridge 高速公路桥的坍塌
3 [sing] [U] (used about a person) a medical condition when a person becomes very ill and suddenly falls down （指人）倒下，昏倒

collapsible
/kəˈlæpsəbl ||; kəˈlæpsəbḷ/adj that can be folded into a shape that makes sth easy to store 可折迭的: a collapsible bed 折迭床

*collar¹
/ˈkɒlə(r) ||; ˈkɑlɚ/noun[C]
1 the part of a shirt, coat, dress, etc that fits round the neck and is often folded over 衣领: a coat with a fur collar 毛皮领子的大衣 ☞picture at lace 见lace插图 ☞Look at dog collar, blue-collar and white-collar 参看dog collar、blue-collar及white-collar。
2 a band of leather that is put round an animal's neck (especially a dog or cat) （猫、狗的）颈圈
collar²
/ˈkɒlə(r) ||; ˈkɑlɚ/verb [T] (informal 非正式) to catch hold of sb who does not want to be caught 捉住；截住: The police officer collared the thief. 警察逮住了小偷。

collarbone
/ˈkɒləbəʊn ||; ˈkɑlɚˈbon/ (formal 正式clavicle) noun [C] one of the two bones that connect your chest bones to your shoulder 锁骨 ☞picture at body 见body插图

collate
/kəˈleɪt ||; kəˈlet/verb[T]
1 to collect information from different places in order to put it together, examine and compare it 核对；校勘: to collate data/information/figures 核对数据╱信息╱数字
2 to collect pieces of paper or pages from a book and arrange them in the correct order 按次序整理（纸张或书页） ➔collation noun [U]: the collation of data 资料整理

collateral¹
/kəˈlætərəl ||; kəˈlætərəl/noun [U] property or sth valuable that you agree to give to sb if you cannot pay back money that you have borrowed （贷款的）担保物，抵押品
collateral²
/kəˈlætərəl ||; kəˈlætərəl/adj (formal 正式) connected with sth else, but in addition to it and less important 伴随的；附带的

*colleague
/ˈkɒli:g ||; ˈkɑlig/noun [C] a person who works at the same place as you 同事

*collect¹
/kəˈlekt ||; kəˈlɛkt/verb
1 [T] to bring a number of things together 收集: All the exam papers will be collected at the end. 全部试卷将在考试结束时收回。
2 [T] to get and keep together a number of objects of a particular type over a period of time as a hobby 作为爱好收集（某类物品）: He used to collect stamps. 他以前爱集邮。
3 [I,T] to ask for money from a number of people 募捐；征收: to collect for charity 为慈善团体募捐 The landlord collects the rent at the end of each month. 房东每到月底就收房租。
4 [I] to come together 集合；聚集: A crowd collected to see what was going on. 人们聚在一起看热闹。 [SYN] gather 同义词为gather
5 [T] (especially Brit 尤为英) to go and get sb/sth from a particular place; to pick sb/sth up 接（某人）；取（某物）: to collect the children from school 到学校接孩子
6 [T] collect yourself/sth to get control of yourself, your feelings, thoughts, etc 控制自己的心情、思绪等: She collected herself and went back into the room as if nothing had happened. 她打起精神回到房间去，彷佛什么事也没有发生过。 I tried to collect my thoughts before the exam. 考试之前我尽力集中精神。
collect²
/kəˈlekt ||; kəˈlɛkt/adj adv (US 美) (used about a telephone call) to be paid for by the person who receives the call （指电话）由受话人付费的: a collect call 受话人付费电话 She called me collect. 她给我打来个要我来付账的电话。 ☞In British English, we make a reverse-charge call or reverse the charges. 英国英语里打受话人付费电话叫做make a reverse-charge call或reverse the charges。

collected
/kəˈlektɪd ||; kəˈlɛktɪd/adj calm and in control of yourself, your feelings, thoughts, etc 冷静；镇定: She felt cool, calm and collected before the interview. 她面试前感到沉着冷静，不慌不忙。

*collection
/kəˈlekʃn ||; kəˈlɛkʃən/noun
1 [C] a group of objects of a particular type that sb has collected as a hobby 收藏品: a stamp collection 邮票藏品
2 [C,U] the act of getting sth from a place or from people 取；收取；领取: rubbish collections 收来的大量垃圾
3 [C] a group of people or things 一群人；一堆物品: a large collection of papers on the desk 桌上的一大堆文件
4 [C] a number of poems, stories, letters, etc published together in one book 集子: a collection of modern poetry 现代诗集
5 [C] the act of asking for money from a number of people (for charity, in church, etc) 募捐；凑钱: a collection for the poor 济贫募捐
6 [C] a variety of new clothes or items for the home that are specially designed and sold at a particular time 时装；应时物品: Armani's stunning new autumn collection 阿曼尼迷人的秋季新装

collective¹
/kəˈlektɪv ||; kəˈlɛktɪv/adj shared by a group of people together; not individual 集体的: collective responsibility 集体责任 ➔collectively adv We took the decision collectively at a meeting. 这个决定是我们在会议上集体通过的。
collective²
/kəˈlektɪv ||; kəˈlɛktɪv/noun [C] [with.sop] an organization or business that is owned and controlled by the people who work in it 集体企业；合作社

colˌlective ˈbargaining
noun [U] discussions between a TRADE UNION(= an organization that protects the rights of workers)and an employer about the pay and working conditions of the union members （劳方与资方的）集体谈判

colˌlective ˈnoun
noun [C] (grammar语法) a SINGULAR noun, such as ‘committee’ or ‘team’, that refers to a group of people, animals or things and, in British English, can be used with either a SINGULAR or a plural verb 集体名词（如committee或team，在英国英语中可与单数或复数动词连用）

collector
/kəˈlektə(r) ||; kəˈlɛktɚ/noun [C] (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) a person who collects things as a hobby or as part of his/her job 收藏者；收集者: a stamp collector 集邮者 a ticket/rent/tax collector 收票╱收租╱收税员

*college
/ˈkɒlɪdʒ ||; ˈkɑlɪdʒ/noun
1 [C,U] an institution where you can study after you leave school (at the age of 16) 学院；高等学校；大学: an art college 艺术学院 a sixth-form college (= an institution where pupils aged 16 to 18 can prepare for A Levels) （16至18岁学生准备高级程度考试的）六年级学校 She's studying Spanish at the college of further education (= a college that is not a university where people who have left school can study). 她在进修学院学习西班牙语。
We talk about college, without the, when we mean that somebody is attending a college or university as a student. He's at college in York. She's going to college in October. but not if somebody goes there for any other reason I went to an art exhibition at the college last night. 如果说某人上大学，college前面就不用the：He's at college in York. 他在约克念大学。She's going to college in October.她十月份上大学。前面有the则用于念书以外的目的：I went to an art exhibition at the college last night.昨晚我去参观那所大学举办的艺术展览。
2 [C] (in Britain) one of the separate institutions into which certain universities are divided （英国某些大学分出来的）学院: Kings College, London 伦敦大学国王学院
3 [C] (in the US) a university, or part of one, where students can study for a degree （美国）大学；可修学位课程的大学学院

collide
/kəˈlaɪd ||; kəˈlaɪd/verb [I] collide (with sb/sth) to crash; to hit sb/sth very hard while moving 相撞: He ran along the corridor and collided with his teacher. 他沿着走廊跑，与老师撞了个满怀。

collie
/ˈkɒli ||; ˈkɑlɪ/noun [C] a type of dog with a long pointed nose and hair that can be either long or short. They are popular as pets and are also used to control sheep on farms. 柯利犬﹙可作宠物或牧羊犬﹚

colliery
/ˈkɒliəri ||; ˈkɑljərɪ/noun [C] (plural collieries) (especially Brit 尤为英) a coal mine and its buildings 煤矿井；矿山；煤矿场

collision
/kəˈlɪʒn ||; kəˈlɪʒən/noun [C,U] a crash; an occasion when things or people collide 相撞: It was a head-on collision and the driver was killed instantly. 两车迎头相撞，司机当场死亡。 be on a collision course (with sb/sth)
1 to be in a situation which is certain to end in a disagreement or argument 沿着导致冲突的轨迹发展: I'm not surprised they're arguing -- they've been on a collision course over money all week. 他们发生争吵我毫不意外，一个星期来他们一直为了钱而闹意见。
2 to be moving in a direction which is certain to cause a crash 沿着碰撞的航向行驶: The ship was on a collision course with an iceberg. 那条船沿着与冰山相撞的航向行驶。

collocate
/ˈkɒləkeɪt ||; ˈkɑloˌket/verb [I] collocate (with sth) (used about words 指词) to be often used together in a language 经常搭配使用；组合: ‘Bitter’ collocates with ‘enemies’ but ‘sour’ does not. bitter可和enemies构成词组，sour却不行。 collocate /ˈkɒləkət ||; ˈkɑləkət/ noun [C]: ‘Bitter’ and ‘enemies’ are collocates. bitter和enemies可以构成词组。

collocation
/ˌkɒləˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑləˈkeʃən/noun [C] a combination of words in a language, that happens very often and more frequently than would happen by chance 词组；搭配: A ‘resounding success’ and a ‘crying shame’ are English collocations. resounding success和crying shame是英语词组。

colloquial
/kəˈləʊkwiəl ||; kəˈlokwɪəl/adj (used about words, phrases, etc) used in spoken conversation, not in formal situations （指词语、词组等）口语的 ➔colloquially /-kwiəli ||; -kwɪəlɪ/ adv

colloquialism
/kəˈləʊkwiəlɪzəm ||; kəˈlokwɪəlˌɪzəm/noun [C] a word or phrase that is used in conversation but not in formal speech or writing 口语用词；口语说法

collusion
/kəˈlu:ʒn ||; kəˈluʒən/noun [U] (formal 正式) secret agreement, especially in order to do sth dishonest 共谋╱勾结╱串通﹙尤指为了干不正派的事﹚: The drugs were brought into the country with the collusion of customs officials. 在海关官员的同谋下，毒品运进了这个国家。

cologne
/kəˈləʊn ||; kəˈlon/ =EAU DE COLOGNE

colon
/ˈkəʊlən ||; ˈkolən/noun[C]
1 the mark (:) used before a list, an explanation, an example, etc 冒号
2 the lower part of the tube in your body(intestine)that carries food away from your stomach to the place where it leaves your body(anus) 结肠 ☞picture at body 见body插图

colonel
/ˈkɜ:nl ||; ˈkɝnḷ/noun [C] an officer of a high level in the army 上校

colonial
/kəˈləʊniəl ||; kəˈlonɪəl/adj connected with or belonging to a country that controls another country (colony) 殖民地的；拥有殖民地的: Spain used to be a major colonial power. 西班牙以往是个殖民强国。

colonialism
/kəˈləʊniəlɪzəm ||; kəˈlonɪəlˌɪzəm/noun [U] the practice by which a powerful country controls another country or countries, in order to become richer 殖民主义

colonist
/ˈkɒlənɪst ||; ˈkɑlənɪst/noun [C] a person who goes to live in a country that has become a colony 殖民地开拓者

colonize
/ˈkɒlənaɪz ||; ˈkɑləˌnaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to take control of another country or place and make it a colony 殖民化；使成为殖民地 ➔colonization(also -isation) /ˌkɒlənaɪˈzeɪʃn; US -nɪˈz- ||; ˌkɑlənəˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

colonnade
/ˌkɒləˈneɪd ||; ˌkɑləˈned/noun [C] a row of stone columns with equal spaces between them, usually supporting a roof 石柱廊

colony
/ˈkɒləni ||; ˈkɑlənɪ/noun [C] (plural colonies)
1 a country or area that is ruled by another, more powerful country 殖民地
2 [with.sop] a group of people who go to live permanently in another country but keep their own habits and traditions 侨民
3 a group of the same type of animals, insects or plants living or growing in the same place 一同生长的一群同类动物、昆虫或植物；群体；集群: a colony of ants 一个蚂蚁群

color
(US 美) =COLOUR

coloratura
/ˌkɒlərəˈtʊərə ||; ˌkɑlərəˈtυrə/noun [U] (in music) complicated passages for a singer, for example in opera （音乐）花腔

colossal
/kəˈlɒsl ||; kəˈlɑsḷ/adj extremely large 庞大的: a colossal building 巨大的建筑 a colossal amount of money 一大笔钱

*colour¹
/ˈkʌlə(r) ||; ˈkʌlɚ/ (US 美 color) noun
1 [C,U] the fact that sth is red, green, yellow, blue, etc 颜色: ‘What colour is your car?’ ‘Red.’ “你的汽车是什么颜色的？”“红色。” What colours do the Swedish team play in? 瑞典队的队衣是什么颜色的？ a dark/deep colour 深色；浓色 a bright colour 鲜艳的颜色 a light/pale colour 浅色；淡色 Those flowers certainly give the room a bit of colour. 那些鲜花令房间生色不少。
We say that a thing is a certain colour, not that it has a colour. 说某物是某种颜色用is，不用has。
2 [U] the use of all the colours, not just black and white 彩色: All the pictures in the book are in colour. 书中的插图都是彩色的。 a colour television 彩色电视机
3 [U] a red or pink colour in your face, particularly when it shows how healthy you are or that you are embarrassed 血色: You look much better now, you've got a bit more colour. 你现在看上去好多了，面色也红润一些了。 Colour flooded her face when she thought of what had happened. 她想起发生的事，脸上就泛起红晕。
4 [U] interesting or exciting details 活力: It's a busy area, full of activity and colour. 这是个繁华的地区，十分热闹，充满生气。
off colour ill 不舒服 with flying colours→FLYING
*colour²
/ˈkʌlə(r) ||; ˈkʌlɚ/ (US 美 color) verb [T]
1 to put colour on sth, for example by painting it 着色: Colour the picture with your crayons. 用蜡笔给这幅图画着色。 The area coloured yellow on the map is desert. 地图上的黄色部份是沙漠。
2 to influence thoughts, opinions, etc 影响（思想、意见等）: You shouldn't let one bad experience colour your attitude to everything. 不该因一次不顺心就改变自己对所有事物的态度。
colour sth in to fill a shape, a picture, etc with colour using pencils, paint, etc 填色: The children were colouring in pictures of animals. 孩子们正把动物图画填上颜色。

ˈcolour-blind
adj unable to see certain colours, especially red and green 色盲的

*coloured
/ˈkʌləd ||; ˈkʌlɚd/ (US 美 colored) adj
1 having colour or a particular colour 有颜色的；某种颜色的: a coffee-coloured dress 咖啡色连衣裙 brightly-coloured lights 灿烂的灯光
2 (used about a person) belonging to a race that does not have white skin （指人）有色人种的 ☞This word is considered offensive nowadays. To refer to a person belonging to a particular racial group, you should use black, Asian, etc as appropriate. 现今认为这个词意带冒犯。说人属于某个种族，用black（黑人）、Asian（亚洲人）等比较合适。

colour fast ( US 美 colourfast)
adj material that is colourfast will not change or lose colour when it is washed 不退色的；不变色的

colourful
/ˈkʌləfl ||; ˈkʌlɚfəl/ (US 美 colorful) adj
1 with bright colours; full of colour 鲜艳的；色彩缤纷的: a colourful shirt 鲜艳的衬衫
2 full of interest or excitement 生动的；刺激的；多彩多姿的: a colourful story 饶有趣味的故事 He has a rather colourful past. 他过去的生活相当多姿多彩。

colouring
/ˈkʌlərɪŋ ||; ˈkʌlərɪŋ/ (US 美 coloring) noun
1 [U] the colour of a person's hair, skin, etc 人的发色、肤色等: to have fair/dark colouring 皮肤白皙／浅黑
2 [C,U] a substance that is used to give a particular colour to sth, especially food 色料，色素（尤指加进食物的）

colourless
/ˈkʌlələs ||; ˈkʌlɚləs/ (US 美 colorless) adj
1 without any colour 无色的: a colourless liquid, like water 一种像水的无色液体
2 not interesting or exciting; dull 枯燥乏味

ˈcolour scheme
noun [C] the way in which colours are arranged, especially in a room 色彩调配（尤指房间的）

colt
/kəʊlt ||; kolt/noun [C] a young male horse 公驹；小雄马 ☞Look at filly. 参看filly。

*column
/ˈkɒləm ||; ˈkɑləm/noun[C]
1 a tall solid vertical post made of stone, supporting or decorating a building or standing alone 石柱；支柱: Nelson's Column is a monument in London. 纳尔逊石柱是伦敦的一座纪念碑。
2 something that has the shape of a column 柱状物: a column of smoke (=smoke rising straight up) 一柱烟
3 one of the vertical sections into which a printed page, especially in a newspaper, is divided 栏（尤指报纸的）
4 a piece of writing in a newspaper or magazine that is part of a regular series or always written by the same writer ﹙报纸﹑杂志上的﹚专栏: the travel/gossip column 旅游╱闲谈专栏
5 a series of numbers written one under the other 纵列数字: to add up a column of figures 把纵列数字加起来
6 a long line of people, vehicles, etc, one following behind another 一列（人、车等）: a column of troops 一列士兵

columnist
/ˈkɒləmnɪst ||; ˈkɑləmnɪst/noun [C] a journalist who writes regular articles in a newspaper or magazine 专栏作家: a gossip columnist 闲谈专栏作家

coma
/ˈkəʊmə ||; ˈkomə/noun [C] a deep unconscious state, often lasting for a long time and caused by serious illness or injury 昏迷

comatose
/ˈkəʊmətəʊs ||; ˈkoməˌtos/adj
1 (informal 非正式) deeply asleep 昏睡的；沉睡的: He had drunk a bottle of vodka and was comatose. 他喝了一瓶伏特加，现在昏睡不醒。
2 (medical医学) deeply unconscious; in a coma 昏迷的

*comb¹
/kəʊm ||; kom/noun
1 [C] a flat piece of metal or plastic with teeth that you use for making your hair tidy 梳子
2 [C] [usu.sing] an act of combing the hair 梳头: Give your hair a comb before you go out. 把头发梳一下再出去。
comb²
/kəʊm ||; kom/verb[T]
1 to make your hair tidy using a comb 梳头
2 comb sth (for sb/sth) to search an area carefully 彻底搜查: Police are combing the woodland for the murder weapon. 警察正在林子里仔细搜查杀人凶器。

combat¹
/ˈkɒmbæt ||; ˈkɑmbæt/noun [C,U] a fight, especially in war 战斗: unarmed combat (= without weapons) 徒手搏斗
combat²
/ˈkɒmbæt ||; ˈkɑmbæt/verb [T] to fight against sth; to try to stop or defeat sth 对抗；抵抗；打击: to combat terrorism 打击恐怖活动 new medicines to combat heart disease 对付心脏病的新药

combatant
/ˈkɒmbətənt ||; ˈkɑmbətənt/noun [C] a person who takes part in fighting, especially in war 战斗人员；战士

*combination
/ˌkɒmbɪˈneɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmbəˈneʃən/noun [C,U] a number of people or things mixed or joined together; a mixture 组合；混合: The team manager still hasn't found the right combination of players. 领队仍未得出合适的选手搭配。 On this course, you may study French in combination with Spanish or Italian. 本课程的学员除法语外，也可同时修读西班牙语或意大利语。

combiˈnation lock
noun [C] a type of lock which can only be opened by using a particular series of numbers or letters 密码锁

*combine¹
/kəmˈbaɪn ||; kəmˈbaɪn/verb
1 [I,T] combine (with sb/sth) to join or mix two or more things together 结合: The two organizations combined to form one company. 两个机构合并为一家新公司。 Bad planning, combined with bad luck, led to the company's collapse. 计划不周，加上运气不好，导致这家公司倒闭。
2 [T] combine A and/with B to do or have two or more things at the same time 兼有: This car combines speed and reliability. 这部汽车既快又可靠。
combine²
/ˈkɒmbaɪn ||; ˈkɑmbaɪn/ (brit also 英亦作 ˌcombine ˈharvester) noun [C] a large farm machine that both cuts corn and separates the grain from the rest of the plant 联合收割机 ☞Look at harvest. 参看harvest。

combined
/kəmˈbaɪnd ||; kəmˈbaɪnd/adj done by a number of people joining together, resulting from the joining of two or more things 结合的；联合的: The combined efforts of the emergency services prevented a major disaster. 各紧急应变部门通力合作，防止了一场大灾难。

combustible
/kəmˈbʌstəbl ||; kəmˈbʌstəbḷ/adj able to begin burning easily 易燃的；可燃的

combustion
/kəmˈbʌstʃən ||; kəmˈbʌstʃən/noun [U] the process of burning 燃烧

*come
/kʌm ||; kʌm/verb [I] (past tense came /keɪm ||; kem/ past participle come)
1 to move to or towards the person who is speaking or the place that sb is talking about 来: Come here, please. 请过来。 Come and see what I've found. 过来看我找到了什么。 I hope you can come to my party. 希望你能光临我的晚会。 They're coming to stay for a week. 他们要来住一个星期。 The children came running into the room. 孩子们跑进房间。
2 come (to...) to arrive somewhere or reach a particular place or time 到: What time are you coming home? 你什么时候回家？ Has the newspaper come yet? 报纸来了没有？ After a few hours in the jungle, we came to a river. 我们在丛林里走了几个小时，然后到达一条河。 Her hair comes down to her waist. 她的头发一直披到腰部。 The water in the pool came up to our knees. 池里的水有膝盖那么深。 The time has come to say goodbye. 是该告辞的时候了。
3 to be in a particular position in a series 在（某位置）: March comes after February. 二月之后是三月。 Charlie came second in the exam. 查利考了第二名。 I can't wait to find out what comes next in the story. 我急着想知道故事的下一个情节。
4 come in sth to be available 有: This blouse comes in a choice of four colours. 这款女衬衫有四种颜色。 Do these trousers come in a larger size? 这种裤子有大一点的尺寸吗？
5 to be produced by or from sth 来自（某事物）: Wool comes from sheep. 羊毛来自绵羊。
6 to become open or loose 松开: Your blouse has come undone. 你衬衫的扣子松开了。 Her hair has come untied. 她的头发没有扎住。
7 come to do sth used for talking about how, why or when sth happened （用于表示某事如何、为何、何时发生）: How did you come to lose your passport? 你是怎样把护照给弄丢的？
8 come to/into sth to reach a particular state 到达（某种状况）: We were all sorry when the holiday came to an end. 假期结束时，我们都感到很遗憾。 The military government came to power in a coup d'état. 军政府在一次政变中上台。
come and go to be present for a short time and then go away 来得快去得快: The pain in my ear comes and goes. 我耳朵一会儿疼一下。 come easily/naturally to sb to be easy for sb to do 轻而易举；对某人来说不难: Apologizing does not come easily to her. 她不到不得已是不会道歉的。 come to nothing;not come to anything to fail; to not be successful 徒劳无功；徒然；失败: Unfortunately, all his efforts came to nothing. 叫人失望的是，他怎么努力都是白搭。 how come...?(informal 非正式) why or how 怎么: How come you're back so early? 你怎么回来得这么早？ to come (used after a noun 用于名词后) in the future 未来的: You'll regret it in years to come. 将来你准会后悔的。 when it comes to sth/to doing sth when it is a question of sth 至于；谈到: When it comes to value for money, these prices are hard to beat. 至于说划不划得来，这样的价钱到哪里去找？ For other idioms containing come, look at the entries for the nouns, adjectives, etc, for example come to a head is at head. 其他含come的习语，参看有关名词、形容词等词条，如come to a head可参看词条head。 come about to happen 发生: How did this situation come about? 弄成这个地步，怎么搞的？ come across/over (as sth) to make an impression of a particular type 给人以…的印象: Elizabeth comes across as being rather shy. 伊莉萨白看上去有点怕羞。 come across sb/sth to meet or find sb/sth by chance 碰见；偶然遇到: I came across this book in a second-hand shop. 我在旧货店无意中看到这本书。 come along
1 to arrive or appear 到达；出现: An old man was coming along the road. 路上来了一位老人。 When the right job comes along, I'll apply for it. 只要有合适的工作出现，我就会申请。
2 =COME ON(2)
3 =COME ON(3)
come apart to break into pieces 碎；裂 come away (from sth) to become loose or separated from sth 松开: The wallpaper is coming away from the wall in the corner. 墙角上的壁纸快要脱下来了。 come away with sth to leave a place with a particular opinion or feeling 怀着某种感想或情绪离开某地: We came away with a very favourable impression of Cambridge. 我们带着美好的印象离开了剑桥。 come back
1 to return 回来: I don't know what time I'll be coming back. 我不知道什么时候才会回来。
2 to become popular or fashionable again 再度流行或时兴: Flared trousers are coming back again. 喇叭裤又时兴起来。
come back (to sb) to be remembered 重现脑海: When I went to Italy again, my Italian started to come back to me. 我再到意大利去的时候，又记起意大利语来了。 come before sb/sth to be more important than sb/sth else 比…重要: Mark feels his family comes before his career. 马克觉得家庭比事业更重要。 come between sb and sb to damage the relationship between two people 损害两人的关系: Arguments over money came between the two brothers. 弟兄俩为了钱财而口角。 come by sth to manage to get sth 设法得到: Fresh vegetables are hard to come by in the winter. 冬天很难找到新鲜蔬菜。 come down
1 to fall down 掉下来: The power lines came down in the storm. 输电线在风暴中掉落下来。
2 (used about an aircraft or spacecraft) to land （指飞机或航天器）降落，着陆: The helicopter came down in a field. 直升机降落在田里。
3 (used about prices) to become lower （指价格）下降: The price of land has come down in the past year. 过去一年地价下跌。
come down to sth/to doing sth(informal 非正式) to be able to be explained by a single important point 归根结底；总而言之: It all comes down to having the right qualifications. 一句话，必须有合适的资格。 come down with sth to become ill with sth 害…病: I think I'm coming down with flu. 我想我患感冒了。 come forward to offer help 给予援手；挺身而出: The police are asking witnesses to come forward. 警方呼吁目击者出来作证。 come from... to live in or have been born in a place 居于；生于: Where do you come from originally? 你的老家在哪里？ come from (doing) sth to be the result of sth 是…的结果: ‘I'm tired.’ ‘That comes from all the late nights you've had.’ “我累了。”“这是你这几天熬夜熬出来的。” come in
1 to enter a place 进入（某个地方）: Come in and sit down. 进来坐吧。
2 (used about the tides of the sea) to move towards the land and cover the beach （指潮汐）涨潮 ☞Look at tide ¹. 参看tide^1。
3 to become popular or fashionable 时兴；流行: Punk fashions came in in the seventies. 七十年代时兴鬅客服饰。
4 (used about news or information) to be received ﹙指消息﹑信息﹚传来: Reports are coming in of fighting in Beirut. 贝鲁特发生冲突的消息不断传来。
come in for sth to receive sth, especially sth unpleasant 受到（尤指令人不快的事情）: The government came in for a lot of criticism. 政府受到诸多批评。 come of sth/of doing sth to be the result of sth 是…的结果: We've written to several companies asking for help but nothing has come of it yet. 我们已给几家公司去信请求帮忙，但直到目前为止仍未有回音。 come off
1 to be able to be removed 能取下；能拿掉: Does the hood come off? 这风帽拿得下来吗？
2 (informal 非正式) to be successful 成功: The deal seems unlikely to come off. 这笔交易看来难以做成。
3 (informal 非正式) (followed by an adverb 后接副词) to be in a good, bad, etc situation as a result of sth 由于…而处于好╱坏等情况: Unfortunately, Dennis came off worst in the fight. 令人遗憾的是，丹尼斯在比赛中敬陪末座。
come off (sth)
1 to fall off sth 从…掉下: Kim came off her bicycle and broke her leg. 金骑自行车的时候跌了一交，把腿摔断了。
2 to become removed from sth 脱落: One of the legs has come off this table. 这桌子掉了一条腿。
come off it(spoken 口语) used to say that you do not believe sb/sth or that you strongly disagree with sb （用于表示不相信或很不同意）得了吧: ‘I thought it was quite a good performance.’ ‘Oh, come off it -- it was awful!’ “这表演倒挺精彩的。”“什么精彩，一点也不好看！” come on
1 to start to act, play in a game of sport, etc 出场: The audience jeered every time the villain came on. 每当坏蛋出场，观众都要嘘他。 The substitute came on in the second half. 替补队员在下半场出场。
2 (also come along) to make progress or to improve 进展；进步: Your English is coming on nicely. 你的英语进步很快。
3 (also Come along!) used to tell sb to hurry up, try harder, etc （表示催促、鼓励等）加把劲: Come on or we'll be late! 快点儿，不然我们要迟到了。
4 to begin 开始: I think I've got a cold coming on. 看来我是着凉了。
come out
1 to appear; to be published 出现；发表: The rain stopped and the sun came out. 雨停了，太阳出来了。 The report came out in 2000. 报告发表于2000年。
2 to become known 为人所知: It was only after his death that the truth came out. 他死后才真相大白。
3 (used about a photograph, etc) to be produced successfully （指照片等）显影成功，冲洗出来
come out (of sth) to be removed from sth 从…除掉: Red wine stains don't come out easily. 要洗掉红葡萄酒的污渍可不容易。 come out against sth to say in public that you do not like or agree with sth 公开反对某事 come out in sth to become covered in spots, etc 长出斑点等: Heat makes him come out in a rash. 他热出痱子来了。 come out with sth to say sth unexpectedly 突然说出…: The children came out with all kinds of stories. 孩子们说的五花八门，都不一样。 come over=COME ACROSS/OVER come over (to...) (from...) to visit people or a place a long way away 访问远处的人或地方: They've invited us to come over to Australia for a holiday. 他们已邀请我们到澳大利亚去度假。 come over sb (used about a feeling) to affect sb （指感觉）影响某人: A feeling of despair came over me. 我感到万分沮丧。 come round
1 (used about an event that happens regularly) to happen （指经常发生的事）发生: The end of the holidays always comes round very quickly. 假期总是很快就结束。
2 (also come to) to become conscious again 苏醒 [OPP] pass out 反义词为pass out
come round (to...) to visit a person or place not far away 到访 come round (to sth) to change your opinion so that you agree with sb/sth 转而同意: They finally came round to our way of thinking. 他们终于接受我们的看法。 come through (used about news, information, etc) to arrive （指消息、信息等）传来: The football results are just coming through. 足球赛果马上就收到。 come through (sth) to escape injury or death in a dangerous situation, illness, etc 经历险境、疾病等而未受伤或死亡；熬过大难: to come through an enemy attack 熬过了敌人的进攻 come to=COME ROUND(2) come to sth
1 to equal or total a particular amount 合共；合计；数量相当于: The bill for the meal came to £35. 饭钱合计35英镑。
2 to result in a bad situation 陷入恶劣境地: We will sell the house to pay our debts if we have to but we hope it won't come to that. 必要时我们会把房子卖了还债，但愿我们不致落到这种地步。
come under to be included in a particular section, department, etc 归入: Garages that sell cars come under ‘car dealers’ in the telephone book. 电话簿将有车出售的汽车服务站归入“汽车商”一栏。 come up
1 to happen or be going to happen in the future 发生或将要发生: Something's come up at work so I won't be home until late tonight. 我有些工作上的事情要办，所以今晚要很晚才回家。
2 to be discussed or mentioned 被讨论或提及: The subject of religion came up. （会中）谈到了宗教问题。
3 (used about the sun and moon) to rise （指太阳、月亮）升起
4 (used about a plant) to appear above the soil （指植物）长出地面
come up against sb/sth to find a problem or difficulty that you have to deal with 遇到（难题） come up to sth to be as good as usual or as necessary 达到平时或所需的水平: This piece of work does not come up to your usual standard. 这件作品比不上你通常的水平。 come up with sth to find an answer or solution to sth 找到答案或解决办法: Engineers have come up with new ways of saving energy. 工程技术人员想出了节约能源的新方法。

comeback
/ˈkʌmbæk ||; ˈkʌmˌbæk/noun [C] a return to a position of strength or importance that you had before 东山再起: The former world champion is hoping to make a comeback. 这位前世界冠军希望东山再起。

comedian
/kəˈmi:diən ||; kəˈmidɪən/ (also comic) noun [C] a person whose job is to entertain people and make them laugh, for example by telling jokes 喜剧演员；丑角 ☞A female comedian is sometimes called a comedienne. 女喜剧演员有时候叫做comedienne。

comedown
/ˈkʌmdaʊn ||; ˈkʌmˌdaυn/noun [C] [usu.sing] (informal 非正式) a loss of importance or social position 失去重要性或社会地位；衰落；没落: It's a bit of a comedown for her having to move to a smaller house. 不得不搬进较小的房子里住，使她有点失落感。

comedy
/ˈkɒmədi ||; ˈkɑmədɪ/noun
1 [C] (plural comedies) an amusing play, film, etc that has a happy ending 喜剧 ☞Look at tragedy. 参看tragedy。
2 [U] the quality of being amusing or making people laugh 喜剧性

comet
/ˈkɒmɪt ||; ˈkɑmɪt/noun [C] an object in space that looks like a bright star with a tail and that moves around the sun 彗星

come-uppance
/kʌmˈʌpəns ||; kʌmˈʌpəns/noun [sing] (informal 非正式) a punishment for sth bad that you have done, that other people feel you really deserve 报应；应有的惩罚: I was glad to see that the bad guy got his come-uppance at the end of the movie. 我很高兴地看到坏蛋在电影结束时得到了应有的惩罚。

*comfort¹
/ˈkʌmfət ||; ˈkʌmfɚt/noun
1 [U] the state of having everything your body needs, or of having a pleasant life 安逸: Most people expect to live in comfort in their old age. 人大都希望能安享晚年。 to travel in comfort 闲适的旅游
2 [U] the feeling of being physically relaxed and in no pain 身体舒服或无痛苦: This car has been specially designed for extra comfort. 这辆汽车经过精心设计，坐起来特别舒适。 [OPP] discomfort 反义词为discomfort
3 [U] help or kindness to sb who is suffering 安慰: I tried to offer a few words of comfort. 我尽量说了几句安慰的话。
4 a comfort (to sb) [sing] a person or thing that helps you when you are very sad or worried 给予安慰的人或物: You've been a real comfort to me. 你的确是我的安慰。
5 [C] something that makes your life easier or more pleasant 使生活舒适的东西: the comforts of home 使家居生活舒适的物品
comfort²
/ˈkʌmfət ||; ˈkʌmfɚt/verb [T] to try to make sb feel less worried or unhappy 安慰: to comfort a crying child 安慰一个哭哭啼啼的小孩子

*comfortable
/ˈkʌmftəbl; US -fərt- ||; ˈkʌmfɚtəbḷ/adj
1 (informal 非正式comfy) that makes you feel physically relaxed and in no pain; that provides you with everything your body needs 舒适的: a comfortable temperature (= not too hot or too cold) 宜人的温度 Sit down and make yourselves comfortable. 请随便坐，别客气。 a comfortable pair of shoes 一双舒服的鞋子 [OPP] opposite uncomfortable 反义词为uncomfortable
2 not having or causing worry, difficulty, etc 安适；自在: He did not feel comfortable in the presence of so many women. 在这么多女人面前，他感到不自在。
3 having or providing enough money for all your needs 生活无忧的；小康的: They are not wealthy but they're quite comfortable. 他们虽然不是富贵人家，但也算得上小康。 ➔comfortably adv Jon was sitting comfortably in the armchair. 乔恩舒服地坐在扶手椅里。 You can't live comfortably on such low wages. 你靠这么低的工资无法过舒服的生活。

comic¹
/ˈkɒmɪk ||; ˈkɑmɪk/adj that makes you laugh; connected with comedy 滑稽的；喜剧的: a comic scene in a play 剧中的滑稽场面
comic²
/ˈkɒmɪk ||; ˈkɑmɪk/noun[C]
1 =COMEDIAN
2 (especially US 尤为美 comic book) a magazine for children that tells stories through pictures 连环画杂志；漫画书

ˈcomic strip
(also strip cartoon) noun [C] a short series of pictures that tell a funny story, for example in a newspaper 连环漫画；连环图画

comical
/ˈkɒmɪkl ||; ˈkɑmɪkḷ/adj that makes you laugh; funny 滑稽的；可笑的 ➔comically /-kli ||; -kḷɪ/ adv

coming
/ˈkʌmɪŋ ||; ˈkʌmɪŋ/noun [C] the moment when sth new arrives or begins 到来: The coming of the computer meant the loss of many jobs. 计算机的出现导致许多人失业。 coming adj We've got a lot of plans for the coming year. 我们来年有许多计划。

comma
/ˈkɒmə ||; ˈkɑmə/noun [C] the mark (,) used for dividing parts of a sentence or items in a list 逗号

*command¹
/kəˈmɑ:nd; US -ˈmænd ||; kəˈmænd/noun
1 [C] an order 命令: The captain's commands must be obeyed without question. 必须服从船长的指挥，不得有异议。
2 [C] (computing计算机技术) an instruction given to a computer （给计算机下的）指令
3 [U] control over sb/sth 控制: Who is in command of the expedition? 谁指挥这次远征？ to take command ofa situation 控制局势
4 [sing] the state of being able to do or use sth well 掌握: She has a good command of French. 她精通法语。
at/by sb's command(formal 正式) because you were ordered by sb 奉行命令: At the command of their officer the troops opened fire. 军官一声命下，士兵立即开火。 be at sb's command to be ready to obey sb 随时待命: I'm completely at your command. 我一切听从您的指示。
*command²
/kəˈmɑ:nd; US -ˈmænd ||; kəˈmænd/verb
1 [I,T] (formal 正式)command (sb to do sth) to tell or order sb to do sth 命令 · I command you to leave now! 我命令你马上离开！
2 command sb/sth [T] to control or be in charge of sb/sth 控制；管辖；指挥: to command a ship/regiment/army 指挥船舰／兵团／军队
3 [T] to deserve and get sth 博得；赢得: The old man commanded great respect. 这位老人家很受尊敬。

commandant
/ˈkɒməndænt ||; ˌkɑmənˈdænt/noun [C] the officer in charge of a particular military group or institution 指挥官；司令

comˌmand eˈconomy
=PLANNED ECONOMY

commandeer
/ˌkɒmənˈdɪə(r) ||; ˌkɑmənˈdɪr/verb [T] to take control or possession of sth for military or police use 征作军用或警用

commander
/kəˈmɑ:ndə(r); US -ˈmæn- ||; kəˈmændɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who controls or is in charge of a military organization or group 指挥官；司令
2 (Brit 英) an officer at a fairly high level in the navy 海军中校

comˌmander-in-ˈchief
noun [C] (abbr C-in-C) (plural commanders-in-chief) the officer who commands all the armed forces of a country or all its forces in a particular area 总司令；最高统帅

commanding
/kəˈmɑ:ndɪŋ ||; kəˈmændɪŋ/adj
1 in charge or having control of sb/sth 处于控制或支配地位的: Who is your commanding officer? 谁是你们的指挥官？
2 strong or powerful 威严的；有权威的: to speak in a commanding tone of voice 用威严的口气说话

commandment
/kəˈmɑ:ndmənt; US -ˈmænd- ||; kəˈmændmənt/ (also Commandment) noun [C] (formal 正式) one of the ten important laws that Christian people should obey 十诫之一

commando
/kəˈmɑ:ndəʊ; US -ˈmæn- ||; kəˈmændo/noun [C] (plural commandos) one of a group of soldiers who is trained to make sudden attacks in enemy areas 突击队员

commemorate
/kəˈmeməreɪt ||; kəˈmɛməˌret/verb [T] to exist or take place in order to make people remember a special event 纪念: a statue commemorating all the soldiers who died in the last war 为纪念上一次战争中所有阵亡战士而竖立的塑像 ➔commemoration /kəˌmeməˈreɪʃn ||; kəˌmɛməˈreʃən/ noun [C,U] The concerts were held in commemoration of the 200th anniversary of Mozart's death. 这些音乐会都是为纪念莫扎特逝世二百周年而举办的。

commence
/kəˈmens ||; kəˈmɛns/verb [I,T] (formal 正式)commence sth/doing sth to start or begin 开始 ➔commencement noun [C,U]

commend
/kəˈmend ||; kəˈmɛnd/verb [T] (formal 正式) to say officially that sb/sth is very good 嘉许；赞扬: Dean was commended for his excellent work. 迪安工作表现出色，受到嘉许。

commendable
/kəˈmendəbl ||; kəˈmɛndəbḷ/adj (formal 正式) that people think is good 值得称赞的: She acted with commendable honesty and fairness. 她处事诚实而公正，委实令人钦佩。

*comment¹
/ˈkɒment ||; ˈkɑmɛnt/noun [C,U] comment (about/on sth) something that you say or write that gives your opinion or feeling about sth 评论: The chancellor was not available for comment. 当时无法邀得总理发表评论。 I heard someone make a rude commentabout my clothes. 我听到有人对我的衣着发表难听的议论。 ☞Look at observation and remark. 参看observation及remark。 no comment used in reply to a question when you do not want to say anything at all （用于响应不愿置评的问题）无可奉告: ‘Mr President, how do you feel about these latest developments?’ ‘No comment.’ “总统先生，您对事态的最新发展有什么看法？”“无可奉告。”
comment²
/ˈkɒment ||; ˈkɑmɛnt/verb [I,T] comment (on sth) to say what you think or feel about sth 评论: Several people commented on how ill David looked. 有几个人都说过戴维的脸色怎样难看，像是病了。

commentary
/ˈkɒməntri; US -terɪ ||; ˈkɑmənˌtɛrɪ/noun (plural commentaries)
1 [C,U] a spoken description on the radio or television of sth as it is happening （电台或电视台的）实况报道，现场评述: a sports commentary 体育比赛的实况报道
2 [C] a written explanation or discussion of sth such as a book or play 评注
3 [C] something that shows what sth is like 说明；写照: This drug scandal is a sad commentary on the state of the sport. 这起兴奋剂丑闻是体坛现状的一个可悲写照。

commentate
/ˈkɒmənteɪt ||; ˈkɑmənˌtet/verb [I] commentate (on sth) to give a spoken description on the radio or television of sth as it is happening （在电台或电视台）作实况报道，作现场评述

commentator
/ˈkɒmənteɪtə(r) ||; ˈkɑmənˌtetɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who commentates on sth 实况广播员；评述员；评论员: a sports commentator 体育评论员
2 a person who gives his/her opinion about sth on the radio, on television or in a newspaper 时事评论员: a political commentator 政治评论员

commerce
/ˈkɒmɜ:s ||; ˈkɑmɝs/noun [U] the business of buying and selling things 商业

*commercial¹
/kəˈmɜ:ʃl ||; kəˈmɝʃəl/adj
1 connected with buying and selling goods and services 商业的: commercial law 商业法
2 making or trying to make money （想要）赚钱的: Although it won a lot of awards, the film was not a commercial success. 这部影片虽然获得多个奖项，但叫好不叫座。
3 selling sth or sold in large quantities to the public 大量出售的: commercial airlines 商业航空公司 commercial products 商品 ➔commercially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv The factory was closed down because it was no longer commercially viable. 丧失了竞销能力，这家工厂只好关门。
commercial²
/kəˈmɜ:ʃl ||; kəˈmɝʃəl/noun [C] an advertisement on television or the radio （电台或电视台的）广告: a commercial break (= a space between television programmes when commercials are shown) （电视节目中间插播广告的）广告时间

commercialism
/kəˈmɜ:ʃəlɪzəm ||; kəˈmɝʃəlˌɪzəm/noun [U] the attitude that making money is more important than anything else 赚钱至上的观念；唯利是图；商业化

commercialize
/kəˈmɜ:ʃəlaɪz ||; kəˈmɝʃəlˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to try to make money out of sth, even if it means spoiling it 商业化: Christmas has become very commercialized over recent years. 最近几年圣诞节的商业味道越来越浓。 ➔commercialization(also -isation) /kəˌmɜ:ʃəlaɪˈzeɪʃn ||; kəˌmɝʃəlaɪˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

commiserate
/kəˈmɪzəreɪt ||; kəˈmɪzəˌret/verb [I] (formal 正式)commiserate (with sb) (on/over/for sth) to feel sorry for and show understanding towards sb who is unhappy or in difficulty 同情；怜悯: I commiserated with Debbie over losing her job. 戴比失业了，我很同情她。

commission¹
/kəˈmɪʃn ||; kəˈmɪʃən/noun
1 oftenCommission [C] [with.sop] an official group of people who are asked to find out about sth 调查委员会；调查团: A Commission was appointed to investigate the causes of the accident. 成立了委员会来调查事故的起因。
2 [C,U] money that you get for selling sth 佣金: Agents get 10% commission on everything they sell. 代理商收取相当于货价一成的佣金。
3 [C,U] money that a bank, etc charges for providing a particular service （银行等提供服务收取的）回扣，佣金
4 [C] a formal request to an artist, writer, etc to produce a piece of work 委托（艺术家、作家等完成某项作品）: He received a commission to write a play for the festival. 他受托为这个会演撰写剧本。
commission²
/kəˈmɪʃn ||; kəˈmɪʃən/verb [T] commission sb (to do sth);commission sth (from sb) to ask an artist, writer, etc to do a piece of work 委托（艺术家、作家等完成某项作品）: to commission an architect to design a building 委托建筑师设计一幢大楼

commissionaire
/kəˌmɪʃəˈneə(r) ||; kəˌmɪʃənˈɛr/noun [C] (Brit 英) (old-fashioned 旧) a person in uniform whose job is to stand at the entrance to a hotel, theatre, cinema, etc and open the door for visitors （在旅馆、剧院、影院等处穿制服为来人开门的）看门人 [SYN]A more common word is doorman. 较常用doorman。

commissioner
/kəˈmɪʃənə(r) ||; kəˈmɪʃənɚ/noun [C] the head of the police or of a government department in some countries （某些国家的）警察局局长，政府部门的长官 ☞Look at High Commissioner. 参看High Commissioner。

*commit
/kəˈmɪt ||; kəˈmɪt/verb [T] (committing;committed)
1 to do sth bad or illegal 犯（罪）；做（不好的事）: to commit a crime 犯罪 to commit suicide 自杀
2 commit sb/yourself (to sth/to doing sth) to make a definite agreement or promise to do sth 承诺（做某事）: I can't commit myself to helping you tomorrow. 我明天不一定能帮你的忙。
3 commit yourself (on sth) to make a decision or give an opinion publicly so that it is then difficult to change it 作出决定；公开表态: I'm not going to commit myself on who will win the election. 我不便就谁会在选举中获胜发表看法。 ☞Look at noncommittal. 参看noncommittal。
4 (formal 正式) to decide to use money or time in a certain way 决定把（金钱、时间）投入: The government has committed £2 billion to education. 政府已决定将20亿英镑投入教育事业。
5 (formal 正式)commit sb to sth to send sb to a prison, mental hospital, etc 送进（监狱、精神病院等）

commitment
/kəˈmɪtmənt ||; kəˈmɪtmənt/noun
1 [U]: commitment (to sth) being prepared to give a lot of your time and attention to sth because you believe it is right or important （将时间、精力等）集中投入，投注: I admire Gary's commitment to protecting the environment. 我很赞赏加里对保护环境的献身精神。
2 [C,U] a promise or agreement to do sth; a responsibility 承诺；责任: When I make a commitment I always stick to it. 一旦作出承诺，我总能信守。 Helen now works fewer hours because of family commitments. 因为要照顾家庭，海伦现已缩短了工作时间。

committed
/kəˈmɪtɪd ||; kəˈmɪtɪd/adj committed (to sth) prepared to give a lot of your time and attention to sth because you believe it is right or important 打算投入很多时间和精力（干正确、重要的事）: The company is committed to providing quality products. 公司保证提供优质产品。

*committee
/kəˈmɪti ||; kəˈmɪtɪ/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of people who have been chosen to discuss sth or decide sth 委员会: to be/sit on a committee 担任委员 The planning committee meets/meet twice a week. 规划委员会每周开两次会。

commodity
/kəˈmɒdəti ||; kəˈmɑdətɪ/noun [C] (plural commodities) a product or material that can be bought and sold 商品: Salt was once a very valuable commodity. 食盐一度是非常珍贵的商品。

commodore
/ˈkɒmədɔ:(r) ||; ˈkɑməˌdɔr/noun [C] an officer at a high level in the navy 海军准将

*common¹
/ˈkɒmən ||; ˈkɑmən/adj
1 happening or found often or in many places; usual 常见的；普遍的: Pilot error is the commonest/most common cause of plane crashes. 飞机失事最常见的原因是驾驶不当。 The daisy is a common wild flower. 雏菊是一种常见的野花。 [OPP] uncommon 反义词为uncommon
2 common (to sb/sth) shared by or belonging to two or more people or groups; shared by most or all people 共同的；共通的: This type of behaviour is common to most children of that age. 那个年纪的小孩大多有这种行为。 We have a common interest in gardening. 我们都喜欢园艺。
3 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) not special; ordinary 普通的；一般的: The officers had much better living conditions than the common soldiers. 军官的生活条件要比普通士兵好得多。
4 (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) having or showing a lack of education 粗鄙；没有教养: Don't speak like that. It's common! 不要这样说话，这太没有教养。
be common/public knowledge→KNOWLEDGE
common²
/ˈkɒmən ||; ˈkɑmən/noun [C] an area of open land that anyone can use 公用地 have sth in common (with sb/sth) to share sth with sb/sth else 有共通之处: to have a lot in common with sb 与某人有很多共通之处 in common with sb/sth(formal 正式) in the same way as sb/sth else; like sb/sth 跟…一样: This company, in common with many others, is losing a lot of money. 这家公司跟其他许多公司一样亏损严重。

ˌcommon deˈnominator
noun [C] (mathematics数学) a number that can be divided exactly by all the numbers below the line in a set ofFRACTIONS 公分母 ☞Look at denominator. 参看denominator。

ˌcommon ˈground
noun [U] beliefs, interests, etc that two or more people or groups share 共同基础，共识（比如信念、利益等）

ˌcommon ˈlaw
noun [U] laws in England that are based on customs and on decisions that judges have made, not laws that were made by Parliament 普通法，习惯法（并非由国会制定，而是以法官的裁决为基准的英国法律） ☞Look at case law and statute law. 参看case law及statue law。

ˌcommon-law ˈhusband
noun [C] a man that a woman has lived with for a long time without being married to him, and who has the same rights in law as an official husband （未正式结婚的）同居丈夫

ˌcommon-law ˈwife
noun [C] a woman that a man has lived with for a long time without being married to her, and who has the same rights in law as an official wife （未正式结婚的）同居妻子

commonly
/ˈkɒmənli ||; ˈkɑmənlɪ/adv normally; usually 通常

ˌcommon ˈnoun
noun [C] (grammar语法) a word, such as book or town that refers to an object or a thing but is not the name of a particular person, place or thing 普通名词（非特定人名、地名或事物名，如 book 或 town）

commonplace
/ˈkɒmənpleɪs ||; ˈkɑmənˌples/adj not exciting or unusual; ordinary 寻常；普遍: Foreign travel has become commonplace in recent years. 最近几年到国外旅游已司空见惯。

ˈcommon room
noun [C] a room in a school, university, etc where students or teachers can go to relax when they are not in class （学校里供学生或教师课余休息的）公用休息室

ˌcommon ˈsense
noun [U] the ability to make good sensible decisions or to behave in a sensible way 常识；情理

commotion
/kəˈməʊʃn ||; kəˈmoʃən/noun [sing] [U] great noise or excitement 喧闹；骚动

communal
/kəˈmju:nl;ˈkɒmjənl ||; kəˈmjunḷ; ˈkɑmjυnḷ/adj shared by a group of people 共享的: a communal kitchen 共享厨房

commune
/ˈkɒmju:n ||; ˈkɑmjun/noun [C] [with.sop] a group of people, not from the same family, who live together and share their property and responsibilities 公社（共同生活、共享财产、共负责任，而又并非同属一个家庭的群体）

*communicate
/kəˈmju:nɪkeɪt ||; kəˈmjunəˌket/verb
1 [I,T] to share and exchange information, ideas or feelings with sb 传达；沟通: Parents often have difficulty communicating with their teenage children. 父母与十来岁的子女之间沟通常遇到困难。 Our boss is good at communicating her ideas to the team. 我们的老板善于把她的思想传达给整个班子。
2 [T] (formal 正式) (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to pass a disease from one person or animal to another 传染（疾病）
3 [I] to lead from one place to another 连接: two rooms with a communicating door 两个有门互通的房间

*communication
/kəˌmju:nɪˈkeɪʃn ||; kəˌmjunəˈkeʃən/noun
1 [U] the act of sharing or exchanging information, ideas or feelings 通讯；交流；沟通: Radio is the only means of communication in remote areas. 无线电是边远地区唯一的通讯工具。 We are in regular communication withour head office in New York. 我们与纽约总部经常保持联系。
2 communications [pl] the methods that are used for travelling to and from a place or for sending messages between places 交通；通讯系统；沟通途径: The telephone lines are down so communications are very difficult. 电话线失灵，通讯甚为困难。
3 [C] (formal 正式) a message 消息；音讯: a communication from head office 由总部发来的信息

communicative
/kəˈmju:nɪkətɪv; US -keɪtɪv ||; kəˈmjunəˌketɪv/adj willing and able to talk and share ideas, etc 健谈的: Paolo has excellent communicative skills. 保罗有极好的沟通技巧。

communion
/kəˈmju:niən ||; kəˈmjunjən/noun [U]:
1 (formal 正式) the sharing of thoughts or feelings （思想、感情等的）交流
2 Communion a Christian church ceremony in which people share bread and wine 圣餐；圣体礼

communiqué
/kəˈmju:nɪkeɪ; US kəˌmju:nəˈkeɪ ||; kəˌmjunəˈke/noun [C] (written 书面语) an official statement, especially from a government, a political group, etc （政府、政治团体等的）公报

communism
/ˈkɒmjunɪzəm ||; ˈkɑmjυˌnɪzəm/noun [U] the political system in which the state owns and controls all factories, farms, services etc and aims to treat everyone equally 共产主义 ☞Look at Marxism, socialism and capitalism. 参看Marxism、socialism及capitalism。

communist
/ˈkɒmjənɪst ||; ˈkɑmjənɪst/ (also Communist) noun [C] a person who believes in or supports communism; a member of the Communist Party 共产主义者 ➔communist(also Communist) adj communist sympathies 对共产主义的支持

*community
/kəˈmju:nəti ||; kəˈmjunətɪ/noun (plural communities)
1 the community [sing] all the people who live in a particular place, area, etc when considered as a group 社会；小区: Recent increases in crime have disturbed the whole community. 最近区内罪案增加，居民都颇为担忧。
2 [C] [with.sop] a group of people who have sth in common 有某种共同之处的群体: the Asian community in Britain 英国的亚洲裔居民 the business community 商界
3 [U] the feeling of belonging to a group in the place where you live 归属感: There is a strong sense of community in the neighbourhood. 区内居民有一种强烈的归属感。

comˈmunity centre
noun [C] a building that local people can use for meetings, classes, sports, etc （供区内居民开会、上课、进行体育活动等的）小区中心

comˌmunity ˈservice
noun [U] work helping people in the local community that sb does without being paid, sometimes because he/she has been ordered to do it by a court of law as a punishment 小区服务（无报酬，有时法庭用以惩罚某人）

commutator
/ˈkɒmjuteɪtə(r) ||; ˈkɑmjυˌtetɚ/noun [C] (technical术语)
1 a device that connects a motor to the electricity supply （连结电动机和电源的）转换开关
2 a device for changing the direction in which electricity flows 转向器；整流子

commute
/kəˈmju:t ||; kəˈmjut/verb [I] to travel a long distance from home to work every day （到离住所较远地方去）上班，通勤: A lot of people commute to London from nearby towns. 很多人从邻近的市镇到伦敦上班。 ➔commuter noun [C]

compact
/kəmˈpækt ||; kəmˈpækt/adj small and easy to carry 小型轻便的: a compact camera 袖珍照相机

ˌcompact ˈdisc
=CD

companion
/kəmˈpæniən ||; kəmˈpænjən/noun [C] a person or animal with whom you spend a lot of time or go somewhere 伴侣；同伴: a travelling companion 旅伴

companionship
/kəmˈpæniənʃɪp ||; kəmˈpænjənˌʃɪp/noun [U] the pleasant feeling of having a friendly relationship with sb and not being alone 友谊；陪伴

*company
/ˈkʌmpəni ||; ˈkʌmpənɪ/noun (plural companies)
1 [C] [with.sop] a business organization selling goods or services 公司: The company is/are planning to build a new factory. 这家公司正在打算建一新厂。 ☞In names company is written with a capital letter. The abbreviation is Co. the Walt Disney Company Milton & Co 公司名称中的company以大写字母开头，缩写作Co.：the Walt Disney Company沃尔特．迪斯尼公司·Milton & Co.米尔顿公司
2 [C] [with.sop] a group of actors, singers, dancers, etc 剧团；歌唱团；舞蹈团: a ballet company 芭蕾舞团 the Royal Shakespeare Company 皇家莎士比亚剧团
3 [U] being with a person 陪伴: I always enjoy Rachel's company. 我总是很喜欢有雷切尔作伴儿。 Jeff is very good company (= pleasant to be with). 杰夫是个很好的伴儿。
4 [U] a visitor or visitors 访客: Sorry, I wouldn't have called if I'd known you had company. 对不起，要是我知道你有客人，我就不会打电话了。
keep sb company to go or be with sb so that he/she is not alone 陪伴某人: She was nervous so I went with her to keep her company. 她很紧张，所以我就陪着她一起去了。 part company→PART²

comparable
/ˈkɒmpərəbl ||; ˈkɑmpərəbḷ/adj comparable (to/with sb/sth) of a similar standard or size; that can be compared with sth 相仿的；可比较的: The population of Britain is comparable to that of France. 英国人口跟法国差不多。 A comparable flat in my country would be a lot cheaper. 在我国一间类似的公寓要便宜得多。

comparative¹
/kəmˈpærətɪv ||; kəmˈpærətɪv/adj
1 that compares things of the same kind 比较的: a comparative study of systems of government 不同政治制度的比较研究
2 compared with sth else or with what is usual or normal 相对的: He had problems with the written exam but passed the practical exam with comparative ease. 他考笔试成绩不太好，但考实践课则比较顺利过关。
3 (grammar语法) (used about the form of an adjective or adverb) expressing a greater amount, quality, size, etc （指形容词或副词形式）比较级的: ‘Hotter’ and ‘more quickly’ are the comparative forms of ‘hot’ and ‘quickly’. hotter和more quickly分别是hot和quickly的比较级。
comparative²
/kəmˈpærətɪv ||; kəmˈpærətɪv/noun [C] (grammar语法) the form of an adjective or adverb that expresses a greater amount, quality, size, etc （形容词或副词的）比较级形式: ‘Bigger’ is the comparative of ‘big’. bigger是big的比较级。

comparatively
/kəmˈpærətɪvli ||; kəmˈpærətɪvlɪ/adv when compared with sth else or with what is usual; fairly 相对来说；比较: The disease is comparatively rare nowadays. 现在这种疾病较为罕见。

*compare
/kəmˈpeə(r) ||; kəmˈpɛr/verb
1 [T] compare A and B;compare A with/to B to consider people or things in order to see how similar or how different they are 比较: I'm quite a patient person, compared with him. 跟他相比，我还是个很有耐心的人。 Compared to the place where I grew up, this town is exciting. 跟我成长的地方相比，这个镇的生活很多姿多彩。 When the police compared the two letters, they realized that they had been written by the same person. 警方比较了这两封信，发现是同一人所写。
2 [T] compare A to B to say that sb/sth is similar to sb/sth else （表示事物与事物或人与人相似）把…比作: When it was built, people compared the stadium to a spaceship. 体育馆落成的时候，人们把它比作一艘宇宙飞船。
3 [I] compare (with/to sb/sth) to be as good as sb/sth 比得上（某人或某事物）: Her last film was brilliant but this one simply doesn't compare. 她上一部影片拍得极好，这一部却望尘莫及。 There is nothing to compare with the taste of bread fresh from the oven. 刚出炉的面包味美绝伦。
compare notes (with sb) to discuss your opinions, ideas, experiences, etc with sb else （跟别人）交换意见、经验等: At the beginning of term we met and compared notes about the holidays. 学期初我们见了面，彼此交流了度假的经历。

*comparison
/kəmˈpærɪsn ||; kəmˈpærəsṇ/noun [C,U] an act of comparing; a statement in which people or things are compared 比较: Put the new one and the old one side by side, for comparison. 把新的和旧的摆在一起作比较。 It's hard to make comparisons between two athletes from different sports. 将不同种类运动的两名运动员作比较是很难的。 by/in comparison (with sb/sth) when compared 和…相比: In comparison with many other people, they're quite well off. 比起很多人，他们的生活算宽裕的了。

compartment
/kəmˈpɑ:tmənt ||; kəmˈpɑrtmənt/noun[C]
1 one of the separate sections into which some larger parts of a train (carriages)are divided （火车厢内的）隔间: a first-class compartment 头等隔间
2 one of the separate sections into which certain containers are divided （容器的）格，层: The drugs were discovered in a secret compartment in his suitcase. 毒品是在他手提箱中的一个暗格里发现的。

compass
/ˈkʌmpəs ||; ˈkʌmpəs/noun[C]
1 an instrument for finding direction, with a needle that always points north 指南针；罗盘: They had to find their way back to the camp using a map and a compass. 他们得靠地图和指南针寻找返回营地的路。
2 compasses [pl] a V-shaped instrument that is used for drawing circles 圆规: a pair of compasses 一把圆规

compassion
/kəmˈpæʃn ||; kəmˈpæʃən/noun [U]: compassion (for sb) understanding or pity for sb who is suffering 同情；怜悯: to have/feel/show compassion 有同情心 ➔compassionate /-ʃənət ||; -ʃənɪt/ adj

compatible
/kəmˈpætəbl ||; kəmˈpætəbḷ/adj compatible (with sb/sth) suitable to be used together, or to live or exist together 合得来的；兼容的；相容的: These two computer systems are not compatible. 这两个计算机系统不兼容。 Lee's diet is not compatible with his active lifestyle. 李的饮食跟他活跃的生活方式不协调。 [OPP] incompatible 反义词为incompatible ➔compatibility /kəmˌpætəˈbɪləti ||; kəmˌpætəˈbɪlətɪ/ noun [U]

compatriot
/kəmˈpætriət; US kəmˈpeɪtrɪət ||; kəmˈpetrɪət/noun [C] a person who comes from the same country as you 同胞

compel
/kəmˈpel ||; kəmˈpɛl/verb [T] (compelling;compelled) (formal 正式)compel sb to do sth to force sb to do sth 强迫: I felt compelled to tell her what I really thought of her. 我觉得必须把自己对她的真实看法告诉她。

compelling
/kəmˈpelɪŋ ||; kəmˈpɛlɪŋ/adj that forces or persuades you to do or to believe sth 强迫性的；令人信服的: compelling evidence 令人信服的证据 ☞noun compulsion 名词为compulsion

compensate
/ˈkɒmpenseɪt ||; ˈkɑmpɛnˌset/verb
1 [I] compensate (for sth) to remove or reduce the bad effect of sth 弥补: His willingness to work hard compensates for his lack of skill. 他虽无一技之长，但愿意勤奋工作以补其不足。
2 [I,T] compensate (sb) (for sth) to pay sb money because you have injured him/her or lost or damaged his/her property 赔偿: The airline sent me a cheque to compensate for losing my luggage. 航空公司丢失了我的行李，送来一张支票作补偿。

compensation
/ˌkɒmpenˈseɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmpɛnˈseʃən/noun
1 [U] compensation (for sth) money that you pay to sb because you have injured him/her or lost or damaged his/her property 赔款: I got £5000 (in) compensation for my injuries. 我受了伤，得到5000英镑的赔款。
2 [C,U] a fact or action that removes or reduces the bad effect of sth 补偿: City life can be very tiring but there are compensations (= good things about it). 城市生活虽然有时很累人，但有失也有得。

*compete
/kəmˈpi:t ||; kəmˈpit/verb [I] compete (in sth) (against/with sb) (for sth) to try to win or achieve sth, or to try to be better than sb else 竞争: The world's best athletes compete in the Olympic Games. 全球最优秀的运动员在奥林匹克运动会上一较高下。 We'll be competing against seven other teams for the trophy. 我们要跟七个队争夺奖杯。 As children, they always used to compete with each other. 他们小时候总是互相竞争。 Supermarkets have such low prices that small shops just can't compete. 超级市场的东西如此便宜，小商店根本无法与之竞争。

competence
/ˈkɒmpɪtəns ||; ˈkɑmpətəns/noun [U] the fact of having the ability or skill that is needed for sth 胜任；称职: She quickly proved her competence in her new position. 她上任不久便证明了自己胜任新职位。 [OPP] incompetence 反义词为incompetence

competent
/ˈkɒmpɪtənt ||; ˈkɑmpətənt/adj
1 having the ability or skill needed for sth 能胜任的；称职的: a highly competent player 一流选手 She is competent at her job. 这工作她很胜任。 [OPP] incompetent 反义词为incompetent
2 good enough, but not excellent 差强人意的: The singer gave a competent, but not particularly exciting, performance. 这歌手唱得还可以，但并不特别精彩。 ➔competently adv

*competition
/ˌkɒmpəˈtɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmpəˈtɪʃən/noun
1 [C] an organized event in which people try to win sth 竞赛；比赛: to go in for/enter a competition 参加比赛 They hold a competition every year to find the best young artist. 他们每年举行竞赛，评出最佳的青年艺术家。 He came second in an international piano competition. 他在一次国际钢琴比赛中夺得第二名。
2 [U] a situation where two or more people or organizations are trying to achieve, obtain, etc the same thing or to be better than sb else 竞争: He is in competition with three other people for promotion. 他要与三名对手角逐晋升机会。 There was fierce competition among the players for places in the team. 运动员为了角逐成为队中选手，竞争非常激烈。
3 the competition [sing] [with.sop] the other people, companies, etc who are trying to achieve the same as you 竞争对手: If we are going to succeed, we must offer a better product than the competition. 我们想要成功，就必须能够提供比竞争对手更好的产品。

competitive
/kəmˈpetətɪv ||; kəmˈpɛtətɪv/adj
1 involving people or organizations competing against each other 涉及竞争的: The travel industry is a highly competitive business. 旅游业是竞争激烈的行业。 competitive sports 体育竞技项目
2 able to be as successful as or more successful than others 竞争力强的: They are trying to make the company competitive in the international market. 他们要让公司在国际市场上具有竞争力。 Our prices are highly competitive (= as low as or lower than those of the others). 我们的价格很有竞争力。
3 (used about people) wanting very much to win or to be more successful than others （指人）好胜的: She's a very competitive player. 她是个志在必胜的选手。 ➔competitively adv Their products are competitively priced. 他们产品的定价很有竞争力。 ➔competitiveness noun [U]

competitor
/kəmˈpetɪtə(r) ||; kəmˈpɛtətɚ/noun [C] a person or organization that is competing against others 竞争者；对手: There are ten competitors in the first race. 首场比赛有十名选手参加。 Two local companies are our main competitors. 我们的主要对手是两家本地公司。

compilation
/ˌkɒmpɪˈleɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmpɪˈleʃən/noun
1 [C] a collection of pieces of music, writing, film, etc that are taken from different places and put together 编缀而成的东西（如音乐、文章、电影等）；汇编: a compilation CD of the band's greatest hits 汇集了乐队最热门歌曲的激光唱片
2 [U] the act of compiling sth 搜集并编排；编制；编纂

compile
/kəmˈpaɪl ||; kəmˈpaɪl/verb
1 [I] to collect information and arrange it in a list, book, etc 搜集并编排资料；编制；编纂: to compile a dictionary/a report/a list 编词典；写报告；列表
2 [I,T] (computing计算机技术) to translate instructions from one computer language into another for a computer to understand （将一种计算机语言）编译（成另一种计算机语言）

complacent
/kəmˈpleɪsnt ||; kəmˈplesṇt/adj feeling too satisfied with yourself or with a situation, so that you think that there is no need to worry 自满的；自鸣得意的: He had won his matches so easily that he was in danger of becoming complacent. 他轻易赢得多项比赛，恐怕会变得自满。 ➔complacency /kəmˈpleɪsnsi ||; kəmˈplesṇsɪ/ noun [U] ➔complacently adv

*complain
/kəmˈpleɪn ||; kəmˈplen/verb[I]
1 complain (to sb) (about sth/that...) to say that you are not satisfied with or happy about sth 抱怨；投诉: People are always complaining about the weather. 人们老在埋怨天气。 We complained to the hotel manager that the room was too noisy. 我们向酒店经理抱怨房间太吵闹。 ☞Look at the notes at grumble and protest. 参看grumble及protest的注释。
2 (formal 正式)complain of sth to say that you have a pain or illness 诉说（病痛）: He went to the doctor, complaining of chest pains. 他去看医生，跟医生说他胸部疼痛。

*complaint
/kəmˈpleɪnt ||; kəmˈplent/noun complaint (about sth);complaint (that...)
1 [C] a statement that you are not satisfied with sth （口头或书面的）投诉: You should make a complaint to the company that made the machine. 你该向机器制造商投诉。
2 [U] the act of complaining 抱怨；投诉: I wrote a letter of complaint to the manager about the terrible service I had received. 我去信经理投诉服务太差。 Jim's behaviour never gave the teachers cause for complaint. 吉姆表现不错，老师们没有不满意的理由。
3 [C] an illness or disease 疾病: a heart complaint 心脏病

complement¹
/ˈkɒmplɪmənt ||; ˈkɑmpləmənt/noun[C]
1 (formal 正式) a thing that goes together well with sth else 互相配合的事物；补足物: Ice cream is the perfect complement to this dessert. 冰淇淋是这个甜点的最佳搭配。
2 the total number that makes a group complete 组成整体的数量；足额: Without a full complement of players, the team will not be able to take part in the match. 没有完整的阵容，这队伍就不能出赛。
3 (grammar语法) a word or words, especially a noun or adjective, used after a verb such as ‘be’ or ‘become’ and describing the subject of that verb 补语（尤指在动词如be或become之后用以描述主语的名词或形容词）: In ‘He's friendly’ and ‘He's a fool’, ‘friendly’ and ‘fool’ are complements. 在He's friendly和He's a fool中，friendly和fool都是补语。
complement²
/ˈkɒmplɪmənt ||; ˈkɑmpləmənt/verb [T] to go together well with 配合；相称: The colours of the furniture and the carpet complement each other. 家具与地毯的颜色十分相衬。

complementary
/ˌkɒmplɪˈmentri ||; ˌkɑmpləˈmɛntərɪ/adj going together well with sb/sth; adding sth which the other person or thing does not have 相配的: They work well together because their skills are complementary: he's practical and she's creative. 他们以专长互补不足，所以合作得很好；他实干，而她则善于创新。

*complete¹
/kəmˈpli:t ||; kəmˈplit/adj
1 having or including all parts; with nothing missing 完整的: I gave a complete list of the stolen items to the police. 我已把失窃对象的列表交给警方。 The book explains the complete history of the place. 本书完整介绍了这个地方的历史。
2 (not before a noun 不用于名词前) finished or ended 完成；结束: The repair work should be complete by Friday. 维修工作到星期五应该能够完成。 [OPP] for senses 1 and 2 incomplete 第1及2义的反义词皆为incomplete
