3 complete (with sth) including sth extra, in addition to what is expected 包括；附有: The computer comes complete with instruction manual and printer. 这台计算机附有说明书和打印机。
4 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) as great as possible; total; in every way 彻底的；完全的: It was a complete waste of time. 这完全是浪费时间。 The room is a complete mess. 房间里乱七八糟。 ➔completeness noun [U]
*complete²
/kəmˈpli:t ||; kəmˈplit/verb[T]
1 to make sth whole 使完整: We need two more players to complete the team. 我们需要添两名队员才能成为一支完整的球队。
2 to finish sth; to bring sth to an end 完成；结束: When the building has been completed, it will look impressive. 这座建筑物完成后一定很宏伟。 He completed his teacher training course in June 1997. 他于1997年6月完成教师训练课程。
3 to write all the necessary information on sth (for example a form) 写上所有必要的信息（如填写表格）: Please complete the following in capital letters. 请以大写字母填表。

*completely
/kəmˈpli:tli ||; kəmˈplitlɪ/adv in every way; fully; totally 彻底地；完全地: The building was completely destroyed by fire. 该建筑物被大火完全焚毁。

completion
/kəmˈpli:ʃn ||; kəmˈpliʃən/noun [U] (formal 正式) the act of finishing sth or the state of being finished 完成；完结: You will be paid on completion of the work. 工作一完成就付给你钱。 The new motorway is due for completion within two years. 新的高速公路预计在两年内完工。

*complex¹
/ˈkɒmpleks; US kəmˈpleks ||; kəmˈplɛks/adj made up of several connected parts and often difficult to understand; complicated 复杂的: a complex problem/subject 复杂的问题╱题目
complex²
/ˈkɒmpleks ||; kəmˈplɛks/noun[C]
1 a group of connected things, especially buildings 组合（尤指建筑物）: a shopping/sports complex 购物中心；综合体育场馆
2 a complex (about sth) a mental problem that makes sb worry a lot about sth 情结: He's got a complex about his height. 他常为自己的身高而烦恼。 an inferiority complex 自卑情结

complexion
/kəmˈplekʃn ||; kəmˈplɛkʃən/noun[C]
1 the natural colour and quality of the skin on your face 脸部的肤色和质地: a dark/fair complexion 黝黑／白皙的肤色 a healthy complexion 健康的面色
2 [usu.sing] the general nature or character of sth 性质；特性: These announcements put a different complexion on our situation. 这些消息发布以后，我们的处境便大为改观。

complexity
/kəmˈpleksəti ||; kəmˈplɛksətɪ/noun (plural complexities)
1 [U] the state of being complex and difficult to understand 复杂: an issue of great complexity 十分复杂的问题
2 [C] one of the many details that make sth complicated 复杂的细节: I haven't time to explain the complexities of the situation now. 现在我没有时间解释形势的复杂细节。

compliant
/kəmˈplaɪənt ||; kəmˈplaɪənt/adj (formal 正式)compliant (with sth) working or done in agreement with particular rules, orders, etc 合乎规定的；顺从命令的: All new products must be compliant with EU specifications. 所有新产品都必须符合欧洲联盟的规格。 ➔compliance noun [U]: a hard hat must be worn at all times in compliance with safety regulations.任何时候都必须遵守安全守则，戴上头盔。

*complicate
/ˈkɒmplɪkeɪt ||; ˈkɑmpləˌket/verb [T] to make sth difficult to understand or deal with 使难懂；使复杂: Let's not complicate things by adding too many details. 我们不要加入太多细节，把事情弄复杂了。 ➔complicated adj a novel with a very complicated plot 一部情节十分复杂的小说

complication
/ˌkɒmplɪˈkeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmpləˈkeʃən/noun[C]
1 something that makes a situation hard to understand or to deal with 使情况复杂的因素: Unless there are any unexpected complications, I'll be arriving next month. 除非有什么意外变化，不然我将于下月到达。
2 a new illness that you get when you are already ill 并发症: Unless he develops complications, he'll be out of hospital in a week. 如果不出现并发症，他将在一个星期内出院。

complicity
/kəmˈplɪsəti ||; kəmˈplɪsətɪ/noun [U] (formal 正式) the fact of being involved with sb else in a crime 同谋；串通

compliment¹
/ˈkɒmplɪmənt ||; ˈkɑmpləmənt/noun
1 [C] a compliment (on sth) a statement or action that shows admiration for sb 称赞；嘉许；恭维: People often pay her complimentson her piano playing. 人们常常称赞她的钢琴造诣。
2 compliments [pl] (formal 正式) used to say that you like sth or to thank sb for sth （用于表示喜欢或谢意）致意，问候，祝贺: Tea and coffee are provided with the compliments of the hotel management (= without charge). 咖啡和茶由酒店管理部门奉送，聊表谢意。
compliment²
/ˈkɒmplɪment ||; ˈkɑmpləˌmɛnt/verb [T] compliment sb (on sth) to say that you think sb/sth is very good 称赞；表示景仰: She complimented them on their smart appearance. 她称赞他们衣着得体潇洒。

complimentary
/ˌkɒmplɪˈmentri ||; ˌkɑmpləˈmɛntərɪ/adj
1 showing that you think sb/sth is very good 赞美的；褒扬的: He made several complimentary remarks about her work. 他说了几句话称赞她的工作。
2 given free of charge 免费的；赠送的: a complimentary theatre ticket 戏票赠券

comply
/kəmˈplaɪ ||; kəmˈplaɪ/verb [I] (present participle complying third person singular present complies;past tense past participle complied) (formal 正式)comply (with sth) to obey an order or request 遵从；依从；符合: All office buildings must comply with the fire and safety regulations. 所有办公楼必须符合消防及安全条例。

component
/kəmˈpəʊnənt ||; kəmˈponənt/noun [C] one of several parts of which sth is made 组成部份: The human eye has two main components. 人的眼睛主要由两个部份组成。 the components of a machine/system 机器╱系统的部件 component adj the component parts of an engine 引擎的零部件

compose
/kəmˈpəʊz ||; kəmˈpoz/verb
1 [T] to be the parts that together form sth 组成；构成: the parties that compose the coalition government 组成联合政府的政党
2 [I,T] to write music 作曲；编曲: Mozart composed forty-one symphonies. 莫扎特创作了四十一首交响曲。
3 [T] to produce a piece of writing, using careful thought （仔细思考后）撰写: I sat down and composed a letter of reply. 我坐下来写了一封回信。
4 [T] to make yourself, your feelings, etc become calm and under control 控制；使（自己、思绪等）平静；克制（自己）: The news came as such a shock that it took me a while to compose myself. 这消息令人震惊，我听后好一会儿才平静下来。

composed
/kəmˈpəʊzd ||; kəmˈpozd/adj
1 composed of sth made or formed from several different parts, people, etc 由…组成或构成；包括: The committee is composed of politicians from all parties. 该委员会包罗各政党的成员。
2 calm, in control of your feelings 镇静；自我克制: Although he felt very nervous, he managed to appear composed. 虽然内心十分紧张，他仍做到外表镇定自若。

composer
/kəmˈpəʊzə(r) ||; kəmˈpozɚ/noun [C] a person who writes music 作曲家

composite
/ˈkɒmpəzɪt ||; kəmˈpɑzɪt/adj consisting of different parts or materials 综合的；混合的 composite noun [C]

composition
/ˌkɒmpəˈzɪʃn ||; ˌkɑmpəˈzɪʃən/noun
1 [U] the parts that form sth; the way in which the parts of sth are arranged 组成部份；构造: the chemical composition of a substance 某种物质的化学成分 the composition of the population 人口结构
2 [C] a piece of music that has been written by sb 音乐作品: Chopin's best-known compositions 肖邦最著名的作品
3 [U] the act or skill of writing a piece of music or text 作曲；撰文；作曲或撰文的技巧: She studied both musical theory and composition. 她修读了音乐理论及作曲技巧。
4 [C] a short piece of writing done at school, in an exam, etc 作文: Write a composition of about 300 words on one of the following subjects. 试选以下其中一个题目写一篇约300字的文章。

compost
/ˈkɒmpɒst ||; ˈkɑmpost/noun [U] a mixture of dead plants, old food, etc that is added to soil to help plants grow 混合肥料，堆肥（由腐烂的植物及废料混成）

composure
/kəmˈpəʊʒə(r) ||; kəmˈpoʒɚ/noun [U] the state of being calm and having your feelings under control 镇静；克制；沉着: The goalkeeper couldn't regain his composure after his mistake. 守门员出了差错以后再也冷静不下来。

compound¹
/ˈkɒmpaʊnd ||; ˈkɑmpaυnd/noun[C]
1 something that consists of two or more things or substances combined together 复合物；综合体；化合物: a chemical compound 化合物
2 (grammar语法) a noun, an adjective or a verb made of two or more words or parts of words, written as one or more words, or joined by a HYPHEN 复合词（由两个或以上词或成分组成，可以是一个词、几个词或用连字符(-)连接）: ‘Car park’, ‘bad-tempered’ and ‘bathroom’ are all compounds. car park、bad-tempered及bathroom都是复合词。
3 an area of land with a group of buildings on it, surrounded by a wall or fence 四周有墙或篱笆、上面有建筑群的一块地；院落
compound²
/kəmˈpaʊnd ||; kəmˈpaυnd/verb [T] to make sth such as a problem worse 使（问题等）恶化或复杂化

comprehend
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhend ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnd/verb [T] (formal 正式) to understand sth completely 领会；理解: She's too young to comprehend what has happened. 她年纪太小，还不明白发生了什么事。

comprehensible
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhensəbl ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnsəbḷ/adj easy to understand 易懂的: The book is written in clear, comprehensible language. 本书行文畅达易懂。 [OPP] incomprehensible 反义词为incomprehensible

comprehension
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhenʃn ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnʃən/noun
1 [U] (formal 正式) the ability to understand 理解力；理解: The horror of war is beyond comprehension. 战争之可怖是难以理解的。 [OPP] incomprehension 反义词为incomprehension
2 [C,U] an exercise that tests how well you understand spoken or written language 理解能力练习: a listening comprehension 听力练习

comprehensive¹
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhensɪv ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnsɪv/adj
1 including everything or nearly everything that is connected with a particular subject 全面的；完备的: a guide book giving comprehensive information on the area 提供该地区详尽数据的指南
2 (Brit 英) (used about education) educating children of all levels of ability in the same school （指教育）综合的（同一学校教育不同能力的学生的）: a comprehensive education system 综合教育制度
comprehensive²
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhensɪv ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnsɪv/ (also compreˈhensive school) noun [C] (Brit 英) a secondary school in which children of all levels of ability are educated 综合中学（教育不同能力学生的中学）: I went to the local comprehensive. 我上本地的综合中学。

comprehensively
/ˌkɒmprɪˈhensɪvli ||; ˌkɑmprɪˈhɛnsɪvlɪ/adv completely; thoroughly 广泛地；全面地

compress
/kəmˈpres ||; kəmˈprɛs/verb[T]
1 compress sth (into sth) to make sth fill less space than usual 压缩: Divers breathe compressed air from tanks. 潜水员呼吸贮气罐里的压缩空气。 He found it hard to compress his ideas into a single page. 他发现很难把自己的想法扼要地写在一页纸上。
2 (computing计算机技术) to make computer files, etc smaller so that they use less space on a disk, etc 压缩（使计算机文档少占磁盘等的空间） [OPP] decompress 反义词为decompress ➔compression /kəmˈpreʃn ||; kəmˈprɛʃən/ noun [U]

comprise
/kəmˈpraɪz ||; kəmˈpraɪz/verb[T]
1 to consist of; to have as parts or members 由…组成；包括: a house comprising three bedrooms, kitchen, bathroom and a living room 一幢有三间卧室、一间厨房、一间浴室和一个客厅的房子
2 to form or be part of sth 组成，构成（整体中的一部份）: Women comprise 62% of the staff. 女性占职员总人数的62%。

compromise¹
/ˈkɒmprəmaɪz ||; ˈkɑmprəˌmaɪz/noun [C,U] a compromise (on sth) an agreement that is reached when each person gets part, but not all, of what he/she wanted 妥协；折衷；妥协或折衷方案: to reach a compromise 达成一项折衷方案 Both sides will have to be prepared to make compromises. 双方将不得不准备妥协。
compromise²
/ˈkɒmprəmaɪz ||; ˈkɑmprəˌmaɪz/verb
1 [I] compromise (with sb) (on sth) to accept less than you want or are aiming for, especially in order to reach an agreement 放弃部份要求（尤指为了达成协议）；妥协: Unless both sides are prepared to compromise, there will be no peace agreement. 除非双方愿意妥协，不然就达不成和约。 The company never compromises on the quality of its products. 公司在产品质量问题上绝不妥协。
2 [T] compromise sb/sth/yourself to put sb/sth/yourself in a bad or dangerous position, especially by doing sth that is not very sensible 使置于糟糕或危险的境地（尤指因行为不明智）；危及；连累: He compromised himself by accepting money from them. 他收受他们的金钱，连累自己。

compulsion
/kəmˈpʌlʃn ||; kəmˈpʌlʃən/noun
1 [U] the act of forcing sb to do sth or being forced to do sth 强迫；被迫: There is no compulsion to take part. You can decide yourself. 不是强迫参加的，你可以自行决定。 ☞verb compel 动词为compel
2 [C] a strong desire that you cannot control, often to do sth that you should not do 强迫作用；难以自制的欲望；冲动 [SYN] urge 同义词为urge

compulsive
/kəmˈpʌlsɪv ||; kəmˈpʌlsɪv/adj
1 (used about a bad or harmful habit) caused by a strong desire that you cannot control （指恶习等）难以自制的: compulsive eating 不由自主地大量进食
2 (used about a person) having a bad habit that he/she cannot control （指人）有难以自制的恶习的: a compulsive gambler/shoplifter 嗜赌成癖的赌徒；偷窃成性的商店货物扒手
3 so interesting or exciting that you cannot take your attention away from it 引人入胜的；令人着迷的: This book makes compulsive reading. 这本书令人爱不释手。 ➔compulsively adv

*compulsory
/kəmˈpʌlsəri ||; kəmˈpʌlsərɪ/adj that must be done, by law, rules, etc 法例、规章等规定的；必须的；强制性的: Maths and English are compulsory subjects on this course. 数学及英语是这个课程的必修科。 It is compulsory to wear a hard hat on the building site. 在建筑工地内必须戴安全帽。 [SYN] obligatory 同义词为obligatory [OPP]Something that you do not have to do is non-compulsory, voluntary or optional. 自愿的用non-compulsory、voluntary或optional。

computational
/ˌkɒmpjuˈteɪʃənl ||; ˌkɑmpjuˈteʃənḷ/adj (usually before a noun 通常用于名词前) using or connected with computers 使用计算机的；与计算机有关的: computational linguistics/theory/skills 计算机语言学/理论/技能

compute
/kəmˈpju:t ||; kəmˈpjut/verb [T] (formal 正式) to calculate sth 计算

*computer
/kəmˈpju:tə(r) ||; kəmˈpjutɚ/noun [C] an electronic machine that can store, find and arrange information, calculate amounts and control other machines 计算机；电子计算机: The bills are all done by computer. 所有单据都由计算机处理。 a computer program 计算机程序 a home/personal computer 家庭╱个人计算机 computer software/games 计算机软件╱游戏 First of all, the details are fed into a computer. 首先，将细节输入计算机。 ☞picture on page S2 见S2页插图

computerize
/kəmˈpju:təraɪz ||; kəmˈpjutəˌraɪz/ (also -ise) verb [T] to use computers to do a job or to store information 计算机化: The whole factory has been computerized. 整家工厂已经计算机化。 We have now computerized the library catalogue. 我们目前已将图书馆的目录计算机化。 ➔computerization(also -isation) /kəmˌpju:təraɪˈzeɪʃn; US -rɪˈz- ||; kəmˌpjutərəˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

comˌputer-ˈliterate
adj able to use a computer 会使用计算机的

comˌputer ˈscience
noun [U] the study of computers and how they can be used 电脑科学；计算机科学: a degree in computer science 计算机科学学位

computing
/kəmˈpju:tɪŋ ||; kəmˈpjutɪŋ/noun [U] the use of computers 使用计算机的技巧；计算机技术: She did a course in computing. 她修读一门计算机应用课程。

compère
/ˈkɒmpeə(r) ||; ˈkɑmpɛr/noun [C] (Brit 英) a person who entertains the audience and introduces the different performers in a show （表演或节目的）主持人 ➔compère verb · Who compèred the show? 谁当了这场表演的主持人？

comrade
/ˈkɒmreɪd; US -ræd ||; ˈkɑmræd/noun[C]
1 (formal 正式) a person who fights on the same side as you in a war 战友: He saw many of his comrades die in battle. 他看到他的许多战友在战斗中牺牲了。
2 (old-fashioned 旧) a person who is a member of the same SOCIALISTpolitical party or group as the speaker （同一政党或组织的）同志: Comrades, we will fight against injustice! 同志们，我们要跟不公正作斗争！ ➔comradeship /ˈkɒmreɪdʃɪp ||; ˈkɑmrædˌʃɪp/ noun [U]: He enjoys the comradeship of the army. 他喜欢部队的战友情谊。

Con
(also Cons) abbr (in British politics) Conservative （英国政治）保守党党员

con¹
/kɒn ||; kɑn/verb [T] (conning;conned) (informal 非正式)con sb (into doing sth/out of sth) to cheat sb, especially in order to get money 诈骗（尤指以金钱为目的）: He conned her into investing in a company that didn't really exist. 他骗她投资于一家根本不存在的公司。 The old lady was conned out of her life savings. 老太太被人骗走了毕生的积蓄。
con²
/kɒn ||; kɑn/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a trick, especially in order to cheat sb out of some money 骗局（尤指用以骗取金钱的） the pros and cons→PRO

con-
/kɒn ||; kɑn/prefix (used in adjectives, adverbs, nouns and verbs 用于构成形容词、副词、名词及动词) with; together 与；共；一起: concurrent 并存的 conurbation 大都市 convene 聚集

concave
/kɒnˈkeɪv ||; kɑnˈkev/adj having a surface that curves towards the inside of sth, like the inside of a bowl 凹 ☞Look at convex. 参看convex。 ☞picture at lens 见lens插图

conceal
/kənˈsi:l ||; kənˈsil/verb [T] (formal 正式)conceal sth/sb (from sb/sth) to hide sth/sb; to prevent sth/sb from being seen or discovered 隐藏；隐瞒: She tried to conceal her anger from her friend. 她试图隐藏愤怒，不让朋友看出。 ➔concealment noun [U]: the concealment of the facts of the case 对案件实情的隐瞒

concede
/kənˈsi:d ||; kənˈsid/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to admit that sth is true although you do not want to 承认（常指无奈地）: When it was clear that he would lose the election, he conceded defeat. 他明白自己在选举中大势已去，于是承认失败。 She conceded that the problem was mostly her fault. 她承认所以造成这个问题主要是她自己不好。
2 concede sth (to sb) to allow sb to take sth although you do not want to 把东西让与他人（常指无奈地）: They lost the war and had to concede territory to their enemy. 他们打了败仗，只得割让土地给敌人。 ☞noun concession 名词为concession

conceit
/kənˈsi:t ||; kənˈsit/noun [U] too much pride in yourself and your abilities and importance 自大；自负 ➔conceited adj He's so conceited -- he thinks he's the best at everything! 他夜郎自大，认为自己样样第一。

conceivable
/kənˈsi:vəbl ||; kənˈsivəbḷ/adj possible to imagine or believe 可想象的；可相信的: I made every conceivable effort to succeed. 我尽了一切努力来争取成功。 [OPP] inconceivable 反义词为inconceivable ➔conceivably /-əbli ||; -əblɪ/ adv She might just conceivably be telling the truth. 她说的可能是真话。

conceive
/kənˈsi:v ||; kənˈsiv/verb
1 [T] (formal 正式) to think of a new idea or plan 想出（主意、计划）；构思: He conceived the idea for the novel during his journey through India. 他在印度的旅途中，有了写这部小说的念头。
2 [I,T] (formal 正式)conceive (of) sb/sth (as sth) to think about sb/sth in a particular way; to imagine 想象为；视为: He started to conceive of the world as a dangerous place. 他开始把世界想象为一个危险的地方。
3 [I,T] to become pregnant 怀孕；受孕 ☞noun conception 名词为conception

*concentrate
/ˈkɒnsntreɪt ||; ˈkɑnsṇˌtret/verb[I,T]
1 concentrate (sth) (on sth/doing sth) to give all your attention or effort to sth 专心致志；集中精神: I need to concentrate on passing this exam. 我需要集中精力，争取考试及格。 I tried to concentrate my thoughts on the problem. 我努力让自己的思绪集中在这个问题上。
2 to come together or to bring people or things together in one place 集合；集中；聚集: Most factories are concentrated in one small area of the town. 大部份工厂集中在镇上的一小片地方。

concentrated
/ˈkɒnsntreɪtɪd ||; ˈkɑnsṇˌtretɪd/adj
1 showing determination 显示决心的: With one concentrated effort we can finish the work by tonight. 只要大家专心致志，我们今晚就能完成任务。
2 made stronger by the removal of some liquid 浓缩的: This is concentrated orange juice. You have to add water before you drink it. 这是浓缩橙汁，加了水才可以喝。 [OPP] dilute 反义词为dilute

*concentration
/ˌkɒnsnˈtreɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsṇˈtreʃən/noun
1 [U] concentration (on sth) the ability to give all your attention or effort to sth 专注；专心: This type of work requires total concentration. 做这种工作需要全神贯注。 Don't lose your concentration or you might make a mistake. 别分心，不然你会犯错误。
2 [C] concentration (of sth) a large amount of people or things in one place 汇集；密集；集中: There is a high concentration of chemicals in the drinking water here. 这里的饮用水化学物质含量很高。

ˌconcenˈtration camp
noun [C] a prison (usually a number of buildings inside a high fence) where political prisoners are kept in very bad conditions 集中营

concentric
/kənˈsentrɪk ||; kənˈsɛntrɪk/adj (used about circles of different sizes) having the same centre point （指不同大小的圆）同心的

concept
/ˈkɒnsept ||; ˈkɑnsɛpt/noun [C] the concept (of sth/that...) an idea; a basic principle 观念；概念；基本原则: It is difficult to grasp the concept of eternity. 永恒这个概念是很难懂的。 ➔conceptual /kənˈseptʃuəl ||; kənˈsɛptʃυəl/ adj

conception
/kənˈsepʃn ||; kənˈsɛpʃən/noun
1 [C,U] (a) conception (of sth) an understanding of how or what sth is （对某事实际情况的）了解，概念: We have no real conception of what people suffered during the war. 我们无法确切了解战时人们所受的苦难。
2 [U] the process of forming an idea or a plan 构思；计划
3 [uc] the moment when a woman or female animal becomes pregnant 受孕 ☞verb conceive 动词为conceive

*concern¹
/kənˈsɜ:n ||; kənˈsɝn/verb[T]
1 to affect or involve sb/sth 影响；牵涉: This does not concern you. Please go away. 这与你无关，请你走吧。 It is important that no risks are taken where safety is concerned. 在有关安全的问题上，绝不能冒险。
2 to be about sth 关于: The main problem concerns the huge cost of the project. 主要问题是关于工程的巨额成本。
3 to worry sb 使担心: What concerns me is that we have no long-term plan. 令我担心的是我们没有长远计划。
4 concern yourself with sth to give your attention to sth 关注: You needn't concern yourself with the hotel booking. The travel agent will take care of it. 你不必为预订酒店房间的事操心，旅行社会给你安排的。
be concerned in sth to have a connection with or be involved in sth 涉及；牵涉: She was concerned in a drugs case some years ago. 若干年前她曾与一宗毒品案有牵连。 be concerned with sth to be about sth 关于: Tonight's programme is concerned with the effects of the law on ordinary people. 今晚的节目是关于法律对一般人的影响。
*concern²
/kənˈsɜ:n ||; kənˈsɝn/noun
1 [C,U] concern (for/about/over sb/sth);concern (that...) a feeling of worry; sth that causes worry 担心；忧虑: The safety officer assured us that there was no cause for concern. 安全官员向我们保证，没有什么可担忧的。 My main concern is that we'll run out of money. 我主要担心我们的钱会用完。
2 [C] something that is important to you or that involves you 对某人重要或有关系的事: Financial matters are not my concern. 财政问题跟我没有关系。
3 [C] a company or business 公司；企业: a large industrial concern 规模宏大的工业机构
a going concern→GOING²

concerned
/kənˈsɜ:nd ||; kənˈsɝnd/adj concerned (about/for sth);concerned (that...) worried and feeling concern about sth （为某事）担心，感到忧虑: If you are concerned about your baby's health you should consult a doctor immediately. 如果你担心婴孩的健康有问题，就该立刻带他去看医生。 [OPP] unconcerned 反义词为unconcerned

*concerning
/kənˈsɜ:nɪŋ ||; kənˈsɝnɪŋ/prep about; on the subject of 关于: She refused to answer questions concerning her private life. 她拒绝回答有关她私生活的问题。

*concert
/ˈkɒnsət ||; ˈkɑnsɝt/noun [C] a performance of music 音乐会；演唱会: The band is on tour doing concerts all over the country. 该乐团正在全国各地巡回举办音乐会。 ☞Look also at recital. 另参看recital。 in concert (with sb/sth)(formal 正式) working together with sb/sth 与…采取一致行动

concerted
/kənˈsɜ:tɪd ||; kənˈsɝtɪd/adj done by a group of people working together 合作的；协力的: We must all make a concerted effort to finish the work on time. 我们必须一致努力才能按时完成任务。

concertina
/ˌkɒnsəˈti:nə ||; ˌkɑnsɚˈtinə/noun [C] a musical instrument that you hold in your hands and play by pressing the ends together and pulling them apart 六角形手风琴 ☞A concertina is like a small accordion. concertina就像小的手风琴(accordion)。 ☞Look at the note at piano. 参看piano的注释。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

concerto
/kənˈtʃɜ:təʊ ||; kənˈtʃɛrto/noun [C] (plural concertos) a piece of music for an orchestra with one instrument playing an important part (solo) 协奏曲: Mozart's second piano concerto 莫扎特的第二钢琴协奏曲

concession
/kənˈseʃn ||; kənˈsɛʃən/noun
1 [C,U] (a) concession (to sb/sth) something that you agree to do in order to end an argument 让步: Employers have been forced to make concessions to the union. 雇主被迫对工会作出让步。 ☞verb concede 动词为concede
2 [C] a lower price for certain groups of people （给特定群体的）优惠价格: Concessions are available for students and pensioners. 学生及已退休者可享受优惠价格。

concessionary
/kənˈseʃənəri; US -nerɪ ||; kənˈsɛʃənˌɛrɪ/adj having a lower price for certain groups of people （给予特定群体）优惠价格的: a concessionary fare 优惠票价

conciliation
/kənˌsɪliˈeɪʃn ||; kənˌsɪlɪˈeʃən/noun [U] the process of ending an argument or disagreement 调解；和解: All attempts at conciliation have failed and civil war seems inevitable. 所有调解的努力均告失败，内战似乎已无可避免。

conciliatory
/kənˈsɪliətəri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; kənˈsɪlɪəˌtɔrɪ/adj that tries to end an argument or disagreement 调解的；和解的: a conciliatory speech/gesture 和解的演讲╱姿态

concise
/kənˈsaɪs ||; kənˈsaɪs/adj giving a lot of information in a few words; brief 简明的；言简意赅的: He gave a clear and concise summary of what had happened. 他清楚扼要地叙述了事情的经过。 ➔concisely adv ➔conciseness noun [U]

conclude
/kənˈklu:d ||; kənˈklud/verb
1 [T] conclude sth from sth to form an opinion as the result of thought or study 总结；归结: From the man's strange behaviour I concluded that he was drunk. 我根据那人的古怪行为得出结论，他喝醉了。
2 [I,T] (formal 正式) to end or to bring sth to an end 结束；完结: The Prince concluded his tour with a visit to a charity concert. 王子于此行结束前，出席了一个慈善音乐会。
3 [T] conclude sth (with sb) to formally arrange or agree to sth 缔结；订立；达成: conclude a business deal/treaty 缔结商业协议╱条约

*conclusion
/kənˈklu:ʒn ||; kənˈkluʒən/noun
1 [C] the conclusion (that...) an opinion that you reach after thinking about sth carefully 结论: After trying to phone Bob for days, I came to the conclusion that he was on holiday. 我一连几天给鲍勃打电话都打不通，于是得出结论他度假去了。 Have you reached any conclusionsfrom your studies? 你从研究中得出什么结论没有？
2 [C] [usu.sing] (formal 正式) an end to sth 终结；结尾: Let us hope the peace talks reach a successful conclusion. 但愿和谈最后会取得成功。
3 [U] an act of arranging or agreeing to sth formally 缔结；订立；达成: The summit ended with the conclusion of an arms-reduction treaty. 裁减军备条约签订后，高峰会议随之结束。
a foregone conclusion→FOREGONE in conclusion finally; lastly 最终；最后 jump to conclusions→JUMP¹

conclusive
/kənˈklu:sɪv ||; kənˈklusɪv/adj that shows sth is definitely true or real 确实的；决定性的: The blood tests gave conclusive proof of Robson's guilt. 验血提供了确凿证据，证明罗伯逊有罪。 [OPP] inconclusive 反义词为inconclusive ➔conclusively adv

concoct
/kənˈkɒkt ||; kənˈkɑkt/verb[T]
1 to make sth unusual by mixing different things together 把不同的成分混合成某物；调制
2 to make up or invent sth (an excuse, a story, etc) 编造；造；虚构 ➔concoction /kənˈkɒkʃn ||; kənˈkɑkʃən/ noun [C]

concord
/ˈkɒŋkɔ:d ||; ˈkɑŋkɔrd/noun [U]:
1 concord (with sth)(formal 正式) peace and agreement 和谐；协调: The two countries now live in concord. 两国现在和睦相处。 [SYN] harmony 同义词为harmony
2 (grammar语法)concord (with sth) (used about words in a phrase) the fact of having to have a particular form according to other words in the phrase ﹙指词组中的词﹚﹙与词组中其他词的﹚一致﹙关系﹚

concordance
/kənˈkɔ:dəns ||; kənˈkɔrdṇs/noun
1 [C] a list in A to Z order of the words used in a book, etc showing where and how often they are used 词语索引（从 A 到 Z 排列，显示书本等所使用的词的位置及频度）
2 [C] a list produced by a computer that shows all the examples of an individual word in a book, etc （计算机编制的书等中某词的）用例一览表
3 [U] (technical术语) the state of being similar to or agreeing with sth 类似；一致: There is reasonable concordance between the results. 结果基本一致。

concourse
/ˈkɒŋkɔ:s ||; ˈkɑnkɔrs/noun [C] a large hall or space inside a building such as a station or an airport （火车站、机场等的）大厅

concrete¹
/ˈkɒŋkri:t ||; ˈkɑnkrit/adj real or definite; not only existing in the imagination 确实的；具体的: Can you give me a concrete example of what you mean? 能否举个具体例子说明你的意思？ [OPP] abstract 反义词为abstract ➔concretely adv
concrete²
/ˈkɒŋkri:t ||; ˈkɑnkrit/noun [U] a hard substance made from cement mixed with sand, water, small stones (gravel), etc, that is used in building 混凝土（一种由水泥、沙、水、细石等混制成的坚硬物质，用于建筑）: a modern office building of glass and concrete 用玻璃及混凝土建成的现代化办公大楼 a concrete floor/bridge 混凝土地板╱桥 ☞picture at building 见building插图
concrete³
/ˈkɒŋkri:t ||; ˈkɑnkrit/verb [T] concrete sth (over) to cover sth with concrete 用混凝土涂于某物

ˈconcrete mixer
=CEMENT MIXER

concur
/kənˈkɜ:(r) ||; kənˈkɝ/verb [I] (concurring;concurred) (formal 正式) to agree 同意

concurrence
/kənˈkʌrəns ||; kənˈkɝəns/noun (formal 正式)
1 [U] [sing] agreement 同意；一致: The doctor must seek the concurrence of a relative before carrying out the procedure. 医生将程序付诸实施之前，必须征得一名亲属的同意。
2 [sing] an example of two or more things happening at the same time （两件或以上事情的）同时发生: an unfortunate concurrence of events 几件事情不幸同时发生

concurrent
/kənˈkʌrənt ||; kənˈkɝənt/adj existing or happening at the same time as sth else 同时存在的；同时发生的 ➔concurrently adv The semi-finals are played concurrently, so it is impossible to watch both. 半决赛同时进行，因此无法两场都看。

concuss
/kənˈkʌs ||; kənˈkʌs/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to injure sb's brain by hitting his/her head 使脑震荡；使脑震伤: I was slightly concussed when I fell off my bicycle. 我从自行车上摔下来，脑部受了轻微震荡。 ➔concussion /kənˈkʌʃn ||; kənˈkʌʃən/ noun [U]

*condemn
/kənˈdem ||; kənˈdɛm/verb[T]
1 condemn sb/sth (for/as sth) to say strongly that you think sb/sth is very bad or wrong 斥责；谴责: A government spokesman condemned the bombing as a cowardly act of terrorism. 一名政府发言人谴责这起炸弹袭击是恐怖主义的懦夫行为。
2 condemn sb (to sth/to do sth) to say what sb's punishment will be; to sentence sb 判罪；判刑: The murderer was condemned to death. 凶手被判处死刑。 (figurative 比喻) Their poor education condemns them to a series of low-paid jobs. 他们教育水平低，注定只能从事低收入工作。
3 condemn sth (as sth) to say officially that sth is not safe enough to use 宣告某物因不安全而不宜使用: The building was condemned as unsafe and was demolished. 这幢大楼被定为危楼，并遭拆除。

condemnation
/ˌkɒndemˈneɪʃn ||; ˌkɑndɛmˈneʃən/noun [C,U] the act of condemning sth; a statement that condemns 斥责；谴责；斥责或谴责的言辞: The bombing brought condemnation from all around the world. 炸弹袭击事件遭到全世界的谴责。

condensation
/ˌkɒndenˈseɪʃn ||; ˌkɑndɛnˈseʃən/noun [U]:
1 small drops of liquid that are formed when warm air touches a cold surface 冷凝物（因暖空气接触到寒冷表面而形成）；冷凝
2 the process of changing a gas to a liquid 凝结

condense
/kənˈdens ||; kənˈdɛns/verb
1 [I,T] to change or make sth change from gas to liquid 冷凝；凝结: Steam condenses into water when it touches a cold surface. 水蒸气接触寒冷的表面即凝结成水珠。 ☞Look at evaporate. 参看evaporate。
2 [T] condense sth (into sth) to make smaller or shorter so that it fills less space 浓缩文字作品；缩写: We'll have to condense these three chapters into one. 我们要将这三章压缩为一章。

condenser
/kənˈdensə(r) ||; kənˈdɛnsɚ/noun[C]
1 a piece of equipment that cools gas in order to turn it into liquid 冷凝器 ☞picture at generator 见generator插图
2 a device that stores electricity, especially in a car engine 电容器（尤指汽车发动机里的）

condescend
/ˌkɒndɪˈsend ||; ˌkɑndɪˈsɛnd/verb[I]
1 condescend (to sb) to behave towards sb in a way that shows that you think you are better or more important than him/her; to patronize sb 表现出优越感；以恩赐的姿态对待
2 condescend (to do sth) to do sth that you believe is below your level of importance 屈尊；屈就；俯就: Celia only condescends to speak to me when she wants me to do something for her. 西莉亚需要我为她做事的时候，才会屈就地来与我说话。 ➔condescending adj a condescending smile 傲慢的微笑 ➔condescension /ˌkɒndɪˈsenʃn ||; ˌkɑndɪˈsɛnʃən/ noun [U]

condiment
/ˈkɒndɪmənt ||; ˈkɑndəmənt/noun[C] [usu.pl]
1 (Brit 英) a substance such as salt or pepper that is used to give flavour to food 调味品（如盐或辣椒）
2 (especially US 尤为美) a sauce, etc that is used to give flavour to food, or that is eaten with food 佐料

*condition¹
/kənˈdɪʃn ||; kənˈdɪʃən/noun
1 [U] [sing] the state that sb/sth is in 状态；情况: to be in poor/good/excellent condition 处于糟糕╱良好╱极好状态 He looks really ill. He is certainly not in a condition to drive home. 他看来病得不轻，肯定不能开车回家。
2 [C] something that must happen so that sth else can happen or be possible 条件: One of the conditions of the job is that you agree to work on Sundays. 这份工作的条件之一是你得同意在星期日工作。 He said I could borrow his bike on one condition -- that I didn't let anyone else ride it. 他说我可以借他的自行车，只一个条件─我不能让别人骑。
3 conditions [pl] the situation or surroundings in which people live, work or do things 情况；环境: The prisoners were kept in terrible conditions. 犯人被关在条件极差的地方。 poor living/housing/working conditions 恶劣的生活╱住房╱工作条件
4 [C] a medical problem that you have for a long time 疾病: to have a heart/lung condition 心脏╱肺有毛病
on condition (that...) only if 在…的条件下；如果: I agreed to help on condition that I got half the profit. 我同意帮忙，条件是一半利润归我。 on no condition(formal 正式) not for any reason 决不: On no condition must the press find out about this. 在任何情况下都不能让新闻界知道这件事。 out of condition not physically fit 健康不佳
condition²
/kənˈdɪʃn ||; kənˈdɪʃən/verb [T] to affect or control the way that sb/sth behaves 影响；控制；支配: Boys are conditioned to feel that they are stronger than girls. 男孩子从小所受的教育使他们觉得自己比女孩子强。

*conditional
/kənˈdɪʃənl ||; kənˈdɪʃənḷ/adj
1 conditional (on/upon sth) that only happens if sth else is done or happens first 有条件的: My university place is conditional on my getting good marks in the exams. 大学录取我的条件是我必须在考试中取得好成绩。 [OPP] unconditional 反义词为unconditional
2 (grammar语法) describing a situation that must exist before sth else can happen. A conditional sentence often contains the word ‘if’ （表示有条件的，条件句常包含if）: ‘If you don't study, you won't pass the exam’ is a conditional sentence. If you don't study, you won't pass the exam是个条件句。
For more information about conditional sentences, look at the Quick Grammar Reference section at the back of this dictionary. 有关条件句的详细用法，参看本词典末“语法便览”部份。 ➔conditionally /-ʃənəli ||; -ʃənḷɪ/ adv

conditioner
/kənˈdɪʃənə(r) ||; kənˈdɪʃənɚ/noun [C,U] a substance that keeps sth in a good condition 调节剂（使某物保持良好状态的物质）: Do you use conditioner on your hair? 你使用护发剂吗？

condolence
/kənˈdəʊləns ||; kənˈdoləns/noun [pl] [U] an expression of how sorry you feel for sb whose relative or close friend has just died 吊唁；对死者亲友的慰问: offer your condolences 表达吊唁之意 a message of condolence 慰问的言辞

condom
/ˈkɒndɒm ||; ˈkɑndəm/ (informal 非正式rubber) noun [C] a thin rubber covering that a man wears over his sexual organ during sex to prevent the woman from becoming pregnant or as protection against disease 阴茎套；避孕套；保险套

condominium
/ˌkɒndəˈmɪniəm ||; ˌkɑndəˈmɪnɪəm/ (informal 非正式condo /ˈkɒndəʊ ||; ˈkɑndo/) noun [C] (US 美) a flat or block of flats owned by the people who live in them 公寓（大楼）；共管式住所

condone
/kənˈdəʊn ||; kənˈdon/verb [T] to accept or agree with sth that most people think is wrong 容忍；宽恕: I can never condone violence -- no matter what the circumstances are. 我决不会容忍暴力─在任何情况下都不会。

conducive
/kənˈdju:sɪv; US -ˈdu:s- ||; kənˈdusɪv/adj (formal 正式)conducive (to sth) helping or making sth happen 有助；有益: This hot weather is not conducive to hard work. 这种酷热的天气令人不想勤奋工作。

conduct¹
/kənˈdʌkt ||; kənˈdʌkt/verb[T]
1 (formal 正式) to organize and do sth, especially research 进行（尤指研究）: to conduct tests/a survey/an inquiry 进行测试╱测勘╱调查
2 to stand in front of an orchestra and direct the musicians 指挥（乐团）
3 (formal 正式)conduct yourself well, badly, etc to behave in a particular way 行为（好╱坏等）
4 to allow heat or electricity to pass along or through sth 传导（热或电）: Rubber does not conduct electricity. 橡胶不导电。
conduct²
/ˈkɒndʌkt ||; ˈkɑndʌkt/noun [U]:
1 a person's behaviour 品行；操行；行为: His conduct has always been of the highest standard. 他一向品德高尚、行为端正。 a code of conduct (= a set of rules for behaviour) 行为准则
2 (formal 正式)conduct of sth the act of controlling or organizing sth （对某事的）管理，组织，处理: She was criticized for her conduct of the bank's affairs. 她处理银行事务的方式受到批评。

conduction
/kənˈdʌkʃn ||; kənˈdʌkʃən/noun [U] (technical术语) the process by which heat or electricity passes through a material （热或电的）传导

conductive
/kənˈdʌktɪv ||; kənˈdʌktɪv/adj able to conduct electricity, heat, etc 导电的；导热的；有传导力的 ➔conductivity /ˌkɒndʌkˈtɪvəti ||; ˌkɑndʌkˈtɪvətɪ/ noun [U]

conductor
/kənˈdʌktə(r) ||; kənˈdʌktɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who stands in front of an orchestra and directs the musicians （乐团的）指挥
2 (Brit 英) a person whose job is to collect money from passengers on a bus or to check their tickets （公共汽车的）售票员，收费员
3 (US 美) =GUARD¹(5)
4 a substance that allows heat or electricity to pass through or along it （导热或导电的）导体，传导体 ☞Compare semiconductor. 与semiconductor比较。

cone
/kəʊn ||; kon/noun[C]
1 a shape or object that has a round base and a point at the top 圆锥体: traffic cones 锥形交通路标 an ice cream cone 盛冰淇淋的锥形蛋卷 ☞adjective conical 形容词为conical ☞picture at cube 见cube插图
2 the hard fruit of some trees (pine)and(fir) 球果；球花；球穗花序 ☞picture on page C2 见C2页插图 ☞Look at conifer. 参看conifer。

confectionery
/kənˈfekʃənəri; US -ʃənerɪ ||; kənˈfɛkʃənˌɛrɪ/noun [U] sweets, cakes, chocolates, etc 甜食；糖果

confederacy
/kənˈfedərəsi ||; kənˈfɛdərəsɪ/noun [sing] a union of states, groups of people or political parties with the same aim （国家、组织、政党等的）同盟，联盟

confederate¹
/kənˈfedərət ||; kənˈfɛdərɪt/noun [C] a person who helps sb, especially to do sth illegal or secret 同党，同犯，共谋者（尤指干非法或秘密事者）
confederate²
/kənˈfedərət ||; kənˈfɛdərɪt/adj belonging to a union of states, groups of people or political parties with the same aim(a confederacy) 结盟的﹔属于某同盟﹙同盟叫做confederacy﹚

confederation
/kənˌfedəˈreɪʃn ||; kənˌfɛdəˈreʃən/noun [C,U] an organization of smaller groups which have joined together 同盟；联盟；邦联: a confederation of independent republics 由独立共和国组成的联盟

confer
/kənˈfɜ:(r) ||; kənˈfɝ/verb (conferring;conferred)
1 [I] confer (with sb) (on/about sth) to discuss sth with sb before making a decision 咨询；商讨: The President is conferring with his advisers. 总统正征询顾问的意见。
2 [T] (written 书面语)confer sth (on sb) to give sb a special right or advantage 颁授，授予（某种权利等）

*conference
/ˈkɒnfərəns ||; ˈkɑnfərəns/noun [C] a large official meeting, often lasting several days, at which members of an organization, profession, etc meet to discuss important matters 会议；大会: an international conference on global warming 关于全球气候变暖的国际会议

ˈconference call
noun [C] a telephone call in which several people in different places take part at the same time 电话会议

*confess
/kənˈfes ||; kənˈfɛs/verb [I,T] confess (to sth/to doing sth);confess (sth) (to sb) to admit that you have done sth bad or wrong 承认，招认（罪责、错误等）: The young woman confessed to the murder of her boyfriend/to murdering her boyfriend. 这名年轻女子供认谋杀了她的男朋友。 They confessed to their mother that they had spent all the money. 他们向母亲承认已把钱全都花掉了。 ☞Look at own up (to sth). It is less formal. 参看own up (to sth)。这个词多用于非正式场合。

confession
/kənˈfeʃn ||; kənˈfɛʃən/noun [C,U] an act of admitting that you have done sth bad or wrong （罪责、错误等的）承认，招认: The police persuaded the man to make a full confession. 警方说服那名男子全部招供。

confessional
/kənˈfeʃənl ||; kənˈfɛʃənḷ/noun [C] a private enclosed place in a church where people confess to a priest ﹙教堂内的﹚告解室，忏悔室

confetti
/kənˈfeti ||; kənˈfɛtɪ/noun [U] small pieces of coloured paper that people throw over a man and woman who have just got married （撒向新郎及新娘的）五彩碎纸

confide
/kənˈfaɪd ||; kənˈfaɪd/verb [T] confide sth to sb to tell sb sth that is secret 吐露（秘密）: She did not confide her love to anyone -- not even to her best friend. 她没有把她的恋情告诉别人─连她的挚友也没有。 confide in sb to talk to sb that you trust about sth secret or private 向自己信赖的人倾诉衷情或吐露心事

*confidence
/ˈkɒnfɪdəns ||; ˈkɑnfədəns/noun [U]:
1 confidence (in sb/sth) trust or strong belief in sb/sth （对某人、某事的）信心，信任: The public is losing confidence in the present government. 公众对现政府渐渐失去信心。 I have every confidence in Emily's ability to do the job. 我对埃米莉完成这项工作的能力绝对有信心。
2 the feeling that you are sure about your own abilities, opinion, etc 自信；信心: I didn't have the confidence to tell her I thought she was wrong. 我没有足够的自信告诉她我认为她错了。 to be full of confidence 充满信心 ‘Of course we will win,’ the team captain said with confidence. 队长信心十足地说﹕“我们一定会赢。” ☞Look at self-confidence. 参看self-confidence。
3 a feeling of trust in sb to keep sth a secret 信任关系；对对方保守秘密的确信: The information was given to me in strict confidence. 这资料是人家极其信任地交给我的。 It took a while to win/gain her confidence. 花了一些时间才赢得她的信任。

ˈconfidence trick
noun [C] a way of getting money by cheating sb 诈骗钱财的伎俩；骗局

*confident
/ˈkɒnfɪdənt ||; ˈkɑnfədənt/adj confident (of sth/that...);confident (about sth) feeling or showing that you are sure about your own abilities, opinions, etc 有信心的: Kate feels confident of passing/that she can pass the exam. 凯特自信考试能及格。 to be confident of success 有信心能成功 You should feel confident about your own abilities. 你应当对自己的能力有信心。 Dillon has a very confident manner. 迪龙表现得信心十足。 ☞Look at self-confident. 参看self-confident。 ➔confidently adv She stepped confidently onto the stage and began to sing. 她信心十足地走上舞台开始唱歌。

confidential
/ˌkɒnfɪˈdenʃl ||; ˌkɑnfəˈdɛnʃəl/adj secret; not to be shown or told to other people 秘密的；机密的；保密的: The letter was marked ‘private and confidential’. 这封信标有“密件”和“亲启”字样。 ➔confidentiality /ˌkɒnfɪˌdenʃiˈæləti ||; ˌkɑnfɪˌdɛnʃɪˈælɪtɪ/ noun [U] ➔confidentially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv

configuration
/kənˌfɪgəˈreɪʃn ||; kənˌfɪgjəˈreʃən/noun[C]
1 (formal 正式) the way in which the parts of sth, or a group of things, are arranged 布局；结构
2 (computing计算机技术) the equipment and programs that form a computer system and the particular way that these are arranged （计算机系统设备及程序的）配置

configure
/kənˈfɪgə(r) ||; kənˈfɪgjɚ/verb[T]
1 (formal 正式) to arrange parts of sth, or a group of things, in a particular way （以某方式）装配，安装
2 (computing计算机技术) to arrange computer equipment for a particular task （为某任务）配置（计算机设备）

confine
/kənˈfaɪn ||; kənˈfaɪn/verb[T]
1 confine sb/sth (in/to sth) to keep a person or animal in a particular, usually small, place （把人或动物）关起来，囚禁，禁闭（于狭小的地方）: The prisoners are confined to their cells for long periods at a time. 犯人每次都被长期关在囚室里。
2 confine sb/sth/yourself to sth to stay within the limits of sth 限制于（某范围内）: Please confine your questions to the topic we are discussing. 提出问题时不要离题。

confined
/kənˈfaɪnd ||; kənˈfaɪnd/adj (used about a space) very small （指空间）有限的，很小的

confinement
/kənˈfaɪnmənt ||; kənˈfaɪnmənt/noun [U] being kept in a small space 禁闭；监禁: to be kept in solitary confinement (= in a prison) 单独监禁

confines
/ˈkɒnfaɪnz ||; ˈkɑnfaɪnz/noun [pl] (formal 正式) the limits of sth 界限；范围: Patients are not allowed beyond the confines of the hospital grounds. 病人不准走出医院范围。

*confirm
/kənˈfɜ:m ||; kənˈfɝm/verb[T]
1 to say or show that sth is true; to make sth definite 证实；确认: Seeing the two of them together confirmed our suspicions. 看见他们二人在一起，证实了我们的怀疑。 Can you confirm that you will be able to attend? 你能否确认会出席？
2 to accept sb as a full member of a Christian Church in a special ceremony （教会）施行坚信礼，施行按手礼: He was confirmed at the age of thirteen. 他十三岁时行坚信礼。 ➔confirmation /ˌkɒnfəˈmeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnfɚˈmeʃən/ noun [C,U] We are waiting for confirmation of the report. 我们正等候有关方面对这份报告的确认。

confirmed
/kənˈfɜ:md ||; kənˈfɝmd/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) fixed in a particular habit or way of life 习惯的；积习成癖的: a confirmed bachelor 抱独身主义的男子

confiscate
/ˈkɒnfɪskeɪt ||; ˈkɑnfɪsˌket/verb [T] to take sth away from sb as a punishment 没收；充公: Any cigarettes found in school will be confiscated. 在校内发现的香烟都要没收。 ➔confiscation /ˌkɒnfɪˈskeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnfɪsˈkeʃən/ noun [C,U]

*conflict¹
/ˈkɒnflɪkt ||; ˈkɑnflɪkt/noun[C,U]
1 (a) conflict with sb/sth (over sth) a fight or an argument 冲突；打斗；争执: an armed conflict 武装冲突 The new laws have brought the Government into conflict with the unions over pay increases. 新法规导致政府与工会就加薪问题起争执。
2 a difference between two or more ideas, wishes, etc 矛盾；抵触；分歧: Many women have to cope with the conflict between their career and their family. 许多妇女不得不处理好事业与家庭之间的矛盾。 a conflict of interests 利益冲突
conflict²
/kənˈflɪkt ||; kənˈflɪkt/verb [I] A and B conflict;A conflicts with B to disagree with or be different from sb/sth 矛盾；抵触: The statements of the two witnesses conflict. 两个证人的供词互相矛盾。 John's statement conflicts with yours. 约翰的说法与你的不一致。 conflicting results 相反的结果

conform
/kənˈfɔ:m ||; kənˈfɔrm/verb [I] conform (to sth)
1 to obey a rule or law 遵守（规章、法律）: This building does not conform to fire regulations. 这座大厦违反消防条例。
2 to behave in the way that other people and society expect you to behave 顺从，依从（他人及社会的期望）；从众: Children are under a lot of pressure to conform when they first start school. 儿童刚开始上学时会受到很大压力，他们要学会遵守校规。 ➔conformity /kənˈfɔ:məti ||; kənˈfɔrmətɪ/ noun [U]

conformist
/kənˈfɔ:mɪst ||; kənˈfɔrmɪst/noun [C] a person who behaves in the way that people are expected to behave by society 墨守成规者；循规蹈矩的人 [OPP] non-conformist 反义词为non-conformist

confront
/kənˈfrʌnt ||; kənˈfrʌnt/verb[T]
1 confront sth;confront sb with sb/sth to think about, or to make sb think about, sth that is difficult or unpleasant （使别人）面对（困难或不愉快的事）: to confront a problem/difficulty/issue 面对问题╱困难等 When the police confronted him with the evidence, he confessed. 警方给他出示证据，他只好招认。
2 to stand in front of sb, for example because you want to fight him/her 对峙；对抗: The unarmed demonstrators were confronted by a row of soldiers. 手无寸铁的示威者与一列士兵对峙。

confrontation
/ˌkɒnfrʌnˈteɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnfrʌnˈteʃən/noun [C,U] a fight or an argument 对抗；冲突；争执

*confuse
/kənˈfju:z ||; kənˈfjuz/verb[T]
1 (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to make sb unable to think clearly or to know what to do 使（某人的思绪）混乱；扰乱: He confused everybody with his pages of facts and figures. 他一页页的事实与数据把所有人都弄胡涂了。
2 confuse A and/with B to mistake sb/sth for sb/sth else 混淆: I often confuse Lee with his brother. They look very much alike. 我常把李和他弟弟弄混了。他们长得很像。
3 to make sth complicated 使复杂化: The situation is confused by the fact that so many organizations are involved. 由于涉及很多机构，情况变得复杂了。

*confused
/kənˈfju:zd ||; kənˈfjuzd/adj
1 not able to think clearly 困惑的；头脑不清的: When he regained consciousness he was dazed and confused. 他恢复知觉后，仍感眩晕而且思绪混乱。
2 difficult to understand 费解的；难懂的: The article is very confused -- I don't know what the main point is. 这篇文章实在令人费解─我不知道要点为何。 ➔confusedly /-ədli ||; -ədlɪ/ adv

*confusing
/kənˈfju:zɪŋ ||; kənˈfjuzɪŋ/adj difficult to understand 费解的；难懂的: Her instructions were contradictory and confusing. 她的指示自相矛盾，令人费解。 ➔confusingly adv

*confusion
/kənˈfju:ʒn ||; kənˈfjuʒən/noun [U]:
1 the state of not being able to think clearly or not understanding sth 困惑；胡涂；紊乱: He stared in confusion at the exam paper. 他茫然凝视着试卷。 There is still a great deal of confusion as to the true facts. 真相仍未明朗。
2 a state of disorder 混乱；紊乱: Their unexpected visit threw all our plans into confusion. 他们突然来访，打乱了我们的全部计划。
3 the act of mistaking sb/sth for sb/sth else 混淆: To avoid confusion, all luggage should be labelled with your name and destination. 为了避免混淆，所有行李都必须标上姓名及目的地。

congeal
/kənˈdʒi:l ||; kənˈdʒil/verb [I,T] (used about a liquid) to become solid; to make a liquid solid （指液体）（使）凝固，（使）凝结: congealed blood 凝血

congenial
/kənˈdʒi:niəl ||; kənˈdʒinjəl/adj (formal 正式) pleasant 合宜的；适宜的: We spent an evening in congenial company. 我们与意气相投的朋友度过了一个晚上。

congenital
/kənˈdʒenɪtl ||; kənˈdʒɛnətḷ/adj (used about a disease) beginning at and continuing since birth （指疾病）先天的，天生的

congested
/kənˈdʒestɪd ||; kənˈdʒɛstɪd/adj so full of sth that nothing can move 拥塞的: The streets of London are congested with traffic. 伦敦的街上车水马龙，交通拥塞。 ➔congestion /kənˈdʒestʃən ||; kənˈdʒɛstʃən/ noun [U]: severe traffic congestion 严重的交通拥塞

conglomerate
/kənˈglɒmərət ||; kənˈglɑmərɪt/noun [C] a large firm made up of several different companies （由多家公司组成的）企业集团；联合大企业

conglomeration
/kənˌglɒməˈreɪʃn ||; kənˌglɑməˈreʃən/noun [C] a group of many different things that have been brought together 综合；聚合

*congratulate
/kənˈgrætʃuleɪt ||; kənˈgrætʃəˌlet/verb [T] congratulate sb (on sth) to tell sb that you are pleased about sth he/she has done; to praise sb 祝贺；道贺: I congratulated Sue on passing her driving test. 我祝贺苏珊驾驶考试及格。

*congratulations
/kənˌgrætʃuˈleɪʃnz ||; kənˌgrætʃəˈleʃənz/noun [pl] used for telling sb that you are pleased about sth he/she has done （表示称许或欣羡）恭喜: Congratulations on the birth of your baby boy! 恭喜你天赐麟儿。

congregate
/ˈkɒŋgrɪgeɪt ||; ˈkɑŋgrɪˌget/verb [I] to come together in a crowd or group 聚集；集合

congregation
/ˌkɒŋgrɪˈgeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑŋgrɪˈgeʃən/noun [C] [with.sop] the group of people who attend a particular church 教堂会众

congress
/ˈkɒŋgres; US -grəs ||; ˈkɑŋgrəs/noun[C] [with.sop]
1 a large formal meeting or series of meetings （一个或一连串大型正式的）会议，代表大会: a medical congress 医学会议
2 Congress the name in some countries (for example the US) for the group of people who are elected to make the laws 国会（某些国家，如美国等的立法机关，成员由选举产生）
The US Congress is made up of the Senate and the House of Representatives. 美国国会由参议院（Senate）及众议院（House of Representatives）组成。

congressional
/kənˈgreʃənl ||; kənˈgrɛʃənḷ/adj connected with a congress or Congress 与会议或国会有关的

Congressman
/ˈkɒŋgresmən ||; ˈkɑŋgrəsmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a male member of Congress in the US, especially the House of Representatives （美国）国会议员（尤指众议员）

Congresswoman
/ˈkɒŋgreswʊmən ||; ˈkɑŋgrəsˌwυmən/noun [C] (plural -women /-wɪmɪn ||; -ˌwɪmɪn/) a female member of Congress in the US, especially the House of Representatives （美国）女国会议员（尤指女众议员）

congruent
/ˈkɒŋgruənt ||; ˈkɑŋgrυənt/adj
1 (mathematics数学) having exactly the same size and shape 大小、形状恰好相同的；全等的: congruent triangles 全等三角形
2 (formal 正式)~ (with sth) suitable for sth 适合的

conic
/ˈkɒnɪk ||; ˈkɑnɪk/adj connected with CONES 与圆锥（形）有关的

conical
/ˈkɒnɪkl ||; ˈkɑnɪkḷ/adj having a round base and getting narrower towards a point at the top 圆锥形的 ☞noun cone 名词为cone

conifer
/ˈkɒnɪfə(r);ˈkəʊn- ||; ˈkɑnəfɚ; ˈkon-/noun [C] a tree with short, very thin leaves (needles) that stay green all through the year and that has hard brown fruit (cones) 球果植物；针叶树 ➔coniferous /kəˈnɪfərəs; US kəʊˈn- ||; koˈnɪfərəs/ adj

conjecture
/kənˈdʒektʃə(r) ||; kənˈdʒɛktʃɚ/verb [I,T] (formal 正式) to guess about sth without real proof or evidence 猜测；臆测；推测 conjecture noun [C,U]

conjoined
/kənˈdʒɔɪnd ||; kənˈdʒɔɪnd/adj (technical术语) joined together 连在一起的

conˌjoined ˈtwin
=SIAMESE TWIN

conjugal
/ˈkɒndʒəgl ||; ˈkɑndʒυgḷ/adj (formal 正式) connected with marriage and the relationship between husband and wife 婚姻的；夫妻关系的

conjugate
/ˈkɒndʒəgeɪt ||; ˈkɑndʒəˌget/verb [T] to give the different forms of a verb 列举动词的不同形式 ➔conjugation /ˌkɒndʒuˈgeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑndʒəˈgeʃən/ noun [C,U]

conjunction
/kənˈdʒʌŋkʃn ||; kənˈdʒʌŋkʃən/noun [C] a word that is used for joining other words, phrases or sentences 连接词；连词: ‘And’, ‘but’ and ‘or’ are conjunctions. and、but及or都是连接词。 in conjunction with sb/sth together with sb/sth 同某人或某物

conjunctivitis
/kənˌdʒʌŋktɪˈvaɪtɪs ||; kənˌdʒʌŋktəˈvaɪtɪs/noun [U] an eye disease that causes pain and swelling in part of the eye, and that can be passed from one person to another 结膜炎

conjure
/ˈkʌndʒə(r) ||; ˈkʌndʒɚ/verb [I] to do tricks by clever, quick hand movements, that appear to be magic 玩戏法；变魔术 ➔conjuring noun [U]: a conjuring trick 魔术 conjure sth up
1 to cause an image to appear in your mind 使某事物呈现于脑海；想象；追忆: Hawaiian music conjures up images of sunshine, flowers and sandy beaches. 夏威夷音乐使人想起阳光、鲜花和沙滩。
2 to make sth appear quickly or suddenly 使某事物迅速或突然出现；使闪现: Mum can conjure up a meal out of almost anything. 妈妈几乎用什么材料都可马上做出一顿饭来。

conjuror
/ˈkʌndʒərə(r) ||; ˈkʌndʒərɚ/ (also conjurer) noun [C] a person who does clever tricks that appear to be magic 魔术师 ☞Look at magician. 参看magician。

conker
/ˈkɒŋkə(r) ||; ˈkɑŋkɚ/ (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) (also horse chestnut) noun [C] the seed of the HORSE CHESTNUT tree, used in a children's game (conkers) 七叶树果（用于一种叫做康克戏的儿童游戏）

*connect
/kəˈnekt ||; kəˈnɛkt/verb
1 [I,T] connect (sth) (up) (to/with sth) to be joined to sth; to join sth to sth else 连接；连结: The tunnels connect (up) ten metres further on. 这两条隧道再往前十米就接通了。 The printer is connected to the computer. 打印机与计算机相连接。 This motorway connects Oxford with Birmingham. 这条高速公路连接牛津和伯明翰。 ☞Look at disconnect. 参看disconnect。
2 [T] connect sb/sth (with sb/sth) to have an association with sb/sth else; to realize or show that sb/sth is involved with sb/sth else 把…联系到…；发现或表明…与…有关: There was no evidence that she was connected with the crime. 没有证据显示她与那宗罪案有牵连。
3 [I] connect (with sth) (used about a bus, train, plane, etc) to arrive at a particular time so that passengers can change to another bus, train, plane, etc （指公共汽车、火车、飞机等）衔接: a connecting flight 联运航班

*connection
/kəˈnekʃn ||; kəˈnɛkʃən/noun[C]
1 a connection between A and B;a connection with/to sth an association or relationship between two or more people or things 关联；关系: Is there any connection between the two organizations? 这两个组织之间是否有关联呢？ What's your connection with Brazil? Have you worked there? 你跟巴西有什么关系？你是不是在那里工作过？
2 a place where two wires, pipes, etc join together （两根电线、管子等的）接合点，接合面: The radio doesn't work. There must be a loose connection somewhere. 这收音机不响了。一定是哪里接头松了。
3 a bus, train, plane, etc that leaves soon after another arrives （提供中转服务的）联运交通工具: Our bus was late so we missed our connection. 我们的公共汽车误点了，赶不上接乘的班车。
in connection with sb/sth(formal 正式) about or concerning 关于；有关: I am writing to you in connection with your application. 有关你的申请，现回复如下。 in this/that connection(formal 正式) about or concerning this/that 关于这╱那方面

connive
/kəˈnaɪv ||; kəˈnaɪv/verb [I] connive at sth;connive (with sb) (to do sth) to work secretly with sb to do sth that is wrong; to do nothing to stop sb doing sth wrong 共谋，默许，纵容（做非法或不对的事）: The two parties connived to get rid of the president. 两党共谋想要搞掉总统。

connoisseur
/ˌkɒnəˈsɜ:(r) ||; ˌkɑnəˈsɝ/noun [C] a person who knows a lot about art, good food, music, etc （艺术、美食、音乐等的）行家，鉴赏家

connotation
/ˌkɒnəˈteɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnəˈteʃən/noun [C] an idea expressed by a word in addition to its main meaning （词的）隐含意义，言外之意: ‘Spinster’ means a single woman but it has negative connotations. spinster指单身女性，但带有负面的意义。

conquer
/ˈkɒŋkə(r) ||; ˈkɑŋkɚ/verb[T]
1 to take control of a country or city and its people by force, especially in a war 占领；攻取；征服: Napoleon's ambition was to conquer Europe. 拿破仑的野心是征服欧洲。 (figurative 比喻) The young singer conquered the hearts of audiences all over the world. 这年轻歌手赢得全球听众的心。
2 to succeed in controlling or dealing with a strong feeling, problem, etc 克服（强烈的情绪、问题等）: She's trying to conquer her fear of flying. 她正努力克服自己对乘坐飞机的恐惧。

conqueror
/ˈkɒŋkərə(r) ||; ˈkɑŋkərɚ/noun [C] a person who has conquered (1) sth 征服者；战胜者

conquest
/ˈkɒŋkwest ||; ˈkɑŋkwɛst/noun
1 [C] [U] an act of conquering sth 征服: the Norman conquest (= of England in 1066) 诺曼征服 the conquest of Mount Qomolangma 征服珠穆朗玛峰
2 [C] an area of land that has been taken in a war 被攻占的土地

conscience
/ˈkɒnʃəns ||; ˈkɑnʃəns/noun [C,U] the part of your mind that tells you if what you are doing is right or wrong 良心；良知: a clear/a guilty conscience 问心无╱有愧 have sth on your conscience to feel guilty because you have done sth wrong （因做错事而）内疚，良心受责

conscientious
/ˌkɒnʃiˈenʃəs ||; ˌkɑnʃɪˈɛnʃəs/adj
1 (used about people) careful to do sth correctly and well （指人）认真的，尽责的，勤恳的: He's a conscientious worker. 他是个非常尽忠职守的职工。
2 (used about actions) done with great care and attention （指行动）小心谨慎的: conscientious work 细致用心的工作 ➔conscientiously adv

ˌconscientious obˈjector
noun [C] a person who refuses to join the army, etc because he/she believes it is morally wrong to kill other people （因认为杀人不道德而）拒服兵役者

*conscious
/ˈkɒnʃəs ||; ˈkɑnʃəs/adj
1 able to see, hear, feel, etc things; awake 有知觉；有感觉；清醒: The injured driver was still conscious when the ambulance arrived. 救护车开到的时候，受伤的司机依然清醒。 [OPP] unconscious 反义词为unconscious
2 conscious (of sth/that...) noticing or realizing that sth exists; aware of sth 察觉到；意识到: She didn't seem conscious of the danger. 她似乎并没有意识到这种危险。 Bill suddenly became conscious that someone was following him. 比尔突然察觉到有人在跟踪他。
3 that you do on purpose or for a particular reason 故意的；刻意的: We made a conscious effort to treat both children equally. 我们有意识地努力平等对待两个孩子。 ☞Look at deliberate. It has a similar meaning. 参看deliberate，意思相近。 ➔consciously adv

*consciousness
/ˈkɒnʃəsnəs ||; ˈkɑnʃəsnɪs/noun
1 [U] the state of being able to see, hear, feel, etc 清醒；有知觉；有感觉: As he fell, he hit his head and lost consciousness. 他跌倒时撞着头部，失去了知觉。 She regained consciousness after two weeks in a coma. 她昏迷了两个星期才恢复知觉。
2 [U] [sing] consciousness (of sth) the state of realizing or noticing that sth exists 察觉；意识到: There is (a) growing consciousness of the need to save energy. 人们越来越意识到必须节约能源。

conscript¹
/kənˈskrɪpt ||; kənˈskrɪpt/verb [T] to make sb join the army, navy or air force 征召入伍 ➔conscription noun [U]
conscript²
/ˈkɒnskrɪpt ||; ˈkɑnskrɪpt/noun [C] a person who has been conscripted 被征召入伍的人 ☞Look at volunteer ¹(2). 参看volunteer^1(2)。

consecrate
/ˈkɒnsɪkreɪt ||; ˈkɑnsɪˌkret/verb [T] to state formally in a special ceremony that a place or an object can be used for religious purposes 祝圣 ➔consecration /ˌkɒnsɪˈkreɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsɪˈkreʃən/ noun [C,U]

consecutive
/kənˈsekjətɪv ||; kənˈsɛkjətɪv/adj coming or happening one after the other 连续的: This is the team's fourth consecutive win. 这是该队连续第四次获胜。 ➔consecutively adv

consensus
/kənˈsensəs ||; kənˈsɛnsəs/noun [sing] [U]: (a) consensus (among/between sb) (on/about sth) agreement among a group of people 一致意见；共识: to reach a consensus 达成一致意见 There is no consensus among experts about the causes of global warming. 关于全球气候变暖的起因，专家们意见不一。

consent¹
/kənˈsent ||; kənˈsɛnt/verb [I] consent (to sth) to agree to sth; to allow sth to happen 同意；答应；准许
consent²
/kənˈsent ||; kənˈsɛnt/noun [U] agreement; permission 同意；准许: The child's parents had to give their consent to the operation. 动手术必须得到小孩的父母同意。 the age of consent→AGE¹

consequence
/ˈkɒnsɪkwəns; US -kwens ||; ˈkɑnsəˌkwɛns/noun
1 [C] something that happens or follows as a result of sth else 结果；后果；影响: Many people may lose their jobs as a consequence of recent poor sales. 由于销售不景气，许多人可能会失业。
2 [U] (formal 正式) importance 重要性: It is of no consequence. 这倒无关紧要。

consequent
/ˈkɒnsɪkwənt ||; ˈkɑnsəˌkwɛnt/adj (formal 正式) (only before a noun 只用于名词前) following as the result of sth else 因之而起的: The lack of rain and consequent poor harvests have led to food shortages. 由于缺乏雨水，以及随之而来的歉收，导致食物短缺。 ➔consequently adv She didn't work hard enough, and consequently failed the exam. 她不够努力，结果考试不及格。

conservation
/ˌkɒnsəˈveɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsɚˈveʃən/noun [U]:
1 the protection of the natural world （对大自然的）保护: Conservation groups are protesting against the plan to build a road through the forest. 保护自然组织反对兴建道路穿越森林的计划。
2 not allowing sth to be wasted, damaged or destroyed 保护；保存；节约: the conservation of energy 节约能源 ☞verb conserve 动词为conserve

conservationist
/ˌkɒnsəˈveɪʃənɪst ||; ˌkɑnsɚˈveˌʃənɪst/noun [C] a person who believes in protecting the natural world 主张保护自然环境的人

conservatism
/kənˈsɜ:vətɪzəm ||; kənˈsɝvəˌtɪzəm/noun [U]:
1 the disapproval of new ideas and change 保守；守旧
2 usuallyConservatism the beliefs of the Conservative Party 保守主义

conservative¹
/kənˈsɜ:vətɪv ||; kənˈsɝvətɪv/adj
1 not liking change; traditional 保守的；守旧的；传统的
2 Conservative connected with the British Conservative Party 与英国保守党有关的: Conservative voters 支持保守党的选民
3 (used when you are guessing how much sth costs) lower than the real figure or amount （指估计等）谨慎的，保守的，偏低的: Even a conservative estimate would put the damage at about £4000 to repair. 即使保守估计，也要大约4000英镑才能修好损坏的地方。 ➔conservatively adv
conservative²
/kənˈsɜ:vətɪv ||; kənˈsɝvətɪv/noun[C]
1 a person who does not like change 守旧的人；保守的人
2 usuallyConservative a member of the British Conservative Party 英国保守党党员

Conˈservative Party
noun [C] one of the main political parties in Britain. The Conservative Party supports a free market and is against the state controlling industry 保守党（英国主要政党之一） ☞Look at Labour Party and Liberal Democrats. 参看Labour Party及Liberal Democrats。

conservatory
/kənˈsɜ:vətri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; kənˈsɝvəˌtɔrɪ/noun [C] (plural conservatories) a room with a glass roof and walls often built onto the outside of a house 温室

conserve
/kənˈsɜ:v ||; kənˈsɝv/verb [T] to avoid wasting sth 节约；节省: to conserve water 节约用水 ☞noun conservation 名词为conservation

*consider
/kənˈsɪdə(r) ||; kənˈsɪdɚ/verb[T]
1 consider sb/sth (for/as sth);consider doing sth to think about sth carefully, often before making a decision 考虑: She had never considered nursing as a career. 她从没有想过以当护士为职业。 We're considering going to Spain for our holidays. 我们计划到西班牙度假。
2 consider sb/sth (as/to be) sth;consider that... to think about sb/sth in a particular way 认为；视为: He considered the risk (to be) too great. 他认为风险太大。 He considered that the risk was too great. 他认为风险太大。 Jane considers herself an expert on the subject. 简认为自己是这个问题的专家。
3 to remember or pay attention to sth, especially sb's feelings 顾及，考虑到（尤指某人的感受）: I can't just move abroad. I have to consider my family. 我不能随便移居国外，我得顾及我的家人。

*considerable
/kənˈsɪdərəbl ||; kənˈsɪdərəbḷ/adj great in amount or size 多的；大的: A considerable number of people preferred the old building to the new one. 相当多的人宁愿选择那旧大厦，也不要这座新的。 ➔considerably /-əbli ||; -əblɪ/ adv This flat is considerably larger than our last one. 这套公寓比我们旧的要大得多。

considerate
/kənˈsɪdərət ||; kənˈsɪdərɪt/adj considerate (towards sb);considerate (of sb) (to do sth) careful not to upset people; thinking of others 顾及他人的；为他人着想的；体贴的: It was very considerate of you to offer to drive me home. 你说要开车送我回家，真是十分体贴。 [OPP] inconsiderate 反义词为inconsiderate

*consideration
/kənˌsɪdəˈreɪʃn ||; kənˌsɪdəˈreʃən/noun
1 [U] (formal 正式) an act of thinking about sth carefully or for a long time 考虑；深思熟虑: I have given some consideration to the idea but I don't think it would work. 我考虑过这个想法，但我认为不可行。
2 [C] something that you think about when you are making a decision 考虑的因素: If he changes his job, the salary will be an important consideration. 如果他换工作，薪金将是一项重要的考虑因素。
3 [U] consideration (for sb/sth) the quality of thinking about what other people need or feel 为（他人）设想；顾及（他人）；体贴: Most drivers show little consideration for cyclists. 多数汽车司机不大为骑自行车的人着想。
take sth into consideration to think about sth when you are forming an opinion or making a decision 考虑到，顾及到（某事物）

considering
/kənˈsɪdərɪŋ ||; kənˈsɪdərɪŋ/prep conj (used for introducing a surprising fact) when you think about or remember sth （用以引出令人惊奇的事实）就…而论，照…来看，鉴于: Considering you've only been studying for a year, you speak English very well. 就才刚学了一年而论，你英语已说得不错。

consign
/kənˈsaɪn ||; kənˈsaɪn/verb [T] (formal 正式)consign sb/sth to sth to put or send sb/sth somewhere, especially in order to get rid of him/her/it 放在，送到（某处）（尤指为了处理掉）: I think I can consign this junk mail straight to the bin. 我看我可以把这垃圾邮件直接丢进垃圾箱。

consignment
/kənˈsaɪnmənt ||; kənˈsaɪnmənt/noun [C] goods that are being sent to sb/sth 运送或托运的货物: a new consignment of books 一批新运来的书

*consist
/kənˈsɪst ||; kənˈsɪst/verb (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时) consist in sth to have sth as its main point 要点或特征在于: Her job consisted in welcoming the guests as they arrived. 她的工作主要是接待来宾。 consist of sth to be formed or made up of sth 由…组成: The band consists of a singer, two guitarists and a drummer. 这乐队由一名歌手、两名吉他手及一名鼓手组成。 Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) It's a full-time course consisting of six different modules. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：It's a full-time course consisting of six different modules. 这是一门全日制课程，由六个不同单元组成。

consistency
/kənˈsɪstənsi ||; kənˈsɪstənsɪ/noun (plural consistencies)
1 [U] the quality of always having the same standard, opinions, behaviour, etc （水平、意见、行为等的）一致性，一贯性: Your work lacks consistency. Sometimes it's excellent but at other times it's full of mistakes. 你的工作水平不稳定，有时做得很好，有时则错漏百出。 [OPP] inconsistency 反义词为inconsistency
2 [C] [U] how thick or smooth a liquid substance is （液体的）浓度，匀度: The mixture should have a thick, sticky consistency. 这种混合物应该稠而黏。

consistent
/kənˈsɪstənt ||; kənˈsɪstənt/adj
1 always having the same opinions, standard, behaviour, etc; not changing （意见、水平、行为等）前后一致的，一贯的
2 consistent (with sth) agreeing with or similar to sth 与…一致；符合: I'm afraid your statement is not consistent with what the other witnesses said. 你的供词恐怕与其他证人的不一致。 [OPP] inconsistent 反义词为inconsistent ➔consistently adv We must try to maintain a consistently high standard. 我们一定要设法始终保持高水平。

consolation
/ˌkɒnsəˈleɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsəˈleʃən/noun [C,U] a thing or person that makes you feel better when you are sad 带来安慰的人或事物；安慰；慰藉: It was some consolation to me to know that I wasn't the only one who had failed the exam. 知道不单是我考试不及格，这对我来说倒是一种安慰。 ☞ synonym comfort 同义词为comfort

console¹
/kənˈsəʊl ||; kənˈsol/verb [T] to make sb happier when he/she is very sad or disappointed 安慰 [SYN] synonym comfort 同义词为comfort
console²
/ˈkɒnsəʊl ||; ˈkɑnsol/noun [C] a flat surface which contains all the controls and switches for a machine, a piece of electronic equipment, etc 控制板；仪表盘

consolidate
/kənˈsɒlɪdeɪt ||; kənˈsɑləˌdet/verb [I,T] to become or to make sth firmer or stronger 巩固；加强: We're going to consolidate what we've learnt so far by doing some revision exercises today. 我们今天做些复习练习，巩固至今所学过的东西。 ➔consolidation /kənˌsɒlɪˈdeɪʃn ||; kənˌsɑləˈdeʃən/ noun [U]

consonant
/ˈkɒnsənənt ||; ˈkɑnsənənt/noun [C] any of the letters of the English alphabet except a, e, i, o, and u 辅音，子音（英语字母表里除a、e、i、o及u以外，其余都是辅音）: The letters ‘t’, ‘m’, ‘s’ and ‘b’ are all consonants. 字母t、m、s和b都是辅音。 ☞Look at vowel. 参看vowel。

consortium
/kənˈsɔ:tiəm; US -ˈsɔ:rtiəm ||; kənˈsɔrtɪəm/noun [C] (plural consortiums or consortia /-tiə ;-ʃɪə||; -tɪə/) a group of companies that work closely together for a particular purpose 财团；联营企业

conspicuous
/kənˈspɪkjuəs ||; kənˈspɪkjυəs/adj easily seen or noticed 显著的；明显的 [OPP] inconspicuous 反义词为inconspicuous ➔conspicuously adv

conspiracy
/kənˈspɪrəsi ||; kənˈspɪrəsɪ/noun [C,U] (plural conspiracies) a secret plan by a group of people to do sth bad or illegal 阴谋，共谋（做坏事或非法的事）: a conspiracy against the president 不利于总统的阴谋

conspirator
/kənˈspɪrətə(r) ||; kənˈspɪrətɚ/noun [C] a member of a group of people who are planning to do sth bad or illegal 同谋；共谋者；阴谋家

conspire
/kənˈspaɪə(r) ||; kənˈspaɪr/verb[I]
1 conspire (with sb) (to do sth) to plan to do sth bad or illegal with a group of people 密谋，同谋，串谋（做坏事或非法的事）: A group of terrorists were conspiring to blow up the plane. 一群恐怖分子正密谋炸毁飞机。
2 conspire (against sb/sth) (used about events) to seem to work together to make sth bad happen （指事情）似乎凑在一起（造成坏结果）: When we both lost our jobs in the same week, we felt that everything was conspiring against us. 我们俩在同一个星期内失去工作，使人觉得什么事情都在同我们作对。

constable
/ˈkʌnstəbl; US ˈkɒn- ||; ˈkɑnstəbḷ/ =POLICE CONSTABLE

constabulary
/kənˈstæbjələri; US -lerɪ ||; kənˈstæbjəˌlɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural constabularies) the police force of a particular area （某一地区的）警察部队: the West Yorkshire Constabulary 西约克郡警察部队

*constant
/ˈkɒnstənt ||; ˈkɑnstənt/adj
1 happening or existing all the time or again and again 经常的；不断的: The constant noise gave me a headache. 噪音不断，使我头痛。
2 that does not change 不变的；固定的: You use less petrol if you drive at a constant speed. 以稳定速度驾驶可节省汽油。

constantly
/ˈkɒnstəntli ||; ˈkɑnstəntlɪ/adv always; again and again 经常；不断: The situation is constantly changing. 情况在不断变化。

constellation
/ˌkɒnstəˈleɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnstəˈleʃən/noun [C] a group of stars that forms a pattern and has a name 星座；星群

consternation
/ˌkɒnstəˈneɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnstɚˈneʃən/noun [U] a feeling of shock or worry 惊愕；惊恐；惊慌: We stared at each other in consternation. 我们两人在惊愕中瞠目对视。

constipated
/ˈkɒnstɪpeɪtɪd ||; ˈkɑnstəˌpetɪd/adj not able to empty waste from your body 便秘的 ➔constipation /ˌkɒnstɪˈpeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnstəˈpeʃən/ noun [U]:to suffer from/have constipation 有便秘的毛病

constituency
/kənˈstɪtjuənsi ||; kənˈstɪtʃυənsɪ/noun [C] (plural constituencies) a district and the people who live in it that a politician represents 选区；选区的选民

constituent
/kənˈstɪtjuənt ||; kənˈstɪtʃυənt/noun[C]
1 one of the parts that form sth 成分: Hydrogen and oxygen are the constituents of water. 水由氢和氧组成。
2 a person who lives in the district that a politician represents 选民

constitute
/ˈkɒnstɪtju:t; US -stətu:t ||; ˈkɑnstəˌtut/verb linking verb (formal 正式) (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时)
1 to be one of the parts that form sth 构成；组成: Women constitute a high proportion of part-time workers. 妇女在兼职工作者中占很大的部份。
2 to be considered as sth; to be equal to sth 被认为是；等于: The presence of the troops constitutes a threat to peace. 驻军对和平构成威胁。
Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (=-ingform) Management has to fix a maximum number of hours as constituting a day's work. 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：Management has to fix a maximum number of hours as constituting a day's work. 资方不得不把一天的工时设定得尽可能长。

constitution
/ˌkɒnstɪˈtju:ʃn; US -stəˈtu:ʃn ||; ˌkɑnstəˈtuʃən/noun
1 [C] the basic laws or rules of a country or organization 宪法；章程: the United States constitution 美国宪法
2 [U] the way the parts of sth are put together; the structure of sth 结构；构成: the constitution of DNA 脱氧核糖核酸的结构

constitutional
/ˌkɒnstɪˈtju:ʃənl; US -stəˈtu:- ||; ˌkɑnstəˈtuʃənḷ/adj connected with or allowed by the constitution of a country, etc 与宪法等有关的；宪法等允许的: It is not constitutional to imprison a person without trial. 不经审判就囚禁人是违反宪法的。

constrain
/kənˈstreɪn ||; kənˈstren/verb [T] (formal 正式)constrain sb/sth (to do sth) to limit sb/sth; to force sb/sth to do sth 限制；约束；强迫: The company's growth has been constrained by high taxes. 公司的发展受到高赋税的掣肘。

constraint
/kənˈstreɪnt ||; kənˈstrent/noun [C,U] something that limits you 限制；约束: There are always some financial constraints on a project like this. 类似这样的工程总是在财政方面受到掣肘。 [SYN] restriction 同义词为restriction

constrict
/kənˈstrɪkt ||; kənˈstrɪkt/verb[I,T]
1 to become or make sth tighter, narrower or less 紧缩；收缩；收紧: She felt her throat constrict with fear. 由于害怕，她觉得喉咙哽住了。 The valve constricts the flow of air. 阀门减少空气的流动。
2 to limit a person's freedom to do sth 限制 ➔constriction noun [C,U]

construct
/kənˈstrʌkt ||; kənˈstrʌkt/verb [T] to build or make sth 建筑；建造: Early houses were constructed out of mud and sticks. 早期的房屋是用泥土和树枝建造的。 ☞ Construct is more formal than build. 与build相比，construct多用于正式场合。

*construction
/kənˈstrʌkʃn ||; kənˈstrʌkʃən/noun
1 [U] the act or method of building or making sth 建造；修筑；施工: A new bridge is now under construction. 一座新桥正在施工。 He works in the construction industry. 他从事建筑业。
2 [C] (formal 正式) something that has been built or made; a building 建筑物；造成的东西: The new pyramid was a construction of glass and steel. 新的金字塔用玻璃和钢建成。
3 [C] the way that words are used together in a phrase or sentence 词句的结构: a grammatical construction 语法结构

conˈstruction site
noun [C] (especially US 尤为美) = building site

constructive
/kənˈstrʌktɪv ||; kənˈstrʌktɪv/adj useful or helpful 有用的；有益的；建设性的: constructive suggestions/criticisms/advice 有益的建议╱批评╱忠告 ➔constructively adv

construe
/kənˈstru: ||; kənˈstru/verb [T] (formal 正式)construe sth (as sth) to understand the meaning of sth in a particular way 把…理解为: Her confident manner is often construed as arrogance. 她信心十足的样子常被认为是傲慢。 ☞Look at misconstrue. 参看misconstrue。

consul
/ˈkɒnsl ||; ˈkɑnsḷ/noun [C] an official who works in a foreign city helping people from his/her own country who are living or visiting there 领事 ☞Look at ambassador. 参看ambassador。 ➔consular /ˈkɒnsjələ(r); US -səl- ||; ˈkɑnsḷɚ/ adj

consulate
/ˈkɒnsjələt; US -səl- ||; ˈkɑnsḷɪt/noun [C] the building where a consul works 领事馆 ☞Look at embassy. 参看embassy。

consult
/kənˈsʌlt ||; kənˈsʌlt/verb
1 [T] consult sb/sth (about sth) to ask sb for some information or advice, or to look for it in a book, etc 咨询；请教；参考: If the symptoms continue, consult your doctor. 如果症状不消失，要找医生诊治。
2 [I] consult with sb to discuss sth with sb 商讨；商量；商议: Harry consulted with his brothers before selling the family business. 哈里卖掉家族生意之前曾跟兄弟商量过。

consultancy
/kənˈsʌltənsi ||; kənˈsʌltənsɪ/noun (plural consultancies)
1 [C] a company that gives expert advice on a particular subject 咨询公司；顾问公司
2 [U] expert advice that sb is paid to provide on a particular subject 专家意见

consultant
/kənˈsʌltənt ||; kənˈsʌltənt/noun[C]
1 a person who gives advice to people on business, law, etc 顾问: a firm of management consultants 管理顾问公司
2 (Brit 英) a hospital doctor who is a specialist in a particular area of medicine 顾问医师: a consultant psychiatrist 精神科顾问医师

consultation
/ˌkɒnslˈteɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsḷˈteʃən/noun[C,U]
1 a discussion between people before a decision is taken 磋商会；讨论会；咨询会: Diplomats met for consultations on the hostage crisis. 外交官员就人质危机进行磋商。 The measures were introduced without consultation. 当局没有征询意见就实行该等措施。
2 (formal 正式) meeting sb to get information or advice, or looking for it in a book 咨询；商议；参考: a consultation with a doctor 找医生看病

consume
/kənˈsju:m;-ˈsʌ:m/verb [T] (formal 正式)
1 to use sth such as fuel, energy or time 使用，消耗（燃料、能源或时间）: This car consumes a lot of petrol. 这辆汽车的耗油量很大。
2 to eat or drink sth 吃；喝: Wrestlers can consume up to 10000 calories in a day. 摔跤运动员一天可消耗多达10000卡路里热量。 ☞noun consumption 名词为consumption
3 (used about fire) to destroy sth （指火）烧毁，焚毁
4 (used about an emotion) to affect sb very strongly （指情绪）支配，影响: She was consumed by grief when her son was killed. 她因儿子遇害而痛不欲生。

*consumer
/kənˈsju:mə(r); US -ˈsu:- ||; kənˈsumɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who buys things or uses services 消费者
2 a person or an animal that eats or uses sth 取食者；消耗者 ☞picture at food chain 见food chain插图

consuming
/kənˈsju:mɪŋ ||; kənˈsumɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that takes up a lot of your time and attention 占去大量时间和精力的: Sport is her consuming passion. 她热衷于运动。

consummate¹
/ˈkɒnsəmət ||; kənˈsʌmɪt/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (formal 正式) extremely skilled; a perfect example of sth 造诣极高的；技术完美的: a consummate performer/professional 造诣极高的表演者╱专业人员
consummate²
/ˈkɒnsəmeɪt ||; ˈkɑnsəˌmet/verb [T] (formal 正式) to make a marriage or relationship complete by having sex （新婚夫妇行房以）完婚，圆房 ➔consummation /ˌkɒnsəˈmeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnsəˈmeʃən/ noun [C,U]

consumption
/kənˈsʌmpʃn ||; kənˈsʌmpʃən/noun [U]:
1 the amount of fuel, etc that sth uses （燃料等的）消耗量: a car with low fuel consumption 耗油量低的汽车
2 the act of using, eating, etc sth 食用；使用；消耗: The meat was declared unfit for human consumption (= for people to eat). 这种肉被宣布为不适宜人类食用。 ☞verb consume 动词为consume

cont.
(also contd) abbr continued 待续: cont. on p 91 下接第91页

*contact¹
/ˈkɒntækt ||; ˈkɑntækt/noun
1 [U] contact (with sb/sth) meeting, talking to or writing to sb else 联络；联系；接触: They are trying to make contact with the kidnappers. 他们正设法与绑架者接触。 We keep in contact with our office in New York. 我们与纽约的办事处保持联系。 It's a pity to lose contact with old schoolfriends. 跟老同学失去联系是一件很遗憾的事。
2 [U] contact (with sb/sth) the state of touching sb/sth 挨着；碰着；接触: This product should not come into contact with food. 这种产品不应接触食物。
3 [C] a person that you know who may be able to help you 可以提供协助的相识: business contacts 业务上有用的相识
4 [C] an electrical connection 接触（器）；触点: The switches close the contacts and complete the circuit. 开关闭合接触器，电路便通了。 ☞picture at bulb 见bulb插图
contact²
/ˈkɒntækt ||; ˈkɑntækt/verb [T] to telephone or write to sb 联络；联系: Is there a phone number where I can contact you? 能不能给我一个电话号码，以便同你联络？

ˈcontact lens
noun [C] a small piece of plastic that fits onto your eye to help you to see better 隐形眼镜 ☞picture at glasses 见glasses插图

contagious
/kənˈteɪdʒəs ||; kənˈtedʒəs/adj (used about a disease) that you can get by touching sb/sth （指疾病）可通过接触传染的: Smallpox is a highly contagious disease. 天花是一种很容易通过接触传染的疾病。 (figurative 比喻) Her laugh is contagious. 她的笑声引起连锁反应。 Look at the note at infectious. 参看infectious的注释。 ➔contagion /kənˈteɪdʒən ||; kənˈtedʒən/ noun [U]

*contain
/kənˈteɪn ||; kənˈten/verb [T] (not used in the continuous tenses 不用于进行时)
1 to have sth inside or as part of itself 包含；含有: Each box contains 24 tins. 每箱装有24罐。
2 to keep sth within limits; to control sth 限制；控制；抑制: efforts to contain inflation 控制通货膨胀的努力 She found it hard to contain her anger. 她觉得难以抑制自己的怒气。
Although this verb is not used in the continuous tenses, it is common to see the present participle (= -ing form) petrol containing lead 虽然这个动词不用于进行时，但它的现在分词还是常见：petrol containing lead含铅汽油 Contain or include ? We use contain to talk about objects which have other things inside them a jar containing olives This film contains violent scenes.we use include to show that sb/sth forms part of a whole or belongs to something a team of seven people including a cameraman and a doctor The price of the holiday includes accommodation. 用contain抑或用include？contain用于内里有其他东西的对象：a jar containing olives装有橄榄的瓶子 · This film contains violent scenes. 这部影片里有暴力场面。include用于若干东西构成一个整体或属于某物：a team of seven people including a camaraman and a doctor 一组七人，包括一名摄影师及一名医生 · The price of the holiday includes accommodation. 度假的费用包括住宿。

*container
/kənˈteɪnə(r) ||; kənˈtenɚ/noun[C]
1 a box, bottle, packet, etc in which sth is kept 容器: a plastic container 塑料容器
2 a large metal box that is used for transporting goods by sea, road or rail 集装箱；货柜: a container lorry/ship 集装箱卡车╱船

contaminant
/kənˈtæmɪnənt ||; kənˈtæmənənt/noun [C] any substance that makes sth dirty or not pure 致污物

contaminate
/kənˈtæmɪneɪt ||; kənˈtæməˌnet/verb [T] to add a substance which will make sth dirty or harmful 污染: The town's drinking water was contaminated with poisonous chemicals. 这城市的饮用水被有毒化学物质污染。 ➔contamination /kənˌtæmɪˈneɪʃn ||; kənˌtæməˈneʃən/ noun [U]

contemplate
/ˈkɒntəmpleɪt ||; ˈkɑntəmˌplet/verb[T]
1 to think carefully about sth or the possibility of doing sth 思量；考虑；盘算: Before her illness she had never contemplated retiring. 她患病之前从没有考虑过退休。
2 to look at sb/sth, often quietly or for a long time 凝视；注视；沉思 ➔contemplation /ˌkɒntəmˈpleɪʃn ||; ˌkɑntəmˈpleʃən/ noun [U]

contemplative
/kənˈtemplətɪv ||; kənˈtɛmplətɪv/adj (formal 正式)
1 thinking quietly and seriously about sth 沉思默想的: She was in a contemplative mood. 她在沉思默想。
2 spending time thinking deeply about religious matters 冥想的；敛心默祷的: the contemplative life(= life in a religious community) 宗教冥想生活

*contemporary¹
/kənˈtemprəri; US -pərerɪ ||; kənˈtɛmpəˌrɛrɪ/adj
1 belonging to the same time as sb/sth else 同时期的；同时代的: The programme includes contemporary film footage of the First World War. 这节目包括第一次世界大战时期的电影镜头。
2 of the present time; modern 当代的: contemporary music/art/society 当代音乐╱艺术╱社会
contemporary²
/kənˈtemprəri; US -pərerɪ ||; kənˈtɛmpəˌrɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural contemporaries) a person who lives or does sth at the same time as sb else 同时期的人；同辈

contempt
/kənˈtempt ||; kənˈtɛmpt/noun [U]: contempt (for sb/sth) the feeling that sb/sth does not deserve any respect or is without value 蔑视；轻视；鄙视: The teacher treated my question with contempt. 老师对我的问题嗤之以鼻。 ➔contemptuous /kənˈtemptʃuəs ||; kənˈtɛmptʃυəs/ adj The boy just gave a contemptuous laugh when I asked him to be quiet. 我让那个男孩安静的时候，他只是轻蔑地一笑。

contemptible
/kənˈtemptəbl ||; kənˈtɛmptəbḷ/adj (formal 正式) not deserving any respect at all 卑劣的；不值得尊敬的: contemptible behaviour 卑劣行为

contempt of court ( also contempt)
noun [U] the crime of refusing to obey an order made by a court of law; not showing respect for a court or judge 藐视法庭﹙罪﹚: Any person who disregards this order will be found in contempt of court. 任何漠视这一指令的人将被判藐视法庭。

contend
/kənˈtend ||; kənˈtɛnd/verb
1 [I] contend with/against sb/sth to have to deal with a problem or a difficult situation 克服（难题或困难局面）: She's had a lot of problems to contend with. 她有很多难题要克服。
2 [T] (formal 正式) to say or argue that sth is true 断言；主张；辩白: The young man contended that he was innocent. 该青年男子声称自己是无辜的。
3 [I] contend (for sth) to compete against sb to win or gain sth 争夺；竞争: Two athletes are contending for first place. 两名运动员正在争夺第一名。

contender
/kənˈtendə(r) ||; kənˈtɛndɚ/noun [C] a person who may win a competition 竞赛者；竞争者: There are only two serious contenders for the leadership. 只有两位人士在认真角逐领袖的地位。

*content¹
/kənˈtent ||; kənˈtɛnt/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) content (with sth);content to do sth happy or satisfied with what you have or do 满足；满意: I don't need a new car -- I'm perfectly content with the one I've got. 我不需要新车─现有的这辆车我已经很满意了。
*content²
/ˈkɒntent ||; ˈkɑntɛnt/noun
1 contents [pl] the thing or things that are inside sth 内容；里面的东西: Add the contents of this packet to a pint of cold milk and mix well. 将包内的材料加入一品脱冷牛奶，然后搅匀。
2 [sing] the main subject, ideas, etc of a book, article, television programme, etc （书、文章、电视节目等的）内容，要义，要旨: The content of the essay is good, but there are too many grammatical mistakes. 这文章内容不错，可惜语法错误太多。
3 [sing] the amount of a particular substance that sth contains 含量: Many processed foods have a high sugar content. 许多加工食品含糖量很高。
content³
/kənˈtent ||; kənˈtɛnt/noun[sing] to your heart's content→HEART
content⁴
/kənˈtent ||; kənˈtɛnt/verb [T] content yourself with sth to accept sth even though it was not exactly what you wanted 将就: The restaurant was closed, so we had to content ourselves with a sandwich. 餐馆已经关门，我们只好将就一下，吃一块三明治。

contented
/kənˈtentɪd ||; kənˈtɛntɪd/adj happy or satisfied 快乐；满意: The baby gave a contented chuckle. 婴儿发出满足的笑声。 ➔contentedly adv

contention
/kənˈtenʃn ||; kənˈtɛnʃən/noun (formal 正式)
1 [U] arguing; disagreement 争辩；争论
2 [C] your opinion; sth that you say is true 意见；主张；论点: The government's contention is that unemployment will start to fall next year. 政府的论点是失业人数明年会开始下降。
in contention (for sth) having a chance of winning a competition 竞争；争夺: Four teams are still in contention for the cup. 仍有四个队在争夺奖杯。

contentious
/kənˈtenʃəs ||; kənˈtɛnʃəs/adj likely to cause argument 可能惹起争议的: a contentious issue 有争议的问题

contentment
/kənˈtentmənt ||; kənˈtɛntmənt/noun [U] a feeling of happy satisfaction 满意；满足

contest¹
/ˈkɒntest ||; ˈkɑntɛst/noun [C] a competition to find out who is the best, strongest, most beautiful, etc 比赛；竞赛: I've decided to enter that writing contest. 我决定参加那个写作比赛。 The by-election will be a contest between the two main parties. 这次补选将是两个主要政党的一场对垒。
contest²
/kənˈtest ||; kənˈtɛst/verb[T]
1 to take part in a competition or try to win sth 参加竞争；争取赢得: Twenty-four teams will contest next year's World Cup. 将有二十四支球队争夺明年的世界杯。
2 to say that sth is wrong or that it was not done properly 反驳；质疑: They contested the decision, saying that the judges had not been fair. 他们对裁决提出质疑，说法官不公正。

contestant
/kənˈtestənt ||; kənˈtɛstənt/noun [C] a person who takes part in a contest 参赛者；竞争者: Four contestants appear on the quiz show each week. 每周有四名参赛者在这个问答节目中亮相。

context
/ˈkɒntekst ||; ˈkɑntɛkst/noun[C,U]
1 the situation in which sth happens or that caused sth to happen （事情发生或引致事情发生的）背景，环境: To put our company in context, we are now the third largest in the country. 从行业整体来看的话，我们现在是全国第三大公司。
2 the words that come before or after a word, phrase or sentence that help you to understand its meaning 上下文: You can often guess the meaning of a word from its context. 你常常可以根据上下文推测词义。 Taken out of context, his comment made no sense. 断章取义的话，他的话毫无意义。

*continent
/ˈkɒntɪnənt ||; ˈkɑntənənt/noun
1 [C] one of the seven main areas of land on the Earth 洲（地球上七大洲之一）: Asia, Africa and Antarctica are continents. 亚洲、非洲和南极洲是地球上三个大洲。
2 the Continent [sing] (Brit 英) the main part of Europe not including the British Isles 欧洲大陆（不包括不列颠群岛）

continental
/ˌkɒntɪˈnentl ||; ˌkɑntəˈnɛntḷ/adj
1 connected with or typical of a continent 大陆性的；与大陆有关的: Moscow has a continental climate: hot summers and cold winters. 莫斯科属大陆性气候﹕夏天炎热，冬天寒冷。
2 (Brit 英) connected with the main part of Europe not including the British Isles 与欧洲大陆有关的（不包括不列颠群岛）: continental holidays 欧洲大陆假期

ˌcontinental ˈbreakfast
noun [C] a cold breakfast of bread and jam with coffee 欧洲大陆式早餐（只有面包、果酱加咖啡的清淡早餐） ☞Look at English breakfast. 参看English breakfast。

ˌcontinental ˈdrift
