noun [U] (in geology 地质学) the slow movement of the continents towards and away from each other during the history of the earth 大陆漂移（说） ☞Look at plate tectonics. 参看plate tectonics。

ˌcontinental ˈshelf
noun [sing] (in geology 地质学) the area of land under the sea on the edge of a continent 大陆架；大陆棚

ˌcontinental ˈslope
noun [sing] (in geology 地质学) the steep surface that goes down from the outer edge of the CONTINENTAL SHELF to the ocean floor 大陆斜坡（指大陆架外缘向海床倾斜的坡面）

contingency
/kənˈtɪndʒənsi ||; kənˈtɪndʒənsɪ/noun [C] (plural contingencies) a possible future situation or event 可能出现的情况；可能发生的事情；偶发事件: We'd better make contingency plans just in case something goes wrong. 我们最好制订应变计划，以防万一出现什么问题。 We've tried to prepare for every possible contingency. 我们准备应付任何有可能发生的情况。

contingent
/kənˈtɪndʒənt ||; kənˈtɪndʒənt/noun[C] [with.sop]
1 a group of people from the same country, organization, etc who are attending an event 代表团: the Irish contingent at the conference 出席会议的爱尔兰代表团
2 a group of armed forces forming part of a larger force 分遣队；小分队

continual
/kənˈtɪnjuəl ||; kənˈtɪnjυəl/adj happening again and again 一次又一次的；持续的: His continual phone calls started to annoy her. 他频频打电话给她，开始令她生厌。 ☞Look at incessant. 参看incessant。 ➔continually adv

continuation
/kənˌtɪnjuˈeɪʃn ||; kənˌtɪnjυˈeʃən/noun[sing] [U] something that continues or follows sth else; the act of making sth continue 延续；继续 [sing] The team are hoping for a continuation of their recent good form. 这支球队希望保持他们近来的良好状态。 Continuation of the current system will be impossible. 让现行制度继续下去是不可能的。

*continue
/kənˈtɪnju: ||; kənˈtɪnju/verb
1 [I] to keep happening or existing without stopping 连续发生或存在: If the pain continues, see your doctor. 如果疼痛持续，你得找医生诊治。
2 [I,T] continue (doing/to do sth);continue (with sth) to keep doing sth without stopping 继续: They ignored me and continued their conversation. 他们不理会我，继续谈话。 He continued working/to work late into the night. 他继续工作直至深夜。 Will you continue with the lessons after the exam? 考完后你还继续上课吗？
3 [I,T] to begin to do or say sth again after you had stopped （中止后）再继续: The meeting will continue after lunch. 午饭后会议将继续进行。
4 [I,T] to go further in the same direction 继续前进: The next day we continued our journey. 第二天我们继续旅程。

continued
/kənˈtɪnju:d ||; kənˈtɪnjυd/adj going on without stopping 持续的: There are reports of continued fighting near the border. 外传边界附近不断有战斗。

conˌtinuing eduˈcation
noun [U] = adult education

continuity
/ˌkɒntɪˈnju:əti;-ˈnu:-/noun [U] the fact of continuing without stopping or of staying the same 持续；连续性；连贯性: The pupils will have the same teacher for two years to ensure continuity. 这班学生将跟随同一位老师学习两年以确保连贯性。

continuo
/kənˈtɪnjuəʊ ||; kənˈtɪnjυˌo/noun [U] music that is played as a background to the main voice or instrument （音乐）数字低音

*continuous
/kənˈtɪnjuəs ||; kənˈtɪnjυəs/adj happening or existing without stopping 连续的；不间断的: There was a continuous line of cars stretching for miles. 车龙绵延数英里。 ➔continuously adv It has rained continuously here for three days. 这里已连续下了三天雨。

conˌtinuous asˈsessment
noun [U] a system of giving a student a final mark based on work done during a course of study rather than on one exam 持续评估（指给学生最后打分，不是取决于一次考试，还要看平时成绩）

continuum
/kənˈtɪnjuəm ||; kənˈtɪnjυəm/noun [C] (plural continua /-juə ||; -jυə/) a continuous series of things, in which each one is only slightly different from the things next to it, but the last is very different from the first 连续体（后一事物比前一事物略微不同，但最后一物跟第一事物大不一样）

contort
/kənˈtɔ:t ||; kənˈtɔrt/verb [I,T] to move or to make sth move into a strange or unusual shape 扭曲；扭歪: His face contorted/was contorted with pain. 他痛得脸都变了形。 ➔contortion noun [C]

contour
/ˈkɒntʊə(r) ||; ˈkɑntυr/noun[C]
1 the shape of the outer surface of sth 轮廓；外形: I could just make out the contours of the house in the dark. 黑暗中我只能勉强看出房子的轮廓。
2 (also contour line) a line on a map joining places of equal height 等高线（地图上由同等高度的点连起来的线）

contra-
/ˈkɒntrə ||; ˈkɑntrə/prefix (used in nouns, verbs and adjectives 用于构成名词、动词及形容词) against; opposite 反对；相反: contradict (= say the opposite) 反驳

contraband
/ˈkɒntrəbænd ||; ˈkɑntrəˌbænd/noun [U] goods that are taken into or out of a country illegally 走私货；违禁品: contraband cigarettes 走私香烟

contraception
/ˌkɒntrəˈsepʃn ||; ˌkɑntrəˈsɛpʃən/noun [U] the ways of preventing a woman from becoming pregnant 避孕；节育: a reliable form of contraception 可靠的避孕方法 ☞Look at birth control and family planning. 参看birth control及family planning。

contraceptive
/ˌkɒntrəˈseptɪv ||; ˌkɑntrəˈsɛptɪv/noun [C] a drug or a device that prevents a woman from becoming pregnant 避孕药；避孕用品 contraceptive adj

*contract¹
/ˈkɒntrækt ||; ˈkɑntrækt/noun [C] a written legal agreement 契约；合同；合约: They signed a three-year contract witha major record company. 他们与一家大唱片公司签了一份为期三年的合约。 a temporary contract 临时合同
contract²
/kənˈtrækt ||; kənˈtrækt/verb
1 [I,T] to become or to make sth smaller or shorter 收缩；缩小；缩短: Metals contract as they cool. 金属冷却便收缩。 [OPP] expand 反义词为expand
2 [T] to get an illness or disease, especially a serious one 染上（疾病，尤指重病）: to contract pneumonia 染上肺炎
3 [I,T] to make a written legal agreement with sb to do sth 订立合约；签订合约: His firm has been contracted to supply all the furniture for the new building. 他的公司已经签约，为新大厦供应所有家具。
contract sth out (to sb) to arrange for work to be done by sb outside your own company 外包（把公司工作发给外人）

contraction
/kənˈtrækʃn ||; kənˈtrækʃən/noun
1 [U] the process of becoming or of making sth become smaller or shorter 收缩；缩小: the expansion and contraction of a muscle 肌肉的扩张与收缩
2 [C] a strong movement of the muscles that happens to a woman as her baby is born （女性分娩时的）子宫收缩
3 [C] a shorter form of a word or words （词语的）缩约形式: ‘Mustn't’ is a contraction of ‘must not’. mustn't是must not的缩约形式。

contractor
/kənˈtræktə(r) ||; kənˈtræktɚ/noun [C] a person or company that has a contract to do work or provide goods or services for another company 承包人；承包商；承建商

contractual
/kənˈtræktʃuəl ||; kənˈtræktʃυəl/adj connected with or included in a contract 与合同有关的；契约的

contradict
/ˌkɒntrəˈdɪkt ||; ˌkɑntrəˈdɪkt/verb [T] to say that sth is wrong or not true; to say the opposite of sth 否定；反驳；驳斥: These instructions seem to contradict previous ones. 这些指示似乎与先前的互相抵触。

contradiction
/ˌkɒntrəˈdɪkʃn ||; ˌkɑntrəˈdɪkʃən/noun [C,U] a statement, fact or action that is opposite to or different from another one 有抵触或矛盾的说法、事实或行为: There were a number of contradictions in what he told the police. 他对警方说的话有若干矛盾之处。 This letter is in complete contradiction totheir previous one. 这封信与他们先前的那封完全矛盾。

contradictory
/ˌkɒntrəˈdɪktəri ||; ˌkɑntrəˈdɪktərɪ/adj being opposite to or not matching sth else 相抵触的；有矛盾的: Contradictory reports appeared in the newspapers. 报刊上出现相互矛盾的报道。

contraflow
/ˈkɒntrəfləʊ ||; ˈkɑntrəˌflo/noun [C] the system that is used when one half of a wide road is closed for repairs, and traffic going in both directions has to use the other side 单线双向行车（通常由于半边道路需要封闭维修）

contralto
/kənˈtræltəʊ ||; kənˈtrælto/noun [C,U] the lowest female singing voice; a woman with this voice 女低音；女低音歌手

contraption
/kənˈtræpʃn ||; kənˈtræpʃən/noun [C] a strange or complicated piece of equipment 新奇或复杂的器械或装置: The first aeroplanes were dangerous contraptions. 最早期的飞机是危险的新鲜玩意儿。

contrapuntal
/ˌkɒntrəˈpʌntl ||; ˌkɑntrəˈpʌntḷ/adj (in music) having two or more tunes played together to form a whole （音乐）复调的 ☞noun counterpoint 名词为counterpoint

contrary¹
/ˈkɒntrəri; US -trerɪ ||; ˈkɑntrɛrɪ/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) completely different; opposite 完全不同的；相反的: I thought it was possible, but she took the contrary view. 我认为行得通，但她的看法相反。
2 contrary to completely different from; opposite to; against 完全不同于；与…相反；反对；违反: Contrary to popular belief (= to what many people think), not all boxers are stupid. 跟许多人的看法相反，不是所有的拳击手都是很笨的。
contrary²
/ˈkɒntrəri; US -trerɪ ||; ˈkɑntrɛrɪ/noun on the contrary the opposite is true; certainly not 相反；反而: ‘You look as if you're not enjoying yourself.’ ‘On the contrary, I'm having a great time.’ “你看来玩得不太开心。”“才不，我玩得很高兴。” to the contrary(formal 正式) saying the opposite 与之相反: Unless I hear anything to the contrary, I shall assume that the arrangements haven't changed. 除非接到更改的通知，否则我就认为安排不变。

*contrast¹
/ˈkɒntrɑ:st; US -træst ||; ˈkɑntræst/noun
1 [U] comparison between two people or things that shows the differences between them 对比: In contrast to previous years, we've had a very successful summer. 与往年相比，我们今年夏季的收获很丰富。
2 [C,U] (a) contrast (to/with sb/sth); (a) contrast (between A and B) a clear difference between two things or people that is seen when they are compared 明显差别: There is a tremendous contrast between the climate in the valley and the climate in the hills. 山谷的气候与山上的气候回然不同。
3 [C] something that is clearly different from sth else when the two things are compared 截然不同的事物: This house is quite a contrast to your old one! 这幢房子与你旧有的不大相同！
*contrast²
/kənˈtrɑ:st; US -ˈtræst ||; kənˈtræst/verb
1 [T] contrast (A and/with B) to compare people or things in order to show the differences between them 对比: The film contrasts his poor childhood with his later life as a millionaire. 这影片将他贫穷的童年和后来成为富翁的生活加以对比。
2 [I] contrast with sb/sth to be clearly different when compared 形成鲜明的对照: This comment contrasts sharply with his previous remarks. 他这话与先前的说法有天渊之别。

contravene
/ˌkɒntrəˈvi:n ||; ˌkɑntrəˈvin/verb [T] (formal 正式) to break a law or a rule 违法；违章 ➔contravention /ˌkɒntrəˈvenʃn ||; ˌkɑntrəˈvɛnʃən/ noun [C,U]

*contribute
/ˈkɒntrɪbju:t; US kənˈtrɪbju:t ||; kənˈtrɪbjυt/verb contribute (sth) (to/towards sth)
1 [I,T] to give a part of the total, together with others 贡献；参与；捐助: Would you like to contribute towards our collection for famine relief? 你愿意给我们的饥荒赈济基金捐款吗？ The research has contributed a great deal to our knowledge of cancer. 这项研究工作大大增进了我们对癌症的认识。
2 [I] to be one of the causes of sth 导致；促成: It is not known whether the bad weather contributed to the accident. 坏天气是不是造成这起事故的原因之一，现在还不清楚。
3 [I,T] to write articles for a magazine or newspaper （给杂志或报纸）撰稿，投稿

contribution
/ˌkɒntrɪˈbju:ʃn ||; ˌkɑntrəˈbjuʃən/noun [C] a contribution (to/toward sth) something that you give, especially money or help, or do together with other people 贡献，捐献（尤指钱或帮助）: If we all make a small contribution, we'll be able to buy Ray a good present. 如果我们大家都出一点钱，就能给雷买一件好的礼物。

contributor
/kənˈtrɪbjətə(r) ||; kənˈtrɪbjətɚ/noun [C] a person who contributes to sth 作出贡献者；捐助者；投稿人

contributory
/kənˈtrɪbjətəri; US -tɔ:rɪ ||; kənˈtrɪbjəˌtɔrɪ/adj helping to cause or produce sth 有助或促成…的: Alcohol was a contributory factor in her death. 酒精是造成她死亡的一个因素。

contrive
/kənˈtraɪv ||; kənˈtraɪv/verb[T]
1 to manage to do sth, although there are difficulties 成功地应付；克服: If I can contrive to get off work early, I'll see you later. 如果我能设法早点下班，我们就待会儿见。
2 to plan or invent sth in a clever and/or dishonest way 策划；发明；谋划: He contrived a scheme to cheat insurance companies. 他想出一个计谋来欺骗保险公司。

contrived
/kənˈtraɪvd ||; kənˈtraɪvd/adj hard to believe; not natural or realistic 不真实的；虚构的: The ending of the film seemed rather contrived. 电影的结局似乎有点牵强。

*control¹
/kənˈtrəʊl ||; kənˈtrol/noun
1 [U] control (of/over sb/sth) power and ability to make sb/sth do what you want 控制: Rebels managed to take control of the radio station. 叛乱分子设法控制了那家电台。 Some teachers find it difficult to keep control of their class. 有些老师觉得很难管好自己的班级。 He lost control of the car and crashed. 他的车失去控制撞毁了。 I was late because of circumstances beyond my control. 我因为一些自己无法控制的事而迟到。
2 [C,U] (a) control (on/over sth) a limit on sth; a way of keeping sb/sth within certain limits 限制；约束: price controls 物价控制 The faults forced the company to review its quality control procedures. 因为出了毛病，公司不得不检讨质量管理程序。
3 [C] one of the parts of a machine that is used for operating it 控制器；操纵装置: the controls of an aeroplane/a TV 飞机╱电视机的操纵装置 a control panel 控制盘
4 [sing] the place from which sth is operated or where sth is checked 控制室；检查站: We went through passport control and then got onto the plane. 我们通过护照检查，然后登机。
be in control (of sth) to have the power or ability to deal with sth 掌握，控制（某事物）: The police are again in control of the area following last night's violence. 昨夜暴力事件发生后，警方已重新控制该地区。 be/get out of control to be/become impossible to deal with 不受控制；失去控制: The demonstration got out of control and fighting broke out. 示威失去控制，打斗随之发生。 under control being dealt with successfully 得到控制: It took several hours to bring the fire under control. 花了好几个小时火势才得到控制。
*control²
/kənˈtrəʊl ||; kənˈtrol/verb [T] (controlling;controlled)
1 to have power and ability to make sb/sth do what you want 支配；控制；掌管: One family controls the company. 这家公司由一个家族控制。 Police struggled to control the crowd. 警方竭力控制群众。 I couldn't control myself any longer and burst out laughing. 我再也忍不住，大笑起来。
2 to keep sth within certain limits 限制；管制: measures to control price rises 管制物价上扬的措施 ➔controller noun [C] air traffic controllers 空中交通管制人员

conˈtrol freak
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person who always wants to be in control of his/her own and others' lives, and to organize how things are done 控制狂；爱指挥别人的人

conˌtrolled ˈsubstance
noun [C] (technical 术语) an illegal drug 毒品: to be arrested for possession of a controlled substance 因拥有毒品而被捕

conˈtrol tower
noun [C] a building at an airport from which the movements of aircraft are controlled （机场的）指挥塔台

controversial
/ˌkɒntrəˈvɜ:ʃl ||; ˌkɑntrəˈvɝʃəl/adj causing public discussion and disagreement 引起争论的: a controversial issue/decision/plan 有争议的问题╱决定╱计划

controversy
/ˈkɒntrəvɜ:si;kənˈtrɒvəsi||; ˈkɑntrəˌvɝsɪ/noun [C,U] (plural controversies) public discussion and disagreement about sth 公开争议；论战: The plans for changing the city centre caused a great deal of controversy. 市中心的改造计划引起极大的争议。

conurbation
/ˌkɒnɜ:ˈbeɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnɚˈbeʃən/noun [C] a very large area of houses and other buildings where towns have grown and joined together 大都会，集合城市（由多个城市发展联合而成）

convalesce
/ˌkɒnvəˈles ||; ˌkɑnvəˈlɛs/verb [I] to rest and get better over a period of time after an illness 康复 ➔convalescence /ˌkɒnvəˈlesns ||; ˌkɑnvəˈlɛsṇs/ noun [sing] [U] ➔convalescent /ˌkɒnvəˈlesnt ||; ˌkɑnvəˈlɛsṇt/ adj

convection
/kənˈvekʃn ||; kənˈvɛkʃən/noun [U] the process in which heat moves through a gas or a liquid as the hotter part rises and the cooler, heavier part sinks （空气或液体的）对流: convection currents 对流气流

convene
/kənˈvi:n ||; kənˈvin/verb [I,T] (formal 正式) to come together or to bring people together for a meeting, etc 集合，召集（人们）（开会等）

convenience
/kənˈvi:niəns ||; kənˈvinjəns/noun
1 [U] the quality of being easy, useful or suitable for sb 方便；便利: a building designed for the convenience of disabled people 为方便残疾人士而设计的大厦 For convenience, you can pay for everything at once. 为方便起见，你可一次缴付所有费用。
2 [C] something that makes things easier, quicker or more comfortable 使事情更方便、更快捷或更舒适的东西: houses with all the modern conveniences (= central heating, hot water, etc) 具备各种现代化设施的房屋
3 [C] (Brit 英) a public toilet 公开厕所

conˈvenience food
noun [C,U] food that you buy frozen or in a box or can, that you can prepare very quickly and easily 方便食品

*convenient
/kənˈvi:niənt ||; kənˈvinjənt/adj
1 suitable or practical for a particular purpose; not causing difficulty 方便；便利: I'm willing to meet you on any day that's convenient for you. 我乐意在你方便的任何一天与你见面。 It isn't convenient to talk at the moment, I'm in the middle of a meeting. 现在谈不方便，我正在开会。 [OPP] inconvenient 反义词为inconvenient
2 close to sth; in a useful position 近便: Our house is convenient for the shops. 我们家离商店很近，去商店很方便。 ➔conveniently adv

convent
/ˈkɒnvənt; US -vent ||; ˈkɑnvɛnt/noun [C] a place where NUNS (= members of a female religious community) live together 女修道院 ☞Look at monastery. 参看monastery。

convention
/kənˈvenʃn ||; kənˈvɛnʃən/noun
1 [C,U] a traditional way of behaving or of doing sth 习俗；常规；惯例: A speech by the bride's father is one of the conventions of a wedding. 由新娘的父亲致辞是婚礼的习俗之一。 The film shows no respect for convention. 这部电影不落俗套。
2 [C] a large meeting of the members of a profession, political party, etc （专业、政党等举行的）大会，大型会议: the Democratic Party Convention 民主党全国代表大会 [SYN] conference 同义词为conference
3 [C] a formal agreement, especially between different countries 公约；协定: the Geneva Convention 日内瓦公约

conventional
/kənˈvenʃənl ||; kənˈvɛnʃənḷ/adj always behaving in a traditional or normal way 依照惯例的；传统的；保守的: conventional attitudes 传统的态度 I quite like him but he's so conventional (= boring, because of this). 我很喜欢他，但他太古板了。 [OPP] unconventional 反义词为unconventional ➔conventionally /-ʃənəli ||; -ʃənḷɪ/ adv

converge
/kənˈvɜ:dʒ ||; kənˈvɝdʒ/verb [I] converge (on sb/sth) (used about two or more people or things) to move towards each other or meet at the same point from different directions （指两个或以上的人或事物）聚集，会合: Fans from all over the country converge on the village during the annual music festival. 乐迷们从全国各地聚集到村子里，参加这一年一度的音乐节。 ☞picture at short-sighted 见short-sighted插图 ➔convergence noun [U] ➔convergent adj

conversant
/kənˈvɜ:snt ||; kənˈvɝsṇt/adj (formal 正式)conversant with sth knowing about sth; familiar with sth 熟悉: All employees should be conversant with basic accounting. 所有雇员都应当熟悉基本的会计知识。

*conversation
/ˌkɒnvəˈseɪʃn ||; ˌkɑnvɚˈseʃən/noun [C,U] a talk between two or more people 交谈: I had a long conversationwith her about her plans for the future. 我与她谈了很久，谈她的未来计划。 His job is his only topic of conversation. 他的工作是他唯一的话题。 deep in thought/conversation→DEEP¹

conversational
/ˌkɒnvəˈseɪʃənl ||; ˌkɑnvɚˈseʃənḷ/adj
1 not formal; as used in conversation 随便的；谈话式的
2 (onlybeforea noun 只用于名词前) connected with conversation 与谈话有关的 ➔conversationally /-nəli ||; -nḷɪ/ adv

converse
/kənˈvɜ:s ||; kənˈvɝs/verb [I] (formal 正式) to talk to sb; to have a conversation 谈话；交谈

conversely
/ˈkɒnvɜ:sli ||; ˈkənvɝslɪ/adv (formal 正式) in a way that is opposite to sth 相反；颠倒: People who earn a lot of money have little time to spend it. Conversely, many people with limitless time do not have enough money to do what they want. 挣大钱的人没多少时间花钱。相反，许多时间多得不得了的人却没有足够的钱来做想做的事。

conversion
/kənˈvɜ:ʃn; US kənˈvɜ:rʒn ||; kənˈvɝʒən/noun [C,U] (a) conversion (from sth) (into/to sth)
1 the act or process of changing from one form, system or use to another 转换；转变；转化: a conversion table for miles and kilometres 英里与公里换算表
2 becoming a member of a different religion 皈依，改宗，归正（指信仰的改变）

convert¹
/kənˈvɜ:t ||; kənˈvɝt/verb[I,T]
1 convert (sth) (from sth) (into/to sth) to change from one form, system or use to another 转换；转变: a sofa that converts into a double bed 可用作双人床的沙发 How do you convert pounds into kilos? 怎样把磅换算为公斤？
2 convert (sb) (from sth) (to sth) to change or to persuade sb to change to a different religion （使别人）改变宗教信仰；（使）皈依: As a young man he converted to Islam. 他年青时已皈依伊斯兰教。 to convert people to Christianity 使人皈依基督教
convert²
/ˈkɒnvɜ:t ||; ˈkɑnvɝt/noun [C] a convert (to sth) a person who has changed his/her religion 皈依者；改宗者；改变宗教信仰的人

convertible¹
/kənˈvɜ:təbl ||; kənˈvɝtəbḷ/adj able to be changed into another form 可改变的；可变换的: convertible currencies (= those that can be exchanged for other currencies) 可兑换货币
convertible²
/kənˈvɜ:təbl ||; kənˈvɝtəbḷ/noun [C] a car with a roof that can be folded down or taken off 折迭式敞篷汽车

convex
/ˈkɒnveks ||; ˈkɑnvɛks/adj having a surface that curves towards the outside of sth, like an eye 凸的；凸圆的: a convex lens 凸透镜 ☞Look at concave. 参看concave。 ☞picture at lens 见lens插图

convey
/kənˈveɪ ||; kənˈve/verb[T]
1 convey sth (to sb) to make ideas, thoughts, feelings, etc known to sb 传达；表达: The film conveys a lot of information but in an entertaining way. 这部电影以趣味十足的手法传达很多信息。 Please convey my sympathy to her at this sad time. 在此哀伤时刻，请转达我对她的慰问。
2 (formal 正式) to take sb/sth from one place to another, especially in a vehicle 运输；运送；输送

conˈveyor belt
noun [C] a moving belt that carries objects from one place to another, for example in a factory 传送带；运输带；输送带

convict¹
/kənˈvɪkt ||; kənˈvɪkt/verb [T] convict sb (of sth) to say officially in a court of law that sb is guilty of a crime 宣判…有罪；定罪: He was convicted of armed robbery and sent to prison. 他被判持械行劫罪而入狱。 [OPP] acquit 反义词为acquit
convict²
/ˈkɒnvɪkt ||; ˈkɑnvɪkt/noun [C] a person who has been found guilty of a crime and put in prison （已定罪的）囚犯，监犯

conviction
/kənˈvɪkʃn ||; kənˈvɪkʃən/noun
1 [C,U] the action of finding sb guilty of a crime in a court of law 定罪；判罪: He has several previous convictions for burglary. 他曾经多次被判犯了盗窃罪。
2 [C] a very strong opinion or belief 坚定的立场或信念: religious convictions 坚定的宗教信念
3 [U] the feeling of being certain about what you are doing 坚定: He played without conviction and lost easily. 他信心不足，在比赛中轻易地就输了。

*convince
/kənˈvɪns ||; kənˈvɪns/verb[T]
1 convince sb (of sth/that...) to succeed in making sb believe sth 使人相信；说服: She convinced him of the need to go back. 在她说服之下他终于相信有必要回去。 I couldn't convince her that I was right. 我无法使她相信我是对的。
2 convince sb (to do sth) to persuade sb to do sth 说服；劝说: The salesman convinced them to buy a new cooker. 售货员说服他们买一个新炉子。

*convinced
/kənˈvɪnst ||; kənˈvɪnst/adj (not before a noun 不用于名词前) completely sure about sth 确信；坚信: He's convinced of his ability to win. 他确信自己有能力获胜。

convincing
/kənˈvɪnsɪŋ ||; kənˈvɪnsɪŋ/adj
1 able to make sb believe sth 令人信服的: Her explanation for her absence wasn't very convincing. 她对自己缺席的解释并不太令人信服。
2 (used about a victory) complete; clear （指胜利）完全的，彻底的: a convincing win 彻底的胜利 ➔convincingly adv

convivial
/kənˈvɪviəl ||; kənˈvɪvɪəl/adj (formal 正式) happy and friendly in atmosphere or character （气氛或性格）快活的，友好的 ➔conviviality /kənˌvɪviˈæləti ||; kənˌvɪvɪˈælətɪ/ noun [U]

convoy
/ˈkɒnvɔɪ ||; ˈkɑnvɔɪ/noun [C,U] a group of vehicles or ships travelling together 车队；船队: a convoy of lorries 一队卡车 warships travelling in convoy 结队航行的战舰

convulse
/kənˈvʌls ||; kənˈvʌls/verb [I,T] to make sudden violent movements that you cannot control; to cause sb to move in this way （使）抽搐；（使）剧烈摇动: He was convulsed with pain. 他痛得直摇晃。

convulsion
/kənˈvʌlʃn ||; kənˈvʌlʃən/noun [C] [usu.pl] a sudden violent movement that you cannot control 抽搐；痉挛: Children sometimes have convulsions when they are ill. 孩子生病时，有时会出现痉挛。

convulsive
/kənˈvʌlsɪv ||; kənˈvʌlsɪv/adj (used about movements or actions 指动作或行动) sudden and impossible to control 突发的；无法控制的

coo
/ku: ||; ku/verb[I]
1 to make a soft low sound like a bird (a dove) 发出像鸽子叫的咕咕声
2 to speak in a soft, gentle voice 轻柔地说话；低语；喁喁哝哝: He went to the cot and cooed over the baby. 他走到小床边，轻柔地对着婴儿说话。

*cook¹
/kʊk ||; kυk/verb
1 [I,T] to prepare food for eating by heating it 煮，烹，做（饭菜）: My mother taught me how to cook. 妈妈教我怎样做饭。 The sauce should be cooked on a low heat for twenty minutes. 这酱汁必须以慢火煮二十分钟。 He cooked us a meal. 他给我们做了一顿饭。
2 [I] (used about food) to be prepared for eating by being heated （指食物）煮着: I could smell something cooking in the kitchen. 我闻到厨房里有煮东西的味道。
Food can be cooked in various ways: by boiling in a saucepan of hot water; by frying in a frying pan with hot oil or fat; or by grilling under a grill, which heats the food from above. We can toast bread under a grill or in a toaster to make it crisp and brown. Cakes and bread are baked in the oven, but we use the word roast for cooking meat or potatoes in the oven. 食物可以不同方式来烹调：可放在长柄平底锅内用热水煮(boil)；放在煎锅内用热油或脂肪煎(fry)；或用烤架把食物烤熟(grill)。面包可放在烤架或烤面包器内烤(toast)，使之松脆及色泽金黄。蛋糕及面包放在烤箱内烘(bake)，而肉类或马铃薯则放在烤箱里烤(roast)。 cook sth up(informal 非正式) to invent sth that is not true 虚构，杜撰（某事物）: She cooked up an excuse for not arriving on time. 她为迟到编造借口。
cook²
/kʊk ||; kυk/noun [C] a person who cooks 厨师；烹调食物的人: My sister is an excellent cook. 我姐姐的烹饪技术很棒。

cookbook
/ˈkʊkbʊk ||; ˈkυkˌbυk/ (brit also 英亦作 cookery book) noun [C] a book that gives instructions on cooking and how to cook individual dishes(recipes) 烹饪书；食谱

*cooker
/ˈkʊkə(r) ||; ˈkυkɚ/noun [C] a large piece of kitchen equipment for cooking using gas or electricity. It consists of an oven, a flat top on which pans can be placed and often a device which heats the food from above (a grill). （炊事用的）炉具，炉灶（使用气体或电力，包括烤箱、放锅的炉面及烤架） ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

cookery
/ˈkʊkəri ||; ˈkυkərɪ/noun [U] the skill or activity of preparing and cooking food 烹饪法；烹调术: Chinese/French/Italian cookery 中式╱法式╱意大利式烹饪

cookie
/ˈkʊki ||; ˈkυkɪ/noun[C]
1 (US 美) =BISCUIT
2 (computing计算机技术) a computer file with information in it that is sent to the central SERVER each time a particular person uses a NETWORK or the Internet 甜饼；网络跟踪器

*cooking
/ˈkʊkɪŋ ||; ˈkυkɪŋ/noun [U]:
1 the preparation of food for eating 烹饪；烹调: Cooking is one of her hobbies. 烹饪是她的嗜好之一。
A common way of talking about the activity of preparing food is do the cooking In our house, I do the cleaning and my husband does the cooking. 做饭一般叫do the cooking：In our house, I do the cleaning and my husband does the cooking. 在家里，我负责打扫，我丈夫负责做饭。
2 food produced by cooking 饭菜；熟菜: He missed his mother's cooking when he left home. 他离家以后很怀念母亲所做的饭菜。

*cool¹
/ku:l ||; kul/adj
1 fairly cold; not hot or warm 凉的: It was a cool evening so I put on a pullover. 那天傍晚有些凉，我穿了套头毛衣。 What I'd like is a long cool drink. 我想要的是一大杯清凉的饮料。 ☞Look at the note at cold ¹. 参看cold^1的注释。
2 calm; not excited or angry 冷静的；镇定的: She always manages to remain cool under pressure. 她在压力之下总能保持冷静。
3 unfriendly; not showing interest 冷淡的；冷漠的: When we first met, she was rather cool towards me, but later she became friendlier. 我们初次见面时，她对我颇为冷淡，但后来她就变得比较友好。
4 (slang 俚语) very good or fashionable 顶刮刮的；时髦的: Those are cool shoes you're wearing! 你穿着那么时髦的鞋子！
*cool²
/ku:l ||; kul/verb
1 [I,T] cool (sth/sb) (down/off) to lower the temperature of sth; to become cool¹(1) （使）温度下降；（使）变凉: Let the soup cool (down). 让汤凉一凉。 After the game we needed to cool off. 比赛之后，我们得凉快一会儿。 A nice cold drink will soon cool you down. 喝上一杯可口的冷饮，你很快就会凉快起来。
2 [I] (used about feelings) to become less strong （指感情）渐淡
cool (sb) down/off to become or make sb calmer （使）冷静下来
cool³
/ku:l ||; kul/noun [sing] the cool a cool temperature or place; the quality of being cool 略低的气温；阴凉处；清凉: We sat in the cool of a cafe, out of the sun. 我们坐在阴凉的小餐馆里，晒不着太阳。 keep/lose your cool(informal 非正式) to stay calm/to stop being calm and become angry, nervous, etc 能够╱不能够保持冷静

coolant
/ˈku:lənt ||; ˈkulənt/noun [C,U] a liquid that is used for cooling an engine, a nuclear REACTOR, etc 冷却剂，减热润滑剂（用于冷却发动机、核反应堆等）

ˌcooling-ˈoff period
noun [C] a period of time when sb can think again about a decision that he/she has made （某人可对自己的决定进行反思的）冷静期

coolly
/ˈku:lli ||; ˈkullɪ/adv in a calm way; without showing much interest or excitement 冷静；冷淡: At first she was very angry; then she explained the problem coolly. 起初她很生气，后来冷静地把问题解释了一下。

coolness
/ˈku:lnəs ||; ˈkulnəs/noun [U] the quality or state of being cool 凉；冷静；冷漠: the coolness of the water 水的清凉 his coolness under stress 他在压力下的冷静 their coolness towards strangers 他们对陌生人的冷漠态度

coop¹
/ku:p ||; kup/noun [C] a cage for chickens, etc 鸡笼；（关家禽的）笼子
coop²
/ku:p ||; kup/verb coop sb/sth up (in sth) to keep sb/sth inside a small space 将某人或某物限制于狭小的空间内: The children were cooped up indoors all day because the weather was so bad. 由于天气恶劣，孩子们被迫整天留在室内。

cooperate
/kəʊˈɒpəreɪt ||; koˈɑpəˌret/ (brit also 英亦作 co-operate) verb [I] cooperate (with sb/sth)
1 to work with sb else to achieve sth 合作；协力: Our company is cooperating with a Danish firm on this project. 我们公司与一家丹麦公司在这项目上合作。
2 to be helpful by doing what sb asks you to do 合作；协助: If everyone cooperates by following the instructions, there will be no problem. 如果人人都遵循指示办事就不会有问题。

cooperation
/kəʊˌɒpəˈreɪʃn ||; koˌɑpəˈreʃən/ (brit also 英亦作 co-operation) noun [U]:
1 cooperation (with sb) working together with sb else to achieve sth 合作；协力: Schools are working in close cooperation with parents to improve standards. 学校与家长紧密合作以提高教学水平。
2 help that you give by doing what sb asks you to do 合作；协助: The police asked the public for their cooperation in the investigation. 警方呼吁公众协助调查。

cooperative¹
/kəʊˈɒpərətɪv ||; koˈɑpərətɪv/ (brit also 英亦作 co-operative) adj
1 done by people working together 合作的；协力的: a cooperative business venture 合作企业
2 helpful; doing what sb asks you to do 愿意合作或协助: My firm were very cooperative and allowed me to have time off. 我任职的公司十分合作，准许我请假。 [OPP] uncooperative 反义词为uncooperative
cooperative²
/kəʊˈɒpərətɪv ||; koˈɑpərətɪv/ (brit also 英亦作 co-operative) noun [C] a business or organization that is owned and run by all of the people who work for it 合作社: a workers' cooperative 工人合作社

coordinate¹
/kəʊˈɔ:dɪneɪt ||; koˈɔrdṇˌet/ (brit also 英亦作 co-ordinate) verb [T] to organize different things or people so that they work together 协调；统筹: It is her job to coordinate the various departments. 协调各个部门是她的责任。
coordinate²
/kəʊˈɔ:dɪnət ||; koˈɔrdṇɪt/ (Brit 英 co-ordinate) noun [C] one of the two sets of numbers and/or letters that are used for finding the position of a point on a map （地图上的）坐标

coordination
/kəʊˌɔ:dɪˈneɪʃn ||; koˌɔrdṇˈeʃən/ (brit also 英亦作 co-ordination) noun [U]:
1 the organization of different things or people so that they work together 协调；统筹
2 the ability to control the movements of your body properly （身体各部份活动的）协调: Children's coordination improves as they get older. 随着渐渐长大，孩子身体的协调能力提高了。

coordinator
/kəʊˈɔ:dɪneɪtə(r) ||; koˈɔrdɪˌnetɚ/ (brit also 英亦作 co-ordinator) noun [C] a person who is responsible for organizing different things or people so that they work together 协调人；统筹人

cop¹
/kɒp ||; kɑp/ (also copper) noun [C] (informal 非正式) a police officer 警察；警员
cop²
/kɒp ||; kɑp/verb (copping;copped) (informal 非正式) cop out (of sth)(informal 非正式) to avoid sth that you should do, because you are afraid or lazy （因害怕或懒惰而）逃避: She was going to help me with the cooking but she copped out at the last minute. 她本来预备帮我做饭，但却临阵退缩。

cope
/kəʊp ||; kop/verb [I] cope (with sb/sth) to deal successfully with a difficult matter or situation （成功地）应付，对付（困难的事情或环境）: She sometimes finds it difficult to cope with all the pressure at work. 她有时觉得很难应付工作上的巨大压力。

copier
/ˈkɒpiə(r) ||; ˈkɑpɪɚ/ (especially US 尤为美) =PHOTOCOPIER

copious
/ˈkəʊpiəs ||; ˈkopɪəs/adj in large amounts 大量的；丰富的: She made copious notes at the lecture. 她在课堂上做了大量笔记。 [SYN] plentiful 同义词为plentiful ➔copiously adv

ˈcop-out
noun [C] (informal 非正式) a way of avoiding sth that you should do 逃避；推委

copper
/ˈkɒpə(r) ||; ˈkɑpɚ/noun
1 [U] (symbol Cu) a common reddish-brown metal 铜: water pipes made of copper 铜制的水管
2 [C] (Brit 英) a coin of low value made of brown metal （低币值的）铜币: I only had a few coppers left. 我只剩下几个铜币。
3 [C] =COP¹

copra
/ˈkɒprə ||; ˈkɑprə/noun [U] the dried white part of a COCONUT 干椰子仁

copse
/kɒps ||; kɑps/noun [C] a small area of trees or bushes 树丛；灌木林

copulate
/ˈkɒpjuleɪt ||; ˈkɑpjəˌlet/verb [I] (formal 正式) (used especially about animals) to have sex （尤指动物）交配，交媾 ➔copulation /ˌkɒpjuˈleɪʃn ||; ˌkɑpjəˈleʃən/ noun [U]

*copy¹
/ˈkɒpi ||; ˈkɑpɪ/noun [C] (plural copies)
1 something that is made to look exactly like sth else 副本；复制品；拷贝: I kept a copy of the letter I wrote. 我留下一份我写的信的副本。 the master copy(= the original piece of paper from which copies are made) 原件 to make a copy of a computer file 替计算机文件制作副本 ☞Look at hard copy and photocopy. 参看hard copy及photocopy。
2 one book, newspaper, record, etc of which many have been printed or produced （成批制造的书报、唱片等的）一本，一份: I managed to buy the last copy of the book left in the shop. 我赶上买了这本书，这是那店内最后的一本。
*copy²
/ˈkɒpi ||; ˈkɑpɪ/verb (present participle copying third person singular present copies;past tense past participle copied)
1 [T] to make sth exactly the same as sth else 复制: The children copied pictures from a book. 孩子们临摹书里的图片。 It is illegal to copy videos. 复制录像带是违法的。
2 [T] copy sth (down/out) to write down sth exactly as it is written somewhere else 抄写；誊写: I copied down the address on the brochure. 我从小册子上抄下地址。 I copied out the letter more neatly. 我把信更整齐地誊写一遍。
3 [T] =PHOTOCOPY
4 [T] to do or try to do the same as sb else 模仿；仿效: She copies everything her friends do. 她什么都学她朋友的样子。 [SYN] imitate 同义词为imitate
5 [I] copy (from sb) to cheat in an exam or test by writing what sb else has written 抄袭: He was caught copying from another student in the exam. 他被发觉考试时在抄袭另一个学生的答案。

copycat¹
/kɒpikæt ||; ˈkɑpɪˌkæt/noun [C] (informal 非正式) used especially by children about and to a person who copies what sb else does because he/she has no ideas of his/her own ﹙尤为儿童用语﹚模仿者，抄袭者
copycat²
/kɒpikæt ||; ˈkɑpɪˌkæt/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used especially about crimes) similar to and seen as copying an earlier well-known crime, etc ﹙尤指犯罪﹚模仿先前案例的: The copycat phenomenon is a danger to which the media may be contributing. 模仿先前案例的犯罪现象可能是媒体报道导致的。

copyright
/ˈkɒpiraɪt ||; ˈkɑpɪˌraɪt/noun [C,U] the legal right to be the only person who may print, copy, perform, etc a piece of original work, such as a book, a song or a computer program 版权

coral
/ˈkɒrəl; US ˈkɔ:rəl ||; ˈkɔrəl/noun [U] a hard red, pink or white substance that forms in the sea from the bones of very small sea animals 珊瑚: a coral reef (= a line of rock in the sea formed by coral) 珊瑚礁

cord
/kɔ:d ||; kɔrd/noun
1 [C,U] (a piece of) strong, thick string 绳；索
2 [C,U] (especially US 尤为美) (a piece of) wire covered with plastic; flex （塑料皮的）电线，导线 ☞picture at cable 见cable插图
3 cords [pl] trousers made of a thick soft cotton cloth(corduroy) 灯芯绒裤子 ☞Look at vocal cords. 参看vocal cords。

cordial
/ˈkɔ:diəl; US ˈkɔ:rdʒəl ||; ˈkɔrdʒəl/adj pleasant and friendly 友好的；亲切的；热诚的: a cordial greeting/smile 亲切的问候╱笑容 ➔cordially /-diəli; US -dʒəlɪ ||; -dʒəlɪ/ adv

cordless
/ˈkɔ:dləs ||; ˈkɔrdləs/adj without a cord (2) 无线的: a cordless phone/kettle/iron 无线电话；交直流两用式电水壶╱电熨斗

cordon¹
/ˈkɔ:dn ||; ˈkɔrdṇ/noun [C] a line or ring of police or soldiers that prevents people from entering an area （由警察或士兵组成的）警戒线，封锁线，警戒圈
cordon²
/ˈkɔ:dn ||; ˈkɔrdṇ/verb cordon sth off to stop people entering an area by surrounding it with a ring of police or soldiers 以警戒线封锁（某地方）: The street where the bomb was discovered was quickly cordoned off. 发现炸弹的街道很快便被封锁起来。

corduroy
/ˈkɔ:dərɔɪ ||; ˌkɔrdəˈrɔɪ/noun [U] a thick soft cotton cloth with lines on it, used for making clothes 灯芯绒: a corduroy jacket 灯芯绒上衣

core
/kɔ:(r) ||; kɔr/noun
1 [C] the hard centre of certain fruits, containing seeds 果心；果核: an apple core 苹果心
2 [sing] the central or most important part of sth 核心: the core curriculum (= the subjects that all pupils have to study) 核心课程 What's the core issue here? 核心问题是什么？
3 [C] the central part of a planet 行星的核心: the earth's core 地核 ☞picture at seismic 见seismic插图
to the core completely; in every way 完全；彻底: The news shook him to the core (= shocked him very much). 这消息把他吓坏了。

coriander
/ˌkɒriˈændə(r) ||; ˌkɔrɪˈændɚ/noun [U] a plant whose leaves and seeds are used in cooking to flavour food 芫荽，香菜（叶和种子用于调味）

cork
/kɔ:k ||; kɔk/noun
1 [U] a light soft material which comes from the outside of a type of tree 栓皮；软木: cork floor tiles 软木地板
2 [C] a round piece of cork that you push into the end of a bottle to close it, especially a bottle of wine 软木瓶塞 ☞picture at container 见container插图

corkscrew
/ˈkɔ:kskru: ||; ˈkɔrkˌskru/noun [C] a tool that you use for pulling corks (2) out of bottles 瓶塞钻（拔软木瓶塞用的） ☞picture at kitchen 见kitchen插图

*corn
/kɔ:n ||; kɔrn/noun
1 [U] (especially Brit 尤为英) any plant that is grown for its grain, such as wheat; the seeds from these plants 谷类作物；谷物；谷子: a field of corn 一片庄稼 a corn field 庄稼地
2 [U] (US 美) =MAIZE ☞picture at cereal 见cereal插图
3 [U] (US 美) =SWEETCORN ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图
4 [C] a small, painful area of hard skin on the toe （长脚趾上的）鸡眼

cornea
/ˈkɔ:niə ||; ˈkɔrnɪə/noun [C] the transparent part that covers and protects the outer part of your eye 角膜 ☞picture at eye 见eye插图 ➔corneal /ˈkɔ:niəl ||; ˈkɔrnɪəl/ adj

*corner¹
/ˈkɔ:nə(r) ||; ˈkɔrnɚ/noun[C]
1 a place where two lines, edges, surfaces or roads meet 角；角落: Put the lamp in the corner of the room. 把灯放在房间的角落里。 Write your address in the top right-hand corner. 将你的住址写在右上角。 The shop is on the corner of Wall Street and Long Road. 该店位于华尔街和朗道的拐角。 He went round the corner at top speed. 他以高速拐过弯去。
2 a quiet or secret place or area 隐蔽处；僻静处: a remote corner of Scotland 苏格兰一处遥远而偏僻的地方
3 a difficult situation from which you cannot escape 困境；困局: to get yourself into a corner 使自己陷入困境
4 (used in football) a free kick from the corner of the field （指足球）角球
cut corners to do sth quickly and not as well as you should 取巧；走快捷方式 (just) round the corner very near 很近: There's a phone box just round the corner. 电话亭就在附近。
*corner²
/ˈkɔ:nə(r) ||; ˈkɔrnɚ/verb[T]
1 to get a person or an animal into a position from which he/she/it cannot escape 使走头无路: He cornered me at the party and started telling me all his problems. 他在宴会中把我叫到一边，向我诉说他的种种难题。
2 to get control in a particular area of business so that nobody else can have any success in it 垄断: That company's really cornered the market in health foods. 那家公司确实垄断了健康食品的市场。

cornerstone
/ˈkɔ:nəstəʊn ||; ˈkɔrnɚˌston/noun[C]
1 a stone at the corner of the base of a building, often put there in a special ceremony 奠基石
2 the most important part of sth that the rest depends on （某物的）最重要部份，基础

cornflakes
/ˈkɔ:nfleɪks ||; ˈkɔrnˌfleks/noun [pl] food made of small pieces of dried corn and eaten with milk for breakfast 玉米片（烘过的玉蜀黍，常加牛奶作早餐吃）

cornflour
/ˈkɔ:nflaʊə(r) ||; ˈkɔrnˌflaυr/ (US 美 cornstarch /ˈkɔ:nstɑ:tʃ ||; ˈkɔrnˌstɑrtʃ/) noun [U] very fine flour often used to make sauces, etc thicker 玉米粉

ˌcorn on the ˈcob
noun [U] corn that is cooked with all the yellow grains still on the inner part and eaten as a vegetable 玉米棒子 ☞picture at cereal 见cereal插图

corny
/ˈkɔ:ni ||; ˈkɔrnɪ/adj (informal 非正式) too ordinary or familiar to be interesting or amusing 平淡无奇的；陈腐的；陈旧的: a corny joke 陈旧的笑话

corollary
/kəˈrɒləri ||; ˈkɔrəˌlɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural corollaries) a situation, a statement or a fact that is the natural and direct result of another one 必然结果

coronary¹
/ˈkɒrənri; US ˈkɔ:rənerɪ ||; ˈkɔrəˌnɛrɪ/adj connected with the heart 与心脏有关的；冠状动脉的
coronary²
/ˈkɒrənri; US ˈkɔ:rənerɪ ||; ˈkɔrəˌnɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural coronaries) a type of heart attack 冠状动脉血栓

coronation
/ˌkɒrəˈneɪʃn; US ˌkɔ:r- ||; ˌkɔrəˈneʃən/noun [C] an official ceremony at which sb is made a king or queen 加冕典礼

coroner
/ˈkɒrənə(r); US ˈkɔ:r- ||; ˈkɔrənɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to find out the causes of death of people who have died in violent or unusual ways 验尸官

Corp.
abbr (US 美) Corporation 公司: West Coast Motor Corp 西海岸汽车公司

corporal
/ˈkɔ:pərəl ||; ˈkɔrpərəl/noun [C] a person at a low level in the army or air force （陆军或空军的）下士

ˌcorporal ˈpunishment
noun [U] the punishment of people by hitting them, especially the punishment of children by parents or teachers 体罚（尤指家长或老师对儿童进行的） ☞Look at capital punishment. 参看capital punishment。

corporate
/ˈkɔ:pərət ||; ˈkɔrpərɪt/adj of or shared by all the members of a group or organization 全体的；共同的: corporate responsibility 共同责任

corporation
/ˌkɔ:pəˈreɪʃn ||; ˌkɔrpəˈreʃən/noun[C] [with.sop]
1 a large business company 大公司: multinational corporations 跨国公司 the British Broadcasting Corporation 英国广播公司
2 (Brit 英) a group of people elected to govern a particular town or city 市政府（一群经选举产生的人士，负责管治某一市镇）

corps
/kɔ:(r) ||; kɔr/noun [C] [with.sop] (plural corps /kɔ:(r) ||; kɔr/)
1 a part of an army with special duties 特种部队: the medical corps 医疗部队
2 a group of people involved in a special activity 从事某一特别活动的一组人: the diplomatic corps 外交使节团

corpse
/kɔ:ps ||; kɔrps/noun [C] a dead body, especially of a person 尸体（尤指人的） ☞Look at carcass. 参看carcass。

corpus
/ˈkɔ:pəs ||; ˈkɔrpəs/noun [C] (plural corpora /ˈkɔ:pərə ||; ˈkɔrpərə/or corpuses /-sɪz ||; -sɪz/) a collection of written or spoken texts 文集；演说集

corpuscle
/ˈkɔ:pʌsl ||; ˈkɔrpʌsḷ/noun [C] any of the red or white cells found in blood 血球；细胞: red/white corpuscles 红╱白细胞

*correct¹
/kəˈrekt ||; kəˈrɛkt/adj
1 with no mistakes; right or true 正确的；对的；无误的: Well done! All your answers were correct. 做得好！你的答案全对了。 Have you got the correct time, please? 你可否告诉我正确的时间呢？
2 (used about behaviour, manners, dress, etc) suitable, proper or right （指行为、态度、衣着等）得体的，合乎礼仪的: What's the correct form of address for a vicar? 该怎么称呼教区牧师才正确？ [OPP] incorrect 反义词为incorrect ➔correctly adv ➔correctness noun [U]
*correct²
/kəˈrekt ||; kəˈrɛkt/verb[T]
1 to make a mistake, fault, etc right or better 改正；纠正: to correct a spelling mistake 纠正拼写错误 to correct a test (= mark the mistakes in it) 批改测验卷子
2 to tell sb what mistakes he/she is making or what faults he/she has 指出（某人的）错误: He's always correcting me when I'm talking to people. 我与人谈话时，他总是指出我的错误。 ➔correction noun [C,U] Some parts of the report needed correction. 报告中有几处需要修改。

corˈrection fluid
noun [U] a white liquid that you use to cover mistakes that you make when you are writing or typing, and that you can write on top of 修正液；改正液 ☞Look at Tipp-Ex. 参看Tipp-Ex。 ☞picture at stationery 见stationery插图

corrective
/kəˈrektɪv ||; kəˈrɛktɪv/adj intended to make sth right that is wrong 有矫正作用的: to take corrective action 采取纠偏行动

correlate
/ˈkɒrəleɪt; US ˈkɔ:r- ||; ˈkɔrəˌlet/verb [I,T] to have or to show a relationship or connection between two or more things 有关联；显示有联系 ➔correlation /ˌkɒrəˈleɪʃn; US ˌkɔ:r- ||; ˌkɔrəˈleʃən/ noun [C,U] There is a correlation between a person's diet and height. 饮食与身高有关系。

correspond
/ˌkɒrəˈspɒnd; US ˌkɔ:r- ||; ˌkɔrəˈspɑnd/verb[I]
1 correspond (to/with sth) to be the same as or equal to sth; to match 与…一致；符合: Does the name on the envelope correspond with the name inside the letter? 信封上的名字是否跟信内的一致？
2 (formal 正式)correspond (with sb) to write letters to and receive them from sb 通信: They corresponded for a year before they got married. 他们结婚前通了一年信。

correspondence
/ˌkɒrəˈspɒndəns; US ˌkɔ:r- ||; ˌkɔrəˈspɑndəns/noun
1 [U] (formal 正式) the act of writing letters; the letters themselves 通信；信件: There hasn't been any correspondence between them for years. 他们已多年没有通信。
2 [C,U] a close connection or relationship between two or more things 密切的联系或关系: There is no correspondence between the two sets of figures. 两组数字之间没有关联。

correspondent
/ˌkɒrəˈspɒndənt; US ˌkɔ:r- ||; ˌkɔrəˈspɑndənt/noun[C]
1 a person who provides news or writes articles for a newspaper, etc, especially from a foreign country 通讯员，记者，特派员（尤指驻海外的）: our Middle East correspondent, Andy Jenkins 我们驻中东的通讯员安迪˙詹金斯
2 a person who writes letters to sb 通信者

corresponding
/ˌkɒrəˈspɒndɪŋ ||; ˌkɔrəˈspɑndɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) related or similar to sth 相关的；相当的: Sales are up 10% compared with the corresponding period last year. 销售量比去年同期上升百分之十。 ➔correspondingly adv

*corridor
/ˈkɒrɪdɔ:(r); US ˈkɔ:r- ||; ˈkɔrədɚ/noun [C] a long narrow passage in a building or train, with doors that open into rooms, etc 走廊；过道；通道

corrie
/ˈkɒri ||; ˈkɑrɪ/ (also cirquecwm) noun [C] (in geography 地理学) a round area shaped like a bowl in the side of a mountain 山侧碗形凹地

corroborate
/kəˈrɒbəreɪt ||; kəˈrɑbəˌret/verb [T] (formal 正式) to support a statement, idea, etc by providing new evidence （以新的证据）证实，支持（某种说法、意见等）: The witness corroborated Mr Patton's statement about the night of the murder. 证人证实了巴顿先生有关那晚凶杀案的陈述。 ➔corroboration /kəˌrɒbəˈreɪʃn ||; kəˌrɑbəˈreʃən/ noun [U]

corrode
/kəˈrəʊd ||; kəˈrod/verb [I,T] (used about metals) to become weak or to be destroyed by chemical action; to cause a metal to do this （指金属）（由于化学作用而）（被）腐蚀，侵蚀: Parts of the car were corroded by rust. 这辆汽车有些部份生了锈。 ➔corrosion /kəˈrəʊʒn ||; kəˈroʒən/ noun [U] ➔corrosive /kəˈrəʊsɪv ||; kəˈrosɪv/ adj

corrugated
/ˈkɒrəgeɪtɪd ||; ˈkɔrəˌgetɪd/adj (used about metal or cardboard) shaped into folds （指金属或纸板）起皱的，起波纹的

corrupt¹
/kəˈrʌpt ||; kəˈrʌpt/adj
1 doing or involving illegal or dishonest things in exchange for money, etc. （为了钱）干非法或不诚实的事的；贪污的；腐败的: corrupt officials who accept bribes 受贿的贪官 corrupt business practices 商业舞弊
2 (computing计算机技术) containing changes or faults and no longer in the original state 讹误的；有改动或毛病的: corrupt software 损坏的软件 The text on the disk seems to be corrupt. 磁盘上的文本好像有改动。
corrupt²
/kəˈrʌpt ||; kəˈrʌpt/verb
1 [T] to cause sb/sth to start behaving in a dishonest or immoral way 使腐败；使腐化；使堕落: Too many people are corrupted by power. 太多的人当权以后腐化了。
2 [I,T] (computing计算机技术) to cause mistakes to appear in a computer file, etc. with the result that the information in it is no longer correct 损坏；破坏: The program has somehow corrupted the system files. 这程序不知怎地把系统里的文文件损坏了。 corrupted data 错误的数据 The disk will corrupt if it is overloaded. 磁盘要是过载便会出现讹误。

corruption
/kəˈrʌpʃn ||; kəˈrʌpʃən/noun [U]:
1 dishonest or immoral behaviour or activities 舞弊行为或活动；贪污行为或活动: There were accusations of corruption among senior police officers. 有人指控高级警官当中有舞弊的情况。
2 the process of making sb/sth corrupt 腐败；腐化；堕落

corset
/ˈkɔ:sɪt ||; ˈkɔrsɪt/noun [C] a piece of clothing that some women wear pulled tight around their middle to make them look thinner （女性穿的）紧身内衣（使看起来更苗条）

cortex
/ˈkɔ:teks ||; ˈkɔrtɛks/noun [C] (plural cortices /ˈkɔ:tɪsi:z ||; ˈkɔrtɪˌsiz/) (technical术语) the outer layer of an organ in the body, especially the brain （器官）皮层（尤指脑皮层）: the cerebral cortex(= around the brain) 大脑皮层

cortisone
/ˈkɔ:tɪzəʊn;-səʊn ||; ˈkɔrtɪˌzon; -son/noun [U] (medical医学) aHORMONE(= a natural substance produced by the body)that is used to reduce swelling caused by certain diseases and injuries 可的松，可体松（一种激素，用于缓和某些疾病和受伤引起的肿胀）

cosine
/ˈkəʊsaɪn ||; ˈkosaɪn/noun [C] (mathematics数学) (abbr cos) the RATIOof the length of the side next to an ACUTE ANGLE(= one that is less than 90°)to the length of the longest side(the hypotenuse)in a RIGHT-ANGLEDtriangle 余弦（三角形中贴近锐角的一边与斜边之比） ☞Compare sine and tangent. 与sine及tangent比较。

cosmetic¹
/kɒzˈmetɪk ||; kɑzˈmɛtɪk/noun [C] [usu.pl] a substance that you put on your face or hair to make yourself look more attractive 化妆品 ☞Look at make-up. 参看make-up。
cosmetic²
/kɒzˈmetɪk ||; kɑzˈmɛtɪk/adj
1 used or done in order to make your face or body more attractive 化妆用的；美容的: cosmetic products 化妆用品 cosmetic surgery 整容外科
2 done in order to improve only the appearance of sth, without changing it in any other way 表面的；粉饰门面的: changes in government policy which are purely cosmetic 政府在政策上的改变纯粹是摆样子而已

cosmic
/ˈkɒzmɪk ||; ˈkɑzmɪk/adj connected with space or the universe 宇宙的

cosmopolitan
/ˌkɒzməˈpɒlɪtən ||; ˌkɑzməˈpɑlətṇ/adj
1 containing people from all over the world 世界性的；有各国人的: a cosmopolitan city 国际都市
2 influenced by the culture of other countries 受别国文化影响的: a cosmopolitan and sophisticated young woman 一个见多识广而又世故的年轻女子

*cost¹
/kɒst; US kɔ:st ||; kɔst/noun
1 [C,U] the money that you have to pay for sth 费用；价格: The cost of petrol has gone up again. 汽油的价格又涨了。 The hospital was built at a cost of £10 million. 盖这家医院花了1000万英镑。 The damage will have to be repaired regardless of cost. 无论费用多少也要把受损的地方修好。 ☞Look at the note at price. 参看price的注释。
2 [sing] [U] what you have to give or lose in order to obtain sth else 代价；牺牲: He achieved great success but only at the cost of a happy family life. 他牺牲了家庭幸福才换来杰出的成就。
3 costs [pl] the amount of money that the losing side has to pay to the winning side in a court of law 诉讼费用: a £250 fine and £100 costs 250英镑罚款及100英镑诉讼费
at all costs/at any cost using whatever means are necessary to achieve sth 不惜任何代价: We must win at all costs. 我们要不计代价非赢不可。 cover the cost (of sth)→COVER¹ to your cost in a way that is unpleasant or bad for you 付出代价；吃了苦头: Life can be lonely at university, as I found out to my cost. 我因付出过代价才知道，大学生活可能是寂寞的。
*cost²
/kɒst; US kɔ:st ||; kɔst/verb [T] (past tense past participle cost)
1 to have the price of 值；价钱为: How much does a return ticket to London cost? 买一张去伦敦的来回票多少钱？ We'll take the bus -- it won't cost much. 我们乘公共汽车去─这不会花很多钱。 (informal 非正式) How much did your car cost you? 你买这辆车花了多少钱？
2 to make you lose sth 使丧失；使损失: That one mistake cost him his job. 那次错误使他丢了工作。
cost the earth/a fortune to be very expensive 很昂贵

co-star
/ˈkəʊstɑ:(r) ||; ˈkoˈstɑr/verb (co-starring;co-starred)
1 [T] (used about a film, play, etc) to have two or more famous actors as its stars （指电影、戏剧等）（由两位或以上的明星）合演，联合主演: a film co-starring Leonardo di Caprio and Kate Winslett 一部由李奥纳多˙狄˙卡普里欧和凯特˙温斯莱特合演的电影
2 [I] (used about actors) to be one of two or more stars in a film, play, etc （指演员）（与其他演员）合演: Kate Winslett co-stars with Leonardo di Caprio in the film. 凯特˙温斯莱特与李奥纳多˙狄˙卡普里欧在这部影片中携手演出。 co-star noun [C]: His co-star was Marilyn Monroe. 他的搭挡演员是玛丽莲梦露。

ˌcost-efˈfective
adj giving the best possible profit or results in comparison with the money that is spent 有成本效益的；划算的: This alarm system is the most cost-effective way of protecting your property. 装这警报系统是保护你的财产最划算的办法。

costly
/ˈkɒstli; US ˈkɔ:st- ||; ˈkɔstlɪ/adj (costlier;costliest)
1 costing a lot of money; expensive 花钱很多的；昂贵的: a costly repair bill 高昂的修理费用
2 involving great loss of time, effort, etc 代价高的（以致损失大量时间、精力等）: a costly mistake 造成重大损失的错误

ˌcost ˈprice
noun [U] the cost of producing sth or the price at which it is sold without making any money 成本价格 ☞Compare asking price and selling price. 与asking price及selling price比较。

costume
/ˈkɒstju:m; US -tu:m ||; ˈkɑstum/noun[C,U]
1 a set or style of clothes worn by people in a particular country or in a particular historical period （某地或某时期的）服装: 17th century costume 17世纪的服装 Welsh national costume 威尔士的民族服装
2 [C,U] clothes that an actor, etc wears in order to look like sth else 戏装等: One of the children was dressed in a pirate's costume. 孩子当中的一个穿着海盗服装。 The last rehearsal of the play will be done in costume. 该戏的最后一次排练要穿上戏装。
3 [C] (Brit 英) =SWIMSUIT

costume jewellery ( US 美 costume jewelry)
noun [U] large heavy jewellery that can look expensive but is made with cheap materials ﹙廉价﹚人造珠宝饰物

ˈcostume party
noun [C] (US 美) a party where all the guests wear special clothes, in order to look like a different person, an animal, etc 化装舞会

cosy
/ˈkəʊzi ||; ˈkozɪ/adj (cosier;cosiest) (US 美 cozy) warm and comfortable 温暖而舒适的: The room looked cosy and inviting in the firelight. 房间在炉火映照下显得暖和舒适，十分吸引人。

cot
/kɒt ||; kɑt/ (US 美 crib) noun [C]
1 a bed with high sides for a baby 婴儿床
2 (US 美) =CAMP BED ☞picture at bed 见bed插图

cottage
/ˈkɒtɪdʒ ||; ˈkɑtɪdʒ/noun [C] a small and usually old house, especially in the country 村舍，小屋（尤指乡间的）

ˌcottage ˈcheese
noun [U] a type of soft white cheese in small wet lumps 农家干酪（一种白色的小块软干酪）

*cotton
/ˈkɒtn ||; ˈkɑtṇ/noun [U]:
1 a natural cloth or thread made from the thin white hairs of the cotton plant 棉布；棉线: a cotton shirt 棉衬衫 ☞picture at knit 见knit插图
2 (US 美) =COTTON WOOL

ˌcotton ˈwool
noun [U] a soft mass of cotton, used for cleaning the skin, cuts, etc 脱脂棉

cotyledon
/ˌkɒtɪˈli:dn ||; ˌkɑtḷˈidṇ/noun [C] a part inside a seed that looks like a small leaf, which the developing plant uses as a store of food. Cotyledons are the first parts of the seed to appear above the ground when it begins to grow. 子叶（位于种子内部，形似小叶子，种子发芽时首先露出地面）

couch¹
/kaʊtʃ ||; kaυtʃ/noun [C] a long seat, often with a back and arms, for sitting or lying on 长沙发，躺椅（通常有靠背和扶手）: They were sitting on the couch in the living room. 他们坐在客厅的长沙发上。
couch²
/kaʊtʃ ||; kaυtʃ/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) (formal 正式) to express a thought, idea, etc in the way mentioned （以某种语气）表达，措辞: His reply was couched in very polite terms. 他的回复措辞十分得体有礼。

cougar
/ˈku:gə(r) ||; ˈkugɚ/ (US 美) =PUMA

*cough¹
/kɒf; US kɔ:f ||; kɔf/verb
1 [I] to send air out of your throat and mouth with a sudden loud noise, especially when you have a cold, have sth in your throat, etc 咳嗽: Cigarette smoke makes me cough. 香烟的烟雾呛得我咳嗽。 ☞picture at sneeze 见sneeze插图
2 [T] cough (up) sth to send sth out of your throat and mouth with a sudden loud noise 咳出: When I started coughing (up) blood I called the doctor. 我开始咳血，便叫了医生。
cough (sth) up(informal 非正式) to give money when you do not want to （不情愿地）提供（金钱）: Come on, cough up what you owe me! 快，把你欠我的还给我！
cough²
/kɒf; US kɔ:f ||; kɔf/noun[C]
1 an act or the sound of coughing 咳嗽；咳嗽声: He gave a nervous cough before he started to speak. 他紧张地咳了一声，然后开始说话。
2 an illness or infection that makes you cough a lot （因病或感染而）咳嗽: Kevin's got a bad cough. 凯文咳嗽咳得厉害。

*could
/kəd;strong form kʊd ||; kəd; kυd/ modal verb (negative could not short form couldn't /ˈkʊdnt ||; ˈkυdṇt/)
1 used for saying that sb had the ability or was allowed to do sth （用于表示曾经有能力或被允许做某事）: I could run three miles without stopping when I was younger. 我年轻一点的时候一口气能跑三英里。 Elena said we could stay at her house. 埃琳娜说我们可以住在她家里。
If something was possible on one occasion in the past, use was/were able to or managed to The firemen were able to/managed to rescue the children.But in negative sentences could not can be used, too The firemen couldn't rescue the children. 若指某事在过去可能发生，可用was／were able to或managed to：The firemen were able to/managed to rescue the children. 消防员成功把孩子们救出。否定句中也可以用could not：The firemen couldn't rescue the children. 消防员无法把孩子们救出。
2 used for saying that sth may be or may have been possible （用于表示某事有可能或本来有可能发生）: I could do it now if you like. 你喜欢的话，我现在就可以做。 She could be famous one day. 她有朝一日会出名的。 He could have gone to university but he didn't want to. 他本来可以上大学的，但他不想。 You could have said you were going to be late!(= I'm annoyed that you didn't) 其实你可以预先说好会迟到的！
3 used for asking permission politely （用于礼貌地请求准许）: Could I possibly borrow your car? 我可否借用你的车子？
4 used for asking sb politely to do sth for you （用于礼貌地请求别人做某事）: Could you open the door? My hands are full. 请你替我开门行吗？我两手都拿着东西。
For more information about modal verbs, look at the Quick Grammar Reference section at the back of this dictionary. 有关情态动词的详细用法，参看本词典末“语法便览”部份。
5 used for making a suggestion （用于提出建议）: ‘What do you want to do tonight?’ ‘We could go to the cinema or we could just stay in.’ “你今晚想做什么？”“我们可以去看电影，或者就待在家里。”
6 used with the verbs ‘feel’, ‘hear’, ‘see’, ‘smell’, ‘taste’ （与feel、hear、see、smell、taste等动词连用）
These verbs are not used in the continuous tenses. If we want to talk about seeing, hearing, etc at a particular moment in the past, we use could We could hear/see children playing outside. (NOTWe were hearing…) 这些动词不用于进行时。若指曾经看见、听见等可用could：We could hear／see children playing outside. 我们听见／看见孩子们在外面玩耍。（不可说We were hearing…）
coulomb
/ˈku:lɒm ||; kuˈlɑm/noun [C] (abbr C) a unit of electric charge, equal to the quantity of electricity carried in one second by one AMPERE (= one unit of current) 库伦（电量单位，等于电流强度为一安培时一秒钟通过导体的电量）

*council
/ˈkaʊnsl ||; ˈkaυnsḷ/ (also Council) noun [C] [with.sop]
1 a group of people who are elected to govern an area such as a town or county 议会；地方议会: The city council has/have decided to build a new road. 市议会已决定建一条新路。 a council house (= one that a council owns and lets to people who do not have much money) 市或郡建房（市或郡盖了租给穷人住的房子） My dad's on the local council. 我父亲是地方议会议员。
2 a group of people chosen to give advice, manage affairs, etc for a particular organization or activity 委员会；理事会: the Arts Council 文艺委员会

councillor
/ˈkaʊnsələ(r) ||; ˈkaυnsḷɚ/noun [C] a member of a council 议员；委员；理事: to elect new councillors 选出新的议员

counsel¹
/ˈkaʊnsl ||; ˈkaυnsḷ/verb [T] (counselling;counselled (US 美) counseling;counseled)
1 to give professional advice and help to sb with a problem 提供专业意见；指导；辅导
2 (written 书面语) to tell sb what you think he/she should do; to advise 建议；提议: Mr Dean's lawyers counselled him against making public statements. 迪安先生的律师建议他不要发表公开声明。
counsel²
/ˈkaʊnsl ||; ˈkaυnsḷ/noun [U]:
1 (written 书面语) advice 建议；指导；忠告
2 a lawyer who speaks in a court of law 诉讼律师: the counsel for the defence/prosecution 辩方╱控方律师

counselling
/ˈkaʊnsəlɪŋ ||; ˈkaυnsḷɪŋ/ (US 美 counseling) noun [U] professional advice and help given to people with problems 专业意见；指导；辅导: Many students come to us for counselling. 很多学生来找我们辅导。

counsellor
/ˈkaʊnsələ(r) ||; ˈkaυnsḷɚ/ (US 美 counselor) noun [C] a person whose job is to give advice 顾问；辅导员: a marriage counsellor 婚姻问题辅导员

*count¹
/kaʊnt ||; kaυnt/verb
1 [I] to say numbers one after another in order 数（数目）: Close your eyes and count (up) to 20. 闭起眼睛，从1数到20。
2 [T] count sth to calculate the total number or amount of sth 计算，查点（总数或数额）: The teacher counted the children as they got on the bus. 孩子们一边上公共汽车，老师一边清点人数。
3 [T] to include sb/sth when you are calculating an amount or number 计算在内: There were thirty people on the bus, not counting the driver. 公共汽车上有三十个人，司机不算在内。
4 [I] count (for sth) to be important or valuable 重要；有价值: I sometimes think my opinion counts for nothing at work. 我有时觉得，我的意见对工作无足轻重。
5 [I] count (as sth) to be valid or accepted 有效；得到承认: The referee had already blown his whistle so the goal didn't count. 裁判已经吹过哨，所以这个进球无效。 Will my driving licence count as identification? 我的驾驶执照可以作为身分的证明吗？
6 [I,T] to consider sb/sth in a particular way 认为；视作: You should count yourself lucky to have a good job. 你有一份好工作，应该感到幸运。 On this airline, children over 12 count/are counted as adults. 在这条航线上，超过12岁的孩子要算作大人。
Don't count your chickens (before they're hatched) used to say that you should not be too confident that sth will be successful because sth might still go wrong （用于说别对成功信心太足，因为可能会出问题） count against sb to be considered as a disadvantage 被认为对某人不利: Do you think my age will count against me? 你认为我的年纪对我来说是一个不利因素吗？ count on sb/sth to expect sth with confidence; to depend on sb/sth 指望；依赖；依靠: Can I count on you to help me? 我能不能指望得到你的帮助？ count sb/sth out
1 to count things slowly, one by one 逐个数: She carefully counted out the money into my hand. 她仔细地把钱逐一数到我的手里。
2 (informal 非正式) to not include sb/sth 不把某人或某物包括进去: If you're going swimming, you can count me out! 去游泳的话，别把我算在里面！
count²
/kaʊnt ||; kaυnt/noun[C]
1 [usu.sing] an act of counting or a number that you get after counting 计算；查点；算出的数目: At the last count, there were nearly 2 million unemployed. 根据最新的计算结果，有将近200万人失业。 On the count of three, all lift together. 数到三的时候，大家一起提起来。
2 [usu.pl] a point that is made in a discussion, argument, etc 论点: I proved her wrong on all counts. 我把她的论点逐一击破。
keep/lose count (of sth) to know/not know how many there are of sth 晓得╱不晓得有多少: I've lost count of the number of times he's told that joke! 我已记不清他把那个笑话说过多少遍了！

countable
/ˈkaʊntəbl ||; ˈkaυntəbḷ/adj (grammar语法) that can be counted 可数的；可计算的: 'Chair' is a countable noun, but 'sugar' isn't. chair是可数名词，但sugar是不可数名词。 Countable nouns are marked [C] in this dictionary. 本词典里，可数名词以[C]标示。 [OPP] uncountable 反义词为uncountable For more information about countable nouns, look at the Quick Grammar Reference section at the back of this dictionary. 有关可数名词的详细用法，参看本词典末“语法便览”部份。
countdown
/ˈkaʊntdaʊn ||; ˈkaυntˌdaυn/noun [C] the act of saying numbers backwards to zero just before sth important happens 倒数；倒数计时: the countdown to the lift-off of a rocket 火箭发射前的倒数计时 (figurative 比喻) The countdown to this summer's Olympic Games has started. 今年夏天的奥林匹克运动会已进入倒数计时。

countenance
/ˈkaʊntənəns ||; ˈkaυntənəns/noun [C] (written 书面语) a person's face or his/her expression 脸；表情

counter-
/ˈkaʊntə(r) ||; ˈkaυntɚ/prefix (in nouns, verbs, adjectives and adverbs 用于构成名词、动词、形容词及副词) against; opposite 反；逆: counterterrorism 对抗性恐怖主义 a counter-argument 相反的论点 counterproductive 产生相反结果的

counter¹
/ˈkaʊntə(r) ||; ˈkaυntɚ/noun[C]
1 a long, flat surface in a shop, bank, etc, where customers are served 柜台: The man behind the counter in the bank was very helpful. 银行柜台后面那位男士非常肯帮忙。
2 a small object (usually round and made of plastic) that is used in some games to show where a player is on the board 筹码；棋子
3 an electronic device for counting sth 计数器；计算器: The rev counter is next to the speedometer. 转速表就在里程计旁边。 ☞Look at Geiger counter. 参看Geiger counter。
counter²
/ˈkaʊntə(r) ||; ˈkaυntɚ/verb[I,T]
1 to reply or react to criticism 回答；反驳: He countered our objections with a powerful defence of his plan. 他驳斥我们的反对意见，为自己的计划作出有力的辩护。
2 to try to reduce or prevent the bad effects of sth 减少，防止（不良影响）: The shop has installed security cameras to counter theft. 这家商店安装了安全摄像机来对付偷窃。
counter³
/ˈkaʊntə(r) ||; ˈkaυntɚ/adv counter to sth in the opposite direction to sth 与…相反: The results of these experiments run counter to previous findings. 这些试验的结果与先前的发现相悖。

counteract
/ˌkaʊntərˈækt ||; ˌkaυntɚˈækt/verb [T] to reduce the effect of sth by acting against it 抵消: measures to counteract traffic congestion 疏导交通阻塞的措施

ˈcounter-attack
noun [C] an attack made in reaction to an enemy or opponent's attack 反击；反攻 counter-attack verb [I,T]

ˌcounter-ˈclockwise
(US 美) =ANTICLOCKWISE

counterfeit
/ˈkaʊntəfɪt ||; ˈkaυntɚfɪt/adj not genuine, but copied so that it looks like the real thing 伪造的；假冒的: counterfeit money 假钱币

counterfoil
/ˈkaʊntəfɔɪl ||; ˈkaυntɚˌfɔɪl/noun [C] the part of a cheque, ticket, etc that you keep when you give the other part to sb else 存根；票根

counterpart
/ˈkaʊntəpɑ:t ||; ˈkaυntɚˌpɑrt/noun [C] a person or thing that has a similar position or function in a different country or organization 地位相等的人；对应物: the French President and his Italian counterpart (= the Italian President) 法国总统和意大利总统

counterpoint
/ˈkaʊntəpɔɪnt ||; ˈkaυntɚˌpɔɪnt/noun
1 [U] (in music) the combination of two or more tunes to form a whole （音乐）对位法，复调: The two melodies are played in counterpoint. 两支曲调以对位法演奏。 ☞adjective contrapuntal 形容词为contrapuntal
2 [C] a counterpoint (to sth) (in music) a tune played in combination with another one （音乐）对位声部

ˌcounterproˈductive
adj having the opposite effect to the one you want 产生反效果的: It can be counterproductive to punish children. 惩罚孩子可能会产生反效果。

countersign
/ˈkaʊntəsaɪn ||; ˈkaυntɚˌsaɪn/verb [T] (technical术语) to sign a document that has already been signed by another person, especially in order to show that it is valid 副署，会签（文件）

ˈcounter-tenor
noun [C] a man who is trained to sing with a very high voice 上男高音

countless
/ˈkaʊntləs ||; ˈkaυntlɪs/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) very many 无数的；极多的: I've tried to phone him countless times but he's not there. 我给他拨了无数次电话，但他不在那里。

*country
/ˈkʌntri ||; ˈkʌntrɪ/noun (plural countries)
1 [C] an area of land with its own people, government, etc 国家: France, Spain and other European countries 法国、西班牙及其他欧洲国家 There was snow over much of the country during the night. 夜里国内许多地区都下了雪。
State is used for talking about a country as an organized political community controlled by one government. It can also mean the government itself a politically independent state the member states of the EU You get a pension from the state when you retire. state education. Land is more formal or literary Explorers who set out to discover new lands. state指由政府管治的有组织的政治共同体。这个词也可指政府本身：a politically independent state政治上独立的国家 · the member states of the EU欧洲联盟成员国 · You get a pension from the state when you retire. 你退休后会获得政府发给的退休金。· state education 国家教育 。land用于较正式的场合，多用于文学作品：Explorers who set out to discover new lands出发去寻找新土地的探险家
2 the country [sing] the people who live in a country 国民: a survey to find out what the country really thinks 国民民意调查
3 the country [sing] land which is away from towns and cities 乡村: Do you live in a town or the in the country ? 你住在城市还是乡间？
The word countryside also refers to areas of land that are away from towns but it emphasizes the natural features such as hills, rivers, trees, etc that you find there beautiful countryside the destruction of the countryside by new roads.look also at the note at scenery. countryside同样指远离市区的地方，但强调的是有山冈、河流、树木等的自然环境：beautiful countryside美丽的郊野 ·the destruction of the countryside by new roads新建的道路破坏了郊野景观。另参看scenery的注释。
4 [U] an area of land 地带: We looked down over miles of open country. 我们俯瞰连绵数英里的旷野。 hilly country 山区 [SYN] terrain 同义词为terrain
5 =COUNTRY AND WESTERN

ˌcountry and ˈwestern
noun [U] a type of popular music based on traditional music from southern and western US 乡村与西部音乐（源自美国南部和西部的流行音乐）

ˈcountry club
noun [C] a club in the country, or on the edge of a town, where people can play sports and go to social events 乡村俱乐部

ˌcountry ˈhouse
noun [C] a large house in the country, usually owned by an important family and often with a lot of land 乡间邸宅

countryman
/ˈkʌntrimən ||; ˈkʌntrɪmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-mən ||; -mən/) a person from your own country (1) 同一个国家的人；同胞: The Italian Castorri beat his fellow countryman Rossi in the final. 意大利运动员卡斯托里在决赛中击败了他的同胞罗西。

county
/ˈkaʊnti ||; ˈkaυntɪ/noun [C] (plural counties) an area in Britain, Ireland or the US which has its own local government 郡；县: the county of Nottinghamshire 诺丁汉郡 Orange County, California 加利福尼亚州奥兰治县 ☞Compare province and state ¹(4). 与province及state^1(4)比较。

coup
/ku: ||; ku/noun[C]
1 (also coup d'état) /ˌku: deɪˈtɑ:/ a sudden, illegal and often violent change of government 政变: a coup to overthrow the President 计划推翻总统的政变 an attempted coup (= one which did not succeed) 流产的政变
2 a clever and successful thing to do 巧妙而成功的一着: Getting that promotion was a real coup. 这次晋升真赢得漂亮。

*couple¹
/ˈkʌpl ||; ˈkʌpḷ/noun [C] [with.sop] two people who are together because they are married or in a relationship 夫妇；情侣: a married couple 一对夫妻 Is/Are that couple over there part of our group? 那对夫妻是跟我们一起的吗？ ☞ Look also at pair. 另参看pair。 a couple of people/things
1 two people/things 两个人；两件事物: I need a couple of glasses. 我需要一对玻璃杯。
2 a few 若干: I last saw her a couple of months ago. 我上次见她是在几个月前。
couple²
/ˈkʌpl ||; ˈkʌpḷ/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to join or connect sb/sth to sb/sth else 连同: The fog, coupled with the amount of traffic on the roads, made driving very difficult. 大雾加上道路交通拥塞，使驾驶十分困难。

couplet
/ˈkʌplət ||; ˈkʌplɪt/noun [C] two lines of poetry of equal length one after the other 对句（指一前一后两行同等长度的诗）

coupon
/ˈku:pɒn ||; ˈkupɑn/noun[C]
1 a small piece of paper which you can use to buy goods at a lower price, or which you can collect and then exchange for goods 优惠券；赠券；优待券: a coupon worth 10% off your next purchase 下次购物可节省一成的优惠券
2 a printed form in a newspaper or magazine which you use to order goods, enter a competition, etc （剪自报刊的）订购表格，参赛表格

*courage
/ˈkʌrɪdʒ ||; ˈkɝɪdʒ/noun [U] the ability to control fear in a situation that may be dangerous or unpleasant 勇气: It took real courage to go back into the burning building. 要返回燃烧中的大楼需要真正的勇气。 She showed great courageall through her long illness. 她在患病的漫长日子里始终显示出无比的勇气。 [SYN] bravery 同义词为bravery ➔courageous /kəˈreɪdʒəs ||; kəˈredʒəs/ adj pluck up courage→PLUCK¹

courgette
/kɔ:ˈʒet ||; kυrˈʒɛt/ (especially US 尤为美 zucchini) noun [C] a long vegetable with dark green skin that is white inside 小胡瓜 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

courier
/ˈkʊriə(r) ||; ˈkυrɪɚ/noun[C]
1 a person whose job is to carry letters, important papers, etc, especially when they are urgent 信使（尤指送急件的）: The package was delivered by motorcycle courier. 包裹是骑摩托车的信使送来的。
2 a person whose job is to look after a group of tourists 导游

*course
/kɔ:s ||; kɔrs/noun
1 [C] a course (in/on sth) a complete series of lessons or studies 课程: I've decided to enrol on a computer course. 我已决定报名参加计算机课程。 I'm going to take/do a course in self-defence. 我要去学习自恒术课程。
2 [C,U] the route or direction that sth, especially an aircraft, ship or river, takes 航道；航向；河道: The hijackers forced the captain to change course and head for Cuba. 劫机者强迫机长改变航向，驶往古巴。 to be on/off course(= going in the right/wrong direction) 朝正确╱错误的方向走 (figurative 比喻) I'm on course (= making the right amount of progress) to finish this work by the end of the week. 我这项工作进展顺利，周末可以完成。 The road follows the course of the river. 这条路顺着河道延伸。
3 (also course of action) [C] a way of dealing with a particular situation 行动方针；做法: In that situation resignation was the only course open to him. 在那种情况下，他只得辞职。
4 [sing] the development of sth over a period of time 经过；发展过程: events that changed the course of history 改变历史进程的事件 In the normal course of events (= the way things normally happen) such problems do not arise. 在正常情况下，这些问题是不会出现的。
5 [C] the first, second, third, etc separate part of a meal 一道菜: a three-course lunch 有三道菜的午餐 I had chicken for the main course. 我吃的主菜是鸡。
6 [C] an area where golf is played or where certain types of race take place 高尔夫球场；赛马等场地: a golf course 高尔夫球场 a racecourse 赛马场
7 [C] a course (of sth) a series of medical treatments 疗程: The doctor put her on a course of tablets. 医生给她一个疗程的药片吃。
be on a collision course (with sb/sth)→COLLISION in the course of sth during sth 在某事物进行期间: He mentioned it in the course of conversation. 他在谈话过程中提及那事。 in the course of time when enough time has passed; eventually 最终；总有一天 in due course→DUE¹ a matter of course→MATTER¹ of course naturally; certainly 自然；当然: Of course, having children has changed their lives a lot. 有了孩子自然大大改变了他们的生活。 ‘Can I use your phone?’ ‘Of course (you can).’ “我可以借用你的电话吗？”“你随便用吧。” ‘You're not annoyed with me, are you?’ ‘Of course (I'm) not.’ “你不是在生我的气吧？”“当然不是。”

coursebook
/ˈkɔ:sbʊk ||; ˈkɔrsˌbυk/noun [C] a book for studying from that is used regularly in class 课本；教材

coursework
/ˈkɔ:swɜ:k ||; ˈkɔrsˌwɝk/noun [U] work that students do during a course of study, not in exams, that is included in their final mark 平时作业: Coursework accounts for 50% of the final marks. 平时作业占总分的50%。

*court¹
/kɔ:t ||; kɔrt/noun
1 [C,U] a place where legal trials take place and crimes, etc are judged 法庭；法院: A man has been charged and will appear in court tomorrow. 有一名男子被起诉，明天出庭。 Bill's company are refusing to pay him so he's decided to take them to court. 比尔的公司拒绝付他工资，所以他决定控告他们。
2 the court [sing] the people in a court, especially those taking part in the trial 法庭内的人（尤指参与审判者）: Please tell the court exactly what you saw. 请你把当时看见的确切情况告诉本庭。
3 [C,U] an area where certain ball games are played （某些球类活动的）场地: a tennis/squash/badminton court 网球╱壁球╱羽毛球场 ☞Compare pitch ¹. 与pitch^1比较。
court²
/kɔ:t ||; kɔrt/verb[T]
1 to try to gain sb's support by paying special attention to him/her 取悦；讨好: Politicians from all parties will be courting voters this week. 所有政党都会在本周设法赢得选民支持。
2 to do sth that might have a very bad effect 招惹；招致: Britain is courting ecological disaster if it continues to dump waste in the North Sea. 如果英国继续把废物倾倒在北海，就会惹来生态灾难。

courteous
/ˈkɜ:tiəs ||; ˈkɝtɪəs/adj polite and pleasant, showing respect for other people 有礼貌的；彬彬有礼的；客气的 [OPP] discourteous 反义词为discourteous ➔courteously adv

courtesy
/ˈkɜ:təsi ||; ˈkɝtəsɪ/noun (plural courtesies)
1 [U] polite and pleasant behaviour that shows respect for other people 礼貌: She didn't even have the courtesy to say that she was sorry. 她连说声对不起的礼貌也没有。
2 [C] (formal 正式) a polite thing that you say or do when you meet people in formal situations 礼貌的行为或言辞: The two presidents exchanged courtesies before their meeting. 两位总统互相寒暄几句之后就开始会谈。
(by) courtesy of sb(formal 正式) with the permission or because of the kindness of sb 蒙某人允许；由于某人的好意；由某人提供: These pictures are being shown by courtesy of BBC TV. 这些图片由英国广播公司电视台提供。

ˌcourt ˈmartial
noun [C] a military court that deals with matters of military law; a trial that takes place in such a court 军事法庭；军事审判: His case will be heard by a court martial. 他的案件将由军事法庭审理。 court-martial verb [T] (court-martialling;court-martialled (US 美) court-martialing;court-martialed)

ˌcourt of ˈlaw
=COURT¹(1)

ˌcourt ˈorder
noun [C] a decision that is made in a court of law about what must happen in a particular situation 法院指令；庭谕: They didn't send their daughter to school until a court order forced them to. 他们直到接到法院指令才把他们的女儿送到学校。

courtroom
/ˈkɔ:tru:m ||; ˈkɔrtˌrum/noun [C] the place or room where a court of law meets 法庭；审判室

courtship
/ˈkɔ:tʃɪp ||; ˈkɔrtʃɪp/noun [C,U] (old-fashioned 旧) the relationship between a man and a woman before they get married 恋爱（期）；求爱（期）

courtyard
/ˈkɔ:tjɑ:d ||; ˈkɔrtˌjɑrd/noun [C] an area of ground, without a roof, that has walls or buildings around it, for example in a castle or between houses or flats 庭院；天井

couscous
/ˈku:sku:s ||; ˈkusˌkus/noun [U] a type of North African food made from crushed wheat 蒸粗麦粉（一种北非食物）

*cousin
/ˈkʌzn ||; ˈkʌzṇ/ (also ˌfirst ˈcousin) noun [C] the child of your aunt or uncle 堂兄弟；堂姐妹；表兄弟；表姐妹；表亲: Paul and I are cousins. 保罗和我是表兄弟。 ☞The same word is used for both male and female cousins. 这个词可用于男性或女性表亲。 ☞Look at second cousin 参看second cousin。

covalent
/ˌkəʊˈveɪlənt ||; koˈvelənt/adj (technical术语) (used about the way atoms are joined together) sharing an ELECTRON (= a very small part of an atom that has a negative electrical charge) （指原子结合的方式）共享电子的

cove
/kəʊv ||; kov/noun [C] a small area of the coast where the land curves round so that it is protected from the wind, etc 小海湾；小湾: a sandy cove 多沙的小海湾

covenant
/ˈkʌvənənt ||; ˈkʌvənənt/noun [C] a promise to sb, or a legal agreement, especially one to pay a regular amount of money to sb/sth 承诺，契约，合同（尤指定期向某人或某机构付款的） covenant verb · All profits are covenanted to local charities. 所有利润都按照合同定期捐赠给当地的慈善机构。

*cover¹
/ˈkʌvə(r) ||; ˈkʌvɚ/verb[T]
1 cover sb/sth (up/over) (with sth) to put sth on or in front of sth to hide or protect it 盖；遮: Could you cover the food and put it in the fridge? 请你把食物盖好，然后放进冰箱。 She couldn't look any more and covered her eyes. 她再也看不下去，于是闭上双眼。 I covered the floor with newspaper before I started painting. 我先在地板上铺了报纸，然后才涂油漆。 (figurative 比喻) Paula laughed to cover (= hide) her embarrassment. 葆拉笑起来，想要掩饰她的窘态。 [OPP] uncover 反义词为uncover
2 cover sb/sth in/with sth to be on the surface of sth; to make sth do this 盖上一层…: A car went through the puddle and covered me with mud. 汽车驶过水洼，溅了我一身泥。 Graffiti covered the walls. 墙上到处都是乱涂乱画。 The eruption of the volcano covered the town in a layer of ash. 火山爆发使该镇覆盖着一层火山灰。
3 to fill or spread over a certain area 遍布；覆盖: The floods cover an area of about 15000 square kilometres. 洪水已淹没大约15000平方公里的地区。
4 to include or to deal with sth 包括；处理；涵盖: All the papers covered the election in depth. 各报章都详细报道这次选举。 The course covered both British and European history. 这门课程讲述英国和欧洲的历史。
5 to travel a certain distance 走（一段路程）: We covered about 500 kilometres that day. 我们那天走了500公里左右。
6 to be enough money for sth 足够支付: We'll give you some money to cover your expenses. 我们会给你一些钱支付你的开支。
7 cover sb/sth against/for sth to protect sb/sth by insurance 给以保险: The insurance policy covers us for any damage to our property. 这保险单承包我们任何财物损失。
8 cover (for sb) to do sb's job while he/she is away from work 代替（某人）: Matt's phoned in sick so we'll have to find someone to cover (for him). 马特打电话来说病了，所以我们得找个人替他。
cover the cost (of sth) to have or make enough money to pay for sth 有或挣足够的钱支付: We made so little money at our school dance that we didn't even cover the cost of the band. 我们学校舞会挣的钱真少，甚至还不够支付乐队的费用。 cover (sth) up to prevent people hearing about a mistake or sth bad 隐瞒，掩饰（错误、恶行等）: The police have been accused of trying to cover up the facts of the case. 有人指责警方试图隐瞒案件的真相。 cover up for sb to hide a person's mistakes or crimes in order to protect him/her 替某人掩饰、隐瞒错误或罪行；包庇: His wife covered up for him to the police. 他的妻子对警方隐瞒他的罪行。
*cover²
/ˈkʌvə(r) ||; ˈkʌvɚ/noun
1 [C] something that is put on or over sth, especially in order to protect it 遮盖物；盖子；套子: a plastic cover for a computer 计算机的塑料套 a duvet cover 羽绒被被套
2 [C] the outside part of a book or magazine （书刊的）封面，封底，封皮: I read the magazine from cover to cover (= from beginning to end). 我把杂志从头到尾看过了。
3 [U] cover (against sth) insurance against sth, so that if sth bad happens you get money or help in return 保险: The policy provides cover against theft. 这保险单提供盗窃保险。
4 [U] protection from the weather, damage, etc 掩蔽；遮盖；庇护所: When the storm started we had to take cover in a shop doorway. 起风暴时，我们不得不躲进一家商店的门道里。 When the gunfire started everyone ran for cover. 枪声响起，人人都奔跑躲避。 [SYN] shelter 同义词为shelter
5 the covers [pl] the sheets, etc on a bed 被单等床上用品
6 [C,U] a cover (for sth) something that hides what sb is really doing 掩饰（以隐藏真相）: The whole company was just a cover for all kinds of criminal activities. 整家公司只是为各种犯罪活动作掩护。 police officers working under cover 以掩护身分工作的警方
7 [U] doing sb's job for him/her while he/she is away from work 代替人；替补: Joanne's off next week so we'll have to arrange cover. 乔安妮下周休息，所以我们得安排一个人代替她。
under (the) cover of sth hidden by sth 在某事物遮掩下: They attacked under cover of darkness. 他们以黑夜为掩护发动攻击。

coverage
/ˈkʌvərɪdʒ ||; ˈkʌvərɪdʒ/noun [U]:
1 the act or amount of reporting on an event in newspapers, on television, etc 报道；报道涵盖的范围: TV coverage of the Olympic Games was excellent. 有关奥林匹克运动会的电视报道十分出色。
2 the amount or quality of information included in a book, magazine, etc （书刊等的）涉及范围，信息质量: The grammar section provides coverage of all the most problematic areas. 语法部份涉及所有最疑难的范围。

coveralls
/ˈkʌvərɔ:lz ||; ˈkʌvəˌrɔlz/ (US 美) =OVERALL²(2)

covered
/ˈkʌvəd ||; ˈkʌvɚd/adj
1 covered in/with sth having a layer or a large amount of sth on sb/sth 盖上或充满…的: She was covered in mud/sweat/dust. 她满身是泥╱汗╱灰尘。 nuts covered with chocolate 果心巧克力
2 having a cover, especially a roof 有顶盖（尤指有屋顶）: a covered shopping centre 有顶盖的购物中心

covering
/ˈkʌvərɪŋ ||; ˈkʌvərɪŋ/noun [C] something that covers the surface of sth 覆盖物: There was a thick covering of dust over everything. 厚厚的灰尘覆盖着所有的东西。

ˌcovering ˈletter
noun [C] a letter that you send with a package, etc that gives more information about it （随包裹等发出的）附函: To apply for the job, send your CV with a covering letter. 若要申请这份工作，请寄上你的简历及附函。

covert
/ˈkʌvət; US ˈkəʊvɜ:rt ||; ˈkovɚt/adj done secretly 秘密的；暗地里的: a covert police operation 警方的秘密行动 ➔covertly adv

ˈcover-up
noun [C] an act of preventing sth bad or dishonest from becoming known 掩饰；隐瞒: Several newspapers have claimed that there had been a government cover-up. 几家报纸声称政府有隐瞒行为。

covet
/ˈkʌvət ||; ˈkʌvɪt/verb [T] (formal 正式) to want to have sth very much (especially sth that belongs to sb else) 垂涎，觊觎，贪求（他人之物）

*cow
/kaʊ ||; kaυ/noun[C]
1 a large female animal that is kept on farms to produce milk 母牛；乳牛: to milk a cow 挤牛奶 a herd of cows 一群母牛
Cow is often used for both male and female animals. The special word for a male is bull. A male that cannot produce any young and which was used in past times for pulling heavy loads is an ox. A young cow is a calf. A number of cows together can be called cattle. Look at the note at meat. cow常用以兼指公牛及母牛。bull特指公牛。不会生育、过去用来拉车的公牛叫做ox。小牛叫calf。牛群称cattle。参看meat的注释。
2 the adult female of certain large animals, for example elephants 某些大型动物的雌性（如母象）

coward
/ˈkaʊəd ||; ˈkaυɚd/noun [C] a person who has no courage and is afraid in dangerous or unpleasant situations 懦夫；胆小鬼: I hate going to the dentist's because I'm a terrible coward. 我害怕去找牙医，因为我实在很胆小。 ➔cowardly adj

cowardice
/ˈkaʊədɪs ||; ˈkaυɚdɪs/noun [U] a lack of courage; behaviour that shows that you are afraid 胆小；怯懦

cowboy
/ˈkaʊbɔɪ ||; ˈkaυˌbɔɪ/noun[C]
1 a man whose job is to look after cows (usually on a horse) in certain parts of the US （美国某些地区骑马的）牧牛人，牛仔
2 (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) a person in business who is not honest or who does work badly 不诚实的商人；不称职的商人: a cowboy builder 不老实的建筑商

cower
/ˈkaʊə(r) ||; ˈkaυɚ/verb [I] to move back or into a low position because of fear 退缩；畏缩；蜷缩: The dog cowered under the table when the storm started. 风暴来的时候，那条狗瑟缩在桌子底下。

cowl
/kaʊl ||; kaυl/noun [C] a covering for the head that is worn especially by a man belonging to a religious group(a monk) 蒙头斗篷（尤指修道士所穿的）

coy
/kɔɪ ||; kɔɪ/adj
1 pretending to be shy or innocent 假装害羞或天真的: She lifted her head a little and gave him a coy smile. 她微微抬起头来，忸怩地朝他笑了一笑。
2 not wanting to give information about sth or to answer questions that tell people too much about you 含糊其辞的；不愿表白的: Don't be coy, tell me how much you earn. 不要吞吞吐吐，告诉我你赚多少钱。 ➔coyly adv

cozy
(US 美) =COSY

CPU
/ˌsi: pi: ˈju: ||; ˌsi pi ˈju/abbr =CENTRAL PROCESSING UNIT

crab
/kræb ||; kræb/noun
1 [C] a sea animal with a flat shell and ten legs. The front two legs have long curved points(pincers)on them. Crabs move sideways. 蟹；螃蟹；蟹肉
2 [U] the meat from a crab 蟹肉 ☞picture at shellfish 见shellfish插图

*crack¹
/kræk ||; kræk/verb
1 [I,T] to break or to make sth break so that a line appears on the surface, but without breaking into pieces （使）出现裂口或裂缝: Don't put boiling water into that glass -- it'll crack. 不要把滚热的水倒进去，那玻璃杯会裂的。 The stone cracked the windscreen but didn't break it. 那石块打裂了挡风玻璃，但没有把它砸碎。 ☞picture at chip 见chip插图
2 [T] to break sth open 打破；砸开: Crack two eggs into a bowl. 将两个鸡蛋打进碗里。
3 [I,T] to make a sudden loud, sharp sound; to cause sth to make this sound （使）发出劈啪声: to crack a whip/your knuckles 啪啪地甩鞭子；拧指关节
4 [T] to hit a part of your body against sth; to hit sb with sth （身体部份）撞到，碰到（某物）: She stood up and cracked her head on the cupboard door. 她站起来，头撞着橱柜的门。 She cracked the thief over the head with her umbrella. 她用雨伞敲窃贼的脑袋。
5 [I] to no longer be able to deal with pressure and so lose control （由于不能应付压力而）精神崩溃，失控: He cracked under the strain of all his problems. 他在问题重重的压力下精神崩溃了。
6 [I] (used about sb's voice) to suddenly change in a way that is not controlled （指某人的声音）变粗，发哑: Her voice cracked as she spoke about her parent's death. 她说到父母去世时，声音沙哑了。
7 [T] (informal 非正式) to solve a problem 解决（某个问题）: to crack a code 破译密码 The police have cracked an international drug-smuggling ring. 警方破获了一个国际毒品走私集团。
8 [T] to tell or make a joke 说笑话；开玩笑: Stop cracking jokes and do some work! 别再开玩笑了，干点活吧！
get cracking (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) to start doing sth immediately 立即行动: I have to finish this job today so I'd better get cracking. 我今天得完成这工作，所以最好还是马上开始。 crack down (on sb/sth) (used about people in authority) to start dealing strictly with bad or illegal behaviour （指掌握权力者）严办，严惩，严厉对待（不良或违法的人或行为）: The police have started to crack down on drug dealers. 警方已经开始严厉打击毒贩。 crack up
