1 (informal 非正式) to be unable to deal with pressure and so lose control and become mentally ill （由于不能应付压力而）失控，精神崩溃: He cracked up when his wife left him. 他的妻子一离开他，他便精神崩溃。
2 (slang 俚语) to suddenly start laughing, especially when you should be serious 突然大笑（尤指在应该严肃的时候）
*crack²
/kræk ||; kræk/noun
1 [C] a line on the surface of sth where it has broken, but not into separate pieces 裂缝；裂口: a pane of glass with a crack in it 有一处裂缝的窗玻璃 (figurative 比喻) They had always seemed happy together, but then cracks began to appear in their relationship. 他们似乎一直相亲相爱，然后他们的关系开始出现裂缝。 ☞picture at chip 见chip插图
2 [C] a narrow opening 窄缝；狭长的开口: a crack in the curtains 窗帘间的缝隙
3 [C] a sudden loud, sharp sound 劈啪声；爆裂声: There was a loud crack as the gun went off. 开炮了，发出砰的一声巨响。
4 [C] a hard hit on a part of the body 猛烈的一击: Suddenly a golf ball gave him a nasty crack on the head. 突然之间，一个高尔夫球猛然打在他头上，难受极了。
5 [C] (informal 非正式) an amusing, often critical, comment; a joke 俏皮话；笑话: She made a crack about his bald head and he got angry. 她拿他的秃头开玩笑，使他生气。
6 [U] a dangerous and illegal drug that some people take for pleasure and cannot then stop taking 强效纯可卡因；强效纯古柯碱
the crack of dawn very early in the morning 破晓；黎明 have a crack (at sth/at doing sth)(informal 非正式) to try to do sth 尝试: I'm not sure how to play but I'll have a crack at it. 我不知道怎样玩，但我想试一试。
crack³
/kræk ||; kræk/adj (used about soldiers or sports players) very well trained and skilful （指士兵或运动员）训练有素的，技术精湛的: crack troops 精锐部队 He's a crack shot (= very accurate at shooting) with a rifle. 他打步枪是个神射手。

crackdown
/ˈkrækdaʊn ||; ˈkrækˌdaυn/noun [C] action to stop bad or illegal behaviour （对不良或非法行为的）严厉打击，取缔: Fifty people have been arrested in a police crackdown on street crime. 在警方一次严厉打击街头犯罪的行动中已有五十人被捕。

cracker
/ˈkrækə(r) ||; ˈkrækɚ/noun[C]
1 a thin dry biscuit that is often eaten with cheese 薄脆饼干（多与干酪一起吃） ☞picture at cake 见cake插图
2 (also Christmas cracker) a cardboard tube covered in coloured paper and containing a small present. Crackers are pulled apart by two people, each holding one end, at Christmas parties. They make a loud noise as they break. 圣诞鞭炮（内有小礼物）
3 (Brit 英) (informal 非正式) a very good example of sth 一个极好的例子: That story he told was a real cracker. 他讲的那个故事确实很精彩。

crackle
/ˈkrækl ||; ˈkrækḷ/verb [I] to make a series of short, sharp sounds 发出一连串短而尖的声响: The radio started to crackle and then it stopped working. 收音机开始发出一阵劈里啪啦声，然后就坏了。 crackle noun [sing] the crackle of dry wood burning 干柴燃烧时发出的劈啪声

cradle¹
/ˈkreɪdl ||; ˈkredḷ/noun [C] a small bed for a baby. Cradles can often be moved from side to side. 摇篮 ☞picture at bed 见bed插图
cradle²
/ˈkreɪdl ||; ˈkredḷ/verb [T] to hold sb/sth carefully and gently in your arms 小心翼翼地抱着

craft
/krɑ:ft; US kræft ||; kræft/noun
1 [C,U] a job or activity for which you need skill with your hands 手工艺: an arts and crafts exhibition 美术及工艺品展览 I studied craft and design at school. 我在学校学习手工艺和设计。 ☞Look at handicraft. 参看handicraft。
2 [C] any job or activity for which you need skill 需要技巧的工作或活动: He regards acting as a craft. 他认为演戏是一种技艺。
3 [C] (plural craft) a boat, aircraft or spacecraft 船；飞机；航天器

craftsman
/ˈkrɑ:ftsmən; US ˈkræfts- ||; ˈkræftsmən/noun [C] (plural -men /-men ||; -mɛn/) a person who makes things skilfully, especially with his/her hands 手艺工人；工匠 [SYN] artisan 同义词为artisan

craftsmanship
/ˈkrɑ:ftsmənʃɪp ||; ˈkræftsmənˌʃɪp/noun [U] the skill used by sb to make sth of high quality with his/her hands 手艺；技艺

crafty
/ˈkrɑ:fti; US ˈkræftɪ ||; ˈkræftɪ/adj clever at getting or achieving things by using unfair or dishonest methods 狡猾的；诡计多端的 ➔craftily adv

crag
/kræg ||; kræg/noun [C] a steep, rough rock on a hill or mountain 巉岩；峭壁；悬崖

craggy
/krægi ||; krægɪ/adj
1 having a lot of steep rough rock 陡峭的；多岩的
2 (used about a man's face) strong and with deep lines, especially in an attractive way （指男人的脸）轮廓分明的

cram
/kræm ||; kræm/verb (cramming;crammed)
1 [T] to push people or things into a small space 将…勉强挤进（细小的空间）: I managed to cram all my clothes into the bag but I couldn't close it. 我终于将所有衣服都塞进袋里，但却无法锁合袋口。 We only spent two days in Rome but we managed to cram a lot of sightseeing in. 我们在罗马只逗留了两天，但还是游览了不少景点。
2 [I] to move, with a lot of other people, into a small space 挤进（狭小的空间）: He only had a small car but they all managed to cram in. 他的汽车很小，但他们全都挤了进去。
3 [I] to study very hard and learn a lot in a short time before an exam （考试前）赶紧温习: She's cramming for her exams. 她为应付考试而赶着温习。

crammed
/kræmd ||; kræmd/adj very or too full 充满；挤满: That book is crammed with useful information. 那本书里有许许多多有用的资料。

cramp
/kræmp ||; kræmp/noun [U] a sudden pain that you get in a muscle, that makes it difficult to move 抽筋；痉挛

cramped
/kræmpt ||; kræmpt/adj not having enough space 空间不足的: The flat was terribly cramped with so many of us living there. 我们这么多人住在一起，公寓就显得很挤。

cranberry
/ˈkrænbəri; US -berɪ ||; ˈkrænˌbɛrɪ/noun [C] (plural cranberries) a small red berry with a sour taste, that can be made into sauce or juice 越橘

crane¹
/kreɪn ||; kren/noun [C] a large machine with a long metal arm that is used for moving or lifting heavy objects 起重机；吊车
crane²
/kreɪn ||; kren/verb [I,T] to stretch your neck forward in order to see or hear sth 引颈；伸着脖子: We all craned forward to get a better view. 我们都伸长脖子以便看得清楚些。

ˈcrane fly
noun [C] a small flying insect with very long legs 大蚊（一种小飞虫，长有长足）

cranium
/ˈkreɪniəm ||; ˈkrenɪəm/noun [sing] (formal 正式) the bone inside your head 颅；颅骨 [SYN] skull 同义词为skull ➔cranial adj

crank
/kræŋk ||; kræŋk/noun [C] a person with strange ideas or who behaves in a strange way 思想或行为古怪的人: Lots of cranks phoned the police confessing to the murder. 许多怪人打电话给警方，自称是那宗谋杀案的凶手。

cranny
/ˈkræni ||; ˈkrænɪ/noun [C] (plural crannies) a small opening in a wall, rock, etc （墙、岩石等上的）小孔，缝隙 every nook and cranny→NOOK

*crash¹
/kræʃ ||; kræʃ/verb
1 [I,T] to have an accident in a vehicle; to drive a vehicle into sth 驾车失事；驾车碰撞: He braked too late and crashed into the car in front. 他剎车剎得太晚，撞着前面的车子。
2 [I] to hit sth hard, making a loud noise 轰然撞击: The tree crashed to the ground. 那棵树轰然倒在地上。
3 [I] to make a loud noise 发出巨响: I could hear thunder crashing outside. 我听到外面雷声隆隆。
4 [I] (used about money or business) to suddenly lose value or fail （指钱或生意）突然贬值，倒闭
5 [I] (used about a computer) to suddenly stop working （指计算机）发生故障，当机，死机: We lost the data when the computer crashed. 计算机发生故障，我们失去了那些数据。
*crash²
/kræʃ ||; kræʃ/noun[C]
1 a sudden loud noise made by sth breaking, hitting sth, etc 突然的巨响；破裂声；碰撞声: I heard a crash and ran outside. 我听见一声巨响便跑了出去。
2 an accident when a car or other vehicle hits sth and is damaged 交通意外: a car/plane crash 车祸；空难
3 (used about money or business) a sudden fall in the value or price of sth （指钱或生意）突然跌价: the Stock Market crash of 1987 1987年的股灾
4 a sudden failure of a machine, especially a computer 机器突然发生故障（尤指计算机）；当机；死机
crash³
/kræʃ ||; kræʃ/adj done in a very short period of time 速成的: She did a crash course in Spanish before going to work in Madrid. 她前往马德里工作之前修了一门西班牙语速成课程。

ˈcrash barrier
noun [C] a fence that keeps people or vehicles apart, for example when there are large crowds or between the two sides of the road 防撞栏

ˈcrash helmet
noun [C] a hard hat worn by motorbike riders, racing drivers, etc 防撞头盔；安全帽 ☞picture at hat 见hat插图

ˌcrash-ˈland
verb [I] to land a plane in a dangerous way in an emergency （飞机的）紧急着陆 ➔crash-landing noun [C] to make a crash-landing 逼降

crass
/kræs ||; kræs/adj stupid, showing that you do not understand sth 愚昧的: It was a crass comment to make when he knew how upset she was. 他既然知道她那么烦恼，就不应该说那样的蠢话。

crate
/kreɪt ||; kret/noun [C] a large box in which goods are carried or stored 板条箱

crater
/ˈkreɪtə(r) ||; ˈkretɚ/noun[C]
1 a large hole in the ground （地面的）坑: The bomb left a large crater. 炸弹爆炸后留下了一个大坑。 craters on the moon 月球上的环形山
2 the hole in the top of a mountain through which hot gases and liquid rock are forced (a volcano) 火山口 ☞picture at volcano 见volcano插图

cravat
/krəˈvæt ||; krəˈvæt/noun [C] a wide piece of cloth that some men tie around their neck and wear inside the collar of their shirt （男子系于衬衫衣领内的）围巾

crave
/kreɪv ||; krev/verb [I,T] crave (for) sth to want and need to have sth very much 渴望；热切期待: Sometimes I really crave for some chocolate. 有时候我真想吃点巧克力。

craving
/ˈkreɪvɪŋ ||; ˈkrevɪŋ/noun [C] a strong desire for sth 强烈的欲望: When she was pregnant she used to have cravings for all sorts of peculiar food. 她怀孕时很想吃各种特别的食物。

*crawl¹
/krɔ:l ||; krɔl/verb[I]
1 to move slowly with your body on or close to the ground, or on your hands and knees 爬；爬行；匍匐前进: Their baby has just started to crawl. 他们的婴孩刚开始会爬。 An insect crawled across the floor. 一只昆虫在地板上爬过。
2 (used about vehicles) to move very slowly （指车辆）缓慢移动: The traffic crawls through the centre of town in the rush-hour. 高峰时刻车辆缓慢地穿过市中心。
3 (informal 非正式)crawl (to sb) to be very polite or pleasant to sb in order to be liked or to gain sth 奉承；谄媚；巴结: He only got promoted because he crawled to the manager. 他获得擢升只因为他对经理阿谀奉承。
be crawling with sth to be completely full of or covered with unpleasant animals 充满或满布讨厌的动物: The kitchen was crawling with insects. 厨房里满是爬来爬去的虫子。 (figurative 比喻) The village is always crawling with tourists at this time of year. 每年这个时候村里总是挤满游客。
crawl²
/krɔ:l ||; krɔl/noun
1 [sing] a very slow speed 十分缓慢的速度: The traffic slowed to a crawl. 车辆减速，徐缓行进。
2 oftenthe crawl [sing] [U] a style of swimming which you do on your front. When you do the crawl, you move first one arm and then the other over your head, turn your face to one side so that you can breathe and kick up and down with your legs. 爬泳；自由泳；自由式 ☞picture at sport 见sport插图

crayfish
/ˈkreɪfɪʃ ||; ˈkreˌfɪʃ/ (US also 美亦作 crawfish /ˈkrɔ:fɪʃ ||; ˈkrɔˌfɪʃ/) noun [C,U] a shellfish that lives in rivers, lakes or the sea and can be eaten. A crayfish is similar to, but smaller than a LOBSTER(= another sea animal which can be eaten). 淡水螯虾

crayon
/ˈkreɪən ||; ˈkreən/noun [C,U] a soft, thick, coloured pencil that is used for drawing or writing, especially by children 蜡笔 crayon verb [I,T]

craze
/kreɪz ||; krez/noun [C] a craze (for sth)
1 a strong interest in sth, that usually only lasts for a short time （一时的）狂热: There was a craze for that kind of music last year. 去年那种音乐曾经风靡一时。
2 something that a lot of people are very interested in 时兴的事物；时尚: Pocket TVs are the latest craze among teenagers. 袖珍电视机是青少年热爱的最新玩意儿。

*crazy
/ˈkreɪzi ||; ˈkrezɪ/adj (crazier;craziest) (informal 非正式)
1 very silly or foolish 十分愚蠢的；荒唐的: You must be crazy to turn down such a wonderful offer. 你真蠢，竟然拒绝这么好的提议。
2 very angry 盛怒；大怒: She goes crazy when people criticize her. 每次有人批评她，她都很生气。
3 crazy about sb/sth liking sb/sth very much 酷爱；热爱: He's always been crazy about horses. 他一向十分喜欢马匹。
4 showing great excitement 狂热；情绪高涨: The fans went crazy when their team scored the first goal. 球迷见自己所支持的球队射入第一球，便欣喜若狂。 ➔crazily adv ➔craziness noun [U]

creak
/kri:k ||; krik/verb [I] to make the noise of wood bending or of sth not moving smoothly （物体受压或摩擦时）发出吱吱嘎嘎声: The floorboards creaked when I walked across the room. 我走过房间时，木地板嘎吱作响。 creak noun [C] ➔creaky adj creaky stairs 嘎吱作响的楼梯

*cream¹
/kri:m ||; krim/noun
1 [U] the thick yellowish-white liquid that rises to the top of milk 奶油；乳脂: coffee with cream 加了奶油的咖啡 whipped cream (= cream that has been beaten) 搅打过的奶油 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图
2 [C,U] a substance that you rub into your skin to keep it soft or as a medical treatment 乳霜；药膏: (an) antiseptic cream 消毒膏 ☞picture at health 见health插图
3 the cream [sing] the best part of sth or the best people in a group 精华；精英
cream²
/kri:m ||; krim/adj noun [U] (of) a yellowish-white colour 淡黄色；米色
cream³
/kri:m ||; krim/verb cream sb/sth off to take away the best people or part from sth for a particular purpose 挑选精英；提取精华: The big clubs cream off the country's best young players. 一些大的球会选取了全国最好的年轻选手。

creamer
/kri:mə(r) ||; ˈkrimɚ/noun [U] a liquid or powder that you can put in coffee, etc instead of cream or milk ﹙替代奶油或牛奶的﹚咖啡拌末，咖啡伴侣: non-dairy creamer 咖啡植脂末

creamy
/ˈkri:mi ||; ˈkrimɪ/adj (creamier;creamiest)
1 containing cream; thick and smooth like cream 含奶油的；奶油状的: a creamy sauce 奶油酱汁
2 having a light colour like cream 奶油色的；米色的: creamy skin 浅黄色皮肤

crease¹
/kri:s ||; kris/noun[C]
1 an untidy line on paper, material, a piece of clothing, etc that should not be there 折痕；褶子: Your shirt needs ironing, it's full of creases. 你的衬衫满是皱纹，要烫一烫。 When I unrolled the poster, there was a crease in it. 我把卷着的海报打开时，看见一条折痕。
2 a tidy straight line that you make in sth, for example when you fold it （因折迭而出现的）褶子: He had a sharp crease in his trousers. 他的裤子上有一道清楚的褶子。
crease²
/kri:s ||; kris/verb [I,T] to get creases; to make sth get creases （使）起折痕；（使）起皱: Hang up your jacket or it will crease. 挂好你的上衣，不然会起皱。 Crease the paper carefully down the middle. 把那张纸仔细对折一下。

*create
/kriˈeɪt ||; krɪˈet/verb [T] to cause sth new to happen or exist 创造；制造: a plan to create new jobs in the area 在该地区创造新职位的计划 He created a bad impression at the interview. 他面试时给人坏印象。

creation
/kriˈeɪʃn ||; krɪˈeʃən/noun
1 [U] the act of causing sth new to happen or exist 创造；建立: the creation of new independent states 新独立国家的建立 ☞Look at job creation. 参看job creation。
2 usuallythe Creation [sing] the act of making the whole universe, as described in the Bible 创造世界（指圣经中上帝创造宇宙万物）
3 [C] something new that sb has made or produced 创作；作品

creative
/kriˈeɪtɪv ||; krɪˈetɪv/adj
1 using skill or imagination to make or do new things 有创意的；创新的；有想象力的: She's a fantastic designer -- she's so creative. 她是出色的设计师，多么有创意。
2 connected with producing new things 与创作有关的: His creative life went on until he was well over 80. 他的创作生涯一直持续到他80多岁。 ➔creatively adv

creativity
/ˌkri:eɪˈtɪvəti ||; ˌkrieˈtɪvətɪ/noun [U] the ability to make or produce new things using skill or imagination 创造力；创作力: We want teaching that encourages children's creativity. 我们希望在教学过程中启发儿童的创造力。

creator
/kriˈeɪtə(r) ||; krɪˈetɚ/noun [C] a person who makes or produces sth new 创造者；创作者: He was the creator of some of the best-known characters in literature. 文学上一些最著名的人物就是他创造的。

*creature
/ˈkri:tʃə(r) ||; ˈkritʃɚ/noun [C] a living thing such as an animal, a bird, a fish or an insect, but not a plant 生物（除植物外）；动物: sea creatures 海生动物

credentials
/krəˈdenʃlz ||; krɪˈdɛnʃəlz/noun[pl]
1 the qualities, experience, etc that make sb suitable for sth （适合做某事的）资格: He has the perfect credentials for the job. 他绝对够资格做这个工作。
2 a document that is proof that you have the training, education, etc necessary to do sth, or proof that you are who you say you are 证明书；资格证明

credibility
/ˌkredəˈbɪləti ||; ˌkrɛdəˈbɪlətɪ/noun [U] the quality that sb has that makes people believe or trust him/her 可信性；可靠性: The Prime Minister had lost all credibility and had to resign. 首相已完全失去民众的信任，只好辞职。

credible
/ˈkredəbl ||; ˈkrɛdəbḷ/adj
1 that you can believe 可信的: It's hardly credible that such a thing could happen without him knowing it. 那样的事发生了而他竟然不知，真是难以置信。 [OPP] incredible 反义词为incredible
2 that seems possible 似乎可行的: We need to think of a credible alternative to nuclear energy. 我们要想出核能以外的另一个可行办法。

*credit¹
/ˈkredɪt ||; ˈkrɛdɪt/noun
1 [U] a way of buying goods or services and not paying for them until later 赊购；信贷: I bought the television on credit. 我以信贷方式购买这台电视机。
2 [C,U] a sum of money that a bank, etc lends to sb 贷款: The company was not able to get any further credit and went bankrupt. 这家公司无法再取得贷款，接着就破产了。
3 [U] having money in an account at a bank （在银行账户中）有存款: No bank charges are made if your account remains in credit. 只要你的账户仍有存款，银行就不会收费。
4 [C] a payment made into an account at a bank 存入银行账户的款项: There have been several credits to her account over the last month. 上个月有好几笔款子存入她的账户。 [OPP] debit ¹ 反义词为debit^1
5 [U] an act of saying that sb has done sth well 称赞；嘉许: He got all the credit for the success of the project. 这项目得以顺利完成全归功于他。 I can't take any credit; the others did all the work. 我不能领功；所有工作都是其他人做的。 She didn't do very well but at least give her credit fortrying. 她做得不太好，但曾经作出了努力也值得赞扬。
6 [sing] a credit to sb/sth a person or thing that you should be proud of 值得引以为荣的人或事: She is a credit to her school. 她是她学校的光荣。
7 the credits [pl] the list of the names of the people who made a film or TV programme, shown at the beginning or end of the film （电影或电视节目开头或结尾时的）演员及制作人员名单
8 [C] (US 美) a part of a course at a college or university, that a student has completed successfully 学分
do sb credit (used about sb's qualities or achievements) to be so good that people should be proud of him/her （用于表示某人的质量或成就）值得人们为之骄傲的: His courage and optimism do him credit. 他的勇气和乐观态度使他受到赞赏。 (be) to sb's credit used for showing that you approve of sth that sb has done, although you have criticized him/her for sth else （用于表示赞扬某人所做的某件事情，尽管你曾批评他所做的另一些事情）: The company, to its credit, apologized and refunded my money. 那家公司向我道歉，并且把钱退还给我，这还是值得称许的。 have sth to your credit to have finished sth that is successful 取得某方面的成功: He has three best-selling novels to his credit. 他已经写了三本畅销小说。
credit²
/ˈkredɪt ||; ˈkrɛdɪt/verb[T]
1 to add money to a bank account 把金额记入银行账户: Has the cheque been credited to my account yet? 那张支票记入我的账户了吗？
2 credit sb/sth with sth;credit sth to sb/sth to believe or say that sb/sth has a particular quality or has done something well 认为…具有某种特性或做某事做得很出色: Of course I wouldn't do such a stupid thing -- credit me with a bit more sense than that! 我当然不会做这种蠢事，请你不要把人看扁了！
3 (especially in negative sentences and questions 尤用于否定句及疑问句) to believe sth 相信: I simply cannot credit that he has made the same mistake again! 我简直没法相信他又犯了同样的错误！

creditable
/ˈkredɪtəbl ||; ˈkrɛdɪtəbḷ/adj of a quite good standard that cannot be criticized, though not excellent 值得赞扬的，可敬的（虽然并不十分出色）: It was a creditable result considering that three players were injured. 考虑到有三位球员受伤，这已是可喜的成绩了。

ˈcredit card
noun [C] a small plastic card that allows sb to get goods or services without using money. You usually receive a bill once a month for what you have bought 信用卡: Can I pay by credit card? 我可以用信用卡付款吗？ ☞Look at cash card, cheque card and debit card. 参看cash card、cheque card及debit card。 ☞picture at money 见money插图

ˈcredit note
noun [C] a letter that a shop gives you when you have returned sth and that allows you to have goods of the same value in exchange 贷方票据；欠条

creditor
/ˈkredɪtə(r) ||; ˈkrɛdɪtɚ/noun [C] a person or company from whom you have borrowed money 债权人；债主

ˈcredit rating
noun [C] a judgment made by a bank, etc, about how likely sb is to pay back money that he/she borrows, and how safe it is to lend money to him/her ﹙银行等作出的﹚信用等级评定: A good credit rating is important if you want to buy a house. 假如你想买房，良好的信用等级是非常重要的。

creed
/kri:d ||; krid/noun [C] a set of beliefs or principles (especially religious ones) that strongly influence sb's life 信条，信念（尤指教义）

creek
/kri:k ||; krik/noun[C]
1 (Brit 英) a narrow piece of water where the sea flows into the land 小海湾
2 (US 美) a small river; a stream 小河；溪流

creep¹
/kri:p ||; krip/verb [I] (past tense past participle crept /krept ||; krɛpt/)
1 to move very quietly and carefully so that nobody will notice you 悄悄地移动；蹑手蹑脚地走: She crept into the room so as not to wake him up. 她悄悄地走进房间，生怕吵醒他。
2 to move forward slowly 缓慢地前进: The traffic was only creeping along. 车辆只是在缓慢前进。
make your flesh creep→FLESH creep in to begin to appear 开始出现: All sorts of changes are beginning to creep into the education system. 教育制度渐渐起了各种各样的变化。
creep²
/kri:p ||; krip/noun [C] (informal 非正式) a person that you do not like because he/she tries too hard to be liked by people in authority 马屁精 give sb the creeps(informal 非正式) to make sb feel frightened or nervous 使人觉得讨厌；使人不寒而栗: There's something about him that gives me the creeps. 他身上有种东西让我觉得讨厌。

creeper
/ˈkri:pə(r) ||; ˈkripɚ/noun [C] a plant that grows up trees or walls or along the ground 攀缘植物

creepy
/ˈkri:pi ||; ˈkripɪ/adj (informal 非正式) that makes you feel nervous or frightened 令人毛骨悚然的

cremate
/krəˈmeɪt ||; ˈkrimet/verb [T] to burn the body of a dead person as part of a funeral service 火化；火葬 ➔cremation /krəˈmeɪʃn ||; krɪˈmeʃən/ noun [C,U] ☞Look at the note at funeral. 参看funeral的注释。

crematorium
/ˌkreməˈtɔ:riəm ||; ˌkrɛməˈtɔrɪəm/noun [C] a building in which the bodies of dead people are burned 火葬场

Creole
/ˈkriəʊl ||; ˈkrɪol/ (also creole) noun
1 [C] a person who was born in the Caribbean whose family originally came from Europe and Africa 克里奥耳人（出生在加勒比海地区的欧裔及非洲裔人）
2 [C] a person whose relatives (ancestors) were among the first Europeans to live in the Caribbean and South America, or among the first French or Spanish people to live in the southern states of the US 克里奥耳人（其祖先为首批到加勒比海地区及南美定居的欧洲人，或首批到美国南部各州定居的法国人或西班牙人）: the Creole cooking of New Orleans 新奥尔良的克里奥耳式菜肴
3 [C,U] a language that was originally a mixture of a European language and a local, especially African, language 克里奥耳语（一种欧洲语跟当地语（尤其是非洲语）的混合语）

creosote
/ˈkri:əsəʊt ||; ˈkriəˌsot/noun [U] a thick brown liquid that is painted onto wood to protect it from rain, etc 杂酚油（用于为木料上漆） creosote verb [T]

crept
past tense, past participle ofCREEP¹

crescendo
/krəˈʃendəʊ ||; krəˈʃɛndo/noun [C,U] (plural crescendos) a noise or piece of music that gets louder and louder 渐强的声音或音乐 [OPP] diminuendo 反义词为diminuendo

crescent
/ˈkresnt ||; ˈkrɛsṇt/noun[C]
1 a curved shape that is pointed at both ends, like the moon in its first and last stages 新月形；月牙形 ☞picture at shape 见shape插图
2 a street that is curved 新月形的街道

cress
/kres ||; krɛs/noun [U] a small plant with very small green leaves that does not need to be cooked and is eaten in salads and sandwiches 水芹（可作色拉和三明治材料）

crest
/krest ||; krɛst/noun[C]
1 a group of feathers on the top of a bird's head 羽冠
2 a design used as the symbol of a particular family, organization, etc, especially one that has a long history （尤指有悠久历史的家族、组织等的）饰章: the family/school crest 家族╱学校饰章
3 the top part of a hill or wave 山顶；波峰: surfers riding the crest of the wave 驾于浪顶的冲浪运动员 ☞picture at wave 见wave插图

crestfallen
/ˈkrestfɔ:lən ||; ˈkrɛstˌfɔlən/adj sad or disappointed 沮丧的；垂头丧气的

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
/ˌkrɔɪtsfelt ˈjækɒb dɪzi:z ||; ˌkrɔɪtsfɛlt ˈjækɔb dɪˌziz/noun [U] = CJD

crevasse
/krəˈvæs ||; krəˈvæs/noun [C] a deep crack in a very thick layer of ice （厚冰层上的）裂缝，裂隙

crevice
/ˈkrevɪs ||; ˈkrɛvɪs/noun [C] a narrow crack in a rock, wall, etc （岩石、墙壁等的）狭缝，罅隙

*crew
/kru: ||; kru/noun[C] [with.sop]
1 all the people who work on a ship, aircraft, etc （船只、飞机等的）全体工作人员
2 a group of people who work together 一起工作的一组人；一队工作人员: a camera crew (= people who film things for television, etc) 摄影队

ˈcrew cut
noun [C] a very short style of hair for men

crib¹
/krɪb ||; krɪb/ (especially US 尤为美) =COT
crib²
/krɪb ||; krɪb/verb [I,T] (cribbing;cribbed)crib (sth) (from/off sb) to copy sb else's work and pretend it is your own 抄袭；剽窃

crick
/krɪk ||; krɪk/noun [sing] a pain in your neck, back, etc that makes it difficult for you to move easily （颈、背等的）痛性痉挛 crick verb · I've cricked my neck. 我患了颈部痛性痉挛。

cricket
/ˈkrɪkɪt ||; ˈkrɪkɪt/noun
1 [U] a game that is played with a bat and ball on a large area of grass by two teams of eleven players 板球（运动）
In cricket the bowler bowls the ball to the batsman who tries to hit it with a bat and then score a run by running from one end of the pitch to the other. 在板球运动中，投球员(bowler)把球投向击球员(batsman)，击球员用球板(bat)击球，然后从球场的一端跑到另一端，便可取得一分(run)。
2 [C] an insect that makes a loud noise by rubbing its wings together 蟋蟀

cricketer
/ˈkrɪkɪtə(r) ||; ˈkrɪkɪtɚ/noun [C] a person who plays cricket 板球运动员；板球选手

*crime
/kraɪm ||; kraɪm/noun
1 [C] something which is illegal and which people are punished for, for example by being sent to prison 罪；罪行: to commit a crime 犯罪
2 [U] illegal behaviour or activities 不法行为；犯罪活动: There has been an increase in car crime recently. 近来与汽车有关的犯罪活动增加了。 to fight crime 打击犯罪活动
3 usuallya crime [sing] something that is morally wrong 罪过；罪恶: It is a crime to waste food when people are starving. 浪费食物是一种罪过，很多人还在挨饿呢。

ˈcrime wave
noun [sing] a sudden increase in the number of crimes that are committed 犯罪率激增

*criminal¹
/ˈkrɪmɪnl ||; ˈkrɪmənḷ/noun [C] a person who has done something illegal 罪犯
*criminal²
/ˈkrɪmɪnl ||; ˈkrɪmənḷ/adj
1 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) connected with crime 与犯罪有关的: Deliberate damage to public property is a criminal offence. 蓄意破坏公物是刑事罪行。 criminal law 刑法
2 morally wrong 不道德的: a criminal waste of taxpayers' money 不道德地浪费纳税人的钱

criminally
/ˈkrɪmɪnəli ||; ˈkrɪmənḷɪ/adv according to the laws that deal with crime 根据刑法: criminally insane 根据刑法属精神失常

criminology
/ˌkrɪmɪˈnɒlədʒi ||; ˌkrɪməˈnɑlədʒɪ/noun [U] the scientific study of crime and criminals 犯罪学 ➔criminologist /-dʒɪst ||; -dʒɪst/ noun [C] ➔criminological /ˌkrɪmɪnəˈlɒdʒɪkl ||; ˌkrɪmənəˈlɑdʒɪkḷ/ adj

crimson
/ˈkrɪmzn ||; ˈkrɪmzṇ/adj noun [U] (of) a dark red colour 深红色

cringe
/krɪndʒ ||; krɪndʒ/verb[I]
1 to feel embarrassed 感到尴尬: awful family photographs which make you cringe 使人感到尴尬的难看的家庭照片
2 to move away from sb/sth because you are frightened 退缩；畏缩: The dog cringed in terror when the man raised his arm. 那人举起手时，狗便吓得蜷缩起来。

crinkle
/ˈkrɪŋkl ||; ˈkrɪŋkḷ/verb [I,T] crinkle (sth) (up) to have, or to make sth have, thin folds or lines in it （使）起皱: He crinkled the silver paper up into a ball. 他把那张银色纸团成一个球。 ➔crinkly /ˈkrɪŋkli ||; ˈkrɪŋklɪ/ adj crinkly material 有皱纹的材料

cripple
/ˈkrɪpl ||; ˈkrɪpḷ/verb [T] (usually passive 通常用于被动语态)
1 to damage sb's body so that he/she is no longer able to walk or move normally 使跛；致残: to be crippled with arthritis 因患关节炎而走路不便
2 to seriously damage or harm sb/sth 严重损坏或损害；重创: The recession has crippled the motor industry. 不景气已严重损害汽车工业。 ➔crippling adj They had crippling debts and had to sell their house. 他们债务累累，只好卖掉房子。

crisis
/ˈkraɪsɪs ||; ˈkraɪsɪs/noun [C,U] (plural crises /-si:z ||; -siz/) a time of great danger or difficulty; the moment when things change and either improve or get worse 危机；紧要关头；转折点: the international crisis caused by the invasion 由这次入侵导致的国际危机 a friend you can rely on in times of crisis 在危急时刻可以依赖的朋友

crisp¹
/krɪsp ||; krɪsp/adj
1 pleasantly hard and dry 酥脆的: Store the biscuits in a tin to keep them crisp. 将饼干储存在罐内以保持松脆。
2 firm and fresh or new 新鲜而脆生的；簇新的: a crisp salad/apple 爽脆的色拉╱苹果 a crisp cotton dress 簇新的棉质连衣裙
3 (used about the air or weather) cold and dry （指空气或天气）寒冷而干燥的: a crisp winter morning 一个干冷的冬日早晨
4 (used about the way sb speaks) quick, clear but not very friendly （指说话方式）干脆的，斩钉截铁的: a crisp reply 直截了当的答复 ➔crisply adv ‘I disagree,’ she said crisply. “我不同意。”她干脆地说。 ➔crispy adj (informal 非正式)=CRISP¹(1,2)
crisp²
/krɪsp ||; krɪsp/ (US 美 chip poˈtato chip) noun [C] a very thin piece of potato that is fried in oil, dried and then sold in packets. Crisps usually have salt or another flavouring on them 炸马铃薯片；炸薯片: a packet of crisps 一包炸马铃薯片 ☞picture at chip 见chip插图

criss-cross
/ˈkrɪs krɒs; US -krɔ:s ||; ˈkrɪs ˌkrɔs/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) with many straight lines that cross over each other 十字形的；纵横交错的: a criss-cross pattern 十字形图案 criss-cross verb [I,T] Many footpaths criss-cross the countryside. 乡间许多小路纵横交错。

criterion
/kraɪˈtɪəriən ||; kraɪˈtɪrɪən/noun [C] (plural criteria /-riə ||; -rɪə/) the standard that you use when you make a decision or form an opinion about sb/sth （衡量的）标准，准则，尺度: What are the criteria for deciding who gets a place on the course? 这课程录取新生以什么作为标准呢？

critic
/ˈkrɪtɪk ||; ˈkrɪtɪk/noun[C]
1 a person who says what is bad or wrong with sb/sth 批评者；非难者: He is a long-standing critic of the council's transport policy. 他长久以来一直批评市政府的运输政策。
2 a person whose job is to give his/her opinion about a play, film, book, work of art, etc （戏剧、电影、书、艺术作品等的）批评家，评论家，评论员: a film/restaurant/art critic 电影╱餐馆╱艺术评论员

*critical
/ˈkrɪtɪkl ||; ˈkrɪtɪkḷ/adj
1 critical (of sb/sth) saying what is wrong with sb/sth 批评的；批判的；非难的: The report was very critical of safety standards on the railways. 那份报告对铁路安全标准颇多挑剔。
2 (only before a noun 只用于名词前) describing the good and bad points of a play, film, book, work of art, etc （对戏剧、电影、书、艺术作品等）批评的，评论的: a critical guide to this month's new films 本月新片评价
3 dangerous or serious 危急的；严重的: The patient is in a critical condition. 病人情况危急。
4 very important; at a time when things can suddenly become better or worse 十分重要的；关键的: The talks between the two leaders have reached a critical stage. 两位领导人的会谈已到了关键阶段。 ➔critically /-ɪkli ||; -ɪklɪ/ adv a critically ill patient 垂危的病人 a critically important decision 关系重大的决定

*criticism
/ˈkrɪtɪsɪzəm ||; ˈkrɪtəˌsɪzəm/noun
1 [C,U] (an expression of) what you think is bad about sb/sth 批评；指责；非难: The council has come in for severe criticismover the plans. 议会那些计划受到严厉的批评。
2 [U] the act of describing the good and bad points of a play, film, book, work of art, etc （戏剧、电影、书、艺术作品等的）评论: literary criticism 文学批评

*criticize
/ˈkrɪtɪsaɪz ||; ˈkrɪtəˌsaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [I,T] criticize (sb/sth) (for sth) to say what is bad or wrong with sb/sth 批评；指责；非难: The doctor was criticized for not sending the patient to hospital. 那个医生因没有把病人送往医院而受到指责。

critique
/krɪˈti:k ||; krɪˈtik/noun [C] a piece of writing that describes the good and bad points of sb/sth 评论（文章）

croak
/krəʊk ||; krok/verb [I] to make a harsh low noise like a particular animal(a frog) 发出刺耳又低沉的声音（如蛙叫） croak noun [C]

crochet
/ˈkrəʊʃeɪ; US krəʊˈʃeɪ ||; kroˈʃe/noun [U] a way of making clothes, cloth, etc by using wool or cotton and a needle with a hook at one end 钩针编织 crochet verb [I,T] (past tense past participle crocheted /-ʃeɪd ||; -ˈʃed/) ☞Look at knit. 参看knit。

crockery
/ˈkrɒkəri ||; ˈkrɑkərɪ/noun [U] cups, plates and dishes 陶器，瓦器（如杯、盘、碟等） ☞Look at cutlery. 参看cutlery。

crocodile
/ˈkrɒkədaɪl ||; ˈkrɑkəˌdaɪl/noun [C] a large reptile with a long tail and a big mouth with sharp teeth. Crocodiles live in rivers and lakes in hot countries. 鳄鱼 ☞Look at alligator. 参看alligator。

crocus
/ˈkrəʊkəs ||; ˈkrokəs/noun [C] a small yellow, purple or white flower that grows in early spring 番红花，藏红花（一种黄色、紫色或白色小花，早春开放）

croissant
/ˈkrwæsɒ~;krəˈsɑ:nt/noun [C] a type of bread roll, shaped in a curve, that is often eaten with butter for breakfast 新月形面包；牛角面包 ☞picture at bread 见bread插图

crony
/ˈkrəʊni ||; ˈkronɪ/noun [C] (plural cronies) (informal 非正式) (often used in a critical way) a friend （常用于批评）密友

crook
/krʊk ||; krυk/noun[C]
1 (informal 非正式) a dishonest person; a criminal 骗子；坏蛋
2 a bend or curve in sth 弯曲处: the crook of your arm (= the inside of your elbow) 臂弯

crooked
/ˈkrʊkɪd ||; ˈkrυkɪd/adj
1 not straight or even 弯曲的；歪斜的: That picture is crooked. 那幅画挂歪了。 crooked teeth 不齐整的牙齿
2 (informal 非正式) not honest 不诚实的: a crooked accountant 不诚实的会计师

*crop¹
/krɒp ||; krɑp/noun
1 [C] all the grain, fruit, vegetables, etc of one type that a farmer grows at one time （谷物一茬的）收成，收获: a crop of apples 一茬苹果
2 [C] [usu.pl] plants that are grown on farms for food 农作物: Rice and soya beans are the main crops here. 稻米和大豆是这里的主要农作物。
3 [sing] a number of people or things which have appeared at the same time （同时出现的）一群（人），一批（事物）: the recent crop of movies about aliens 最近一批关于外星人的电影
crop²
/krɒp ||; krɑp/verb (cropping;cropped)
1 [T] to cut sth very short 剪短: cropped hair 短头发
2 [I] to produce a crop¹(1) 种植
crop up to appear suddenly, when you are not expecting it 突然出现: We should have finished this work yesterday but some problems cropped up. 我们昨天本该完成这项工作，可是突然出现了一些问题。

cropper
/ˈkrɒpə(r) ||; ˈkrɑpɚ/noun come a cropper(informal 非正式)
1 to fall over or have an accident 跌倒；发生意外
2 to fail 失败

croquet
/ˈkrəʊkeɪ ||; kroˈke/noun [U] a game that you play on grass. When you play croquet you use long wooden hammers (mallets) to hit balls through metal arches (hoops). 槌球游戏

*cross¹
/krɒs; US krɔ:s ||; krɔs/noun[C]
1 a mark that you make by drawing one line across another (×). The sign is used for showing the position of sth, for showing that sth is not correct, etc 十字记号，交叉记号（用于显示位置或错误等): I drew a cross on the map to show where our house is. 我在地图上画个十字形记号，表示我们房子的位置。 Incorrect answers were marked with a cross. 错的答案都已打了叉。
2 (also the Cross) the two pieces of wood in the shape of a cross on which people were killed as a punishment in former times, or something in this shape (cross) that is used as a symbol of the Christian religion 十字架（古时的刑具）；（象征基督教的）十字架: She wore a gold cross round her neck. 她戴着金十字架项链。 ☞Look at crucifix. 参看crucifix。
3 [usu.sing] a cross (between A and B) something (especially a plant or an animal) that is a mixture of two different types of thing 杂种，混合种（尤指植物或动物的）: a fruit which is a cross between a peach and an apple 桃和苹果的杂交品种
4 (in sports such as football) a kick or hit of the ball that goes across the front of the goal （指足球等运动项目）横传
noughts and crosses→NOUGHT
*cross²
/krɒs; US krɔ:s ||; krɔs/verb
1 [I,T] cross (over) (from sth/to sth) to go from one side of sth to the other 穿过；越过: to cross the road 过马路 Where did you cross the border? 你在哪里越过边境？ Which of the runners crossed the finishing line first? 哪个选手第一个越过终点线？
2 [I] (used about lines, roads, etc) to pass across each other （指线、道路等）交叉，相叉: The two roads cross just north of the village. 这两条路在村子的北面相交。
3 [T] to put sth across or over sth else 使交叉: to cross your arms 交叉双臂 ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图
4 [T] to make sb angry by refusing to do what he/she wants you to do （因拒绝某人想做的事而）惹某人生气: He's an important man. It could be dangerous to cross him. 他是个重要人物，与他作对会很危险。
5 [T] cross sth with sth to produce a new type of plant or animal by mixing two different types 使杂交: If you cross a horse with a donkey, you get a mule. 马与驴杂交就会生出骡。
6 [I,T] (in sports such as football and hockey) to pass the ball across the front of the goal （指足球、曲棍球等运动）横传
cross my heart (and hope to die)(spoken 口语) used for emphasizing that what you are saying is true （用于强调所说属实） cross your fingers;keep your fingers crossed→FINGER¹ cross your mind (used about a thought, idea, etc) to come into your mind （指想法等）出现于脑中: It never once crossed my mind that she was lying. 我从未想到她是在说谎。 cross sth off (sth) to remove sth from a list, etc by drawing a line through it （从清单上等）删掉，删除，画掉: Cross Dave's name off the guest list -- he can't come. 把戴夫的名字从客人名单上画掉吧，他来不了。 cross sth out to draw a line through sth that you have written because you have made a mistake, etc （因写错而）画掉: to cross out a spelling mistake 画掉一个拼写错误
cross³
/krɒs; US krɔ:s ||; krɔs/adj (informal 非正式)cross (with sb) (about sth) angry or annoyed 愤怒；生气: I was really cross with her for leaving me with all the work. 她把所有的工作都留给我，我真的对她非常生气。 ☞ Cross is less formal than angry. 与angry相比，cross多用于非正式场合。 ➔crossly adv ‘Be quiet,’ Dad said crossly. “安静一点。”爸爸愤怒地说。

crossbar
/ˈkrɒsbɑ:(r);ˈkrɔ:s-/noun[C]
1 the piece of wood over the top of a goal in football, etc （足球球门上的）横木
2 the metal bar that joins the front and back of a bicycle （自行车车架上的）横梁 ☞picture at bicycle 见bicycle插图

ˈcross-breed¹
verb [I,T] (past tense past participle cross-bred) to make an animal or a plant breed with a different type of animal or plant; to breed with an animal or plant of a different type （使）杂交繁育: a cross-bred puppy 杂交小狗 ➔ˌcross-ˈbreeding noun [U]
ˈcross-breed²
noun [C] an animal or a plant that has been produced by breeding two different types of animal or plant （动植物的）杂交品种

ˌcross-ˈcheck
verb [T] cross-check sth (against sth) to make sure that information, figures, etc are correct by using a different method or system to check them （以不同方式或制度对信息、数字等）反复核对，反复核实: Cross-check your measurements against those suggested in the manual. 以手册里提出的数据来核对你的测量结果。

ˌcross-ˈcountry
adj adv across fields and natural land; not using roads or tracks 越野的: We walked about 10 miles cross-country before we saw a village. 我们在田野里走了大约10英里，然后看见一个村子。

ˌcross-eˈxamine
verb [T] to ask sb questions in a court of law, etc in order to find out the truth about sth 盘问，盘诘（如在法庭上）: The witness was cross-examined for two hours. 那个证人被盘问了两个小时。 ➔ˌcross-eˌxamiˈnation noun [C,U]

ˈcross-eyed
adj having one or both your eyes looking towards your nose 内斜视的；斗鸡眼的

ˌcross-ˈfertilize
(also -ise) verb [T] to make a plant develop and grow fruit or seeds using a type of powder(pollen)from a different kind of plant 使异花受粉 ➔ˌcross-ˌfertiliˈzation(also -isation) noun [U] [sing]

crossfire
/ˈkrɒsfaɪə(r) ||; ˈkrɔsˌfaɪr/noun [U] a situation in which guns are being fired from two or more different directions （来自两个或以上方向的）交叉火力: The journalist was killed in crossfire. 那名记者在交叉火力中丧生。 (figurative 比喻) When my parents argued, I sometimes got caught in the crossfire. 我父母争吵时，我有时受到两面夹攻，无法脱身。

crossing
/ˈkrɒsɪŋ; US ˈkrɔ:s- ||; ˈkrɔsɪŋ/noun[C]
1 a place where you can cross over sth 人行横道；过境处: You should cross the road at the pedestrian crossing. 你应当从人行横道过马路。 a border crossing 过境处
2 (Brit 英 level crossing) a place where a road and a railway line cross each other （公路与铁路的）平交道
3 a journey from one side of a sea or river to the other 渡；横渡: We had a rough crossing. 我们在风浪中横渡。

cross-legged
/ˌkrɒs ˈlegd; US ˌkrɔ:s- ||; ˈkrɔsˈlɛgd/adj adv sitting on the floor with your legs pulled up in front of you and with one leg or foot over the other 盘着腿（的）: to sit cross-legged 盘腿而坐 ☞picture on page S19 见S19页插图

ˌcross ˈpurposes
noun at cross purposes if two people are at cross purposes, they do not understand each other because they are talking about different things without realizing it 互相误解

ˈcross-reference
noun [C] a note in a book that tells you to look in another place in the book for more information （书中的）相互参照，互见

crossroads
/ˈkrɒsrəʊdz; US ˈkrɔ:s- ||; ˈkrɔsˌrodz/noun [C] (plural crossroads) a place where two or more roads cross each other 十字路口: When you come to the next crossroads turn right. 你到了下一个十字路口便向右转。 ☞picture at roundabout 见roundabout插图

ˈcross section
noun [C]
1 a picture of what the inside of sth would look like if you cut through it 剖面（图）；横切面（图）: a cross section of the human brain 人脑的横切面图 ☞picture at flower 见flower插图
2 a number of people, etc that come from the different parts of a group, and so can be considered to represent the whole group 典型；代表: The families we studied were chosen to represent a cross section of society. 我们研究的家庭都是经过挑选的，在社会上具有代表性。 ➔ˌcross-ˈsectional adj

ˈcross-training
noun [U] doing more than one sport or physical activity regularly, to improve your physical condition generally 交叉训练﹙同时参加多项运动训练以提高竞技能力的做法﹚: His tennis game has improved a lot since he started cross-training. 自从他开始交叉训练以来，他的网球技艺大大提高了。 ➔ˈcross-trainer noun [C]

crosswalk
/ˈkrɒswɔ:k; US ˈkrɔ:s- ||; ˈkrɔsˌwɔk/ (US 美) =PEDESTRIAN CROSSING

crosswind
/ˈkrɒswɪnd ||; ˈkrɔsˌwɪnd/noun [C] a wind that is blowing across the direction that you are moving in 侧风

*crossword
/ˈkrɒswɜ:d; US ˈkrɔ:s- ||; ˈkrɔsˌwɝd/ (also crossword puzzle) noun [C] a word game in which you have to write the answers to questions (clues) in square spaces, which are arranged in a pattern 纵横字谜（可根据提示填上正确的答案）: Every morning I try to do the crossword in the newspaper. 每天上午我都努力做报纸上的纵横字谜。

crotch
/krɒtʃ ||; krɑtʃ/ (also crutch) noun [C] the place where your legs, or a pair of trousers, join at the top 胯部；裤裆

crotchet
/ˈkrɒtʃɪt ||; ˈkrɑtʃɪt/ (US 美 quarter note) noun [C] (used in music 用于音乐) a type of note 四分音符 A semibreve is a musical note that lasts as long as 4 crotchets. A minim lasts twice as long as a crotchet, a quaver lasts half as long as a crotchet and a semiquaver lasts half as long as a quaver. 四个四分音符(crotchet)组成一个全音符(semibreve)。两个四分音符(crotchet)组成一个二分音符(minim)，一个四分音符(crotchet)由两个八分音符(quaver)组成，一个八分音符(quaver)由两个十六分音符(semiquaver)组成。 ☞picture at music 见music插图

crouch
/kraʊtʃ ||; kraυtʃ/verb [I] crouch (down) to bend your legs and body so that you are close to the ground 蹲伏；蹲: He crouched down behind the sofa. 他在沙发后面蹲下来。 ☞picture at kneel 见kneel插图

crouton
/kru:tɒn ||; ˈkrutɑn/noun [C] a small piece of cold, crisp fried bread served in soup or on a salad ﹙放在汤或色拉中的﹚油炸面包丁

crow¹
/krəʊ ||; kro/noun [C] a large black bird that makes a loud noise 乌鸦 as the crow flies (used for describing distances) in a straight line （用于形容距离）成直线: It's a kilometre as the crow flies but three kilometres by road. 按直线只有一公里，但顺着马路要走三公里。
crow²
/krəʊ ||; kro/verb[I]
1 to make a loud noise like a male chicken (cock) makes 发出像公鸡叫的声音；喔喔啼
2 (informal 非正式) to speak very proudly about sth; to boast 自鸣得意地说话；夸口；自夸

crowbar
/ˈkrəʊbɑ:(r) ||; ˈkroˌbɑr/noun [C] a long iron bar that is used for forcing sth open 撬棍；铁撬

*crowd¹
/kraʊd ||; kraυd/noun
1 [C] [with.sop] a large number of people in one place 人群: The crowd was/were extremely noisy. 人群很喧闹。 He pushed his way through the crowd. 他从人群中挤过去。 I go shopping early in the morning to avoid the crowds. 我一大早就去购物，省得人多时凑热闹。
2 the crowd [sing] ordinary people 大众；民众: He wears weird clothes because he wants to stand out from the crowd. 他穿着奇装异服，想要与众不同。
3 [C] [with.sop] (informal 非正式) a group of people who know each other （互相认识的）一伙人，一帮人: John, Linda and Barry will be there -- all the usual crowd. 约翰、琳达、巴里会在那里，都是惯常的那伙人。
*crowd²
/kraʊd ||; kraυd/verb
1 [I] crowd around/round (sb) (used about a lot of people) to stand in a large group around sb/sth （指很多人）聚集，群集: Fans crowded round the singer hoping to get his autograph. 歌迷围着那歌星，希望取得他的亲笔签名。
2 [T] (used about a lot of people) to fill an area （指很多人）挤满，塞满（某地方）: Groups of tourists crowded the main streets. 大街上都挤满了一群群的游客。 (figurative 比喻) Memories crowded her mind. 她脑子充满了对往事的回忆。
crowd into sth; crowd in to go into a small place and make it very full 挤进狭小的地方: Somehow we all crowded into their small living room. 我们所有人都设法挤进了他们那狭小的客厅。 crowd sb/sth into sth; crowd sb/sth in to put a lot of people into a small place 将很多人或物挤进狭小的地方: Ten prisoners were crowded into one small cell. 十个囚犯被关进一个小囚室内。 crowd sth out; crowd sb out (of sth) to completely fill a place so that nobody else can enter 挤满（没人再进得去）: Students crowd out the cafe at lunchtimes. 每到午饭时分，那家小餐馆挤满了学生。 Smaller companies are being crowded out of the market. 小一点的公司正被挤出市场。

crowded
/ˈkraʊdɪd ||; ˈkraυdɪd/adj full of people 拥挤的；挤满人的: a crowded bus 拥挤的公共汽车 people living in poor and crowded conditions 住房条件糟糕且拥挤的人

crown¹
/kraʊn ||; kraυn/noun
1 [C] a circle made of gold and jewels, that a king or queen wears on his/her head on official occasions 王冠；皇冠
2 the Crown [sing] the state as represented by a king or queen 王国: an area of land belonging to the Crown 属于王国的一片土地
3 [sing] the top of your head or of a hat 头顶；帽顶 ☞picture at hat 见hat插图
4 [sing] the top of a hill 山顶
crown²
/kraʊn ||; kraυn/verb[T]
1 to put a crown on the head of a new king or queen in an official ceremony 为…加冕: Elizabeth was crowned in 1952. 伊莉萨白于1952年加冕。 (figurative 比喻) the newly crowned British champion 刚刚胜出的英国冠军
2 (often passive 常用于被动语态) crown sth (with sth) to have or put sth on the top of sth 覆盖（某物）的顶部: The mountain was crowned with snow. 山顶盖满了雪。 (figurative 比喻) Her years of hard work were finally crowned with success. 她经过多年的努力终于获得成功。

crowning
/ˈkraʊnɪŋ ||; ˈkraυnɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) the best or most important 最好的；最重要的: Winning the World Championship was the crowning moment of her career. 赢得世界冠军是她事业中最璀璨的时刻。

ˌCrown ˈprince
noun [C] (feminine ˌCrown prinˈcess) the person who has the right to become the next king or queen 王储

crucial
/ˈkru:ʃl ||; ˈkruʃəl/adj crucial (to/for sth) extremely important 极其重要的: Early diagnosis of the illness is crucial for successful treatment. 及早诊断对于成功治疗关系重大。 [SYN] vital 同义词为 vital ➔crucially /-ʃəli ||; -ʃəlɪ/ adv

crucible
/ˈkru:sɪbl ||; ˈkrusəbḷ/noun[C]
1 a pot in which substances are heated to high temperatures, metals are melted, etc 坩锅；熔化炉 ☞picture at laboratory 见laboratory插图
2 (formal 正式) a place or situation in which people or ideas are tested, often creating sth new or exciting in the process 熔炉；考验人、思想的地方或环境

crucifix
/ˈkru:səfɪks ||; ˈkrusəˌfɪks/noun [C] a small model of a cross with a figure of Jesus on it 有耶稣受难像的十字架

crucifixion
/ˌkru:səˈfɪkʃn ||; ˌkrusəˈfɪkʃən/noun [C,U] the act of crucifying sb （将某人）钉死在十字架上: the Crucifixion of Christ 耶稣被钉死在十字架上

crucify
/ˈkru:sɪfaɪ ||; ˈkrusəˌfaɪ/verb [T] (present participle crucifying third person singular present crucifies;past tense past participle crucified) to kill sb by nailing or tying him/her to a cross 把（某人）钉在或绑在十字架上处死

crud
/krʌd ||; krʌd/noun [U] (informal 非正式) any dirty or unpleasant substance 脏东西

cruddy
/kru:di ||; ˈkrudɪ/adj (cruddier; cruddiest) (especially US, informal 尤为美，非正式) bad, dirty, or of low quality 差劲的；肮脏的；劣质的: We got really cruddy service in that restaurant last time. 上次在那餐馆我们得到了糟糕透顶的服务。

crude
/kru:d ||; krud/adj
1 simple and basic, without much detail, skill, etc 简陋的；粗略的；粗制的: The method was crude but very effective. 方法虽然粗糙，但很有效。 She explained how the system worked in crude terms. 她粗略地解释了一下那种系统的运作过程。
2 referring to sex or the body in a way that would offend many people 粗鲁的；粗鄙的: He's always telling crude jokes. 他老是说一些粗俗的笑话。
3 in its natural state, before it has been treated with chemicals 天然的；未提炼的: crude oil 原油 ➔crudely adv a crudely drawn face 天生的歪脸

*cruel
/kru:əl ||; kruəl/adj (crueller;cruellest) causing physical or mental pain or suffering to sb/sth 残忍的；残酷的；冷酷的: I think it's cruel to keep animals in cages. 我认为把动物关在笼里是很残忍的。 a cruel punishment 残酷的惩罚 ➔cruelly /ˈkru:əli ||; ˈkruəlɪ/ adv

*cruelty
/ˈkru:əlti ||; ˈkruəltɪ/noun (plural cruelties)
1 [U] cruelty (to sb/sth) cruel behaviour 残忍；残酷: cruelty to children 虐待儿童
2 [C] [usu.pl] a cruel act 残暴的行为: the cruelties of war 战争的残暴行为

cruise¹
/kru:z ||; kruz/verb[I]
1 to travel by boat, visiting a number of places, as a holiday 乘船游览；海上航游: to cruise around the Caribbean 乘船周游加勒比海地区
2 to stay at the same speed in a car, plane, etc 乘汽车、飞机等以不变的速度行进: cruising at 80 kilometres an hour 以时速80公里行进
cruise²
/kru:z ||; kruz/noun [C] a holiday in which you travel on a ship and visit a number of different places 乘船旅游（的假期）: They're planning to go on a cruise. 他们打算乘船出游。

cruiser
/ˈkru:zə(r) ||; ˈkruzɚ/noun[C]
1 a large fast ship used in a war 巡洋舰
2 (also cabin cruiser) a motor boat which has room for people to sleep in it 游艇﹙可供住宿﹚ ☞picture at boat 见boat插图

crumb
/krʌm ||; krʌm/noun [C] a very small piece of bread, cake or biscuit 面包屑；饼屑 ☞picture at cake 见cake插图

crumble
/ˈkrʌmbl ||; ˈkrʌmbḷ/verb [I,T] crumble (sth) (up) to break or make sth break into very small pieces 弄碎；使碎为细屑: The walls of the church are beginning to crumble. 教堂的墙壁开始崩塌。 We crumbled up the bread and threw it to the birds. 我们把面包弄碎，丢给鸟吃。 (figurative 比喻) Support for the government is beginning to crumble. 对政府的支持开始消失。 ➔crumbly adj This cheese has a crumbly texture. 这种干酪质地易碎。

crumpet
/ˈkrʌmpɪt ||; ˈkrʌmpɪt/noun [C] (Brit 英) a flat round type of bread roll with holes in the top that you eat hot with butter 烤脆面饼（可以涂上黄油热吃）

crumple
/ˈkrʌmpl ||; ˈkrʌmpḷ/verb [I,T] crumple (sth) (into sth);crumple (sth) (up) to be pressed or to press sth into an untidy shape 起皱；压皱: The front of the car crumpled when it hit the wall. 那辆汽车的前端撞在墙上变了形。 She crumpled the letter into a ball and threw it away. 她把信揉成一团扔掉了。

crunch¹
/krʌntʃ ||; krʌntʃ/verb
1 [T] crunch sth (up) to make a loud noise when you are eating sth hard 嘎吱嘎吱地嚼: to crunch an apple 嘎吱嘎吱地嚼苹果
2 [I] to make a loud noise like the sound of sth being crushed 发出嘎吱嘎吱声: We crunched through the snow. 我们嘎吱嘎吱地踏过雪地。 ➔crunchy /ˈkrʌntʃi/ adj a crunchy apple 爽脆的苹果
crunch²
/krʌntʃ ||; krʌntʃ/noun [sing] an act or noise of crunching 嘎吱作响的咀嚼；嘎吱声: There was a loud crunch as he sat on the box of eggs. 他坐在那箱鸡蛋上时发出一阵响亮的嘎吱声。 if/when it comes to the crunch if/when you are in a difficult situation and must make a difficult decision 到了紧要关头: If it comes to the crunch, I'll stay and fight. 到了紧要关头，我会留下来战斗。

crusade
/kru:ˈseɪd ||; kruˈsed/noun[C]
1 a fight for sth that you believe to be good or against sth that you believe to be bad （为争取好的或反对坏的事物的）运动，斗争，抗争: Mr Khan is leading a crusade against drugs in his neighbourhood. 卡恩先生正在自己的街坊领导一场打击毒品的运动。
2 Crusade one of the wars fought in Palestine by European Christians against Muslims in the Middle Ages 十字军东征 ➔crusader noun [C]

crush¹
/krʌʃ ||; krʌʃ/verb[T]
1 to press sb/sth hard so that he/she/it is broken, damaged or injured 压碎；压破；压坏；压伤: Most of the eggs got crushed when she sat on them. 她坐上去的时候大部份鸡蛋都给压破了。 He was crushed to death by a lorry. 他被卡车压死了。
2 crush sth (up) to break sth into very small pieces or a powder 弄碎；捣碎；压碎: Crush the garlic and fry in oil. 先把蒜捣碎，再在油里爆一下。 ☞picture at squeeze 见squeeze插图
3 to defeat sb/sth completely 彻底击败: The army was sent in to crush the rebellion. 军队被派去镇压叛乱。
crush²
/krʌʃ ||; krʌʃ/noun
1 [sing] a large group of people in a small space 拥挤的人群: There was such a crush that I couldn't get near the bar. 那里挤满了人，我无法走近酒吧间。
2 [C] (informal 非正式)a crush (on sb) a strong feeling of love for sb that only usually lasts for a short time （通常指短暂的）狂热的爱，迷恋: Maria had a huge crushon her teacher. 玛丽亚曾极其迷恋她的老师。

crushing
/ˈkrʌʃɪŋ ||; ˈkrʌʃɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) that defeats sb/sth completely; very bad 压倒的；很糟糕的: a crushing defeat 惨败

crust
/krʌst ||; krʌst/noun[C,U]
1 the hard part on the outside of a piece of bread, a pie, etc 面包皮；馅饼外皮 ☞picture at bread 见bread插图
2 a hard layer on the outside of sth 硬壳: the earth's crust 地壳

crustacean
/krʌˈsteɪʃn ||; krʌsˈteʃən/noun [C] (technical术语) any creature with a soft body in several sections and covered with a hard outer shell. Crustaceans usually live in water. 甲壳纲动物: Crabs, lobsters, shrimps and prawns are crustaceans. 螃蟹、龙虾、小虾及明虾都是甲壳纲动物。

crusty
/ˈkrʌsti ||; ˈkrʌstɪ/adj
1 having a hard crust (1) 有硬皮的: crusty bread 硬片面包
2 (informal 非正式) bad-tempered and impatient 脾气暴躁的；不耐烦的: a crusty old man 脾气暴躁的老头儿

crutch
/krʌtʃ ||; krʌtʃ/noun[C]
1 a type of stick that you put under your arm to help you walk when you have hurt your leg or foot 拐杖: She was on crutches for two months after she broke her ankle. 她弄断脚踝以后有两个月时间靠拐杖走路。 ☞Compare walking stick. 与walking stick比较。 ☞picture at health 见health插图
2 =CROTCH

crux
/krʌks ||; krʌks/noun [sing] the most important or difficult part of a problem （问题的）关键，症结: The crux of the matter is how to stop this from happening again. 问题的关键是如何防止这类事再发生。

*cry¹
/kraɪ ||; kraɪ/verb (present participle crying third person singular present cries;past tense past participle cried)
1 [I] to make a noise and produce tears in your eyes, for example because you are unhappy or have hurt yourself 哭；哭泣: The baby never stops crying. 这婴孩不停地哭。 The child was crying for (= because she wanted) her mother. 那孩子哭着要妈妈。
2 [I,T] cry (out) to shout or make a loud noise 叫喊；呼喊: We could hear someone crying for help. 我们听见有人在大声求救。 ‘Look,’ he cried, ‘There they are.’ “看，”他大声说﹕“他们来了。”
a shoulder to cry on→SHOULDER¹ cry your eyes out to cry a lot for a long time 痛哭流涕；哭得很伤心 cry out for sth to need sth very much 非常需要: Birmingham is crying out for a new transport system. 伯明翰极需新的运输系统。
*cry²
/kraɪ ||; kraɪ/noun (plural cries)
1 [C] a shout or loud high noise 叫喊；大叫；叫喊声: the cries of the children in the playground 运动场上孩子们的叫喊声 We heard Adam give a cry of pain as the dog bit him. 那只狗咬了亚当一口，我们听见他痛得惨叫一声。 (figurative 比喻) Her suicide attempt was really a cry for help. 她企图自杀其实为了吁求帮助。
2 [sing] an act of crying ¹(1) 哭；哭泣: After a good cry I felt much better. 痛哭一场后，我觉得好受多了。
a far cry from sth/from doing sth→FAR¹

crying
/ˈkraɪɪŋ ||; ˈkraɪɪŋ/adj (only before a noun 只用于名词前) (used to talk about a bad situation) very great （指坏的情况）厉害的，严重的: There's a crying need for more doctors. 迫切需要更多医生。 It's a crying shame that so many young people can't find jobs. 这么多年轻人找不到工作，真是太不象话。

crypt
/krɪpt ||; krɪpt/noun [C] a room that is under a church, where people were sometimes buried in the past 教堂地下室（过去有时用以埋葬死者）

cryptic
/ˈkrɪptɪk ||; ˈkrɪptɪk/adj having a hidden meaning that is not easy to understand; mysterious 有隐义的；隐晦难明的；神秘的: a cryptic message/remark 令人困惑的信息╱言语 ➔cryptically /-kli ||; -klɪ/ adv

crypto-
/ˈkrɪptəʊ ||; ˈkrɪpto/prefix (used in nouns 用于构成名词) hidden; secret 隐蔽；秘密

crystal
/ˈkrɪstl ||; ˈkrɪstḷ/noun
1 [C] a regular shape that some mineral substances form when they become solid 结晶体: salt crystals 盐的结晶体
2 [U] a clear mineral that can be used in making jewellery 水晶
3 [U] very high-quality glass 晶质玻璃: a crystal vase 晶质玻璃花瓶

ˌcrystal ˈball
noun [C] a glass ball in which some people say you can see what will happen in the future 水晶球（用于占卜）

ˌcrystal ˈclear
adj
1 (used about water, glass, etc) that you can see through perfectly （指水、玻璃等）清澈，明澈
2 very easy to understand 明白易懂: The meaning is crystal clear. 意思一清二楚。

crystalline
/ˈkrɪstəlaɪn ||; ˈkrɪstḷˌaɪn/adj made of or similar to CRYSTALS(= small pieces of a substance with many even sides) 水晶制的；晶状的

crystallize
/ˈkrɪstəlaɪz ||; ˈkrɪstḷˌaɪz/ (also -ise) verb [I,T]
1 (used about thoughts, beliefs, plans, etc) to become clear and fixed; to make thoughts, etc become clear and fixed （指思想、信念、计划等）（使）具体化，成形: Our ideas gradually began to crystallize into a definite strategy. 我们的想法开始渐渐具体化，成为一项明确的战略。
2 to form or make sth form into CRYSTALS(= small pieces of a substance with many even sides) （使）结晶，晶化 ➔crystallization(also -isation) /ˌkrɪstəlaɪˈzeɪʃn ||; ˌkrɪstḷəˈzeʃən/ noun [U]

crèche
/kreʃ ||; kreʃ/noun [C] a place where small children are looked after while their parents are working, shopping, etc 托儿所

crêpe
/kreɪp ||; krep/ (also crepe) noun
1 [U] a light thin material, made especially from cotton or another natural material(silk), with a surface that is covered in lines as if it has been folded 绉织物: a crêpe bandage 绉绷带
2 [U] a type of strong rubber with a rough surface, used for making the bottoms of shoes 绉胶: crêpe-soled shoes 绉胶底的鞋
3 [C] a very thin type of round cake(pancake) 薄烤饼

cu.
abbr cubic 立方: a volume of 3 cu ft 体积3立方英尺

cub
/kʌb ||; kʌb/noun[C]
1 a young bear, lion, etc 幼熊或幼狮等 ☞picture at lion 见lion插图
2 the Cubs [pl] the part of the Boy Scout organization that is for younger boys 幼童军
3 Cub(also Cub Scout) [C] a member of the Cubs 幼童军成员

cube¹
/kju:b ||; kjub/noun[C]
1 a solid shape that has six equal square sides 立方体；正方体 ☞picture at solid 见solid插图
2 (mathematics数学) the number that you get if you multiply a number by itself twice 立方（某数自乘两次的积）: the cube of 5 (5³) is 125 (= 5x5x5). 5的立方是（5^3）是125。
cube²
/kju:b ||; kjub/verb [T] (mathematics数学) (usually passive 通常用于被动语态) to multiply a number by itself twice 将（某数）自乘两次；求立方: Four cubed (4³)is 64 (= 4 x 4 x 4). 4的立方（4^3）是64。 ☞Look at square ¹and cube root. 参看square^1及cube root。

ˌcube ˈroot
noun [C] (mathematics数学) a number which, when multiplied by itself twice, produces a particular number 立方根: The cube root of 64 (³√64) is 4. 64的立方根(³√64)是4。 ☞Compare square root. 与square root比较。

cubic
/ˈkju:bɪk ||; ˈkjubɪk/adj connected with a measurement of volume expressed as a cube¹(2) 立方的: If a box is 4cm long, 4cm wide and 4cm high, its volume is 64 cubic centimetres. 如果一个箱子是4厘米长，4厘米宽，4厘米高，它的体积是64立方厘米。 The lake holds more than a million cubic metres of water. 该湖蓄水100万立方米以上。

cubicle
/ˈkju:bɪkl ||; ˈkjubɪkḷ/noun [C] a small room that is made by separating off part of a larger room （由较大房间隔出来的）小室: There are cubicles at the swimming pool for changing your clothes. 这游泳池有几个更衣室。

cuckoo
/ˈkʊku: ||; ˈkυku/noun [C] a bird which makes a sound like its name. Cuckoos put their eggs into the NESTS of other birds. 布谷鸟；杜鹃

cucumber
/ˈkju:kʌmbə(r) ||; ˈkjukʌmbɚ/noun [C,U] a long, thin vegetable with a dark green skin that does not need to be cooked 黄瓜；胡瓜 ☞picture on page C3 见C3页插图

cud
/kʌd ||; kʌd/noun [U] the food that cows and similar animals bring back from the stomach into the mouth to eat again （牛等）反刍的食物: cows chewing the cud 牛在咀嚼反刍的食物

cuddle
/ˈkʌdl ||; ˈkʌdḷ/verb [I,T] to hold sb/sth closely in your arms 搂抱: The little girl was cuddling her favourite doll. 那小女孩搂抱着她心爱的洋娃娃。 cuddle noun [C]: He gave the child a cuddleand kissed her goodnight. 他拥抱那小孩一下﹐然后吻了她道晚安。 cuddle up (to/against sb/sth); cuddle up (together) to move close to sb and sit or lie in a comfortable position 偎依；依偎在一起舒适地坐或躺着: They cuddled up together for warmth. 他们搂在一起取暖。

cuddly
/ˈkʌdli ||; ˈkʌdlɪ/adj soft and pleasant to hold close to you 令人想拥抱的: a cuddly toy 令人想搂抱的玩具

cue
/kju: ||; kju/noun[C]
1 a word or movement that is the signal for sb else to say or do sth, especially in a play 提示，暗示（尤指戏剧中提示某人说什么话或做什么动作）: When Julia puts the tray on the table, that's your cue to come on stage. 朱莉娅把托盘放在桌上，就是你要出场的提示。
2 an example of how to behave 榜样: I'm not sure how to behave at a Japanese wedding, so I'll take my cue fromthe hosts. 我不懂日本婚礼的规矩，所以我处处学主人家的样子。
3 a long, thin wooden stick used to hit the ball in some games that are played on a special table (snooker)and(billiards) （玩台球等用的）球杆 ☞picture at pool and sport 见pool及sport插图
(right) on cue at exactly the moment expected 恰好在这个时候: Just as I was starting to worry about Stan, he phoned right on cue. 我正开始为斯坦担心的时候，他恰好打来了电话。

cuff
/kʌf ||; kʌf/noun[C]
1 the end part of a sleeve, which often fastens at the wrist 袖口；袖头 ☞picture on page C6 见C6页插图
2 cuffs [pl] =HANDCUFFS
3 a light hit with the open hand 以手掌轻拍
off the cuff (used about sth you say) without thought or preparation before that moment （指要说的话）未经思考或准备，临时: I haven't got the figures here, but, off the cuff, I'd say the rise is about 10%. 我手头没有相关数字，但据我估计，上升幅度大约10%。

cufflink
/ˈkʌflɪŋk ||; ˈkʌfˌlɪŋk/noun [C] [usu.pl] one of a pair of small objects used instead of a button to fasten a shirt sleeve together at the wrist （衬衫的）袖扣

cuisine
/kwɪˈzi:n ||; kwɪˈzin/noun [U] (formal 正式) the style of cooking of a particular country, restaurant, etc 烹调（法）；菜式: Italian cuisine 意大利菜 ☞A less formal word is cooking. 不大正式的场合用cooking。

cul-de-sac
/ˈkʌl də sæk ||; ˈkʌl də ˈsæk/noun [C] (plural cul-de-sacs) a street that is closed at one end 死胡同；死巷

culinary
/ˈkʌlɪnəri; US -nerɪ ||; ˈkjuləˌnɛrɪ/adj (formal 正式) connected with cooking 与烹调有关的

cull
/kʌl ||; kʌl/verb[T]
1 to kill a number of animals in a group to prevent the group from becoming too large 杀死动物（以防某一群体数量过多）
2 to collect information, ideas, etc, from different places （从不同来源）收集，搜集，拣选（资料、意见等）: I managed to cull some useful addresses from the Internet. 我设法从国际互联网上收集到一些有用的网址。 cull noun [C] a deer cull 旨在控制数量的杀鹿行动

culminate
/ˈkʌlmɪneɪt ||; ˈkʌlməˌnet/verb [I] (formal 正式)culminate in sth to reach a final result 终于达到高潮；到达顶点: The team's efforts culminated in victory in the championships. 这支队伍通过努力终于在锦标赛中取得胜利。 ➔culmination /ˌkʌlmɪˈneɪʃn ||; ˌkʌlməˈneʃən/ noun [sing] The joint space mission was the culmination of years of research. 这次联合太空任务是多年研究的成果。

culottes
/kju:ˈlɒts ||; kjuˈlɑts/noun [pl] women's wide short trousers that are made to look like a skirt （女用）裙裤: a pair of culottes 一条裙裤

culpable
/ˈkʌlpəbl ||; ˈkʌlpəbḷ/adj (formal 正式) responsible for sth bad that has happened 应受责备的；难辞其咎的

culprit
/ˈkʌlprɪt ||; ˈkʌlprɪt/noun [C] a person who has done sth wrong 犯过者；犯罪者

cult
/kʌlt ||; kʌlt/noun[C]
1 a type of religion or religious group, especially one that is considered unusual 教派，宗派（尤指邪教）
2 a person or thing that has become popular with a particular group of people 受崇拜的人或物；时尚的人或物: cult movies 风靡一时的电影

cultivar
/ˈkʌltɪvɑ:(r) ||; ˈkʌltɪˌvɑr/noun [C] (technical术语) a particular variety of a plant whose characteristics have been controlled by people in the way it has been bred 栽培品种；栽培品系

cultivate
/ˈkʌltɪveɪt ||; ˈkʌltəˌvet/verb[T]
1 to prepare and use land for growing plants for food or to sell 耕；耕作: to cultivate the soil 耕地
2 to grow plants for food or to sell 种植: Olives have been cultivated for centuries in Mediterranean countries. 地中海国家种植橄榄树已有数百年的历史。
3 to try hard to develop a friendship with sb 努力结交（朋友）: He cultivated links with colleagues abroad. 他努力跟国外的同事建立良好联系。 ➔cultivation /ˌkʌltɪˈveɪʃn ||; ˌkʌltəˈveʃən/ noun [U] ☞Look at shifting cultivation. 参看shifting cultivation。

cultivated
/ˈkʌltɪveɪtɪd ||; ˈkʌltəˌvetɪd/adj
1 well educated, with good manners 有教养的；有修养的；高雅的
2 (used about land) used for growing plants for food or to sell （指土地）用于耕种的
3 (used about plants) grown on a farm, not wild （指植物）种植的，非野生的

*cultural
/ˈkʌltʃərəl ||; ˈkʌltʃərəl/adj
1 connected with the customs, ideas, beliefs, etc of a society or country 与文化有关的: The country's cultural diversity is a result of taking in immigrants from all over the world. 这个国家文化上的多元性是接纳世界各地移民的结果。 ☞Look at multicultural. 参看multicultural。
2 connected with art, music, literature, etc 与文艺（美术、音乐、文学等）有关的: The city has a rich cultural life, with many theatres, concert halls and art galleries. 这城市的文艺生活很丰富，有很多影剧院、音乐厅和美术馆。 ➔culturally /-rəli ||; -rəlɪ/ adv

*culture
/ˈkʌltʃə(r) ||; ˈkʌltʃɚ/noun
1 [C,U] the customs, ideas, beliefs, etc of a particular society, country, etc 文化（指某个社会、国家等的风俗、思想、信念等）: the language and culture of the Aztecs 阿兹台克人的语言和文化 people from many different cultures 来自很多不同文化背景的人
2 [U] art, literature, music, etc 文化（指美术、文学、音乐等）: London has always been a centre of culture. 伦敦始终是个文化中心。
3 [C] (medical医学) a group of cells or bacteria, especially taken from a person or an animal and grown for medical or scientific study 培养细胞，培养菌（尤指从人或动物身上取下来用作化验或科研的）: Yoghurt is made from active cultures. 酸奶用活培养菌制成。

cultured
/ˈkʌltʃəd ||; ˈkʌltʃɚd/adj well-educated, showing a good knowledge of art, music, literature, etc 有教养的；懂文学、艺术的

ˈculture shock
noun [U] a feeling of confusion, etc that you may have when you go to live in or visit a country that is very different from your own 文化冲击（指面对与自己国家十分不同的文化时产生的困惑）

culvert
/ˈkʌlvət ||; ˈkʌlvɚt/noun [C] a pipe for water that goes under a road, etc （穿越道路等的）涵洞管道

cum
/ˈkʌm ||; ˈkʌm/prep (used for joining two nouns together) also used as; as well as （用于连系名词）兼作，和，与: a bedroom-cum-study 卧室兼作书房的房间

cumbersome
/ˈkʌmbəsəm ||; ˈkʌmbɚsəm/adj
1 heavy and difficult to carry, use, wear, etc 笨重的；携带、使用、穿戴等不方便的
2 (used about a system, etc) slow and complicated （指制度等）繁琐的: cumbersome legal procedures 繁琐的法律程序

cumulative
/ˈkju:mjələtɪv; US -leɪtɪv ||; ˈkjumjəˌletɪv/adj increasing steadily in amount, degree, etc 累积的；渐增的: a cumulative effect 累积的效果

cumulonimbus
/ˌkju:mjʊləʊˈnɪmbəs ||; ˌkjumjəloˈnɪmbəs/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of cloud that forms a large very high mass, with a flat base at a fairly low level, and often a flat top. It is seen, for example, during THUNDERSTORMS 积雨云 ☞picture at cloud 见cloud插图

cumulus
/ˈkju:mjələs ||; ˈkjumjələs/noun [U] (technical术语) a type of thick white cloud 积云 ☞picture at cloud 见cloud插图

cunning
/ˈkʌnɪŋ ||; ˈkʌnɪŋ/adj clever in a dishonest or bad way 狡猾的；诡诈的: He was as cunning as a fox. 他跟狐狸一样狡诈。 a cunning trick 诡计 [SYN] sly or wily 同义词为sly或wily cunning noun [U] ➔cunningly adv

*cup¹
/kʌp ||; kʌp/noun[C]
1 a small container usually with a handle, used for drinking liquids （通常有耳柄的）杯: a teacup 茶杯 a cup of coffee 一杯咖啡
2 (in sport) a large metal cup given as a prize; the competition for such a cup （体育）奖杯，锦标赛: Our team won the cup in the basketball tournament. 我们的球队在篮球锦标赛中赢得了奖杯。 the World Cup 世界杯比赛 ☞picture at medal 见medal插图
3 an object shaped like a cup 杯状物: an eggcup 蛋杯
not sb's cup of tea not what sb likes or is interested in 非某人喜欢或有兴趣的: Horror films aren't my cup of tea. 恐怖片不合我的胃口。
cup²
/kʌp ||; kʌp/verb [T] (cupping;cupped) to form sth, especially your hands, into the shape of a cup; to hold sth with your hands shaped like a cup 使（某物，尤指双手）形成杯状；把双手窝成杯状托住: I cupped my hands to take a drink from the stream. 我把两只手窝成杯状从溪里捧起水来喝。

*cupboard
/ˈkʌbəd ||; ˈkʌbɚd/noun [C] a piece of furniture, usually with shelves inside and a door or doors at the front, used for storing food, clothes, etc 橱，橱柜（放食物、衣服等） ☞picture on page C7 见C7页插图

ˈcup final
noun [C] (Brit 英) (especially in football 尤用于足球) the last match in a series of matches in a competition that gives a cup as a prize to the winner 决赛

cupful
/ˈkʌpfʊl ||; ˈkʌpˌfυl/noun [C] the amount that a cup will hold 一杯的量: two cupfuls of water 满满的两杯水

ˈcup tie
noun [C] (Brit 英) (especially in football 尤用于足球) a match between two teams in a competition that gives a cup as a prize to the winner 优胜杯决赛

curable
/ˈkjʊərəbl ||; ˈkjυrəbḷ/adj (used about a disease) that can be made better （指疾病）可治愈的 [OPP] incurable 反义词为incurable

curate
/ˈkjʊərət ||; ˈkjυrɪt/noun [C] a priest at a low level in the Church of England, who helps the priest in charge (vicar) of a church district 副牧师

curator
/kjʊəˈreɪtə(r) ||; kjυˈretɚ/noun [C] a person whose job is to look after the things that are kept in a museum （博物馆的）馆长

curb¹
/kɜ:b ||; kɝb/verb [T] to limit or control sth, especially sth bad 控制，约束，抑制（尤指坏东西）: He needs to learn to curb his anger. 他需要学会控制自己的火气。
curb²
/kɜ:b ||; kɝb/noun[C]
1 a curb (on sth) a control or limit on sth 控制；限制: a curb on local government spending 对地方政府开支的控制
2 (especially US 尤为美) =KERB

curd
/kɜ:d ||; kɝd/noun [U] (also curds [pl]) a thick soft substance that forms when milk turns sour 凝乳

curdle
/ˈkɜ:dl ||; ˈkɝdḷ/verb [I,T] (used about liquids) to turn sour or to separate into different parts; to make something do this （指液体）（使）变酸，（使）凝结: I've curdled the sauce. 我已使这酱汁凝结。 ☞Look at blood-curdling. 参看blood-curdling。

*cure¹
/kjʊə(r) ||; kjυr/verb[T]
1 cure sb (of sth) to make sb healthy again after an illness 使恢复健康；使痊愈: The treatment cured him of cancer. 这种疗法把他的癌症治好了。
2 to make an illness, injury, etc end or disappear 治愈，根治（疾病、损伤等）: It is still not possible to cure the common cold. 普通的感冒仍然无法可治。 (figurative 比喻) The plumber cured the problem with the central heating. 管子工修好了中央供暖设备。
3 to make certain types of food last longer by drying, smoking or salting them （用风干、烟熏或盐腌等方法）保存，处理（某些食物）: cured ham 经腌制的火腿
cure²
/kjʊə(r) ||; kjυr/noun [C] a cure (for sth)
1 a medicine or treatment that can cure an illness, etc 药物；治疗方法: There is no cure for this illness. 这种病还没有药物可以治疗。
2 a return to good health; the process of being cured 痊愈；治愈；治疗过程: The new drug brought about a miraculous cure. 这种新药有神奇的疗效。

curfew
/ˈkɜ:fju: ||; ˈkɝfju/noun[C]
1 a time after which people are not allowed to go outside their homes, for example during a war 宵禁: The government imposed a dusk-to-dawn curfew. 政府实施了从傍晚到黎明的宵禁。
2 (US 美) a time when children must arrive home in the evening 儿童晚上必须回到家的时间: She has a ten o'clock curfew. 她规定孩子晚上10点前必须回到家。

curiosity
/ˌkjʊəriˈɒsəti ||; ˌkjυrɪˈɑsətɪ/noun (plural curiosities)
1 [U] a desire to know or learn 好奇心；求知欲: I was full of curiosity about their plans. 我们对他们的计划充满好奇。 Out of curiosity, he opened her letter. 他出于好奇，拆了她的信。
2 [C] an unusual and interesting person or thing 奇人；奇事；珍品: The museum was full of historical curiosities. 博物馆里陈列着大批历代珍品。

*curious
/ˈkjʊəriəs ||; ˈkjυrɪəs/adj
1 curious (about sth);curious (to do sth) wanting to know or learn sth 好奇的；感兴趣的: They were very curious about the people who lived upstairs. 他们对住在楼上的人很好奇。 He was curious to know how the machine worked. 他很想知道这机器究竟是怎样运作的。
2 unusual or strange 不寻常的；奇怪的: It was curious that she didn't tell anyone about the incident. 真奇怪，她没有把这起事故告诉任何人。 ➔curiously adv

curl¹
/kɜ:l ||; kɝl/verb
1 [I,T] to form or to make sth form into a curved or round shape （使）卷曲: Does your hair curl naturally? 你的头发是天然鬈曲的吗？
2 [I] to move round in a curve 盘绕；缭绕: The snake curled around his arm. 那蛇盘在他的胳膊上。 Smoke curled up into the sky. 烟袅袅升入天空。
curl up to pull your arms, legs and head close to your body 蜷缩: The cat curled up in front of the fire. 猫儿蜷缩在炉火跟前。
curl²
/kɜ:l ||; kɝl/noun[C]
1 a piece of hair that curves round 鬈发: Her hair fell in curls round her face. 她的鬈发垂在脸颊旁边。
2 a thing that has a curved round shape 卷状物: a curl of blue smoke 一缕青烟

curler
/ˈkɜ:lə(r) ||; ˈkɝlɚ/noun [C] a small plastic or metal tube that you roll your hair around in order to make it curly 卷发夹

curly
/ˈkɜ:li ||; ˈkɝlɪ/adj full of curls; shaped like a curl 卷曲的: curly hair 鬈发 [OPP] straight. 反义词为straight ☞picture at hair 见hair插图

currant
/ˈkʌrənt ||; ˈkɝənt/noun[C]
1 a very small dried grape used to make cakes, etc 小葡萄干
2 (often in compounds 常用于构成复合词) one of several types of small soft fruit 醋栗: blackcurrants 黑醋栗

*currency
/ˈkʌrənsi ||; ˈkɝənsɪ/noun (plural currencies)
1 [C,U] the system or type of money that a particular country uses 货币；货币制度: The currency of Argentina is the austral. 阿根廷的货币是奥斯特拉尔。 foreign currency 外币 a weak/strong/stable currency 疲软╱坚挺╱稳定的货币
2 [U] the state of being believed, accepted or used by many people 流行；通用；流通: The new ideas soon gained currency. 这些新意念不久便流行起来。

*current¹
/ˈkʌrənt ||; ˈkɝənt/adj
1 of the present time; happening now 现时的；现行的: current fashions/events 时装；时事
2 generally accepted; in common use 被普遍接受；通用: Is this word still current? 这个词还通用吗？
current²
/ˈkʌrənt ||; ˈkɝənt/noun
1 [C] a continuous flowing movement of water, air, etc 水流；气流: to swim against/with the current 逆流╱顺流游泳 (figurative 比喻) a current of anti-government feeling 一股反政府的情绪
2 [U] the flow of electricity through a wire, etc 电流

ˌcurrent acˈcount
(US 美 checking account) noun [C] a bank account from which you can take out your money when you want, with a cheque book or cash card 往来账户（可用支票簿或现金卡提款）

ˌcurrent afˈfairs
noun [pl] important political or social events that are happening at the present time 时事

currently
/ˈkʌrəntli ||; ˈkɝəntlɪ/adv at present; at the moment 现在；目前: He is currently working in Spain. 他目前在西班牙工作。 ☞Look at the note at actually. 参看actually的注释。

curriculum
/kəˈrɪkjələm ||; kəˈrɪkjələm/noun [C] (plural curriculums or curricula /-lə ||; -lə/) all the subjects that are taught in a school, college or university; the contents of a particular course of study （学校的）所有科目，课程: Latin is not on the curriculum at our school. 我们学校的课程里没有拉丁文。 ☞Look at syllabus. 参看syllabus。

curriculum vitae
/kəˌrɪkjələm ˈvi:taɪ ||; kəˌrɪkjələm ˈvitaɪ/ =CV

curry
/ˈkʌri ||; ˈkɝɪ/noun [C,U] (plural curries) an Indian dish of meat, vegetables, etc containing a lot of spices usually served with rice 咖喱菜（一种印度菜式，通常拌以饭吃）: a hot/mild curry 辛辣的╱微辣的咖喱菜 ➔curried adj curried chicken 咖喱鸡

ˈcurry powder
noun [U] a fine mixture of strongly flavoured spices that is used to make curry 咖喱粉

curse¹
/kɜ:s ||; kɝs/noun[C]
1 a word used for expressing anger; a swear word 咒骂语
2 a word or words expressing a wish that sth terrible will happen to sb 咒语: The family seemed to be under a curse (= lots of bad things happened to them). 这户人家好像被诅咒似的。
3 something that causes great harm 祸因；祸根: the curse of drug addiction 毒瘾的祸害
curse²
/kɜ:s ||; kɝs/verb
1 [I,T] curse (sb/sth) (for sth) to swear at sb/sth; to use rude language to express your anger 诅咒；咒骂: He dropped the box, cursing himself for his clumsiness. 他骂自己笨手笨脚，把手里的箱子掉了。
2 [T] to use a magic word or phrase against sb because you wish him/her harm 诅咒: She cursed his family. 她诅咒他的家人。

cursor
/ˈkɜ:sə(r) ||; ˈkɝsɚ/noun [C] (computing计算机技术) a small sign on a computer screen that shows the position you are at （计算机屏幕上的）光标，光标 ☞picture on page S3 见S3页插图

cursory
/ˈkɜ:səri ||; ˈkɝsərɪ/adj quick and short; done in a hurry 匆促的；粗略的；草率的: a cursory glance 匆匆的一瞥

curt
/kɜ:t ||; kɝt/adj short and not polite 简短无礼的；唐突草率的: She gave him a curt reply and slammed the phone down. 她三言两语回答了他，然后砰然放下电话筒。 ➔curtly adv ➔curtness noun [U]

curtail
/kɜ:ˈteɪl ||; kɝˈtel/verb [T] (formal 正式) to make sth shorter or smaller; to reduce 缩短；缩小；缩减: I had to curtail my answer as I was running out of time. 我不得不简单回答，因为我没有时间了。 ➔curtailment noun [C,U]

*curtain
/ˈkɜ:tn ||; ˈkɝtṇ/noun[C]
1 (US also 美亦作 drape) a piece of material that you can move to cover a window, etc 窗帘；挂帘；幕: Could you draw the curtains, please? (= Could you open/close the curtains) 可否请你将窗帘拉上？ The curtain goes up at 7pm (= in a theatre, the play begins). 戏晚上7点开演。
2 a thing that covers or hides sth 覆盖或遮蔽（某物）的东西: a curtain of mist 一层薄雾

curtsy
/ˈkɜ:tsi ||; ˈkɝtsɪ/ (also curtsey) noun [C] (plural curtsies or curtseys) a movement made by a woman as a sign of respect, done by bending the knees, with one foot behind the other （妇女所行的）屈膝礼 curtsy(also curtsey) verb [I]

*curve¹
/kɜ:v ||; kɝv/noun [C] a line that bends round 曲线；弧线: a curve on a graph 图表上的曲线 ☞picture at line 见line插图
curve²
/kɜ:v ||; kɝv/verb [I,T] to bend or to make sth bend in a curve （使）弯曲或成曲线: The bay curved round to the south. 海湾呈曲线形向南延伸。 a curved line 一条曲线 ☞picture at line 见line插图

cushion¹
/ˈkʊʃn ||; ˈkυʃən/noun[C]
1 a bag filled with soft material, for example feathers, which you put on a chair, etc to make it more comfortable 软垫子；坐垫；椅垫 ☞A cushion on a bed is a pillow. 枕头叫做pillow。
2 something that acts or is shaped like a cushion 具有软垫功能的东西；垫状物: A hovercraft rides on a cushion of air. 气垫船在垫子般的空气上行驶。
cushion²
/ˈkʊʃn ||; ˈkυʃən/verb[T]
1 to make a fall, hit, etc less painful 缓冲；减轻（坠落、受打击时等的）痛楚: The snow cushioned his fall. 他跌在雪地上，所以伤得不重。
2 to reduce the unpleasant effect of sth 减少（某事物的不良影响）: She spent her childhood on a farm, cushioned from the effects of the war. 她的童年在农场度过，这减少了战争对她的影响。

cushy
/ˈkʊʃi ||; ˈkυʃɪ/adj (informal 非正式) too easy, needing little effort (in a way that seems unfair to others) 轻松的，不费力的（似对其他人不公平）: a cushy job 十分轻松的工作

custard
/ˈkʌstəd ||; ˈkʌstɚd/noun [U] a sweet yellow sauce made from milk, eggs and sugar. In Britain it is eaten hot or cold with sweet dishes 牛奶蛋糊；蛋奶冻 ☞picture on page C4 见C4页插图

custodian
/kʌˈstəʊdiən ||; kʌsˈtodɪən/noun[C]
1 (formal 正式) a person who looks after sth, especially a museum, library, etc 管理员，看管者（尤指博物馆、图书馆等的）
2 (US 美) =CARETAKER

custody
/ˈkʌstədi ||; ˈkʌstədɪ/noun [U]:
1 the legal right or duty to take care of sb/sth 监护（权）；保管（权）: After the divorce, the mother had custody of the children. 离婚后，这位母亲取得对子女的监护权。
2 the state of being guarded, or kept in prison temporarily, especially by the police 拘留；羁押: The man was kept in custody until his trial. 这男子被拘留至开庭审讯。

*custom
/ˈkʌstəm ||; ˈkʌstəm/noun
1 [C,U] a way of behaving which a particular group or society has had for a long time 风俗；习俗: It's the custom in Britain for a bride to throw her bouquet to the wedding guests. 按照英国习俗，新娘子会把花束掷向婚礼的宾客。 according to local custom 根据当地习俗 ☞Look at the note at habit. 参看habit的注释。
2 [sing] (formal 正式) something that a person does regularly （某人的）习惯: It's my custom to drink tea in the afternoon. 我有下午喝茶的习惯。
3 [U] (Brit 英) commercial activity; the practice of people buying things regularly from a particular shop, etc （经常）惠顾，光顾: The local shop lost a lot of custom when the new supermarket opened. 新的超级市场开业后，光顾这家本地商店的人就少了很多。 ☞Look at customs. 参看customs。

customary
/ˈkʌstəməri; US -merɪ ||; ˈkʌstəmˌɛrɪ/adj according to custom; usual 合乎或依照习俗的；惯常的: Is it customary to send cards at Christmas in your country? 你的国家在圣诞节有送贺卡的习惯吗？

*customer
/ˈkʌstəmə(r) ||; ˈkʌstəmɚ/noun[C]
1 a person who buys goods or services in a shop, restaurant, etc 顾客: The shop assistant was serving a customer. 那店员正在招呼一位顾客。 ☞Look at client. 参看client。
2 (informal 非正式) (after certain adjectives 用于某些形容词后) a person 人；家伙: a tough/an awkward/an odd/ customer 刚强╱难缠╱古怪的人

*customs
/ˈkʌstəmz ||; ˈkʌstəmz/ (also Customs) noun [pl] the place at an airport, etc where government officials check your luggage to make sure you are not bringing goods into the country illegally 海关（政府人员检查旅客行李的地方）: a customs officer 海关官员 ☞Look at excise. 参看excise。

*cut¹
/kʌt ||; kʌt/verb (present participle cutting;past tense past participle cut)
1 [I,T] to make an opening, wound or mark in sth using a sharp tool, for example a pair of scissors or a knife （用利器）切开，割破，割伤: Be careful not to cut yourself on that broken glass! 小心不要被玻璃碎片割伤！ This knife doesn't cut very well. 这把刀不快。
2 [T] cut sth (from sth) to remove sth or a part of sth, using a knife, etc （用刀等将某物或某物的一部份）切下，割下: She cut two slices of bread (from the loaf). 她（从整条面包上）切了两片面包。
3 [T] cut sth (in/into sth) to divide sth into pieces with a knife, etc （用刀等将某物）切成，分成（数份）: She cut the cake into eight (pieces). 她把蛋糕切为八份。 He cut the rope in two. 他把那根绳子割成两条。
4 [T] to make sth shorter by using scissors, etc （用剪刀等）剪短，割短: I cut my own hair. 我给自己剪头发。 to have your hair cut (= at the hairdresser's). 在理发店理发 to cut the grass 割草
5 [T] to make or form sth by removing material with a sharp tool （用利器）切成，割成，挖成: She cut a hole in the card and pushed the string through. 她在卡片上戳一个孔，然后将线穿过去。 They cut a path through the jungle. 他们开辟一条小径穿过丛林。
6 [T] to reduce sth or make it shorter; to remove sth 减少；缩短；删除: to cut taxes/costs/spending 减税；降低成本；压缩开支 Several violent scenes in the film were cut. 影片有几个暴力镜头被删剪了。
7 [T] (computing计算机技术) to remove a piece of text from the screen 剪去屏幕上文檔的某一部份: Use the cut and paste buttons to change the order of the paragraphs. 使用“剪贴”按钮改变段落次序。
8 [I] cut across, along, through, etc (sth) to go across, etc sth, in order to make your route shorter 走快捷方式；抄近路: It's much quicker if we cut across the field. 如果我们走快捷方式穿过这片田野可以快很多。
9 [T] (spoken 口语) to stop sth 停止；中断: Cut the chat and get on with your work! 别再聊天了，赶快干活吧！
10 [T] to deeply offend sb or hurt his/her feelings 得罪，伤害（某人的感情）: His cruel remarks cut her deeply. 他无情无义的话严重伤害了她的感情。
For idioms containing cut look at the entries for the nouns, adjectives, etc, for example cut corners is at corner. 含cut的习语，参看有关名词、形容词等词条，如cut corners可参看词条corner。 cut across sth to affect or be true for different groups that usually remain separate 影响，涉及（不同的独立群体）: The question of aid for the earthquake victims cuts across national boundaries. 有关救助地震灾民的问题已经超越了国界。 cut sth back; cut back (on sth) to reduce sth 减少: to cut back on public spending 减少公共开支 cut sth down
1 to make sth fall down by cutting it 砍倒: to cut down a tree 砍倒一棵树
2 to make sth shorter 删减；缩短: I have to cut my essay down to 2000 words. 我得把我的文章删节成2000字。
cut sth down; cut down (on sth) to reduce the quantity or amount of sth; to do sth less often 减少，减低（某物的数量或次数）: You should cut down on fatty foods. 你应少吃脂肪多的食物。 cut in (on sb/sth) to interrupt sb/sth 打断（某人的说话等）: She kept cutting in on our conversation. 她老是打断我们的谈话。 cut sb off (often passive 常用于被动语态) to stop or interrupt sb's telephone conversation 停止或打断某人在电话上的谈话: We were cut off before I could give her my message. 我还没有来得及把消息告诉她，电话就断线了。 cut sb/sth off (often passive 常用于被动语态) to stop the supply of sth to sb 停止对某人供应某物；切断某物的供应: The electricity/gas/water has been cut off. 电╱煤气╱水已经停止供应。 cut sth off to block a road, etc so that nothing can pass 堵塞道路等: We must cut off all possible escape routes. 我们必须把所有可能的逃跑路线切断。 cut sth off (sth) to remove sth from sth larger by cutting （从较大的东西上）剪下，切除: Be careful you don't cut your fingers off using that electric saw. 使用那把电锯要当心，别把手指锯掉了。 cut sb/sth off (from sb/sth) (often passive 常用于被动语态) to prevent sb/sth from moving from a place or contacting people outside 使与外界隔绝: The farm was cut off from the village by heavy snow. 农场因大雪而与附近的村子失去联系。 cut sth open to open sth by cutting 切开；割开: She fell and cut her head open. 她跌倒在地，把头撞破了。 cut sth out
1 to remove sth or to form sth into a particular shape by cutting 切去；剪下；剪成: He cut the job advertisement out of the newspaper. 他从报纸上剪下招聘广告。
2 to not include sth 删去: Cut out the boring details! 把那些乏味的细节删掉吧！
3 (especially US 尤为美) (informal 非正式) to stop saying or doing sth that annoys sb 停止说或做令人烦恼的事: Cut that out and leave me alone! 住口，别烦我了！
4 (informal 非正式) to stop doing or using sth 戒除；不再用: You'll only lose weight if you cut out sweet things from your diet. 你只有不再吃甜食才能减轻体重。
be cut out for sth; be cut out to be sth to have the qualities needed to do sth; to be suitable for sth/sb 有做某事所需要的才能；适合: You're not cut out to be a soldier. 你不是当兵的材料。 cut sth up to cut sth into small pieces with a knife, etc （用刀等）分成小块，切碎
*cut²
/kʌt ||; kʌt/noun[C]
1 an injury or opening in the skin made with a knife, etc （刀等造成的）伤口，切口，破口: He had a deep cut on his forehead. 他的前额上有一道很深的伤口。
2 an act of cutting 切；割；剪；砍: to have a cut and blow-dry (= at a hairdresser's) （让理发师给）理发并吹干和定型
3 a cut (in sth) a reduction in size, amount, etc （尺寸、数量等的）减少，削减: a cut in government spending 削减政府开支 a power cut (= when the electric current is stopped temporarily) 停电
4 a piece of meat from a particular part of an animal 切下的肉块: cheap cuts of lamb 便宜的羊肉块
5 (informal 非正式) a share of the profits from sth, especially sth dishonest 一份利润（尤指以不正当手段获得的） ☞Look at short cut. 参看short cut。

cutback
/ˈkʌtbæk ||; ˈkʌtˌbæk/noun [C] a reduction in amount or number （数量或数目的）减少，削减: The management were forced to make cutbacks in staff. 资方被逼削减职员人数。

cute
/kju:t ||; kjut/adj attractive; pretty 吸引人的；漂亮的；可爱的: Your little girl is so cute! 你的小女孩真可爱！ a cute smile 动人的微笑

cuticle
/ˈkju:tɪkl ||; ˈkjutɪkḷ/noun[C]
1 an area of hard skin at the base of the nails on your fingers and toes （附于甲床边缘的）护膜
2 a hard outer layer that covers and protects a plant （植物表面起保护作用的）角质层，蜡状层

cutlery
/ˈkʌtləri ||; ˈkʌtlərɪ/noun [U] the knives, forks and spoons that you use for eating food 餐具（刀、叉、匙等） ☞Look at crockery. 参看crockery。

cutlet
/ˈkʌtlət ||; ˈkʌtlɪt/noun [C] a small, thick piece of meat, often with bone in it, that is cooked （煎熟或烤熟的）肉排，肉片

ˈcut-off
noun [C] the level or time at which sth stops 截止时间；截止点: The cut-off date is 12 May. After that we'll end the offer. 截止日期为5月12日，过后就不再供应。

ˌcut-ˈprice
(US 美 ˌcut-ˈrate) adj sold at a reduced price; selling goods at low prices 削价的；减价的: cut-price offers 减价 a cut-price store 卖减价货的商店

cutters
/ˈkʌtəz ||; ˈkʌtɚz/noun [pl] a tool that you use for cutting through sth, for example metal 切割工具；刀具: a pair of wire cutters 一把钢丝剪

ˈcut-throat
adj caring only about success and not worried about hurting anyone 冷酷无情的；剧烈的: cut-throat business practices 冷酷无情的商业手法

cutting¹
